column2: As quarterly profits rise, the German giant said it planned a Japanese joint venture, an acquisition of units of Rolls-Royce, and a shift of its power units to the United States.
The confrontation highlighted hair-trigger tensions in the South China Sea as East Asian nations try to contain China’s more aggressive posture in pursuing maritime claims.
The fall of the ruble and “growing uncertainty” led the bank to write down the goodwill of its Russian business. The bank’s net income fell 13%.
The Japanese company is still reaping gains, however, from its cellphone business and investments that include its holding in Alibaba.
A court ruled that Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra had abused her power in 2011. The decision was a victory for protesters who have sought to overthrow the government.
Polls suggested that President Jacob Zuma’s African National Congress will steamroll to victory, but with less support than in the past.
Alain Buffard built a dance theater piece from the seed of a character, a Haitian voodoo spirit, Baron Samedi.
Plus managing multiple iPad mail accounts.
This dish in a bowl mixes sweet and bitter edges.

SCHRAG--Bella F.,beloved wife of the late Allen I. Schrag, cherished mother to Howard, Jonah and Carl Schrag, doting grandmother to Sarah, Molly, Robbie, Jeremy, Toby, Joelle and Avery, died on Sunday, May 4, 2014 just days shy of her 90th birthday. She lived her life with optimism, fidelity, independence, and abiding love. May her guiding spirit reside within us all the days of our lives.

ZIMMERMAN--Charles, M.D.,passed away peacefully from natural causes May 3rd, 2014 in Annapolis, Maryland. He was born in Brooklyn in 1931 to Bella Horn Zimmerman and Louis Zimmerman. He attended Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and Downstate Medical School. In 1955 he married Roslyn Riegel. He completed his Radiology residency at Jacobi Hospital. He served as a Captain in the United States Army at Fort Gordon, Georgia from 1959-1961. He and Roslyn then moved to Northern New Jersey where he practiced Radiology and Nuclear Medicine. He obtained his board certification in Nuclear Medicine in the late 1960's. As an Associate Professor of Radiology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he published many original studies in his field in various professional journals. He was President of the Medical Staff of the Barnert Memorial Hospital in Paterson, New Jersey in the early 1980's and served for many years on the hospital's Board of Directors. In addition to his professional accomplishments he had an encyclopedic knowledge of Civil War history and was an active member of the New York City and South Florida Civil War Roundtables. He had many other deeply explored intellectual pursuits throughout his life which included opera, classical music, ballet, wine appreciation, extensive travel, current affairs and was also an avid reader of classic literature. One of his great talents, which he maintained until the end, was his ability to engage and learn from people he encountered from all walks of life. He was an active member of Congregation Kneseth Israel in Annapolis. He is survived by his wife Roslyn Zimmerman, brother Arthur Zimmerman, of Sacramento, CA, and daughters Susan (William) Zimmerman of Annapolis, MD, and Gloria (Matthew) Zimmerman of New York City and four grandchildren, Stephen, Natalie, Maxwell and Lucy. He was devoted to his immediate and extended family who all cherished him and will miss him greatly. In the words of his granddaughter, Natalie, "people are only truly gone when the memory of them fades, but Grandpa's memory isn't going anywhere anytime soon."

WOODS--Zachary C.,The members of Northlight Financial join the family of our partner, Robert Woods, in mourning the loss of Zachery, the son of Lori and Robert and brother of Mathew and Callie. Zach, 27, was a model young man who passed away Tuesday from injuries suffered when struck by car. In the prime of his life, Zach had just begun graduate classes at the Wharton School to pursue a master's degree in business and international studies. A graduate of Middlebury College, fluent in Mandarin, he successfully engaged in business activities in China, as a plant manager and as an international fund raiser for public-private real estate projects. As the son of one of Northlight's founders, Zach was known to all of us as an engaging, athletic and committed young man whose future was distinct and promising. We extend our sympathies to his family on their loss. Michael H. Jahrmarkt, Mark P. Hirschhorn, Chris E. Jahrmarkt

van der HEIDE--Louis, DVM, PhD, of Columbia, CT died, Monday, May 5th in Ridgewood, NJ. Born in Holland, Louis, a kind-hearted man, admired by many, was a loving father and friend. He devoted his life to his family and Veterinary medicine, where his work in avian disease research was internationally recognized. Louis spent over 20 years at the University of Connecticut, Department of Pathobiology. Predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Ingrid (Klaje) van der Heide, he is survived by two daughters, Marjolein Rust of La Jolla, CA, Ilje Allsup and her husband Brett, of Portland, OR, two sons, Mike van der Heide of Portland, OR and Pieter van der Heide and his wife Kate Armstrong of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, 11 grandchildren, a great-grandchild, and his brother Theo of Holland. He was predeceased by brothers Cleem and Kees. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Tuesday, May 13th at 10am in Corpus Christi Church, 601 Silas Deane Hwy, Wethersfield, CT. Visitation is Monday, May 12th from 4-7pm at Farley Sullivan Funeral Home, 34 Beaver Rd, Wethersfield, CT. Visit farleysullivan.com.

WEITZNER--Charles M.,D.D.S. "Chuck", 73, of Charlestown, RI, formerly of Manhattan, NY, passed away on Tuesday, May 6, 2014. He was the husband of Susan Ford McKenna Weitzner for 18 years. Born in Manhattan, NY, the son of the late Joseph and Frieda (Spindel) Weitzner. Charles was a prosthodontist with practices in both Manhattan and the East Side of Providence for many years. He enjoyed wood working and metal working; was an avid Duke Basketball fan and a proud alumnus. Besides his wife he is survived by three step-daughters, Lauren McKenna of Westerly, Katie Holland and Moira Young both of South Kingstown; eleven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was the brother of the late Jay Weitzner. His funeral and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Wounded Warriors Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, KS 66675. For guestbook and condolences, please visit: averystortifuneralhome.com.

KATZ--Samuel, The Board of Directors and staff of Sid Jacobson JCC mourn the loss of Samuel Katz, father of our Board member Susan Held and father-in-law of Board Member and past president Jonathon Held. We extend sympathy to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Debra Buslik, President David Black, Executive Director

RIEHLMAN--Franklin E.,Art dealer Franklin Riehlman, the proprietor of Franklin Riehlman Fine Art, located at 24 East 73rd Street in New York City, passed away tragically on the evening of April 22 at the age of 61. To the unsuspecting, Franklin was known to identify himself as a used canvas salesman. In actuality, he was widely admired for his expansive knowledge in the field of 19th and 20th-century American art and his passion for early 20th-century art in general, including British modernism, and many other related fields. He was especially proud of his expertise in the work of the artists George Bellows, Clarence Carter, Konrad Cramer, Adolph Dehn, Charles Goeller, Leon Kroll, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Michael Lenson, Frank London, Edmund Lewandowski , Walter Murch, Priscilla Roberts, Harold Shapinsky and Hans Weingartner, along with many other artists of the early 20th-century, particularly those of the Woodstock Art colony. He was just as proud of his relationships with all who shared those interests. He also represented work of contemporary artists such as Leslie Gabosh, Walter Hatke, Robert Kipness, Simeon Lagodich, David Olenick, and Martin Weinstein. Franklin's prior lives included excelling as tight end/linebacker for the Pleasant Valley Vikings, induction into the Butte College Sports Hall of Fame as linebacker for the Butte College Roadrunners, a heavyweight wrestling champion, a painter of new canvases exhibited on both coasts, a student of art history at Hunter College, the Institute of Fine Arts and California State University at Chico, a scholar of ancient Greek vase painting, a salesman of LeRoy Nieman prints at Knoedler Publishing, Inc., a slide curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was also a lecturer, a paintings expert at Phillips, Son & Neale, Inc. in New York, an associate at H.V. Allison Galleries, a business partner of Andrea Scully-Keogh and of Megan Moynihan, a published author of art historical catalogues and essays, a bridge player and a golf addict. He preferred research at the Frick Art Library to the internet and loved books. He was born in Safford, AZ and raised in Utah, Nevada, Santa Barbara, the California Bay Area, and Chico, CA, which he left for New York City in 1977. He is survived by his partner and lover of 30 years, Mary M. Walsh, of New York City, his mother Margaret Whitaker Riehlman, his siblings Mark (Liz), Troy (Mary Ann), Ann (Pat) Patterson and Donald, his uncle, Charles Whitaker, nieces and nephews and many, many friends and colleagues. All of whom are heartbroken and will cherish his memory. He was preceded in death by his father Peter and his nephew Josh. Franklin Riehlman Fine Art will continue as a company under the direction and ownership of Mary M. Walsh. A generous group of colleagues, friends and admirers are holding a memorial service to celebrate his life and compare tales on May 22 at the Lotos Club on 66th and 5th in Manhattan. Contact Franklin Riehlman Fine Art if you have not received an invite and wish to attend. A quote from one of Franklin's many pocket notebooks: "Let us endeavor so to live that when we die, even the undertaker will be sorry."

LANDERS--Jennifer, We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Jennifer Landers. Her spirit, warmth, incredible personality and wit will always be remembered by those lucky enough to have known her. Jennifer was a true original who will be greatly missed. Richard Kirshenbaum and Family

SCHWERIN--Joseph, 1938-2014. Exeter, Yale, W&L Law, then Wall Street. Investment success brought Joe leisure time for an inquisitive mind and a restless soul. He found beauty and adventure in art, women, and the natural world. A renaissance man of great taste (and appetite). Cousin, classmate, best friend and business partner; we will miss The Archdruid. Warren Schwerin

EINHORN--Marvin, Primary Stages mourns the passing of our beloved board and company member, Marvin Einhorn. After a distinguished thirty-year career directing network television news programs ("The Today Show," "NBC Nightly News," "Mr. Wizard"), Marvin focused on acting on stage and in motion pictures. He and his adored wife, Anne, were associated with Primary Stages since our start in 1984, and were highly instrumental in our growth. Our professional theater school, Primary Stages Marvin and Anne Einhorn School of Performing Arts (ESPA), was named in their honor. We send our deepest sympathy to their daughter, Ellen Zerkin, sons, Stephen and Kenneth, and their families.

EVANS--Mary Johnston,of East Hampton and New York City, passed away on May 5, 2014. Beloved wife of James H. Evans (Retired Chairman, Union Pacific Corporation), Mary was born on February 28, 1930 in Shawnee, Oklahoma. She attended Wellesley College and the University of Oklahoma. Mrs. Evans was smart, witty and incredibly charming. She was one of the most successful women of her generation and inspired many young women to take leadership positions in their community and in business. She also had a lifelong love of the New York Yankees and the Oklahoma Sooners. Mrs. Evans's corporate career included serving on the Boards of AMTRAK (vice chair), Delta Air Lines, Household International, Saint-Gobain Corp., Sunoco, Inc., Baxter International, Inc., The Dun & Bradstreet Corp., Moody's Corp. and Scudder, Stevens & Clark. In her civic career, Mary Evans served on the Boards of Carnegie Hall, Major Gifts Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Brick Presbyterian Church in New York and St. Anthony Hospital, Presbyterian Medical Center, United Appeal and YWCA in Oklahoma. Honors included inclusion in "200 Top Corporate Women" in Business Week, member of the Conference Board, induction into the Oklahoma Hall of Fame, first woman to address the Judicial Conference of the Tenth US Circuit Court, President of the Junior League (Oklahoma City), Distinguished Service Award, University of Oklahoma, first woman to address the Economic Club of Oklahoma City, The Liberty Bell Law Day Award for outstanding contributions to the legal profession by a layman, and recipient of the Director's Choice Award of the National Women's Economic Alliance. She was a member of the Colony Club (NYC) and Maidstone Club (East Hampton). Mary is survived by her husband, Jim, her children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Denver, Paul Johnston Head (Jean), Oklahoma City, and Eric Talbot Head (Shelley Magness), Denver, her grandchildren, Paxton X. Head, Atlanta, and Talbott Glover, Houston, her brother, Paul Ross Johnston (Sally), Vail and her step-children, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard). Memorial service will be held at 3:00pm, Friday, May 16 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the NYC Chapter, Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 or the University of Colorado Alzheimer's Research Fund, 13001 East 17th Pl., MS-A065, Aurora, CO 80045.

COLLIS--Charles Albert, 99, of Barrington, RI died on May 6, 2014. Charles Collis, son of Henry J. Collis and Anna J. Walker Collis, passed away peacefully at his home in Barrington, RI. He is survived by his wife, Elfriede A. Collis; his children, Frohman C. Anderson and wife Kimberley; Astrid C. Womble and husband Matt; daughter-in-law Lisa Anderson and seven grandchildren. Born March 13, 1915 in Taunton, MA, Charles attended Huntington School in Boston, MA followed by Dartmouth College in Hanover, NH. After graduating from College in 1937, he started his own shoe company. From 1942-1963 he was co-owner of Armor Bronze and Silver Company, the largest manufacturer of copper and brass giftware in the world. In 1948, Charles Collis entered the direct selling industry, which became a national organization, as co-founder of Copper Craft Guild. In 1963, Charles Collis established his own company, Princess House, Inc. which manufactures and sells hand-blown glass and giftware. He was owner of the Louie Glass Company of Westin, WV, the largest producer of hand blown glass in the country. Charles Collis was a pioneer in developing the direct selling industry. Princess House impacted the lives of tens of thousands of women by offering them a career choice and economic opportunity. Giving back was very important to Charles Collis. He was a leading philanthropist who supported many charitable causes. His lifelong recreational enjoyment was boating, golf and fishing. His seven grandchildren were his pride and joy. Calling hours will be held on Sunday, May 11th from 4pm to 7pm in the W. Raymond Watson Funeral Home, 350 Willett Avenue in Riverside. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, May 12th at 12:30pm in St. Luke's Church, Washington Road in Barrington, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Charles Collis to Hasbro Children's Hospital, PO Box H, Providence RI 02901 and/or The Boys and Girls Club of Taunton, 31 Court Street, Taunton MA 02780.

FRIEDMAN--Alan J. The Board and staff of the Fund for the City of New York mourn the loss of Alan J. Friedman, friend, member of the Fund's Selection Panel for the Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching and long-time board member. Alan will be remembered as a passionate advocate for quality education and as a brilliant translator, making the wonders of sciences available to the public. Alan shared his talent generously with everyone, from young people in the Rockaways to officials in the West Wing. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Mickey. Vaughn Williams Chair of the Board Mary McCormick President

GERSHON--Howard, passed away peacefully at home in NYC on May 8, 2014 at the age of 89. Loving husband to the late Arline, devoted dad to Stacey and Andrea. Caring father-in-law to Bob, and proud and doting Popo to Alex, Sami and Josh. Successful businessman and a man of many interests and talents. A patriotic marine in WWII. We will miss him dearly.

EDELSACK--Pyser Sherman. 1943 2014. Dedicated teacher, leader and colleague, Pyser leaves a great legacy at the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education. His work was integral to accomplishing our mission to train physicians who serve vulnerable, underserved populations. His vision, coupled with his collaborations with community-based organizations enabled the School to develop experiential learning opportunities with agencies and clinicians serving low income populations. His service to the community has been an inspiration to the Sophie Community, has enriched the learning of almost 2,000 graduates, and benefited City College by the collaborative goodwill engendered in the communities served. Pyser's vision, energy and passion have left an indelible mark on the Sophie Davis community.

HILL--Marianne D. Passed away peacefully May 4, 2014, at Greenport, NY. Born Marianne Fahys Dean in Garden City, NY, on October 6, 1922, to Howard Brush Dean and Maria Cook Dean. A lifelong New Yorker, she was brought up in Manhattan, North Haven, and East Hampton. She attended school at Chapin, Miss Porter's, and Bennett Junior College; worked in childhood education in New York City; and was then a longtime resident of Cold Spring Harbor where she raised her family and taught nursery school for many years. Her joys included her church, gardening, tennis, volunteer work, Labrador retrievers, and fishing with her husband and boys. Devoted to family, friends of all ages, and her beloved students, Mair met each day with a positive outlook, a great sense of humor, and a deep and genuine kindness for all. The exceptional generosity of her spirit and the warmth of her character never wavered. Predeceased by her husband Lucien Hill, son Lucien Hill III (Tony), brother Howard B. Dean, Jr., and sister Nancy D. Felch; she is survived by her son John H. Hill, daughter-in-law Renee A. Richards, grandson James L. Hill, sister-in-law Andree M. Dean, and her many nieces, nephews, and cousins. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, on Monday, May 12 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Employee Appreciation Fund at Peconic Landing, Greenport, NY.
GERSHON--Howard. To Howard and Max. From Lois, Baby and Boots. Rest in peace.

BRODIE--Richard E.,96, born in New York, February 23, 1918, died May 4, 2014. Son of Robert B. Brodie and Edith (Clug) Brodie. Served in World War II and Korea. Director of Camp Berkshire. Educational Psychologist and Nutritionist. Established Brodie Park, New Hartford CT. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Esther, sons, Scott and Bruce, daughters-in-law, Susan Lewis and Marie Casey and grandchildren, Joshua and Melissa, Emma, Clara, and Ben Brodie.
GERSHON--Howard. Our profound condolences to Andi, Stacey, Sami, and Alex on the passing of their beloved father and grandfather. May his memory be a blessing. Patricia & Alan B. Abramson

FRIEDMAN--Alan J. The Board and staff of the Fund for the City of New York mourn the loss of Alan J. Friedman, friend, member of the Fund's Selection Panel for the Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching and long-time board member. Alan will be remembered as a passionate advocate for quality education and as a brilliant translator, making the wonders of sciences available to the public. Alan shared his talent generously with everyone, from young people in the Rockaways to officials in the West Wing. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Mickey. Vaughn Williams Chair of the Board Mary McCormick President

MEYER--Florence. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Mrs. Florence Meyer, and extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Barry Swidler, President for the Board of Governor
HYACINTHE--Sylvere. Westchester Community College Foundation mourns the passing of Sylvere Hyacinthe, who served on our board from 2001-2005. Her service to the community will be remembered
GANS--Jamie Lee. Hard to believe it's been 4 years. Hope you have found your peace. Miss you, Mom, Felix and Andy

Link--Eileen. Dr. Alan Guerci, President and CEO, St. Francis Hospital Foundation, and the entire St. Francis Hospital community mourn the passing of our dear friend and benefactress, Eileen Francis Link. Our thoughts and prayers are with her beloved husband Robert E. Link, Jr. and their children and grandchildren.

WALSH--James R.,79 of Whiting, NJ, passed away peacefully at home with his beloved wife, Geraldine Smith Walsh, at his side on May 8, 2014. He was born in New York City (Yorkville) to James and Eileen (Rown) Walsh. He was a graduate of St. Ann's Academy and attended Cornell University; served active duty with the United States Army during the Korean War; and worked as an accountant in the public and corporate sectors. He is survived by his children, Pamela, Jay, Susan, and Sherry and eight grandchildren; his siblings, Vincent, Peter, Elaine, and Nancy Walsh Reilly, four nieces and three nephews, and many cousins. His great passion was sports. He had a great love for the New York Yankees, Rangers and the horses. Visitation will be from 9 to 10:30am on Tuesday, May 13th at Manchester Memorial Funeral Home, 28 Schoolhouse Road, Whiting, NJ with a Funeral Mass following at 10:45 at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton RC Church, 30 Schoolhouse Road, Whiting, NJ. Burial immediately following at Brigadier General William C. Doyle Veteran's Memorial Cemetery, 350 Provinceline Road, Wrightstown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

SCHRAG--Bella F.,beloved wife of the late Allen I. Schrag, cherished mother to Howard, Jonah and Carl Schrag, doting grandmother to Sarah, Molly, Robbie, Jeremy, Toby, Joelle and Avery, died on Sunday, May 4, 2014 just days shy of her 90th birthday. She lived her life with optimism, fidelity, independence, and abiding love. May her guiding spirit reside within us all the days of our lives.

SHAPIRO--Fred, Newmark Grubb Knight Frank extends its deepest condolences and heartfelt sympathies to the family of our esteemed colleague and friend, Fred Shapiro, on his untimely passing. A dedicated and hard-working employee of NGKF for 19 years, Fred was tireless, loyal, kind and touched the hearts of everyone who had the privilege to know him. He will be deeply missed.

ZUCKMAN--Phyllis (nee Rosenfeld), February 9, 1930-May 6, 2014. Predeceased by her loving husband Herman (Hy) Zuckman, parents Morris and Rae Rosenfeld, and brother Norman Rosenfeld. Cherished mother of Grace Goldstein, Ellen Zuckman, and Naomi Brooks; adored grandmother of Emily and Ariel, Rachel and Lucas, and Alison; great-grandmother of Marqel and Mariah. Graduate of Hunter High School, City College, and the College of New Rochelle. Active member of Temple Israel of New Rochelle; special education teacher; lover of reading, Scrabble, Jeopardy, and travel. Wonderful, funny, insightful friend to many. A graveside service occurred on May 7. Memorial donations may be made to Temple Israel of New Rochelle, http://www.tinr.org/, 914-235-1800, or a charity of your choice.

PACKER--Bernard, January 31, 1919 (Bronx) - April 27, 2014 (Brooklyn). Stickball champ, WWII veteran, enthusiastic singer. Survived by daughters, Joyce (Ezra Bialik), Cheryl (Tom Ulie); grandchildren, Rachel (Will Lee), Carl, Alexander, Alison, Daniel; great-granddaughter, Anya; and companion, Lillian. Donations may be sent to nymemorycenter.org or heightsandhills.org.

NOYES--Elizabeth B.,Died peacefully on Monday, May 5th, 2014 in Greenport, NY, at the age of 91. Beloved wife of David C. Noyes, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Susan Noyes Bilkey, son Robert M. Noyes and grandchildren Mali and Mason Noyes. She was predeceased by her son, David C. Noyes, III. She was the daughter of Mildred Patterson Bull and Charles M. Bull. She loved playing tennis, gardening, and swimming in the ocean. Popular, energetic and kind, she volunteered at the Huntington Hospital, NY, as a candy striper for a number of years. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor on June 7th at 11:00am.

FORD--Richard Edwin. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain express our deepest sorrow at the death of our good friend and museum patron Richard Ford. Richard was a member of the Friends of the American Museum in Britain since 1984 and a trustee of the museum for more than 10 years. His generosity, dedication, and friendship will be deeply missed. Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman, Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman American Museum in Britain, Linda Hackett, President, Halcyon Foundation.

BRETTHOLZ--Sidney, on May 9, 2014 at 89 years. Loving father of Edward (Andrea) and Gail Horn (Myles). Dear brother-in-law of Jerry Chizever (Caroline). Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Adoring grandfather of Alex, Jordan, Rebecca and Ariel. Uncle of Rick, Jill, Peter, Andrew and Geoffrey. He was one of a kind and lived life his own way with great optimism and zest. He was completely devoted to his family and will be greatly missed. Donations in his name may be made to the UJA Federation. Services Sunday 10am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ABRAMS--Abraham, D.D.S.,passed away peacefully at age 91, on May 7, in Boca Raton, Florida. A devoted husband to Harriet Abrams (predeceased) and Anita Kessler. Loving father to Gary and Joan Abrams; Janet and Louis Ederer; and Ellen and David Greene. Adored grandfather of Bryan, Elizabeth, Lindsey, Eamonn, and great granddaughter Ella; Jason, Jodi, Kerry and Tracy; and Alexis, Sam and Ryan. Abe was an amazing man who approached life with optimism and a great sense of humor. He built a beautiful and close-knit family, and his spirit and unconditional love will remain with us forever. Services will be held at Guttermans Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY, on May 11, 2014.

STRAUS--George, 83. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1931. Died April 27, 2014. Only son of Emile and Lily Straus, he came to New York City in 1939. Graduated from Queens College. Employed by Equitable for more than 33 years. Devoted to opera, he contributed to the Metropolitan and Santa Fe Opera companies and to various theatres. Survived by Joseph "Jerry" Rodgers, his devoted partner for 30 years, and by cousins Mrs. Lisl Hirsh, Dr. Michael Hirsh and wife Julie Ann, Debbie and Forrest Hitchinson. Memorial to be announced at a later date.

STEINBAUER--Douglas R. Died at home in Manhattan on April 25 at age 87. He was the beloved husband of Mary for 47 years. He is also survived by the children of his first marriage: son Mark (Carrie) and his children Amy, Adam, Aaron; daughter Anne (Liam); grandchildren Troy and Page, children of his late son Reid (Ellen). Doug was born in Pomeroy, OH in 1927 but lived in Columbus for much of his youth. He was drafted at 18 as World War II was ending, stationed in the Philippines for over a year. He attended Ohio State University on the GI Bill and was editor of The Sundial, following in the footsteps of idol James Thurber. After graduation he moved to New York City to become an editor but was sidetracked into art directing at Medical Economics, Architectural Record, Parade, 50 Plus, and Time-Life Books' United States History series. He was the Art Director of Silver Burdett for 19 years and revolutionized the design of children's schoolbooks, using innovative artists, photographers and craftsmen. The books won multiple awards and accolades and were considered "the gold standard" by others in his field. Doug loved poetry, old songs and movies, architecture and design, the theater, the NYC Ballet, The New York Times in print, martinis and single-malt scotch, books, smart women, a good argument, Greenwich Village, the house he designed in Castle Valley, UT, public schools, his family and their many get-togethers. He studied film-making, acted professionally, learned Chinese cooking. He and Mary traveled the country and world together. He was smart, funny, stubborn, modest, polite, creative, friendly, reserved but sentimental, interested in everything, very appreciative of his good life. He will be missed by his loving extended family, valued friends, and all he met. A memorial service and celebration of his life will be held in the future. He was a good guy.

STEIN--Claire A.,died peacefully at home on May 9. Eight months earlier, she joyfully celebrated her 90th birthday in the presence of her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, along with other family and friends. Born Anita Claire Alpern, she was sometimes known as A-Claire or acorn to her childhood friends. She was the daughter of Milton Alpern and Henrietta Nathanson Alpern, and grew up in Brooklyn. She graduated from James Madison High School and Adelphi College, but of all her educational experience she valued most her primary school years at Ethical Culture School in Brooklyn. While in college, her sorority sister and best friend, Lucille Stein, introduced Claire to Lucille's brother Howard. Claire and Howard were married less than a year later, and remained the loves of each other's lives for 63 years, until Howard's death in 2006. They were separated from one another only during World War II, when Howard served in the army in Europe, while Claire stayed on the home front, pregnant with their first child, Brad. As a young wife and mother, Claire studied sculpture with Robert Cronbach and at the Art Students' League. She was a sculptor working in wood carving, plaster modeling for casting, and ultimately, direct metal welding. She was proud to have been praised by a plumber for the quality of her "bead" or weld joint. From 1967 to 1987 she was Executive Director of the National Sculpture Society. She learned the art of making hooked rugs, and enjoyed making pictorial rugs that touched on aspects of family life, notably including the family country home at Copake, New York. For all her interest in art and all her artist friends, her family was always the most important to her. She was a great listener and reader. She rejoiced at the arrival of grandchildren and then great-grandchildren, and loved looking for birthday presents for them all. Her sister Marilyn Alpern Gorlin and brother Buddy Alpern pre-deceased her. She is survived by her brother Nubby Alpern, her sisters-in-law Lucille Stein Kantor and Mildred Alpern, her son Bradford Stein and daughter-in-law Mary Grace Stein, and her daughter Wendy A. Stein and son-in-law Bart Friedman. She is also survived by grandchildren, Elizabeth Ruark, Zachary Stein, Alexander Stein, Benjamin Alpern Friedman and Jacob Stein Friedman, as well as great-grandchildren Isabel Stein, Siena Ruark, Thalia Ruark and Henry Stein. In lieu of flowers, a donation in her name to the Roeliff Jansen Regional Library in Copake, New York 12516 would be appreciated.
GOODSTEIN--Arlene. 5/11--9/8 Happy Birthday Mama! You are our sunshine. I cherish your warmth and every memory. Love Always, Vivi and Juli

van der HEIDE--Louis, DVM, PhD, of Columbia, CT died, Monday, May 5th in Ridgewood, NJ. Born in Holland, Louis, a kind-hearted man, admired by many, was a loving father and friend. He devoted his life to his family and Veterinary medicine, where his work in avian disease research was internationally recognized. Louis spent over 20 years at the University of Connecticut, Department of Pathobiology. Predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Ingrid (Klaje) van der Heide, he is survived by two daughters, Marjolein Rust of La Jolla, CA, Ilje Allsup and her husband Brett, of Portland, OR, two sons, Mike van der Heide of Portland, OR and Pieter van der Heide and his wife Kate Armstrong of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, 11 grandchildren, a great-grandchild, and his brother Theo of Holland. He was predeceased by brothers Cleem and Kees. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Tuesday, May 13th at 10am in Corpus Christi Church, 601 Silas Deane Hwy, Wethersfield, CT. Visitation is Monday, May 12th from 4-7pm at Farley Sullivan Funeral Home, 34 Beaver Rd, Wethersfield, CT. Visit farleysullivan.com.

VANDERKLOOT--Frederic John, on May 1. Dearest husband and hero to Miriam. Devoted father to Kathryn VanderKloot and Pamela Bartel (William). Proud grandfather to Nicholas and Alexander Perkins, and Zoe and Zachary Bartel. Fond stepfather to Marisa Jaffe (Jeffrey Sirlin) and Sara Jaffe (David Ostroff). Grandpa Fred to Noah Sirlin, and Hannah and Nora Ostroff. A loyal and grateful son of Yale, he was co-chairman of his 55th reunion at his death. Fred will be remembered at the Class of 1959 memorial service on June 1. Please consider contributions to Yale University or Planned Parenthood in Fred's memory.

STEWART--Bhob. Died at 76 on February 24 in Plymouth, MA. Born in Meridian, MS, on November 12, 1937, Bhob graduated in 1959 from Sam Houston State. Bhob is widely credited with inventing the term "underground comics" in 1966. In 1969, Bhob curated the first exhibition of underground comic art, at the Corcoran Gallery. Bhob worked as an editor at Topps Chewing Gum and created Wacky Packages. Bhob edited the magazine Castle of Frankenstein, was a contributor to The Realist, Roxy Funnies, The Comics Journal, Heavy Metal, wrote Against the Grain: Mad Artist Wallace Wood (2003) and penned an underground pastiche, Tales from the Fridge (1973). In his later years, he wrote a blog, potrzebie.blogspot.com, and over 1,000 Wikipedia entries. Bhob is survived by his brother Joe B. Stewart of Arlington, VA.
DICK--Marion Pokoik . Thinking of you today on Mother's Day, especially remembering the devoted mother you were to all of your children and grandchildren. Your daughter, Gail

ZUCKMAN--Phyllis (nee Rosenfeld), February 9, 1930-May 6, 2014. Predeceased by her loving husband Herman (Hy) Zuckman, parents Morris and Rae Rosenfeld, and brother Norman Rosenfeld. Cherished mother of Grace Goldstein, Ellen Zuckman, and Naomi Brooks; adored grandmother of Emily and Ariel, Rachel and Lucas, and Alison; great-grandmother of Marqel and Mariah. Graduate of Hunter High School, City College, and the College of New Rochelle. Active member of Temple Israel of New Rochelle; special education teacher; lover of reading, Scrabble, Jeopardy, and travel. Wonderful, funny, insightful friend to many. A graveside service occurred on May 7. Memorial donations may be made to Temple Israel of New Rochelle, http://www.tinr.org/, 914-235-1800, or a charity of your choice.
HALL--Jeffrey L.,5/11/1947- 11/7/2013. "The song has ended, but the memory lingers on". Happy Birthday My Darling! Forever yours, Terry

BYRNE--Patrick. In loving memory and forever in our hearts and minds. BMCC and KJEBI

NUMBER ONE SAM Written and illustrated by Greg Pizzoli. 36 pp. Disney-Hyperion. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) 
 
Pizzoli (“The Watermelon Seed”) brings his dashing screen-print style to the story of Sam, a dog with lovely manners — so long as he’s winning. In a typical race, Sam drives his little red racecar across the finish line under a shower of candy-button confetti. But when Maggie the elephant comes in first, Sam has to learn the art of losing. The story is familiar, but Pizzoli’s zingy ice-pop colors and dramatically varied page compositions take home the blue ribbon.

SUPERWORM By Julia Donaldson. Illustrated by Axel Scheffler. 32 pp. Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6) 
 
In this first American printing of “Superworm,” by Donaldson and Scheffler (of “The Gruffalo,” among other picture-book favorites), Superworm’s strength, length and stretchability make him a hero to his frog and insect friends, whom he rescues from dire predicaments. At last, they get the chance to return the favor when Wizard Lizard puts Superworm under a dreadful enchantment. A word lover’s delight in rousing, rhyming verse.

HOFFMAN--Marjorie Gail, died on April 29th in Phoenix, Arizona. She is survived by her son Jonathan, daughter Carolyn, sister Patricia, and three grandchildren. Margie, as she was known by all, was originally from Buffalo, New York. She graduated from Cornell University with a Bachelor's of Fine Arts and earned her Master's Degree from Columbia University. Margie moved to Arizona in 1986 where she ran Margie Gail, Inc. a business she started in New Jersey that designed and manufactured hand-painted clothing. In 1992, Margie joined Merrill Lynch as a financial consultant where she served her clients for 22 years. Margie was unique. She loved her occupation and her clients. Clients respected her keen understanding of financial markets, but, even more, they loved her kindness, warmth, understanding, and her sage advice in difficult life situations. Margie loved her children and her grandchildren passionately. She was a warm and loving mother and a great friend to all who knew her. A talented artist, Margie's work was exhibited in galleries in New York and her home was filled her with her beautiful oil paintings and water colors. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Inner-City Arts (www.inner-cityarts.org) or Hospice of the Valley (www.hov.org).

SCHOENBERG--Lawrence, 81, of Longboat Key, FL, born New York City; University of Pennsylvania BA 1953, Wharton MBA 1956; US Army Signal Corps 1953-55. A successful business entrepreneur, he was Founder and CEO of AGS Computers, Inc., a NYSE traded company; President of ITAA, the computer services trade association; and held directorships in numerous public and private companies including MERISEL, GTSI, SUNGUARD, and CampusWorks, Inc. In the scholarly world, as a renowned collector of Medieval and Early Modern manuscripts, he created the Schoenberg Database of Manuscripts and established the Schoenberg Institute for Manuscript Studies at U. of Pennsylvania. As a philanthropist, he served on the boards of the American Business Council, St. Barnabas Hospital, Babbage Institute, Dickinson College and University of Pennsylvania Libraries. Survived by his wife Barbara Brizdle, sons Douglas and Eric Schoenberg, daughter Julie Schoenberg Jacobs, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Schoenberg Institute at Penn Libraries, 3420 Walnut St., Philadelphia, PA 19104 or Ringling College of Art and Design Library, 2700 N. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34234. Memorial to follow at Penn Libraries later this summer.
GOLDMAN--Benjamin. Husband of the late Edna, father of Mark and Naomi. Grandfather of Robin, Michael, Rachel and Emet. Services on Sunday, May 11, 2014, 12:30pm, Wellwood Cemetery. Pinelawn, LI.

ROSENBERG--Rose, 98, beloved wife of the late Harold Rosenberg for 76 years, died peacefully May 6th. A resident of Lake Worth, Florida and formerly of Lido Beach, New York. A stunning force of nature, she is survived by her children Jane Stein (Rick), Liz Rosenberg Citron (Phil), Gale Bayer and the late Stephen Bayer; grandchildren John, Maggie, and Johanna Stein, Kate Stein Hilliker, Kim Bayer Olthoff and Jesse Bayer; and great-grandchildren John Stephen, Ruby, True and Cole. HARBER--Bennet Sandford, "Uncle Ben" died peacefully on May 4th at the age of 83. A gentleman and a gentle man, he loved opera, fishing and a good pound cake. He attended Horace Mann and The Wharton School. He is survived by his brother, Leonard Harber; his sister-in-law, Rosalyn Harber; his two nephews and their wives: Steven and Lana Harber; Jonathan and Maria Harber; a grandniece: Sophia and three grandnephews: Oliver, Grayson and James. His kindness, generosity, amazing memory, outgoing nature and independent spirit will be missed by family and many dear friends. No service will be held but donations can be made in his honor to Lighthouse International.

ROBERTS--Michael, died peacefully at his home on May 5th surrounded by the people he loved, his wife Mimi of 67 years, children and grandchildren. He died smiling at them as he did in life. Mike graduated Fordham Law and received his LLB before joining the US Air Force, serving as an officer during WWII. He moved to Great Neck and raised two children, Alec and Judy, and became a respected member of his community. He was honored by UJA, ADL and strongly supported AIPAC, Technion and other charities. He was politically active, especially in support of New York Senator Moynihan, who became a lifelong friend. He was blessed with many devoted friends and shared their lives. He is survived by his loving wife, Mimi, his son, Alec and spouse Barbara, daughter Judy and spouse Mark Tarlov, and three beloved grandchildren, Jessie, Molly and Ben.

HOCH--Eli, PhD, The Board of Directors and Staff of New York Psychotherapy and Counseling Center mourn the passing of Dr. Eli Hoch on May 2, 2014. Eli served with distinction as Director of Clinical Services and as a member of the Governor's Mental Health Services Council. He was a warm, generous, loyal friend and colleague. He was a gentle and wise man beloved by all who knew him. His humanity, compassion, optimism and genial nature will be missed. His leadership and vision guide us to this very day. We extend sincere condolences to his entire family. Devora Brickman, President, Board of Directors Elliott Klein, Executive Director

MEYER--Florence, beloved wife of the late Dr. Ernest Meyer, and the loving wonderful mother of Sharon, Jeff, Lynn, Amy and spouses Steven, Veronica, Gary and Robert. GRAVER--Audrey, passed away Friday, May 9th, 2014 at 11:30pm. We have lost one of the most beautiful, supportive, loving woman to have graced this earth. She leaves behind her legacy, her family. Jack, her devoted and loving husband, her sister Iris, her sister by another mother Maureen, her children Richard, Lori, Susan and all of her precious grand children Michael, Alli, Jessica, Josh, David, Christine, Matthew, Jaclyn, Kevin and the new love of her life, Alexander. She lives in our hearts forever.

O'CONNOR--Katherine (Binky) Maffitt, age 81, died on April 26, 2014. Binky was the great, great granddaughter of Dr. William Maffitt and Julia Chouteau of St. Louis, and the daughter of Edward Pierce Maffitt and Katherine Mulvane Maffitt. She was the widow of Richard O'Connor of Bloomfield Hills, MI, former CEO of Campbell-Ewald and board member of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Previously she had been married to Kasimir Korybut-Daszkiewicz of New York City and Jamaica. Binky is survived by her sons Michael Korybut and Alexis Casimir Korybut-Daszkiewicz, their children, her cousin Peter Chouteau Maffitt, and her step-children: Richard O'Connor, Jr., Timothy O'Connor, John O'Connor, Kathryn Bowman, and Meghan Sullivan. Binky lived a full and extraordinary life. Her father was a career diplomat with the US State Department. Consequently, Binky was born in Stockholm, Sweden, and spent her formative years in Sao Paulo, Brazil and Buenos Aires, Argentina, and thereafter in Spain, Italy, France, India, and Greece. She was fluent in five languages and lived and travelled in countless countries. She was educated at the Foxcroft School in Virginia and graduated from Vassar College. Professionally, she had a successful career as President of Inverness Travel in NYC. Binky was an extremely warm and gregarious individual who loved life and loved people. With a radiant smile and quick laugh, Binky was a good friend to many, a wonderful mother to her children, and a loving wife to her beloved and devoted husband Dick. Pectora animosque amicorum sui illa signum impressit. A memorial service will be held in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, the date of which has not been scheduled yet. For further information, please contact Michael Korybut at 42 Westmoreland Place, St. Louis, MO 63108.

SICA--Carmen. Skilled professional, comic genius, extravagant hostess, loyal friend, and great soul, Carmen Sica left this world on April 21, 2014 after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn on October 26, 1948, daughter of Antonio and Encarna Soler, she began what would be the professional work of her life in 1966, at the age of 18, in the steno pool of Davis Polk & Wardwell. She went on to become a Davis Polk legend, and a beloved and admired figure to a generation of Davis Polk lawyers and staff. Spectacularly competent, supremely intelligent, rigorously organized, and beautifully trained, Carmen was an old fashioned (in the best sense possible) legal secretary. We shall not look upon her like again. Apart from the lightning speed of her fingers, and her indefatigable energy long into the night as deadlines loomed, Carmen understood and contributed to the cases she worked on. Woe to the senior partner who fell in love with a weak argument--"Doesn't your balloon ever land?" She spoke truth to power in the funniest possible way, but her actual point was to assist with the case. She was a consummate professional with a twinkle in her eye and a heart much softer than she liked to acknowledge. Her razor wit, her keen eye for the absurd, and her sometimes scathing (but always hilarious) commentary were reserved for the people she liked and admired. Her good heart never made public fun of those less intellectually fortunate than herself. Having left Davis Polk in 1993 with her good friend Ann McDonald (a move for which Ann was eternally grateful), Carmen continued her amazing legal work at Robinson McDonald & Canna. In addition to her day job at that firm, Carmen was Ann's keeper for the next 20 years. To Ann, as to so many many others, Carmen was a devoted and loyal friend and was generous to a fault. To all her friends, Carmen was also the hostess with the mostest! Summers at Carmen's house in East Atlantic Beach were a festival of food, drink, swimming, many friends and, most of all, merriment and laughter--side splitting laughter because Carmen's comic wit was on a world class level. This was a funny lady! And she was a kind and generous and wise lady too. She had a host of friends that loved her and that she loved, and those relationships took and stuck and lasted long. Carmen is survived by her family in Spain, Maria Elena, Juan Antonio and others, by her brother, Raymond Gil, and by her nephew and niece, Ray and Mercedes Gil. She is also survived by the love of troops of friends and family, including Natalie and Matt, Laura and Michael, Camille and David, Mary R., Christine and Anthony, Mary and Andy, Mark, Bernard, Fritzie, Billy, Amy, Ann, Jayne, Christine C., Lisa, Liz and many many more. She had a big and loving heart, and everyone who knew her adored her and will miss her. "There's a great spirit gone!" William Shakespeare.
