Donations may be sent to nymemorycenter.org or heightsandhills.org.

PIRANI--Luciana Nahmias, passed away in Lenox, MA on May 3, 2014. She is predeceased by her husband Conrad Levi Pirani and survived by a sister, Annalisa Mattei of San Lorenzo, Spain; her children Barbara Alberts Pirani, Bolton, MA, Sylvia Pirani, Albany NY, Robert Pirani, New York, NY, and their spouses; and five grandchildren. Luciana was born in Milano, Italy in 1924. In 1955 she moved to Chicago to marry her future husband. The family moved to Northern New Jersey in 1972 and she and Conrad retired to Lenox, MA in 1999. As a teenager, Luciana assumed responsibility for protecting her frail mother and younger sister after her father passed away fleeing the Nazi occupation in 1943. Luciana was sensitive to injustices wherever she lived, and continued public service throughout her life. Luciana trained as a social worker helping resettle refugees in post-war Italy. She later promoted civil rights and family planning, worked with disabled children, and volunteered with after school and affordable housing programs. Luciana was also a Master Gardener, expert knitter, and excellent cook, setting a wonderful example that her children and grandchildren aspire to emulate. Contributions in her memory can be made to the CAMP Youth Development Program, 13-15 N. 1st Street, Paterson, NJ 07522.

POSES--Richard L. (May 13, 1922-May 8, 2014) Dearest love of wife, Phyllis (Smerling), of 67 years: Proud father of Peter, Jonathan and David; daughter-in-law, Linda; "Gramps" to Zoe and Hannah; and uncle to Rob, Alice, Laurance, Lisa, Matthew and families. Admired/beloved resident of Amsterdam At Harborside, Port Washington, NY B.A., Brooklyn College; attended New School For Social Research. Consummate professional in the textile industry. Far-ranging intellect, culturally inquiring mind and dog-lover. Services: 12 Noon, Monday, May 12, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck. Burial follows: Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. Donations may be sent in memory of R.L. Poses to The Arthritis Foundation - arthritis.org or "We Always Swing" a Jazz Series - wealwaysswing.org.

LOW--Babette Lintz, Adoring daughter of Marjorie Low, wife of Alan Lintz, sister of Peter (Peggy) Low. Loving stepmother of Jennie Ebner and Zachery Lintz, aunt of Amy Chasen (David) and John (Donna) Low. Services private.
LESSER--Ethel G.,died April 11. We'll love you forever. Laurence, Felice, Diane, Julia, Rachel & Joel

LIEGNER--Judith, vocal artist, concert manager and NAPAMA founder, died on April 17th at age 91. She made her vocal debut in 1957 at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her company Liegner Management managed the careers of many singers.

LITTLE--Thomas Joseph, born in San Francisco, CA to Evelyn and Matthew Little, passed Wednesday morning, April 30, 2014. He served as teacher and Head of School at Park Day School for 38 years. Tom was a founding member and Board President of the Progressive Education Network. He was a Klingenstein Fellow at the Columbia University's Teacher's College. The People of Color in Independent Schools organization, also established the Tom Little Head of School Award and made him its inaugural recipient. Tom researched and wrote an upcoming book entitled, "Loving Learning: How Progressive Education Can Save American Schools." Tom was also a Division I NCAA Women's Basketball Official.

LEARY--Paul M.,Jr., 83, of Ridgefield, CT, formerly of Greenwich, CT. President, Paul M. Leary Associates, a manufacturers representative of electrical products, died peacefully May 8, 2014. Husband of the late Carol (nee Costello) Leary, father of Beth (Andrew) Perlman of Ridgefield, CT and Chris (Jennifer) Leary of Greenwich, CT and grandfather to five granddaughters. Funeral Mass, Wednesday, May 14th at 10am St. Michael the Archangel Church, Greenwich, CT. Visitation at the Kane Funeral Home, 25 Catoonah St., Ridgefield, CT on Tuesday from 5pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Friends of the Greenwich Library, Greenwich, CT.

MAISEL--Howard M. Of New York and Sag Harbor, born June 11, 1931, passed peacefully from this world on May 8, 2014, at his home in Manhattan. He had battled pancreatic cancer for nearly a year. He leaves behind his wife Eve France, his children Miriam Maisel, David Maisel and Jennifer Maisel, his brother Jay Maisel, his granddaughters Jessie Fontana-Maisel and Julia Maisel-Berick, and his daughter-in-law Lynn Fontana and son-in-law Michael Berick. In addition, he leaves behind his step-children Kim France, Michael and Shirim France, Todd and Shanna France, and grandchildren Eli, Henry, and Abe, and many nephews, nieces and dear friends who hold him in their hearts. He joins in death his first wife, Joan Epstein Maisel, and his parents Milton Maisel and Rose Schiffman Maisel. A graduate of Cornell University, Howard became President of Columbia Cement Incorporated; he was an executive for British Petroleum in London. He also served on the boards of Temple Adas Israel and Children's Rights. An avid reader and champion of the arts, Howard never stopped learning. A memorial service in celebration of Howard's life will be held Monday, May 12 at noon, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Good Shepherd Services goodshepherds.org and the NPCF pancreaticcancerfoundation. com

KASH--Shirley Black, 92, died of natural causes on Monday, May 5, 2014 in Paradise Valley, Arizona, where she lived for 20 years. Her son Leon Black, his wife Debra and their four children Benjamin, Joshua, Alexander, and Victoria; and her daughter Judy Black and her husband Richard Schlosberg mourn the loss of a beloved mother and grandparent. Born Shirley Lubell on June 20, 1921 in New York City, she grew up in New York City and lived in Westport, Connecticut as well. She pursued a life-long interest in the arts. She was an accomplished water colorist and her works of art were shown at the Alonzo Gallery in New York City. Often inspired by nature, her love of flowers and plants was realized in her vibrant gardens and paintings. She was married to Eli Black for 29 years, who passed away in 1975. Her second husband, William Kash, died in 2010, after 28 years of marriage. She was also predeceased by her sister, Grace Borgenicht, and her brother, Benedict Lubell.

JONES--Charles Meyers Jr. Died May 3, 2014 in Calvary Hospital, The Bronx, NY at the age of 92. He was born in Annapolis, MD and attended the Parkway School in Trenton, NJ. He graduated cum laude from the Lawrenceville School in 1940, and from the Military Academy at West Point in June 1943. He saw immediate service in the 2nd Armored Division in Europe, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. After the war, he was a member of the occupying forces in Germany. He earned a Master of Science degree in Engineering from Johns Hopkins University in 1950. He continued his service with the US Army, working on the Guided Missile Program at the White Sands Proving Grounds, serving as the military attache to the US Embassy in Colombia, serving as the Commanding Officer of the 66th Armored Battalion in Fort Hood Texas, and working with the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington DC. He was a graduate of the US Army War College in 1961. He was awarded the Legion of Merit for his service. In 1966, he retired from the military as a Lt. Colonel and worked for Sylvania as a Strategic Planner, and became the Vice President of Administration and Planning for GTE. He later worked as a consultant for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. When he retired, he pursued his interests in astronomy, model railroading, travel, reading, and concert going. He lived in Greenwich, CT for over 40 years. Charlie was a loving family man and is survived by his wife Estelle Clausen Jones, his son Charles Myers Jones III, (Gretchen) his daughters Susan Jones D'Arbanville and Christine Tabram Jones. He was predeceased by his daughter, Caroline Sherwood Jones (Richard Rutenberg) in 2007. He is also survived by his granddaughters Kate Jones Sampson and Rebecca Rutenberg, his brother Harvey Cooper Jones (Martha) and two nieces, three nephews, three grandnieces and nine grandnephews. A Funeral service will be held at 10:00am on Monday, June 2nd at The US Military Academy (West Point). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Charlie's memory to The Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

KARLIN--Roy J.,of New York, NY passed away peacefully at home after a long illness on May 7, 2014. Born in Brooklyn to Jack and Gladys Karlin and raised upstate with his brother, Michael, he graduated from Union College in 1971 and earned a JD from Albany Law School. Beloved husband of Jane, devoted father to Paula Williams (Jeff) and David, adored grandfather to Jack. He is also survived by his mother and brother, and family, friends, and colleagues who loved him dearly. We will miss his loving devotion to his family, his gentle but firm resolve, and his concern for a just and caring world. He was buried in Stockbridge, MA. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 13 at 3:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 in recognition of Dr. Lewis Kampel or to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70 Street, New York, NY 10021 Attn: Development Department.

SCHWERIN--Joseph, 1938-2014. Exeter, Yale, W&L Law, then Wall Street. Investment success brought Joe leisure time for an inquisitive mind and a restless soul. He found beauty and adventure in art, women, and the natural world. A renaissance man of great taste (and appetite). Cousin, classmate, best friend and business partner; we will miss The Archdruid. Warren Schwerin

SHAPIRO--Fred, Newmark Grubb Knight Frank extends its deepest condolences and heartfelt sympathies to the family of our esteemed colleague and friend, Fred Shapiro, on his untimely passing. A dedicated and hard-working employee of NGKF for 19 years, Fred was tireless, loyal, kind and touched the hearts of everyone who had the privilege to know him. He will be deeply missed.

BRETTHOLZ--Sidney, on May 9, 2014 at 89 years. Loving father of Edward (Andrea) and Gail Horn (Myles). Dear brother-in-law of Jerry Chizever (Caroline). Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Adoring grandfather of Alex, Jordan, Rebecca and Ariel. Uncle of Rick, Jill, Peter, Andrew and Geoffrey. He was one of a kind and lived life his own way with great optimism and zest. He was completely devoted to his family and will be greatly missed. Donations in his name may be made to the UJA Federation. Services Sunday 10am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

EVANS--Mary Johnston,of East Hampton and New York City, passed away on May 5, 2014. Beloved wife of James H. Evans (Retired Chairman, Union Pacific Corporation), Mary was born on February 28, 1930 in Shawnee, Oklahoma. She attended Wellesley College and the University of Oklahoma. Mrs. Evans was smart, witty and incredibly charming. She was one of the most successful women of her generation and inspired many young women to take leadership positions in their community and in business. She also had a lifelong love of the New York Yankees and the Oklahoma Sooners. Mrs. Evans's corporate career included serving on the Boards of AMTRAK (vice chair), Delta Air Lines, Household International, Saint-Gobain Corp., Sunoco, Inc., Baxter International, Inc., The Dun & Bradstreet Corp., Moody's Corp. and Scudder, Stevens & Clark. In her civic career, Mary Evans served on the Boards of Carnegie Hall, Major Gifts Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Brick Presbyterian Church in New York and St. Anthony Hospital, Presbyterian Medical Center, United Appeal and YWCA in Oklahoma. Honors included inclusion in "200 Top Corporate Women" in Business Week, member of the Conference Board, induction into the Oklahoma Hall of Fame, first woman to address the Judicial Conference of the Tenth US Circuit Court, President of the Junior League (Oklahoma City), Distinguished Service Award, University of Oklahoma, first woman to address the Economic Club of Oklahoma City, The Liberty Bell Law Day Award for outstanding contributions to the legal profession by a layman, and recipient of the Director's Choice Award of the National Women's Economic Alliance. She was a member of the Colony Club (NYC) and Maidstone Club (East Hampton). Mary is survived by her husband, Jim, her children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Denver, Paul Johnston Head (Jean), Oklahoma City, and Eric Talbot Head (Shelley Magness), Denver, her grandchildren, Paxton X. Head, Atlanta, and Talbott Glover, Houston, her brother, Paul Ross Johnston (Sally), Vail and her step-children, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard). Memorial service will be held at 3:00pm, Friday, May 16 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the NYC Chapter, Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 or the University of Colorado Alzheimer's Research Fund, 13001 East 17th Pl., MS-A065, Aurora, CO 80045.

BLOCH--Thelma, a wonderful, caring woman. A gifted writer, irreplaceable office manager, devoted friend. Her generosity and intellect inspired all of us. She will be missed. Gerry Nancy Sweder & Family

DAVIS--Bernice, "Bobbie" Mund, of Boca Raton, FL and Martha's Vineyard, MA passed away in the early morning hours on May 7, 2014. She is survived by her husband Sheldon, her three children Jody Howard (Marc), Robin Negin (Geoff) and Jonathan Davis (Sloane) as well as by her eight grandchildren, Zachary Howard, Jake Howard, Sydney Weiss, Simon Negin, Elliot Negin, Jesse Davis, Joey Howard and Chloe Davis. Bobbie was born August 5, 1937 in New York City. She attended both Rider and Columbia Universities and then raised her family in New Rochelle, NY. As a young mother Bobbie volunteered her time to the Girl Scouts. Eventually, she became a full-time executive as Program Director for the Westchester-Putnam Counties. Bobbie spent 25 years creating a wide range of opportunities for girls to build character, to gain self-esteem and to acquire life experiences by serving their communities. She also helped girls accomplish their dream of obtaining a higher education through the many scholarships and grants offered to the Girl Scouts by local and national businesses. During her career she was honored by Mayor Mario Cuomo for creating a program that offered free flying lessons to any Girl Scout who wished to take on the challenge. Among her many talents, Bobbie was an avid painter and won several awards for her work in watercolor. She also sold a number paintings at various art shows on Martha's Vineyard. Her impeccable taste and style was apparent in everything she did. Bobbie will be deeply mourned by her family and friends. Services for Bobbie Davis are being held Monday, May 12, 2014 at 12:00 noon at the Hawthorne Funeral Home in Hawthorne, New York. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society in Bobbie's memory.
BLUMENSTOCK--Katrina, May 18, 1950 - May 5, 2014. A supremely gifted designer; she gave us much joy, humor and color. Her loving family

BRODIE--Richard E.,96, born in New York, February 23, 1918, died May 4, 2014. Son of Robert B. Brodie and Edith (Clug) Brodie. Served in World War II and Korea. Director of Camp Berkshire. Educational Psychologist and Nutritionist. Established Brodie Park, New Hartford CT. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Esther, sons, Scott and Bruce, daughters-in-law, Susan Lewis and Marie Casey and grandchildren, Joshua and Melissa, Emma, Clara, and Ben Brodie.

DEAN--Ambassador Jonathan, (retired), passed away on January 15, 2014. He joined the Foreign Service in 1949 after World War II, and devoted his life to promoting peace. His passion for peace fueled his work on nuclear weapons, missile defense, space weapons, terrorism, and preventing internal and interstate armed conflict. He loved his large family, especially his wife Theodora, his brother David, and also Vienna operetta, accordion playing, and rose growing. A celebration of his life will be held May 24, 2014, 10am at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, McLean, VA.

BELKIN--Abby. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved on the passing of Mrs. Abby Belkin, of blessed memory, the highly esteemed and beloved widow of the late Rabbi Dr. Samuel Belkin, of blessed memory, second President of Yeshiva University, who was his caring Ayshet Chayil and fulfilled her role as his wife in the community as a veritable Grand Lady whose kindness, grace and friendly demeanor caused her to be admired by all. She was accorded the utmost of respect, honor and concern by Dr. Belkin's successors and the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees. Mrs. Belkin, a highly regarded journalist was a former Editor of the Women's Section of the Long Island Daily Press and was a speechwriter for Gov. Hugh Carey and a member of the Women's Newspaper Associations. May her memory ever serve as a source of blessings for all who were privileged to know her. May her family and loved ones be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

BROMBERG--Marvin William, a longtime New Yorker, died May 5, 2014, after a two year battle with glioblastoma. He was 88 years old. Born January 13, 1926, in Brooklyn, Dr. Bromberg was the only child of Velvo (William) and Ruchel (Rose) Bromberg, immigrants from Ukraine. A graduate of New York University, Dr. Bromberg served as a dentist in the Air Force, and for over fifty years, his practice was a magnet for artists, writers and creative thinkers throughout New York. A loving, dedicated husband, father, and grandfather, Dr. Bromberg is survived by his wife of 62 years, Penny Derris Bromberg, their two sons, Craig and Todd, their wives, Hilary and Veronika, and four grandchildren. A private graveside funeral will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Dr. Bromberg's memory to Voices Against Brain Cancer.

BAUER--William, 96; chemical engineer. Son of Noah and Golda Bauer. Born in Russia April 16, 1918; died May 4, 2014 after a fall. Spent his childhood in Turin, Italy; came to USA in 1930 and lived in Manhattan except for US Navy Service in WWII. Invariably gracious, he will be remembered by all who knew him.

BUTLER--John Newell, son of Richard Hartwell Butler and Elizabeth Newell Butler, of Mystic, CT passed away on May 6th. He is survived by his wife, Joan; his brothers, Richard, Robert, and Henry; and his two children, Robert and Katharine. He is also survived by his daughter-in-law, Lisa Sullivan Butler, and his son-in-law, Thomas Wideman, and five grandchildren, John Butler, Ashley Butler, Claire Butler, Nathaniel Wideman, and Thomas Wideman. John graduated from the Kingswood School in West Hartford and Yale University. He served in the United States Army from 195962. John worked for years as an educator and was Assistant Headmaster at Rumsey Hall School, and Headmaster at The Bement School and The Hillside School. He is fondly remembered by his many former students as a kind and steadfast mentor and friend. After moving to Connecticut in 1989, John worked with many local organizations, including Project Oceanology, the Salvation Army of New Haven, and the Archdiocese of Norwich. John devoted his life to being an active member of his community with numerous commitments to charitable organizations and a deep mission for helping people. In 1993, John worked with community leaders to create the Mystic River Park in downtown Mystic. This beautiful public park is enjoyed by many today. In recent years, he served with great dedication The WARM Shelter in Westerly, The Community Foundation of Eastern Connecticut, and Mystic Rotary. John had many interests including a passion for trains, a love of theater, folk music, opera, and gourmet cooking. He was a devoted fan of the New York Yankees and the New York Giants. John was a tremendous reader and an accomplished writer, including writing his own fiction and publishing his own newsletter, The Pearl Street Gazette. He was also very fond of long drives and enjoyed getting lost on small country roads. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his memory to St. Mary, Star of the Sea Church, 10 Huntington St., New London, CT, 06320.

BARTOS--Rena, The Women's Forum of New York records with sorrow the death of Rena Bartos, a longtime member and a pioneer in the field of marketing to women and older adult consumers. The former SVP and Director of Communications at J. Walter Thompson, Rena was the first woman to chair the Advertising Research Foundation. Deepest sympathy to Jim and family. Ami Kaplan, President Rita B. Crotty, Executive Director

FRIEDLANDER--Stanley, of Valley Stream, Long Island, aged 73. Passed away May 6th, 2014 from complications of Alzheimer's. Husband of the late Roberta Friedlander. Survived by his daughter, Emily Peck; two grandchildren, Noah and Avery; and four siblings: Gerald, Lawrence, Charles, and Susan Betsalel. Stanley earned his Bachelors degree from the City College of New York and his PhD from the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University. He taught Mathematics at Queens College and Northwestern University. He taught for over 25 years at Bronx Community College where he served as chairman of the department of Mathematics. He authored many mathematics papers and a foundational college mathematics textbook. He selflessly devoted thousands of hours to the care of others in hospice. He was an accomplished runner, founder of the Valley Stream Running Club, and completed many marathons and ultra-marathons. His humor and kindness will be missed by all.

FRIEDMAN--Alan J. The Board and staff of the Fund for the City of New York mourn the loss of Alan J. Friedman, friend, member of the Fund's Selection Panel for the Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching and long-time board member. Alan will be remembered as a passionate advocate for quality education and as a brilliant translator, making the wonders of sciences available to the public. Alan shared his talent generously with everyone, from young people in the Rockaways to officials in the West Wing. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Mickey. Vaughn Williams Chair of the Board Mary McCormick President

GERSHON--Howard, passed away peacefully at home in NYC on May 8, 2014 at the age of 89. Loving husband to the late Arline, devoted dad to Stacey and Andrea. Caring father-in-law to Bob, and proud and doting Popo to Alex, Sami and Josh. Successful businessman and a man of many interests and talents. A patriotic marine in WWII. We will miss him dearly.

BORTS--Professor George Herbert. Died on May 2nd in Providence, RI. He was a son of the late Elias Alexander and Etta (Silberg) Borts, husband of Muriel "Dolly" (Levenson) Borts, and brother of Lawrence (Beverly) Borts. He was the father of David (Lucia Fontes) Borts, Richard (Paulette York) Borts and Robert (Erin O'Cain) Borts. He was the grandfather of Alexander, Andrew and Liana Borts. Professor Borts was born in New York City on August 29, 1927, and educated at Columbia University. George Borts received his AM in 1949 and his PhD in 1953 from the University of Chicago, studying under Milton Friedman. Professor Borts spent 63 years at Brown University, where he joined the Department of Economics in 1950 at the age of 23. During his career, he served as chairman of the Department of Economics at Brown, as the managing editor of the American Economic Review and as a visiting professor/research fellow at Hokkaido University, London School of Economics and the National Bureau of Economic Research. Professor Borts was an expert in international finance and transportation. He testified frequently before US and Canadian regulatory commissions. During his long and distinguished career, he published numerous scholarly books, articles and monographs, as well as commentary for the Providence Journal. A tireless advocate for the free market, Professor Borts was also a dedicated educator and teacher. He advised both undergraduate and graduate students with equal dedication and led Brown's Phi Beta Kappa chapter for many years. Professor Borts served on many boards, including the Rhode Island School of Design, Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, Rhode Island Blue Shield, Junior Achievement of Rhode Island and Temple Beth-El. He also advised several political candidates on economic and tax policy. His funeral will be held on Monday, May 5th, at Sugarman-Sinai Memorial Chapel, 458 Hope St., Providence, RI at 1:30pm, with burial to follow. Shiva will be at the Borts residence, Barrington, from 5-8pm on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. For information and condolences, www.SugarmanSinai.com.

FORD--Richard Edwin. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain express our deepest sorrow at the death of our good friend and museum patron Richard Ford. Richard was a member of the Friends of the American Museum in Britain since 1984 and a trustee of the museum for more than 10 years. His generosity, dedication, and friendship will be deeply missed. Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman, Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman American Museum in Britain, Linda Hackett, President, Halcyon Foundation.

BOND--George C. The President, Trustees, faculty and entire community of Teachers College, Columbia University, mourn George Clement Bond, the College's William F. Russell Professor of Anthropology and Education, Director of the Center for African Studies and former Chair of the Department of International and Transcultural Studies. Professor Bond made immense contributions to his field, spending decades in Zambia and Uganda to bring forth the historical narratives of indigenous African peoples. He believed passionately that those who are colonized or otherwise subjugated must lay claim to their own stories in order to win political independence and freedom. Yet it was his quiet dignity and humor, presence as a consummate colleague and mentor, and persistent efforts during his 40 years as a TC faculty member to create a climate of fairness and human decency that make him truly irreplaceable. We offer our condolences to his wife, Alison; to their children, Matthew, Rebecca, Jonathan and Sarah; to their grandchildren, Evan, Daniel, Anna and Zachary; and to Professor Bond's sister, Jane Bond. Susan H. Fuhrman, President Thomas James, Provost/Dean

DOWNES--Leo, beloved partner, father and friend passed away peacefully in his sleep April 28, 2014. Services were held at Benta's Funeral Home Satuday, May 3, 2014. Leo is survived by his domestic partner Julie Siestreem, daughter Diana Greenidge, sons Erick Allen and Leo Downes Jr. His sister Oley Sullivan her husband Wali, his cousins John Walrund and Richard Ford, his nieces Miriam, Keziah, Mahadi, Honey and, Adrian, his nephew Hannibal. A memorial service will be held at a future date, contact Julie Siestreem/E james21956@aol.com

FINKEL--Seymour, Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the death of our long-time, devoted member, Seymour Finkel, beloved husband of Natalie Finkel. Our deepest condolences to their children, Stephen and Suzanne and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

CHELNIK--Martin, September 10, 1919 - May 6, 2014 of New York and Palm Beach. Formerly of Scarsdale. Born and raised in the Bronx, the son of Pauline and Charles Chelnik. A Dewitt Clinton graduate, decorated WWII veteran and Purple Heart recipient. Philanthropist and long time contributor to NYU Medical Center. Avid golfer and member of Brae Burn and The Falls. CEO and President of Chelnik Parking Company. Predeceased by devoted wife of 67 years, Harriette, and sister Mildred Goldman. Survived by sister Vera Roseman, children Roberta (Jerry) Roth, Peter and Marc Chelnik. Beloved "Phuffy"of Amy (Jim) Hall, Melissa Jurist and Charles Chelnik. Great-grandfather of five. Shiva Sunday May 11. Donations can be made to Wounded Warriors Project.

DEAN--Ambassador Jonathan, (retired), passed away on January 15, 2014. He joined the Foreign Service in 1949 after World War II, and devoted his life to promoting peace. His passion for peace fueled his work on nuclear weapons, missile defense, space weapons, terrorism, and preventing internal and interstate armed conflict. He loved his large family, especially his wife Theodora, his brother David, and also Vienna operetta, accordion playing, and rose growing. A celebration of his life will be held May 24, 2014, 10am at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, McLean, VA.

EVANS--Mary. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the passing of Mary Evans, the beloved wife of our Life Trustee James H. Evans. Our sympathies are with Mr. Evans and the entire family at this sad time. Frank A. Bennack Jr, Chair, Board of Trustees; Dr. Steven J. Corwin, CEO; Dr. Robert E. Kelly, President, NY-Presbyterian Hospital

CUMMINGS--Judith Ann, Born in Detroit, MI. She was the daughter of James E. Cummings, Sr. and Dorothy Cummings. Graduate of Cass Technical High School and Howard University, whose career in journalism at The New York Times saw her rise through the ranks of Reporter, Correspondent and Bureau Chief. Judith recently passed away at her home in Detroit at the age of 68. Judith was Pro-advancement of African American and Women's Causes. She was a lifetime member of NAACP and a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority. Judith sparkled with her enthusiasm and jovial sense of humor at all family gatherings...Oh, how she sparkled! Judith leaves to cherish her memory, James E. Cummings Jr., and many loving relatives and caring friends. Private services. Donations may be made to the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture Building Fund, P.O.BOX 96832, Washington, DC 20090.

DUKE--Anthony D. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the East Hampton Healthcare Foundation are deeply saddened by the loss of their long time Trustee Emeritus, Anthony D. Duke, who has worked tirelessly to improve healthcare in our community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Tony's entire family. He will be missed. Henry L. Murray, Chairman Gerard M. Turino, M.D., President East Hampton Healthcare Foundation

BARLAZ--Shirley, (nee Kaminetsky), died April 8, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, NY on October 27, 1922. Shirley graduated from New Utrecht High School and Brooklyn College. She is predeceased by her husband Joshua, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Rutgers University. She led a life of humility, devoting herself to raising a family and volunteer service. This began as a young woman with greeting Holocaust survivors arriving in New York Harbor and continued for decades with her service to United Jewish Appeal - Federation and Hadassah. She is survived by daughters Dora Barlaz Hanft (Noah) and Rachel Ann Kenigsberg (Joel) and sons Morton (Deirdre) and Eugene, nine grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Contributions can be made in her memory to Hadassah and Jewish Federation of Middlesex County, NJ.

AMSTERDAM--Elizabeth, on May 10, 2014 after a valiant struggle. Loving wife of the late Theodore A. Amsterdam. Devoted mother of Gail, Joan, and Doris. Grandmother of Rachel Bachmann-Estes and the late Mark Bachmann. Great-grandmother of Sydney Estes. Goodness like hers always lives. She practiced integrity, love of her family, strength, and always spoke her truth. Services Sunday, 9:45am, at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
Today on the Minute, voices from eastern Ukraine, where a vote for autonomy turned alternately celebratory and violent.
Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote.
The use of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese.
The country runs straight into a fork in the road.
A new look at the social organization of some eight-legged predators.
Gynecologists working in Africa suspect that women there are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of waterborne parasites. An ambitious research project aims to revolutionize treatment for young women.
What would the standings look like in a hypothetical league in which a goal does not count unless it is scored by an English player?
Three spunky grandmothers stole the show as bridesmaids in their granddaughters’ weddings.
Corrections appearing in print on May 11, 2014.
Television highlights.
LeBron James’s 16-point first quarter did not faze the Nets, who were most concerned with limiting his teammates. James had just 2 points in the second and 28 over all.
A 33-year-old man faces murder and weapons charges in the deaths of two men from Mount Vernon, N.Y., whose bodies were found in a car in the Bronx.

Cherished mother of Grace Goldstein, Ellen Zuckman, and Naomi Brooks; adored grandmother of Emily and Ariel, Rachel and Lucas, and Alison; great-grandmother of Marqel and Mariah. Graduate of Hunter High School, City College, and the College of New Rochelle. Active member of Temple Israel of New Rochelle; special education teacher; lover of reading, Scrabble, Jeopardy, and travel. Wonderful, funny, insightful friend to many. A graveside service occurred on May 7. Memorial donations may be made to Temple Israel of New Rochelle, http://www.tinr.org/, 914-235-1800, or a charity of your choice.
BREGMAN--Dorothy. May 12, 2013 On the one year anniversary of her death, those who knew and loved Dorothy have missed, and will continue to miss her each day. Abe

VAVALA--Larry J.,died at home in Parkland, Florida at age of 55 on May 10th from liver disease. Loving husband of Michelle and amazing dad to Samantha and Daniel. Devoted son and brother to Joseph and Bruce of Dewey Beach, DE. Adoring son-in law to Myrna and Norman Ricken of Boca Raton. Funeral services on Tuesday, May 13 at Temple Beth El of Boca Raton at 11am. He will be missed forever.

HOLLEY--Barbara C.,of New York City and Vero Beach, FL at home in Greenport, LI on May 9, 2014. Beloved wife of Robert E. Holley. Loving aunt of the late John Lawrence (Kathleen), Priscilla Honcannon (John), Patty Kirstead (John), Gerard Lawrence (Elaine) and Pamela Kiefer (Robert) and many great-nieces and nephews. Barbara also had great joy from her three dogs: Maxie, Mindy and Sami. Visiting on Monday from 7-9pm and Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the DeFriest-Grattan Funeral Home, 51400 Route 25, Southold, NY 11971. Funeral Mass on Wednesday 9:30am at St. Agnes R.C. Church, Greenport, NY. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Memorials to East End Hospice would be appreciated.

MEYER--Florence, beloved wife of the late Dr. Ernest Meyer, and the loving wonderful mother of Sharon, Jeff, Lynn, Amy and spouses Steven, Veronica, Gary and Robert. Proudest grandmother of all time of Michael, Alyssa, Alexandra, Zachary, Maxx, Corey, Emily, Hillary, Harrison and Elana. Director of The Herbert Tarr North Shore Institute For Adult Jewish Education, dedicated to the preservation of Jewish learning. One in a billion- loved by all. Forever in our hearts. Funeral: Monday, May 12, 2014 at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, 1pm.

POSES--Richard L. (May 13, 1922-May 8, 2014) Dearest love of wife, Phyllis (Smerling), of 67 years: Proud father of Peter, Jonathan and David; daughter-in-law, Linda; "Gramps" to Zoe and Hannah; and uncle to Rob, Alice, Laurance, Lisa, Matthew and families. Admired/beloved resident of Amsterdam At Harborside, Port Washington, NY B.A., Brooklyn College; attended New School For Social Research. Consummate professional in the textile industry. Far-ranging intellect, culturally inquiring mind and dog-lover. Services: 12 Noon, Monday, May 12, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck. Burial follows: Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. Donations may be sent in memory of R.L. Poses to The Arthritis Foundation - arthritis.org or "We Always Swing" a Jazz Series - wealwaysswing.org.
MEYER--Florence, You are a dear friend, Woman of Valor and a pillar of our Jewish Community. We will miss you. Martin and Rita Kroll

CEMBALEST--Anne M.,90, beloved sister, wife, mom, aunt, grandma, cousin, mentor, and friend, left us May 10. Born in Vienna and longtime resident of Hewlett with devoted husband Stanley, Anne was a gifted ceramic sculptor, showing her trompe l'oeil still lifes twice in Tiffany's windows. Relentless nurturer of creative spirits (and stray animals), she was chair of Sun 'N Fun and president of Five Towns Music and Arts Foundation. Survived by children Robin and Michael; adored grandchildren Max, William, and Peter; daughter-in-law Rachel; son-in-law Jerry, and many others whose lives she touched.

EVANS--Mary Johnston,of East Hampton and New York City, passed away on May 5, 2014. Beloved wife of James H. Evans (Retired Chairman, Union Pacific Corporation), Mary was born on February 28, 1930 in Shawnee, Oklahoma. She attended Wellesley College and the University of Oklahoma. Mrs. Evans was smart, witty and incredibly charming. She was one of the most successful women of her generation and inspired many young women to take leadership positions in their community and in business. She also had a lifelong love of the New York Yankees and the Oklahoma Sooners. Mrs. Evans's corporate career included serving on the Boards of AMTRAK (vice chair), Delta Air Lines, Household International, Saint-Gobain Corp., Sunoco, Inc., Baxter International, Inc., The Dun & Bradstreet Corp., Moody's Corp. and Scudder, Stevens & Clark. In her civic career, Mary Evans served on the Boards of Carnegie Hall, Major Gifts Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Brick Presbyterian Church in New York and St. Anthony Hospital, Presbyterian Medical Center, United Appeal and YWCA in Oklahoma. Honors included inclusion in "200 Top Corporate Women" in Business Week, member of the Conference Board, induction into the Oklahoma Hall of Fame, first woman to address the Judicial Conference of the Tenth US Circuit Court, President of the Junior League (Oklahoma City), Distinguished Service Award, University of Oklahoma, first woman to address the Economic Club of Oklahoma City, The Liberty Bell Law Day Award for outstanding contributions to the legal profession by a layman, and recipient of the Director's Choice Award of the National Women's Economic Alliance. She was a member of the Colony Club (NYC) and Maidstone Club (East Hampton). Mary is survived by her husband, Jim, her children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Denver, Paul Johnston Head (Jean), Oklahoma City, and Eric Talbot Head (Shelley Magness), Denver, her grandchildren, Paxton X. Head, Atlanta, and Talbott Glover, Houston, her brother, Paul Ross Johnston (Sally), Vail and her step-children, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard). Memorial service will be held at 3:00pm, Friday, May 16 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the NYC Chapter, Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 or the University of Colorado Alzheimer's Research Fund, 13001 East 17th Pl., MS-A065, Aurora, CO 80045.

MESSINGER--Michelle Levine, Too short a life. Too long to suffer. Rest in Peace, Michelle. To Helene, Stu, Adam, Mitch and Jillian, we offer our heartfelt sympathy for your loss. Adele, Howard and Family

FLEDER--Robert. You lived your life as a Lion and went out like a Lamb. Now there won't be anything new, not even the overhead! As your son I was so proud to have emulated you in so many ways. We will all miss you and our love for you will never die. Richard and Mindy, William, Mara and Rachel

MAISEL--Howard, We send our deepest love and sympathy to our dear friend Eve France on the loss of her husband and best friend Howard. May those wonderful memories of your fabulous travels, joint philanthropies and shared passion for theater, films, art, books and politics comfort you always. Love from your poker buddies.

FLEDER--Robert I.,died peacefully at age 92 on May 11th in Sarasota, FL, where he and his wife Helen resided at his death. He was born in Mt. Vernon, NY, the devoted son of Joseph and Adele Fleder and brother of the late Jules Fleder. He graduated A.B. Davis High School in Mt. Vernon, and Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, PA, where he was named to the Board of Trustees. A veteran of World War II, he flew 35 missions over Japan in a B29 bomber, and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, a Purple Heart and a Presidential Citation. During his many years in Harrison, NY, he was the President of the Board of Education, President of the Community Chest, honoree of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. He was the Westchester Senior's Golf Champion in 1979. He served two terms as President of Old Oaks Country Club. His love for Harrison, the New York Giants, Old Oaks and F&M was only exceeded by his dedication to his family. In particular, he loved "Babe" his wife, who remained at his side to the end of 68 years of a special marriage! Bob took great pride in his children John (Jan), Peggy (Bob) and Richard (Mindy) and his grandchildren, Joel, Sacha, William (Mara), Molly and Rachel. Bob Fleder will be missed by all the lives he favorably impacted.

SHERRILL--Betty. Resident of our beloved One Sutton Place South, died on May 12th, 2014. Betty lived here for almost half a century and for nearly half of that time served as President of the Board. We are indebted to her for her many years of leadership and passion for our building. She appreciated the beauty and history of our Rosario Candela building and its unique setting. Betty brought style and experience to enhance its beauty both inside and out. Our sincere condolences to her children, Ann Pyne and Stephen Sherrill, and her many beloved grandchildren. Lucy Lamphere, President on behalf of the Board of Sutton Place South Corp.

SHOFLER--Walter, of Valley Stream, Long Island, aged 97. Passed away May 10th, 2014. Husband of the late Anita Shapiro Shofler. Survived by his children, Dr. Raymond Shofler and Alison Smith, and spouses Barbara and David; five grandchildren, David, Jessica, Samuel, Joshua, and Alex; and two great-grandchildren, Everett, and Daphne. Walter earned his BA and LLB degrees from Columbia University. During World War II, he served as a captain in the signal corps in Europe, and upon his return, became an executive in the auto parts industry in New York and New Jersey. He was an avid skier, tennis player, and a dedicated supporter of the Democratic Club. He was a devoted family man, cherished for his good humor, humility, and kindness. He was beloved by all who knew him and will be dearly missed.

ROBERTS--Donald S.,87, passed away on April 8th. Born in Arlington, MA, Donald spent the majority of his life in his beloved adopted home, Manhattan. Donald worked in the showroom of F. Schumacher & Co. for over 50 years. His charm and wonderful wit will be missed by all. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, May 16th, at 6:00pm. For more info email: gothamdsr@gmail.com

Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10:30am at St. Thomas Moore R.C. Church, Breezy Point. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Maureen Catherine Tully Scholarship Fund, St. Francis College, 180 Remsen St., Brooklyn, NY 11201.

YOUNG--Virginia Knight, of New York and Westhampton Beach, born February 8, 1939 passed peacefully on May 4, 2014. She leaves behind her husband Thomas Young; her children Christian Robert Knight and Karin Elizabeth Knight; her stepchildren Lynn den Daas-Young, Cynthia Neydon and Thomas Young and ten grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held Saturday, June 14 at the family home at Westhampton Beach.

FEINGOLD--Sanford. We mourn the loss of Sandy Feingold, our friend and associate for many years. Our condolences go to his wife, Audrey and his daughters Carol and Susan; sons-in-law, Chuck and John, and grandchildren, Max, Allison and Lily. Sandy fought a courageous battle and we will all miss him. Howard J. Blatt, President, Rampart Agency, Inc.

GREEN--Seymour, Born in Brooklyn to Bennie and Sarah Green on November 23, 1923, he passed peacefully on May 12, 2014. Survived by his beloved wife Lillian, sons Jerry (Jody), Alex (Doreen) Stagnaro-Green and Barry (Jenny), grandchildren Seth, Corey, Danny, Laura, Jake, Ben and Evan. He leaves his sisters Yetta Zeiger and Clara London and was predeceased by his brother, Morris. We will always cherish his memory. Funeral: Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus Tuesday, May 13 at 1pm. Donations can be made in his memory to Cure Alzheimer's Fund (www.curealzfund.org). For Shiva information contact the funeral home.

MARSTON--Helga, 91, of Palm Beach, passed away on April 23rd, 2014. Helga was born in Romania to a Swedish mother and an Italian father. She moved to New York in 1962, where she would soon meet the love of her life, Hunter S. Marston Jr. They were married from 1966 until his passing in 2004. They generously supported The American Heart Association, Red Cross, Salvation Army, Cancer Society and the Norton Museum of Art. Together they lived in New York and Palm Beach. Helga loved traveling the world, and entertaining friends at their beautiful homes. She was the epitome of style, grace and elegance. She always wore her signature red lipstick and her hair was perfectly coiffed. To her younger friends, she was a bridge to a bygone age - the glamorous New York of the post-war years. Helga took great pleasure in dining out, which she did regularly until just days before her passing. Her closest friends miss her deeply and will fondly remember evenings by her side as she sipped champagne and regaled them with stories, always a feisty woman with cheeky sense of humor. A private celebration of Helga's life will be held in Palm Beach later this year.

WOLOVNICK--Arlene (nee Solomon), of Roslyn, NY, on May 11th, formerly of Ballen Isle, Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Old Westbury, NY. Much beloved wife and soul mate of Marvin Wolovnick (deceased), cherished mother of Jared Wolovnick (Julie) and Beth Alderman (Michael), sister of Dr. Sanford Solomon (Gail), devoted and loving Granny to Shana Teig Kantor (Rabbi Shalom Kantor), Benjamin Teig, Arielle Wolovnick Heller (Ben) and Diana Wolovnick and great-grandmother to Rena and Noam Kantor. Born in Brooklyn to David and Mildred Solomon raised in Neponsit/Belle Harbor and a former long-time member of Old Westbury Golf & Country Club, Arlene was a successful professional matchmaker and a bright, shining light who attracted everyone who knew her. She will be greatly missed.

WEISS--Gerald, May 12, 2014. Beloved husband of Pearl for 59 years; adoring father of David (Andrea), Daniel, and Jennifer (Larry Rosenfeld) and grandfather of Jake, Liam, Nora, and Julia. Born in Cologne, Germany on August 3, 1922, Jerry and his family escaped from Nazi Germany, arriving in NYC in December 1939. He graduated from Cooper Union with a degree in electrical engineering; was inducted as a member of Tau Beta Pi, the engineering honor society; volunteered for and served in the U.S. Army; and earned a doctorate from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Jerry was a professor of engineering for 33 years, teaching first at Polytechnic (until 1988), and then at Cooper Union (until 1992). He loved gardening, home repairs, numbers, his students, and especially his family. We've lost our walking encyclopedia of everything and the only person in our family who could wiggle his ears. His memory is our blessing. Services on May 14 at 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.

SHAPIRO--Fred. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend, Fred Shapiro, with whom we had the privilege of working for almost 20 years. Fred was a brilliant accountant and financial asset manager and an even finer human being. Gerstein Strauss & Rinaldi LLP

SHERRILL--Betty. The Women's Committee and Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy mourn the loss of our dear friend Betty Sherrill, a member of the Women's Committee Board since 1994. She served as Honorary Chairman of the Tree Trust and Co-Chairman of the Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, and was a great advocate for the Park's daffodil plantings. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Anne S. Harrison, President, Women's Committee Thomas L. Kempner, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees Douglas Blonsky, President & CEO, Central Park Conservancy
KARLIN--David. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

PANOFF--Aaron, beloved husband, father and grandfather. Born in Brooklyn, November 2, 1922 passed away peacefully in Florida on May 12th. He is survived by children Judy and Bill, granddaughter Rachel, and daughter and son-inlaw Audrey and Nick. He will be dearly missed.

KARLIN--Dr. David B.,85, passed away in New York City on May 10, 2014. He was a devoted husband to Adrienne Roaman, loving father to Linda (deceased) and Diane and adoring grandfather to Winston. He was a prominent board certified ophthalmic surgeon in private practice in New York City and dedicated clinical researcher for over 55 years. He was a tennis player and avid reader who loved history. As an active and longtime member of Temple Emanu-El, he served as an usher for 55 years and was a member and supporter of the Men's Club. He earned his A.B. from Columbia College in 1950 and his M.D. in 1954 from New York Medical College. There after he proudly served in the U.S. Navy. He was a Clinical Fellow at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary of the Harvard Medical School. He was awarded his M.Sc. (Ophth.) by the New York University School of Medicine in 1962. Dr. Karlin was awarded grants by the National Institute of Health, the National Eye Institute and the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. He collaborated with physicists at Bell Laboratory to develop the carbon dioxide laser and was awarded a patent in April of 1986. He was an Associate Clinical Professor Emeritus of Ophthalmology at the Weill Cornell Medical College and Associate Attending Ophthalmic Surgeon at the New York Hospital. He was Adjunct Professor of Ophthalmology at the New York University School of Medicine and Assistant Clinical Professor of Ophthalmology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He was also Attending Ophthalmic Surgeon and Chief of Retina Clinic II at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. Dr. Karlin was the lead author in over 40 articles, completed two books and has written chapters in many ophthalmology books. He presented his work at national and international conferences. The family will hold a reception at the Harmonie Club (4 E 60th St, New York, NY 10022) on Tuesday, May 13, 2014 from 4 to 7pm in honor of Dr. Karlin.

FEINGOLD--Sanford, died on May 11, 2014 in the comfort of his home, after a long illness, weeks before his 89th birthday. Sandy was born and raised in Midwood, Brooklyn. At 18, he enlisted in the U.S. Army, and served with the 96th division on Okinowa in the last battle of WWII. He returned to New York to earn his BS in Accounting from the NYU School of Commerce. At NYU, he met Audrey, the love of his life. They were married in 1949, and celebrated their 64th wedding anniversary last year. After working as a CPA, Sandy began a lengthy and exceptional career in the life insurance industry, working until his 87th birthday. When not working, Sandy was the quintessential New York sports fan, with a lifetime allegiance to the Giants, Knicks, Yankees and Rangers. Besides his expertise in business, Sandy will be remembered for his incredible generosity. His happiest moments were with family and close friends. He is survived by Audrey, daughters Susan and Carol, sons-in-law John and Chuck, and grandchildren, Max, Allison and Lily. A funeral will be held on Tuesday, May 13th, 12 noon, at Temple Sinai, 1 Engle St., Tenafly, NJ, with burial to follow. Shiva will be observed Tuesday through Thursday at their home in Fort Lee, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his memory to a favorite charity. For condolences, directions or information call (201)947-3336 or www.edenmemorial.com.

BELKIN--Abby Gail (Abby) (nee' Frosburg), beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Belkin, daughter of the late Goldie (Altfeld) and Jonas Frosburg, mother of the late Mathew Polesie, cherished sister of the Honorable Judge E. Milton Frosburg and Judy Frosburg of San Diego, California and the late Naomi Becker, Doris Myerberg, Solomon Frosburg and Alan Frosburg of Baltimore, Maryland, stepmother of Linda Belkin of Long Island, New York, and step-grandmother of Stephen Shuchhalter and Tamara Wagner of Long Island, New York and many loving nieces and nephews. Abby was a die-hard New Yorker coming to "The City" from Baltimore, Maryland when she was twenty years of age and started a long career in public relations, culminating in the achievement as an editor of the women's section of a Long Island newspaper. As such she championed women's causes and produced in the writing arena everything from political speeches for prominent figures to ghost writing for well known authors. As the wife of the Chancellor of Yeshiva University, she became fully involved with Jewish issues world wide and as a supporter of Yeshiva's position in the international Jewish community, she and her husband, Dr. Samuel Belkin engaged with prominent political leaders, scientists, and musicians. She was an accomplished cook whose home was always open to everyone and in which there was always a memorable dinner and conversation. Abby's wit, humor, determination, and love of life will be sorely missed by all whose lives she has touched. Funeral services will be held at 12:00pm at the Gutterman Musicant Jewish Funeral Home in Hackensack, New Jersey on 402 Park Street. Donations to Yeshiva University or the ASPCA are welcome.

BIRNBAUM--George. With deep sadness we announce the passing of our patriarch, George 85, of Manchester, NJ. An executive in the apparel industry and aficionado of musical theatre, he most valued family and friends and leaves behind his wife of 57 years, Florence, daughters Susan (Marc) and Aileen (Arlen), grandchildren Alec, Matthew, Ilana and Jordan, brother Seymour (Esther) and a legacy of kindness and goodwill. He will be greatly missed!

FLEDER--Robert. Our deepest condolences to our dear friend Richard, his mother Helen and the entire Fleder family on their loss. Bob was a friend and an example to all of us, and we will miss and remember him with affection and respect at Old Oaks and at all Fleder occasions. Love, Carol Chavkin, David Harris, Alice Knapp and the Breslaw, Chavkin, Goldwater, Kasner, Kay, Kelsey, Mannino, Savitsky and Tabak Families

ENGELHARDT--Roberta, (nee Messing) of Hastings-on-Hudson, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, died peacefully in her home on May 8th after a long illness. Roberta was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1929 to the late Morris Messing and Millie Feder, and was the step-daughter of Hannah Messing. A graduate of Barnard College, class of 1948, Roberta - known as Bobbie - worked as a model for the designer, Vera Maxwell, also later as a travel writer. She's predeceased by her husband, Kenneth Engelhardt, her sister, Vera Shapiro, many close in-laws and friends. She is survived by her three children, Peter Doyne, Nancy Doyne (Bill Teitler) and Elizabeth Doyne (Barry Sanderson). She was a wonderful grandmother to her many grandchildren. There will be a private service for family only on May 17th at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson.

FLEDER--Robert. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend, fellow member and two time former President of the Club, Mr. Robert Fleder. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Ben Kirschenbaum, President

BENNETT--Robert S.,Jr., 78, of Princeton, NJ, died on May 9, 2014 after a valiant four year battle against pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband and father, he is survived by his wife of 49 years, Bobbie G. Bennett, and his daughter, Laura Bennett. Born and raised in Bethlehem, PA, he was pre-deceased by his parents, Alene Grace and Robert S. Bennett. He is also survived by his aunt, Dodie Massey Henry, and his two sisters, Deborah Moore and Cynthia Squire, in addition to many cousins, nephews, and nieces. Bob graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1954 and earned a B.A. in Architecture from Princeton University in 1958. After completing O.C.S. in Newport, RI, he served for four years as an ensign in the Navy's Civil Engineer Corps. Following work in New York for Clark and Rapuano, a large city planning and landscape architecture firm, as well as time spent in commercial real estate development with the Uris Corporation, he opened his own residential architecture firm in Pennington, NJ in 1975. His houses and gardens can be seen in the Northeast and Florida. His passion for what he did was infectious; his houses, rooted in the Classical tradition, a lasting testament to that passion. He leaves a legacy of hard work, loyalty, stimulating conversation and love of family, fun, and country. Ever humble and an optimist, he will be greatly missed. A funeral service will be held at The Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville on May 16 at 11am. For those who wish, contributions may be made to Deerfield Academy, the Princeton Area Community Foundation, or The Pancreas Center, Columbia University, in honor of Dr. Stephen Schreibman. Services are being handled by Mather-Hodge Funeral Home.
FLEDER--Robert. In memory of a loving father, grandfather, avid Giants and Diplomats fan! Condolences to Helen, Richard, Mindy and the Fleder Family. Lisa Charon & Andy Klauber

GORE--Michael, on May 10, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY, age 67. Formerly assistant district attorney in Brooklyn. He was a Diamond Life Master bridge player who participated in many tournaments. He also participated in the Fantasy Baseball Leagues. He is survived by his mother Tinnie and brother Arnold, sister-in-law Susan Epstein, nephew Lazar Treschan, grandniece Celia, brother-in-law Stewart Goodman, nieces Amy Goodman Moringiello, Jenni Goodman Arielly, aunt Lillian Hughes, and cousins Susan Hillman and Sondra Palenbaum. Funeral Thursday May 15, 2014, 10am, "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ADLER--Sol. The 92Y community is deeply saddened by the loss of 92Y's former longtime Executive Director, Sol Adler. Sol was tremendously dedicated to 92Y and our community and he served as an inspiration to many. We are grateful for all of his accomplishments and his love of our institution. Our hearts go out to Sol's wife Debbie, his three sons, Ronnie, Louis and Matthew, and the entire Adler family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The 92nd Street Y

ADLER--Sol, was a good man who dedicated his professional life to helping others. He was a leader, a doer and a man of significant accomplishment. As the Executive Director of the 92nd Street Y, Sol was indefatigable in pursuit of excellence. Indeed, under his stewardship the Y became world renowned for its first-rate array of programs, services and contributions to the City of New York. Sol was a good friend who always wore a smile and was always available to those in need. He cared and he tried to make a difference. May his good works, many good deeds and lifelong commitment to service be a comforting memory and blessing to those who cared and loved him. Suri and Bruce

CARLTON--Richard, died peacefully at home on May 10, 2014. He was the beloved husband of Blossom, father of Joyce, Ralph, Ken and Karen, and grandfather of Mark, Sara, Annie, Jane, Ben, Matthew, Harry and Emma. He was predeceased by his sister, Florence Morris. Born on February 9, 1919 in Manhattan, he attended Townsend Harris High School, graduating at the age of 16. His first job was at Columbia Pictures, after which he served honorably in World War II. After the war, he had a long and distinguished career in film and television. Among the many highlights, he brought such cartoon hits as Felix the Cat and Speed Racer to American audiences as executive vice president of Trans Lux Television. He was later deputy director of the American Film Institute and, finally, executive director of the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, where he led the production of the International Emmy Awards. Although he retired from his business career at 75, he lived every day purposefully, engaged in more things than he had time to do, including traveling, visiting family, writing, and playing tennis competitively until he hung up his racket at 90. Determined to stay current with technology, he created a blog offering his unique viewpoints on life to a large and loyal following which he maintained until shortly before his passing at the age of 95. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 15 at 10am at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorials in his name may be made to the RLS Foundation at rls.org.

GLIMCHER--Melvin J.,MD. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Melvin J. Glimcher, MD, who made extraordinary contributions to the Hospital. Dr. Glimcher served on our Board of Trustees from 2001 to 2009. In 2009 he became a member of the Board of Advisors and served on the Research Committee for many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Kendrick R. Wilson III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Thomas P. Sculco, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO, Hospital for Special Surgery.

LEVIN--Gabrielle Rochelle, 78, of Manhattan, died May 11, 2014. Born August 14, 1935 in Magdeburg, Germany to Kurt and Edith Aronsohn, she grew up in Lancaster, PA and Miami Beach, FL. An alumna of the Charles E. Ellis School of Newton Square, PA, she attended the University of Miami at Coral Gables and the Dante Alighiere University in Rome. Always creatively artistic, she became an accomplished potter late in life. Former spouse of the late writer Ira Levin, she is survived by three sons, Adam Levin-Delson of Bothell WA, Jared Levin of Hastings-on-Hudson and Nicholas Levin of Manhattan, and four grandsons. Memorial service will be held at 1pm on Thursday, May 15, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to the ASPCA.

YOUNG--Virginia Knight, of New York and Westhampton Beach, born February 8, 1939 passed peacefully on May 4, 2014. She leaves behind her husband Thomas Young; her children Christian Robert Knight and Karin Elizabeth Knight; her stepchildren Lynn den Daas-Young, Cynthia Neydon and Thomas Young and ten grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held Saturday, June 14 at the family home at Westhampton Beach.

GLIMCHER--Melvin. Weill Cornell Medical College mourns the passing of Dr. Melvin Glimcher, father of Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, the Stephen and Suzanne Weiss Dean of Weill Cornell. An esteemed physician and surgeon, Dr. Glimcher was a professor emeritus at Harvard Medical School and a former chief of orthopedic surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital and Children's Hospital. We offer our deepest condolences to Dean Glimcher and the entire Glimcher family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman, Weill Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers

HIRSCHLAG--Harold W. Our dear father, Harold W. Hirschlag passed away on Wednesday May 7th, just after his 98th birthday. He served his country as a soldier, he was a devoted husband, and a wonderful Dad. He was a partner at the accounting firm of Milton Rindler and Company, where he worked as a CPA for almost 60 years. He was also a tennis player, a sailor, an artist in wood sculpting and stained glass; and a craftsman par excellence. He designed and crafted (amongst many projects) a beautiful classical guitar and he built a precise grandfather clock completely out of wood, cutting each gear by hand - and it ran perfectly! While he was not a talker, he had a strong voice when it came to social injustice. He and his wife Gertrude openly demonstrated their convictions during the civil rights movement of the 1960s, and in the 1970s their group the Fair Lawn Committee for Peace in Vietnam organized efforts to end that war. They were even out on the picket line in their 90s to protest United States intervention in Iraq. He shared 69 years with our Mom, the love of his life. Our Dad could do anything. We love him dearly. Laura and Richard

SHERRILL--Betty. It is with great sadness that The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering notes the death of their long-standing devoted Board member, Mrs. H. Virgil (Betty) Sherrill. Mrs. Sherrill first joined The Society of MSK in 1956 and most recently served as a member of its President's Council. The Society extends its condolences to her entire family, with particular sympathies to her son, Stephen, daughter-in-law, Kitty, and granddaughter, Elizabeth Pyne, who are dedicated members of The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering. Martha Vietor Glass, President The Society of MSK
FISCHLER--Shirley. Wife of Stan. Mother of Ben and Simon. Grandmother of Ezra, Odel, Ariel, Niko and Avigal.

GROMER--Frank, of New Canaan, CT, died on May 10, 2014. A distinguished advertising executive, he worked for Foote, Cone & Belding for 40 years. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Carol and son, Mark. He is survived by his children Ellen, Paul, Jeanne, their spouses and nine grandchildren. Visitation at Hoyt Funeral Home, New Canaan, CT, May 15 from 4-8pm. Funeral Mass 10am, May 16 at St Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT.

LeFRAK--Ethel Stone. February 1, 1920 - May 14, 2013. With a loving spirit and a gentle heart. Her mission was always to do good. We always knew how much we loved you. We didn't realize how much we would miss you. You are always in our hearts and thoughts. Denise and family

CORREA--Dr. Mary Elizabeth Correa, born October 29, 1946 in New York City, died Friday, May 9, 2014 of complications from Alzheimer's disease. She was the daughter of the late Mathias F. Correa and the late Louise Kennedy Correa. She is survived by her loving sisters Anne Correa and Louise Newland, brother-in-law Eric Newland, nieces Abigail Aglubat and Chloe Newland. Mary graduated from Convent of the Sacred Heart and went on to Boston College where she graduated Cum Laude from the School of Nursing. She also received a Masters degree in Clinical Psychiatry from Yale University. She then worked as head nurse at Yale-New Haven Psychiatric Hospital. Mary also was a professor at the University of Cincinnati and consulted for global corporations, as well as leading a project for the State of Illinois. She then completed her PhD in Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management at Purdue University. After completing her PhD, she became a professor of business at Skidmore College where, among her other accomplishments, she was instrumental in launching the International Affairs Program. However, Mary's prime focus, first and foremost, was her undergraduate students, to whom she devoted enormous amounts of time and attention. She was fully committed to their success and took great pride in their accomplishments. Mary was a Board Member and later a Fellow of the AK Rice Institute. She also served on the Board of Directors of the Organizational Behavior Teaching Society and served as a consultant with Edge Associates of Pittsburgh, focusing on productivity enhancement, organizational design, conflict resolution and career development. She joined the Board of Directors of Saratoga Bridges in 1998 and became president in 2002. Mary became highly involved with the NYSARC where she served on the Board of Governors, chairing their Ethics Committee. Mary was an avid athlete and loved ice dancing, tennis, skiing and hiking. On Friday, May 16th, a Mass will be said at St. Joseph's Church, 95 Plum Brook Road, Somers, NY at 11:30am followed by a reception at the home of Eric and Louise Newland in Katonah. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Mary to the Alzheimer's Association at www.alz.org. As kind as she was brilliant, Mary will be missed by all.

GORE--Michael, on May 10, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY, age 67. Formerly deputy district attorney in Brooklyn. He was a Diamond Life Master bridge player who participated in many tournaments. He also participated in the Fantasy Baseball Leagues. He is survived by his mother Tinnie and brother Arnold, sister-in-law Susan Epstein, nephew Lazar Treschan, grandniece Celia, brother-in-law Stewart Goodman, nieces Amy Goodman Moringiello, Jenni Goodman Arielly, aunt Lillian Hughes, and cousins Susan Hillman and Sondra Palenbaum. Funeral Thursday May 15, 2014, 10am, "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ENGELHARDT--Roberta, (nee Messing) of Hastings-on-Hudson, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, died peacefully in her home on May 8th after a long illness. Roberta was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1929 to the late Morris Messing and Millie Feder, and was the step-daughter of Hannah Messing. A graduate of Barnard College, class of 1948, Roberta - known as Bobbie - worked as a model for the designer, Vera Maxwell, also later as a travel writer. She's predeceased by her husband, Kenneth Engelhardt, her sister, Vera Shapiro, many close in-laws and friends. She is survived by her three children, Peter Doyne, Nancy Doyne (Bill Teitler) and Elizabeth Doyne (Barry Sanderson). She was a wonderful grandmother to her many grandchildren. There will be a private service for family only on May 17th at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson.

MARGOLIS--Marjorie, passed away on May 10, 2014, at age 90. An artist, herself, she established the first art gallery in Boca Raton, Florida and remained a leading gallerist in the area for 37 years exhibiting such international artists as Jules Olitsky, Robert Rauschenberg, Roy Lichtenstein, Joan Mitchell, Hans Hoffman, Philip Pearlstein, Richard Pousette-Dart as well as many young developing artists from Florida. A past president of the Boca Raton Museum of Art she was a daughter of Pearl and Morris Brown, a founder of the Palm Beach Country Club, predeceased by her husband of 47 years, Ely, and son John, she is survived by John's wife Lucy, son Robert and his wife Karen, daughter Kim and her loving companion Stephen Corr, her sister Roberta Franklin, four grandchildren Jennifer, her husband Andy Marquez, Mark, his wife Morgan, David, his wife Diana, and Marjorie, two great-grandchildren Lillian and John. A loving, caring center of their lives she will be sorely missed by her entire beautiful family and her devoted friend William Beaty as well as a host of friends and relatives in Florida, New York and the art world everywhere.

SHERRILL--Betty. The Women's Board and Trustees of The Boys' Club of New York mourn the passing of Betty Sherrill, a dear friend who served as a member of the Women's Board and later its Honorary Board since 1968. Betty and her beloved husband Virgil, a BCNY Trustee, were honored by the Women's Board at its 2008 Spring Dance for their unparalleled service to the Boys' Club. Betty's granddaughter Elizabeth Pyne has followed in her footsteps, joining the Women's Board last year. We are grateful for Betty's longstanding commitment to the boys we serve and her dedication to their welfare. She will be greatly missed. Amy Griffin, President of The Women's Board, Edward Rappa, President of the Board of Trustees, Stephen Tosh, Executive Director

WEISS--Gerald, May 12, 2014. Beloved husband of Pearl for 59 years; adoring father of David (Andrea), Daniel, and Jennifer (Larry Rosenfeld) and grandfather of Jake, Liam, Nora, and Julia. Born in Cologne, Germany on August 3, 1922, Jerry and his family escaped from Nazi Germany, arriving in NYC in December 1939. He graduated from Cooper Union with a degree in electrical engineering; was inducted as a member of Tau Beta Pi, the engineering honor society; volunteered for and served in the U.S. Army; and earned a doctorate from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Jerry was a professor of engineering for 33 years, teaching first at Polytechnic (until 1988), and then at Cooper Union (until 1992). He loved gardening, home repairs, numbers, his students, and especially his family. We've lost our walking encyclopedia of everything and the only person in our family who could wiggle his ears. His memory is our blessing. Services on May 14 at 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.

BENNETT--Robert S.,Jr., 78, of Princeton, NJ, died on May 9, 2014 after a valiant four year battle against pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband and father, he is survived by his wife of 49 years, Bobbie G. Bennett, and his daughter, Laura Bennett. Born and raised in Bethlehem, PA, he was pre-deceased by his parents, Alene Grace and Robert S. Bennett. He is also survived by his aunt, Dodie Massey Henry, and his two sisters, Deborah Moore and Cynthia Squire, in addition to many cousins, nephews, and nieces. Bob graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1954 and earned a B.A. in Architecture from Princeton University in 1958. After completing O.C.S. in Newport, RI, he served for four years as an ensign in the Navy's Civil Engineer Corps. Following work in New York for Clark and Rapuano, a large city planning and landscape architecture firm, as well as time spent in commercial real estate development with the Uris Corporation, he opened his own residential architecture firm in Pennington, NJ in 1975. His houses and gardens can be seen in the Northeast and Florida. His passion for what he did was infectious; his houses, rooted in the Classical tradition, a lasting testament to that passion. He leaves a legacy of hard work, loyalty, stimulating conversation and love of family, fun, and country. Ever humble and an optimist, he will be greatly missed. A funeral service will be held at The Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville on May 16 at 11am. For those who wish, contributions may be made to Deerfield Academy, the Princeton Area Community Foundation, or The Pancreas Center, Columbia University, in honor of Dr. Stephen Schreibman. Services are being handled by Mather-Hodge Funeral Home.

BROWN--Louis E.,of Glen Head, NY on May 12, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Eileen P. Loving father of Edward (Tricia), Alicia Doodian (Robert), Marguerite Toohey (Thomas) and Louis. Cherished grandfather of Sarah, Patrick, Thomas, Grace, Matthew, Henry, Liam, Emma, Anna and William. Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Whitting Funeral Home 300, Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY 11545 www.whitting.com Funeral Mass Monday 10am at St. Mary's R. C. Church, Roslyn, NY. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions may be made to Operation Wounded Warrior.

MARDEN--Jonathan Corey. The partners and staff of Ganfer & Shore, LLP mourn the passing of our friend and colleague. Our warmest thoughts to Jonathan's family, and especially to his wife Stephanie and his daughter Zoe.

SHAPIRO--Fred. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend, Fred Shapiro, with whom we had the privilege of working for almost 20 years. Fred was a brilliant accountant and financial asset manager and an even finer human being. Gerstein Strauss & Rinaldi LLP

GOTTLIEB--Claire, age 86, died peacefully at her home in TriBeCa surrounded by her loving family. Predeceased by Henry, her husband of 52 years and son Roger. She is a Graduate of Syracuse University. Claire was a well loved Kindergarten teacher in the Freeport School system for many years. She was the most wonderful wife, mother, nana, aunt, and sister in the universe. Survived by her sister Renee Kosminsky, daughters Wendy Gottlieb and Hildy Gottlieb Hill (Walter), grandchildren Jennifer (Steve), Ian, Alissa, Jesse, Jo, and Miranda, great-grandchildren Jett and Owen. Donations may be made to MJHS Hospice: www.mjhshospice.org will be appreciated.

GREEN--Seymour, Born in Brooklyn to Bennie and Sarah Green on November 23, 1923, he passed peacefully on May 12, 2014. Survived by his beloved wife Lillian, sons Jerry (Jody), Alex (Doreen) Stagnaro-Green and Barry (Jenny), grandchildren Seth, Corey, Danny, Laura, Jake, Ben and Evan. He leaves his sisters Yetta Zeiger and Clara London and was predeceased by his brother, Morris. We will always cherish his memory. Funeral: Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus Tuesday, May 13 at 1pm. Donations can be made in his memory to Cure Alzheimer's Fund (www.curealzfund.org). For Shiva information contact the funeral home.

TIERSTEN--Irene Ann (nee Edelson), 73, of Maplewood, NJ, died on May 12, 2014, after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. She was a loving wife and mother as well as an author of numerous published novels and plays. She is survived by her husband, Dr. David Tiersten, her brother Michael Edelson, her children Beth Tractenberg and Joel Tractenberg, her stepsons Michael, William and Jonathan Tiersten, and her five grandchildren, Rachel, Ben, Zach, Alex and James. Services will be held at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ on Wednesday May 14 at 1:00pm.

SOLL--Clifford E. The Hunter College community is saddened by the loss of our longtime colleague, Clifford E. Soll, who died at his home in Yonkers, NY, on April 7, 2014. Since 1999, Cliff was the director of the Mass Spectrometry Facility at Hunter College, where he provided services not only to the members of Hunter College but also to all City University of New York (CUNY) campuses, Weill Cornell Medical School and Rockefeller University. Outgoing, energetic and devoted to Hunter, Cliff regularly went well beyond his job duties to provide help in various ways, from repairing air compressors to closing software licensing deals. Outside of work, his wide-ranging interests included cooking and being a crew member of Sal DiPaolo Racing, a drag racing team based in Yonkers. In addition, Cliff, who held a Ph. D. in organic chemistry, enjoyed talking to people from children to adults about science, which he loved. He is survived by his mother Edith Soll. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her.
DUDGEON--Martina. Your elegance, charm and laughter were a gift to all who knew you. Joan and Marty Deutsch
SHERRILL--Betty, Dear Aunt Betty, We will never forget the happy memories that we shared with you. We will carry you in our hearts. With all of our love, Lucas, James and Alastair
