PATTERSON--Anne Hyde Choate, Died peacefully in her home in Hobe Sound, FL, on May 11, 2014, at the age of 95. Born in New York to Arthur Osgood Choate and Anne Hyde Clarke Choate, she attended St. Timothy's School and Columbia University. She and her husband of 64 years, Ellmore Clark Patterson, who died in 2004, lived in Westchester County, New York City, Fisher's Island, NY, and Hobe Sound, and raised five sons, Michael, Arthur, Robert, David and Thomas Patterson, who survive her along with their wives and fourteen grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren, of all of whom she was immensely proud. She will be remembered by her loving family and all who knew her as athletic, spunky, interested and smart, with a quick and challenging mind. Her family asks that you consider a contribution in her memory to Island Health Project, Fisher's Island, Inc., PO Box 344, Fisher's Island, NY 06390.
SCHWARTZ--Ellen. Gone one year, but with us every day. Michael, Liza, Alyson & Joseph

HERMAN--Morton, autodidact, businessman, and old-school newsman and photographer who in the fifties, sixties, and early seventies wrote and took pictures for the Daily Mirror, the New York Journal American, and the New York Knickerbocker, among other publications, died on May 14, 2014 in New York City after a long illness. Born in the Bronx in 1930, Morty Herman grew up in the Bronx and in Brooklyn. His beloved maternal grandfather, Josef Klapholz, who lived with the family, was a tailor; his father, Al Herman, owned a hardware store in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. It was in Brighton Beach, at seventeen, that Morty met the great love of his life, fourteen-year-old Sheila Weiss. Famous for his enthusiasms -- friendship, travel, good food, a good story, a good book, and the songs of Al Jolson; print, radio, and television journalism; and (perhaps most of all) a good conversation -- as well for as his restless determination to keep busy, right up to the end, Mort Herman in the seventies and eighties owned a pension-consulting business; in the nineties, he took up the management of a commercial real estate company, a business he would run skillfully, energetically, and with great pleasure until the time of his death. He was also well known for his abundant generosity and the genuine interest he took in others and their interests and goals. He was a tireless supporter of his children's and grandchildren's enthusiasms, talents, educations, and careers, and a mentor and friend to many. He made and kept new friends effortlessly and constantly, and even in his final weeks he was offering advice and telling stories to an army of young people -- aspiring dancers, actors, comedy writers, journalists -- who came to sit with him in the hospital. He is survived by his lifelong love, his wife of sixty-two years, Sheila Herman; his daughter, Michelle Herman, and her husband, Glen Holland; his son, Scott Herman, and his wife, Beth Amey Herman; his granddaughters Grace Herman-Holland and Jamie Lynn Lescher; his grandsons Sean Herman and Greg Herman; two grandchildren-in-law, TJ Lescher and Naomi Herman; two great-grandchildren, Kai Lescher and Skylar Herman; and two brothers, Barry Herman and Mark Herman, and their families. The funeral will be held on Tuesday, May 20, 2014 at 11:30am at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, NJ 07088 (908-964-1500). A memorial service in Manhattan is being planned for July 8. The family asks that you make donations to the Sisters of Mercy Mid-Atlantic Community, 150 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, NY, 10530 or Temple Sinai, 208 Summit Avenue Summit, NJ 07901.

Polley, President and Chief Executive Officer.

LEVIN--Gabrielle Rochelle, 78, of Manhattan, died May 11, 2014. Born August 14, 1935 in Magdeburg, Germany to Kurt and Edith Aronsohn, she grew up in Lancaster, PA and Miami Beach, FL. An alumna of the Charles E. Ellis School of Newton Square, PA, she attended the University of Miami at Coral Gables and the Dante Alighiere University in Rome. Always creatively artistic, she became an accomplished potter late in life. Former spouse of the late writer Ira Levin, she is survived by three sons, Adam Levin-Delson of Bothell WA, Jared Levin of Hastings-on-Hudson and Nicholas Levin of Manhattan, and four grandsons. Memorial service will be held at 1pm on Thursday, May 15, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to the ASPCA.

FOFFE--Maria Catherine. January 24, 1948 - May 10, 2014. Beloved mother of Victoria Foffe-Jameson and loving wife of Dr. Kenneth Jameson, passed away peacefully in her sleep early Saturday morning following a long and courageous battle against neuroendocrine carcinoma. Maria was a life-long Brooklynite, and grew up in her parent's famous Foffe Restaurant where US Presidents dined with Brooklyn's power brokers. A woman of many accomplishments, she was a successful executive vice president of human resources at Merrill Lynch and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and in later years, a consultant, properties manager and legal advisor. Maria earned a BA at Boston University, an MS at Columbia Teacher's College, an MBA at Fordham University and a JD at New York Law School. Maria's humanity and love of both children and civic engagement touched many lives through her considerable volunteer work. She was the first president of the Brooklyn Chapter of the Families with Children from China, the president of the Montague Street BID and a board member of the Dodge YMCA. The family invites all who knew Maria to gather this Saturday, May 17th between 2-4pm at Guido Funeral Home, 550 Clinton Street, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Maria Foffe Fund at Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston Street, NY, NY 10014 or www.gildasclubnyc.org. Gilda's Club NYC and the members of her support team gave Maria immeasurable encouragement and joy.
FISCHLER--Shirley. Wife of Stan. Mother of Ben and Simon. Grandmother of Ezra, Odel, Ariel, Niko and Avigal.

MASTRUZZI--Robert R.,a long time resident of Mamaroneck, entered into eternal rest on May 13, 2014. Bob was born on July 25, 1927 in the Bronx. He was the youngest child of Concetta and Joseph Mastruzzi. Bob began his career as a physical education teacher in the New York City Board of Education. He rose to the position of Superintendent of Manhattan High Schools and subsequently to a five borough Superintendent for Special Education and School Improvement. He retired from his position in 1992 after serving 43 years in public education. Throughout his career, Bob received many honors and accolades and was highly respected by colleagues in his profession. Bob found his greatest pleasure in spending time with his family. He is survived by his loving wife, Corinne, of 62 years, his devoted daughter, Linda Oliverio (Salvatore), and his beloved grandchildren, Kristin, Robbie, Matt, and Ali, who were his pride and joy. Visitation will be Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. A Funeral Mass will be held Friday at 10am at Saint Vito's Church in Mamaroneck, NY. Interment will follow at Saint Mary's Cemetery in Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Diabetes Association or to the American Cancer Society.

LICKDYKE--Jay Cary. December 10, 1931 - May 10, 2014. Born New York City to Helen Carey and John J. Lickdyke. Certified Seaman in Merchant Marines, 1946-1959. Worked on Oil Tankers. Graduate St. Bonaventure University 1958. City Desk and Religion Department George Murphy New York Times 58-59. Junior partner Clark Dodge & Co. 1961, broker/ Vice President at Kidder Peabody & Co., Vice President Gruntal & Co., Ingalls & Snyder. Sergeant and MP at US Army Arlington Hall, VA 1952-55. Wounded in Korea. Artist, carpenter, reader and great family man. Survived by wife Priscilla Cunningham, daughter Sarah Morissette (Garry), sisters Helene Lickdyke and Suzanne Varney. Brother Brian LickDyke, four grandchildren, one stepson, six nephews, devoted cousins and caregivers Anita Cadogan, Shirley Bannister and Myrna Glenn. Memorial Services at later date.

Survived by her daughter Rhona and son Theo, and two grandchildren Natasha and Sam and daughter-in-law Lisa, to whom she was totally devoted. KISCH--Gloria, A talented sister, full of life and energy with a big laugh who loved her family and created beautiful artworks. To our dear brother Leonard, niece Rhona (Daniel), Nephew Theo (Lisa) and Natasha and Sam, we send our our heartfelt condolences. Jean and Armand Lindenbaum and Family

HOROWITZ--Fred. The Yeshiva University family is saddened to learn of the passing of our long time supporter, Fred Horowitz, in Israel. POLAK--Catharina "Ina" Soep, 91, of Eastchester, NY, passed away peacefully on May 14, 2014. Devoted wife of Jack for 68 years. Loving mother of Fred (Carrie), Tony (Amy), and Margrit (Harvey), grandmother to Josh (Sarah), Ann (Jordan), Jamie (Abbie), Emily and Sofi, great-grandmother of seven. Born in Amsterdam, The Netherlands on January 3, 1923 to Abraham and Toni. Holocaust survivor of transit camp Westerbork, where she met her beloved husband Jack, and concentration camp Bergen Belsen. Their love story is memorialized in the book and award winning documentary "Steal a Pencil For Me." Avid New York Times reader, theatre and movie goer, Ina led a vibrant and fulfilling life till the end. She will be remembered for her extraordinary beauty and her loving spirit. She called her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren "her best revenge against The Holocaust." Services today at Congregation Shaarei Tikvah in Scarsdale at 11:30am. Donations should be made to Anne Frank Center USA.

STUART--Robert D.,Jr. Robert D. Stuart, Jr. former Ambassador to Norway, long time chief executive of the Quaker Oats Company, and a leader in civic and business affairs for more than 60 years, died on May 8, 2014 en route from France to the United States with his beloved wife Lillan. He was 98. Whether business, politics, or philanthropy, Ambassador Stuart's consistent ambition was to live up to the title of his privately published memoirs: Making a Difference. By all accounts, he did. As a young law student at Yale in 1940, Stuart joined with a group of classmates, including Gerald Ford, Potter Stewart and Kingman Brewster--a future U.S. President, Supreme Court Justice and Yale College president--to found the America First Committee, a grass roots organization dedicated to keeping America out of the developing European conflict. At its peak, America First had as many as 800,000 members. After his discharge from the Army in 1946 with the rank of Major, he returned to law school at Yale. Upon graduation, he joined the Quaker Oats Company, co-founded by his grandfather Robert Stuart and led at the time by his father R. Douglas Stuart and uncle John Stuart. He spent 38 years at Quaker, the last 15 as chief executive, and during his tenure pushed to diversify the company and to expand its international presence. Two themes animated his leadership: a belief in the power of strong brands and the certainty that corporations like Quaker had a duty both to their shareholders and to the communities in which they lived and operated. From the time he became president in 1962 to his stepping down in 1984 to join the diplomatic corps, sales grew from $365 million to more than $3 billion. As Ronald Regan's ambassador to Norway from 1984 to 1989, Amb. Stuart followed in the tradition of his father, who was the American ambassador to Canada in the mid-1950s. The younger Stuart served in the waning years of the Cold War, when Norway's location north of the Barents Sea and its proximity to the former Soviet Union was of great strategic relevance both to the United States and to NATO. He fell in love with Norway, as did his wife Barbara. The feeling was apparently mutual, as the Norwegian press termed Ambassador Stuart "en flink gutt"--a good guy. Upon his return from Norway, he was nominated for the Defense Base Case Closure and Realignment Commission by President George H.W. Bush in 1991 and then President Bill Clinton in 1993. Robert D. Stuart, Jr. was born in 1916 in Hubbard Woods, Illinois and grew up in Lake Forest. He graduated from the Los Alamos Ranch School in New Mexico and then Princeton University in 1937, where he earned a degree in politics. In 1938, he married the former Barbara Edwards from Syracuse, NY. They had five children, three of whom survive him. His wife died in 1993, and two years later, he married Lillan Lovenskiold, a Norwegian whom he had met during his time as ambassador, who along with her late husband, had been close friends. She was the second great love of his life. For many years, he was a trustee of Princeton University. He also served as a director of United Airlines, the Burlington Northern Railroad, the First National Bank of Chicago Deere and Company, and Molson Companies, Ltd. of Canada. A life long Republican, he served as National Committeeman from Illinois and Finance Chair in Illinois for the Reagan campaign, among many assignments. In 1962, he founded the Lake County Republican Federation, reflecting his long-standing belief in the importance of local politics. As his political and business interests wound down, Amb. Stuart focused on philanthropy, founding a family foundation that supported civic education, campaign finance reform and national security. Ambassador Stuart was pre-deceased in death by sons Huntingdon Douglas Stuart and R. Douglas Stuart III. He is survived by his wife Lillan, sister Margaret, his son James M. Stuart and wife Dianne, daughter Marian S. Pillsbury, son Alexander D. Stuart and wife Robin, daughter-in-law Nancy M. Stuart, eight grandchildren--Pamela Stuart, Donaldson Pillsbury, Jr., Blair Pillsbury Enders, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, Christopher Stuart, Ann Robinson Stuart, and Robert Douglas Stuart IV--as well as six great-grandchildren: Clark and Annika Pillsbury, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Tyler and Sam Eichmann. Ambassador Stuart also had numerous Norwegian step-children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He adored them all, on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. And they adored him. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on Saturday, May 17th at the First Presbyterian Church of Lake Forest. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gorton Community Center in Lake Forest or Princeton University.
PARTINGTON--Jeanne Brideson. On May 11, 2014, age 91. Former violin prodigy who performed at the old Roxy Theatre. Wife of her beloved late husband Jack.

SHERRILL--Betty. The family of Betty Stevens Sherrill mourns the loss of our beloved mother, grandmother, and aunt. She died at One Sutton Place South, surrounded by her family, as the sun broke over the East River. She will be remembered by us and by her many friends for her impish sense of humor, her love of people and parties, and her desire to make the world a better place. Betty was the bright light of our lives, and we miss her. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church at 4:00pm, on Thursday, May 22nd. Donations may be made in her honor to The Central Park Conservancy, The Boys' Club of New York, Memorial Sloan Kettering, and The Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture. Ann and John Pyne; Elizabeth Pyne; Melinda and John Pyne, Jr.; Stephen and Kitty Sherrill; Stephen Sherrill, Jr.; William Sherrill; Katherine Sherrill; Sybil Calhoun; Isabelle Justo.

PINCUS--William, Passed away May 15, 2014 at age 94 and in the 74th year of his marriage to Elsa. William was the loving husband of Elsa, devoted father of Susan Rachel and Jillian Pincus and the late Lanni Tama, loving grandfather of Jordan Tama, and adoring great-grandfather of Amos and Jesse Tama and their mother Julia Tama, dedicated brother of the late Beatrice Levine, and admired uncle to his nieces and nephews. As a dedicated family man in good and bad times, he never missed a family rite of passage. He always "took care of everything" whenever needed. William had a big presence in life matched only by his love of life. He enjoyed traveling the world, investigating new cultures, and collecting art and cultural objects. Before any travel, he would read about the culture and area to be visited, often serving as his own travel guide. Fine food and wine were something to be savored. He loved theater, art, dancing, swimming (especially in the ocean), and knowledge in general. These loves were passed on to his appreciative family. William had the wonderful experience of seeing the natural beauty of the United States in the early 1950s as part of his work in the National Park Service; he wanted to share this experience with his family. Especially remembered are the two resulting cross-USA driving trips in 1953 and 1959 with his wife and three daughters to visit the National Parks -- quite a challenge back then. William was born on April 29, 1920 in Philadelphia and received a B.A. in Government from Brooklyn College (1940), an M.A. in Public Administration from American University (1948), and a J.D. from George Washington University (1953). William worked for the Federal Government from 1941 to 1957. His appointments there included advisory and managerial positions in the War Department (Lend Lease Depot), Bureau of the Budget, Bureau of Land Management, First and Second Hoover Commissions, and the U.S. Congress. Some of his government work resulted in major reorganization of government agencies. From 1957 to 1968, William worked in the government and law division of the Ford Foundation, responsible for making grants for new directions in legal education and for research to improve the administration of justice. His most lasting work as President of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibility (CLEPR) started in 1968, CLEPR was responsible for reforms in the system of legal education by starting the clinical movement in law school curriculums and providing law students with real-life professional responsibilities and exposure to the people-oriented aspect of the legal profession. Creative and pioneering CLEPR projects resulted in clinical programs existing in almost every U.S. law school and internationally. In his lifetime, William worked tirelessly to establish clinical legal education as an Important part of legal studies and as an especially effective means for teaching professional responsibility. Administration of clinical justice and the attainment of the ideal of equal justice under the law were of paramount importance to him. William's dedication to Justice and clinical education were recognized by many legal organizations. He was the recipient of the President's Medal from The Catholic University of America for his pioneering work in clinical legal education and he received an honorary doctorate of laws from Georgetown in Washington, DC. The Association of American Law Schools (AALS) clinical section yearly bestows The William Pincus Award in his honor to one or more Individuals or institutions that have effected outstanding contributions to the cause of clinical legal education. William is missed by his loving family. Services: Sunday, May 18, 2014 at 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

VENTRONE--Collette, of Ossining, formerly of New York City, Los Angeles, and Dallas. She was a former Vice President of Store Planning and Design in Dallas at Neiman Marcus. Survived by his loving wife, Leila, of 63 years; four adoring children and their spouses, and nine grandchildren. Memorial Mass at The Church of the Resurrection, Solon, OH, May 19 at 11am. Full Military Honors Funeral at West Point June 3 at 10am.

RATNER--Elinor. The Board and staff of Educational Alliance are deeply saddened by the passing of Elinor Ratner, a 30 year veteran of our Board. Elinor was truly special and dedicated to making the world a better place. Her compassion and commitment were unending. We will miss the wisdom she brought to every interaction. Our deepest condolences to her sons Peter and David and to her entire family.

SADOLF--Milton, 87, died on May 8, 2014 in New York City, of natural causes. A native New Yorker and a Veteran of World War II, Milton was a graduate of the City College of New York, the New York School of Interior Design and Pratt Institute. He was a librarian at the New York Public Library from 1960 to 1988, from 1968, in the Picture Collection at 42nd Street. He is survived by his wife, Judith Bartlett, his sister, Rosalind Reisman, of Jamesburg, NJ, a niece, Marlene Reisman, of New York City and his nephews, Stephen Reisman, of Nashville TN and David Reisman of Istanbul, Turkey. Milton was a sweet and gentle man; he will be sorely missed.

POMERANTZ--Rita, The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow of the passing of Rita Pomerantz, beloved mother of our friend and Of Counsel, Mark F. Pomerantz. We express our deepest sympathies to Mark, Judy and to all other members of the family

RATNER--Elinor Frances Goodfriend, died peacefully in her home in New York on May 15, 2014, aged 94. She was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania and received her Bachelor of Arts from Wellesley College in 1944. Shortly after her graduation she moved to Washington, DC., where she worked in the Office of War Information. Later she worked for the State Department in New York. Elinor Ratner had a lifetime commitment to social and civil projects. She was a passionate advocate for child welfare programs, principally with Day Care and Head Start in the Bronx. She was Vice President and Trustee of the Educational Alliance, a Co-Founder, former Secretary and Vice President and Board Member of Leake & Watts Children's Services and a co-founder and Board Member of the GO Project. She was an adviser to the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation and a founder of the Village Temple as well as a tireless supporter of the Temple's Soup Kitchen. In 1944 she married Robert S. Ratner (1918 1980) and after the war they moved to an apartment on lower Fifth Avenue where she continued to live until her death. She is survived by her two sons, Peter and David Ratner, her daughters-in-law Carol Walters and Dr. Laura Schiller and her beloved grandchildren, Molly, Sophie, Sacha, Suzanne, Erin, Simon and Frances and her great-grandchildren, Ezra, Lilith and Elinor. She held so many in her warm embrace and will be dearly missed. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, May 21 at 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the GO Project or the Educational Alliance.

SALK--Evelyn Lois, passed away on May 12, 2014, at age 92. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Robert, and daughter, Susan. Mrs. Salk was a longtime resident of New York City who most recently lived in Massachusetts to be close to her family. She is survived by her son Stephen, grandson Benjamin and daughter-in-law Joanne.

POLAK--Ina Soep. The Anne Frank Center USA is heartbroken over the passing of Ina Soep Polak, wife of the Center's Chairman Emeritus Jack Polak. Our deepest condolences go to him, their children, Margrit, Tony, and Fred, and their grandchildren.

SHERRILL--Betty. McMillen Inc. is sad to announce the death of Betty Sherrill. She served as president of our firm from 1972 to 2002, and as Chairman of The Board of McMillen Inc. until her death on Monday. We will miss her relentless energy, her humor, her frustrating qualities, her creativity, and her intuitive wisdom. McMillen Inc.

MOLONEY--Patrick Noel, of Sag Harbor, NY, born in Limerick City, Ireland, passed away from complications from pancreatic cancer on May 14, 2014. He was the beloved husband of Elizabeth for 50 years, father of five, and grandfather of seven, with another grandchild due in August. His beloved brother, William, and sister, Moria, predeceased him in Ireland. He was an inveterate sportsman, particularly hurling, rowing, Irish football, and all forms of Gaelic games. He was an avid golfer, or as he would say, "hacker," and had his first hole in one at Hampton Hills Golf Club on July 2, 2013, while in the midst of chemotherapy treatment. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club for 25 years, the Shamrock Golf club for 35 years, the Smithtown Landing Men's Golf Association for 41 years, and a lifetime overseas member of the Ballybunion Golf Club in County Kerry, Ireland. He founded Independent Investors, Inc. in 1983 after spending 25 years in the Fiduciary Division at Chemical Bank. He and his wife Elizabeth founded The Moloney Family Foundation in 2013 to further their philanthropic ideals. He was a true Irishman but never forgot what the United States meant to him. He will be missed by so many. Visitation will be held at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home in Sag Harbor, NY on Friday, May 16 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm and Saturday, May 17 from 11am-1pm. Funeral Mass will follow at St. Andrews R.C. Church in Sag Harbor on Saturday, May 17 at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the SCA Indian Province, the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement, or the Lustgarten Foundation.

McSWEENEY--Josephine. Professor Emeritus, Pratt Institute Library, died on May 11, 2014 at age 85. Jo graduated from SUNY, earned an M.A. from Columbia and an M.L.S. from Pratt. She was a resident of Manhattan, a world traveler, and an avid bridge player. Jo enjoyed many summers at Twilight Park in the Catskills, where she was Secretary of the Board for several years. A private celebration of her life will be held later. She will be greatly missed by her many cousins and friends. Maureen Molloy & Sydney Starr

CHRISTIANSEN--Arthur Alexander. Born New York City, February 14, 1920, died Front Royal, Virginia on May 10, 2014. Patriot, Yankee fan, aviator, carpenter, educator, bibliophile, world traveler and Bon Vivant. Burial in Arlington National Cemetery. RATNER--Elinor Frances Goodfriend, died peacefully in her home in New York on May 15, 2014, aged 94. She was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania and received her Bachelor of Arts from Wellesley College in 1944. Shortly after her graduation she moved to Washington, DC., where she worked in the Office of War Information. Later she worked for the State Department in New York. Elinor Ratner had a lifetime commitment to social and civil projects. She was a passionate advocate for child welfare programs, principally with Day Care and Head Start in the Bronx. She was Vice President and Trustee of the Educational Alliance, a Co-Founder, former Secretary and Vice President and Board Member of Leake & Watts Children's Services and a co-founder and Board Member of the GO Project. She was an adviser to the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation and a founder of the Village Temple as well as a tireless supporter of the Temple's Soup Kitchen. In 1944 she married Robert S. Ratner (1918 1980) and after the war they moved to an apartment on lower Fifth Avenue where she continued to live until her death. She is survived by her two sons, Peter and David Ratner, her daughters-in-law Carol Walters and Dr. Laura Schiller and her beloved grandchildren, Molly, Sophie, Sacha, Suzanne, Erin, Simon and Frances and her great-grandchildren, Ezra, Lilith and Elinor. She held so many in her warm embrace and will be dearly missed. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, May 21 at 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the GO Project or the Educational Alliance.

POMERANTZ--Rita, The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow of the passing of Rita Pomerantz, beloved mother of our friend and Of Counsel, Mark F. Pomerantz. We express our deepest sympathies to Mark, Judy and to all other members of the family

MARKLE--Mary E. Passed away peacefully on Thursday, May 8, 2014 in Sun City, AZ at the age of 90. Beloved wife of Roger A. Markle, she is survived by her grandsons Michael Donofrio, Alan Dendinger, and Eric Dendinger and was predeceased by her daughters, Sandra D'Onofrio and Barbara Dendinger. Mary was one of a kind and lived life her own way with great optimism and zest. Her spirit and love will remain with us forever.

POLAK--Catharina "Ina" Soep. Ira and I would like to extend our deepest and most sincere condolences to Jack and the Polak family on their most tragic loss. Ina was the epitome of elegance, beauty, charm and wit. She represented all that was bright and hopeful. We considered her Dutch Royalty, a brave survivor and representative of the best that came to America. She was loved by all she met and will be missed by all. The Polak family has made a very big influence in our lives both legal and social. I idolized Ina and tried to comport myself the way Ina did. With heartfelt sympathy, Joan and Ira Berman

MacDONALD--Robert Ian. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain are greatly saddened by the death of Robert Ian MacDonald in Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, on 12 May. Robert MacDonald had deep roots in England, Scotland, and America. His paternal great-grandfather, George MacDonald, was a well-known Scottish writer whose book The Light Princess was recently turned into a successful musical at the National Theatre in London. His maternal great-grandfather was Charles Pratt of Brooklyn, a director of Standard Oil and the founder of the Pratt Institute. Robert worked as an investor in London and as a lifelong dairy farmer on his family's estate in Devon. He also took a keen interest in the theatrical world in London and New York and backed a number of plays, including The Light Princess. Like his mother before him, Robert MacDonald was an ardent supporter of the American Museum. In 2011, during the Museum's fiftieth-anniversary year, he was presented with the Dallas Pratt Commemorative Medal, named after one of the Museum's co-founders, who was also a descendant of one of Standard Oil's founding families. Robert's wife, Carolyn MacDonald, served as Deputy Chair of the Museum's trustees and continues to serve as a director of the Halcyon Foundation in New York. His generosity, friendship and dry wit will be deeply missed. Richard Wendorf, FSA, Director, Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman, Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman, American Museum in Britain, Linda Hackett, President, Halcyon Foundation

SHULMAN--Zophia. Our beloved friend, Zophia Shulman, survivor of the Holocaust, born in Poland, passed away on May 14th in New Rochelle, NY. She was a psychiatric nurse who spent her life helping the disadvantaged and actively keeping alive the memory of the Shoah. She is survived by her brother Lou Shulman and his family and her cherished life-long partner and companion, Haim Grossman. A remarkable woman and devoted friend, she will always live in the memory of the myriad of friends who knew and loved her. The funeral will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, May 18th at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam Ave. and 91st St. in Manhattan.

EDELMAN--George, age 93, of Schroon Lake, NY and Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice; proud and loving father of Richard and Sara Edelman, Laurie Edelman, and Jamie and Mark Pollack; adoring grandfather of Jessica Pollack, Alison and A.J. Elbert, Max and Jill Edelman, and Aimee Anker; "Zaide George" to his beautiful great-grandchildren, Dexter and Samantha Edelman and Angelina Anker; devoted uncle to Jonathan Prenner and Stacey Prenner Harel and their families; treasured cousin to Sylvia and David Posner, Rachel Posner Warshauer and Raphael Posner and their families, and the Ingber, Fuks and Scheiner families, cherished friend to so many. He was a life-long educator and the Director of Camp Idylwold, who quietly mentored and guided his students, campers and counselors; a veteran of World War II; and a grateful alumnus of Brooklyn College, where he served on the Board of the Brooklyn College Alumni Association. Funeral Service Sunday, May 18, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

McSWEENEY--Josephine. Professor Emeritus, Pratt Institute Library, died on May 11, 2014 at age 85. Jo graduated from SUNY, earned an M.A. from Columbia and an M.L.S. from Pratt. A private celebration of her life will be held later. She will be greatly missed by her many cousins and friends. Maureen Molloy & Sydney Starr

STUART--Robert D.,Jr. Robert D. Stuart, Jr. former Ambassador to Norway, long time chief executive of the Quaker Oats Company, and a leader in civic and business affairs for more than 60 years, died on May 8, 2014 en route from France to the United States with his beloved wife Lillan. He was 98. Whether business, politics, or philanthropy, Ambassador Stuart's consistent ambition was to live up to the title of his privately published memoirs: Making a Difference. By all accounts, he did. As a young law student at Yale in 1940, Stuart joined with a group of classmates, including Gerald Ford, Potter Stewart and Kingman Brewster--a future U.S. President, Supreme Court Justice and Yale College president--to found the America First Committee, a grass roots organization dedicated to keeping America out of the developing European conflict. At its peak, America First had as many as 800,000 members. After his discharge from the Army in 1946 with the rank of Major, he returned to law school at Yale. Upon graduation, he joined the Quaker Oats Company, co-founded by his grandfather Robert Stuart and led at the time by his father R. Douglas Stuart and uncle John Stuart. He spent 38 years at Quaker, the last 15 as chief executive, and during his tenure pushed to diversify the company and to expand its international presence. Two themes animated his leadership: a belief in the power of strong brands and the certainty that corporations like Quaker had a duty both to their shareholders and to the communities in which they lived and operated. From the time he became president in 1962 to his stepping down in 1984 to join the diplomatic corps, sales grew from $365 million to more than $3 billion. As Ronald Regan's ambassador to Norway from 1984 to 1989, Amb. Stuart followed in the tradition of his father, who was the American ambassador to Canada in the mid-1950s. The younger Stuart served in the waning years of the Cold War, when Norway's location north of the Barents Sea and its proximity to the former Soviet Union was of great strategic relevance both to the United States and to NATO. He fell in love with Norway, as did his wife Barbara. The feeling was apparently mutual, as the Norwegian press termed Ambassador Stuart "en flink gutt"--a good guy. Upon his return from Norway, he was nominated for the Defense Base Case Closure and Realignment Commission by President George H.W. Bush in 1991 and then President Bill Clinton in 1993. Robert D. Stuart, Jr. was born in 1916 in Hubbard Woods, Illinois and grew up in Lake Forest. He graduated from the Los Alamos Ranch School in New Mexico and then Princeton University in 1937, where he earned a degree in politics. In 1938, he married the former Barbara Edwards from Syracuse, NY. They had five children, three of whom survive him. His wife died in 1993, and two years later, he married Lillan Lovenskiold, a Norwegian whom he had met during his time as ambassador, who along with her late husband, had been close friends. She was the second great love of his life. For many years, he was a trustee of Princeton University. He also served as a director of United Airlines, the Burlington Northern Railroad, the First National Bank of Chicago Deere and Company, and Molson Companies, Ltd. of Canada. A life long Republican, he served as National Committeeman from Illinois and Finance Chair in Illinois for the Reagan campaign, among many assignments. In 1962, he founded the Lake County Republican Federation, reflecting his long-standing belief in the importance of local politics. As his political and business interests wound down, Amb. Stuart focused on philanthropy, founding a family foundation that supported civic education, campaign finance reform and national security. Ambassador Stuart was pre-deceased in death by sons Huntingdon Douglas Stuart and R. Douglas Stuart III. He is survived by his wife Lillan, sister Margaret, his son James M. Stuart and wife Dianne, daughter Marian S. Pillsbury, son Alexander D. Stuart and wife Robin, daughter-in-law Nancy M. Stuart, eight grandchildren--Pamela Stuart, Donaldson Pillsbury, Jr., Blair Pillsbury Enders, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, Christopher Stuart, Ann Robinson Stuart, and Robert Douglas Stuart IV--as well as six great-grandchildren: Clark and Annika Pillsbury, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Tyler and Sam Eichmann. Ambassador Stuart also had numerous Norwegian step-children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He adored them all, on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. And they adored him. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on Saturday, May 17th at the First Presbyterian Church of Lake Forest. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gorton Community Center in Lake Forest or Princeton University.

CLARE--David Ross, 88, of Westfield, NJ, and North Palm Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on May 10, 2014, in his Florida home surrounded by his family. David Clare was born in Perth Amboy, NJ and graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1945 with a B.S. in mechanical engineering. After serving as an officer in the Navy, David joined Johnson and Johnson in 1946 and in 1976 he became President and Chairman of the Executive Committee. On April 26, 1989 he stepped down from the position. Among his activities, he served as long-term chairman of the Governor's Management Improvement Program, Inc. for New Jersey and on the Board of Overlook Hospital and its Foundation. He was co-chairman of the first Pew Health Professions Commission, which is concerned with the nation's health care needs in the future. He was a member of the President's Drug Advisory Council and the advisory board of the New Jersey Science Technology Center and also a member of the board of trustees of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. David also is a member of Echo Lake Country Club in Westfield and Lost Tree Country Club and Seminole Golf Club in North Palm Beach. He was a parishioner of St. Helen's Church in Westfield and St. Paul of the Cross in North Palm Beach. David is predeceased by his wife of 64 years, Peggy and is survived by their four children, thirteen grandchildren, eight great-grandsons and one great-granddaughter on her way. Services handled by the Dooley Colonial Home, Westfield.

THORNBERRY--Cedric, died 6 May 2014 in England, aged 77, after a long illness. An international lawyer and peacekeeper, and UN Assistant Secretary General. Born in Belfast, worked for human rights, democracy and peace in London, Greece, New York, Namibia, Cyprus, Middle East, Yugoslavia, Somalia.

STREETER--Tal, sculptor of "Endless Column" and author of The Art of the Japanese Kite passed away on April 17, 2014 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Streeter's art centered on the creation of large-scale steel sculptures, and large kites, both of which find their inspiration and home in the sky. A celebration of his life, work and legacy will be held in 2015 on the opening of the Dream of Flight Museum and Library, Santa Fe New Mexico, established by the non profit Friends of the Sky Foundation in 2012 to preserve Tal's vision, sculpture, sky related material, photographic and kite archives. He is survived by his wife, potter Romig Streeter, daughter Lissa Streeter, brother Ronald J. Streeter, collaborator Bruce George, and his Santa Fe family - David, Fiona and Tiger Wong-Wagner. To those that wish, all correspondence and donations may be made to : Friends of the Sky Foundation, 4007 Old Santa Fe Trail, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87505. "Rather than center himself in the American space as an Action Painter does, Streeter makes the surrounding lack of scale reveal itself; the endlessness is in the American sky." - Carter Ratcliff

SAYDAH--Lyra Brizell, May 13, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Edward, loving mother of Marie-Louise Saydah Sherer, Charles, adored grandmother and great-grandmother by all. She lived with grace, style, and dignity and will be deeply missed. Services private.

STEIN--Rebecca (Becky) Kramer, an accomplished dancer, artist and political/social activist, died on April 8, 2014 two days short of her 98th birthday. At an early age she got a scholarship to study dance with Hanya Holmes. A founding member of the New Dance Group, she later became the dancing partner of Jack Cole, the father of theatrical jazz dance. After a long run at the Rainbow Room they toured the world, eventually ending-up dancing for the Ziegfeld Follies. After her dance career, she became a sculptor and a collage artist. She is survived by her son Marc Narkus-Kramer, her daughter AAshiel Blue Sill (nee Deborah Kramer), her stepson Dr. Peter Stein, nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

SHAMOIAN--Dr. Charles. The faculty and staff of the Department of Psychiatry at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Charles Shamoian. Dr. Shamoian started the Geriatric Psychiatry program at Weill Cornell Medical College, and was one of the founding fathers of Geriatric Psychiatry worldwide. He was beloved by his patients for his devoted care, and respected and admired by his students and peers for his wonderful clinical and leadership skills. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Paula Shamoian, and his entire family. He will be sorely missed. Jack D. Barchas, M.D. Chair, Weill Cornell Department of Psychiatry Philip J. Wilner, M.D., MBA Executive Vice Chair, Weill Cornell Department of Psychiatry George S. Alexopoulos, M.D. Vice Chair, Geriatric Psychiatry, Weill Cornell Institute of Geriatric Psychiatry Stephen J. Ferrando, M.D. Vice Chair for Clinical Programs, New York- Presbyterian Hospital/ Westchester Division

LISS--Elliott R. 7/6/31-5/18/04. "Not a day goes by, not a single day" for 10 years that we don't think of your smile and your laugh. Love, Dotty and the kids

SEMLER--Evelyn Williams, a longtime New Yorker, died April 28 at the age of 92. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College and Columbia University, she worked at the Metropolitan Museum for many years. She was predeceased by her beloved husband George in 1997. They enjoyed music and extensive travels around the world and were both active members of St. James Episcopal Church, the Cosmopolitan Club and the Blue Hill Troupe. Survived by a nephew, Stewart Williams(swilliams@dfwefh.com), a niece, Deborah Brooks, many great-nieces and nephews and members of the Semler family. Services will be held May 31 at 2pm at the Crown Hill Memorial Park Chapel in Kirkland, NY near her hometown of Utica.

STAAL--Doris, died on Monday, May 5th, 2014 after a long and productive life. Cherished sister to Norma Gluck, beloved auntie to Amy and Rob Eberhardt, David Gluck, Kristina Kendall and Benjamin and Sara Gluck. Doris was a teacher, world traveler and artist. She loved, and was loved, by many. A remembrance and celebration of her life and art will be held on Sunday, June 1st at 2pm at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn.
GUSKIND--Sherry. You've been gone for 40 years! You still haven't gone. Elin

SHEIFER--Ethel Florence, (nee Titon) passed away at age 94 in her Boca Raton, FL, home on March 16. Her immediate family and dog Judy were by her side. Ethel was the daughter of Dina and William Titon, the latter known for many years as Macy's Famous Taster. She was predeceased by her parents, her husband, Loeb Boucchechter Sheifer, and her brother, Milton Titon. Born in New York City, Ethel attended Elmira College, receiving her bachelor's degree from NYU. In the late 1940s, she and Loeb moved to Morristown, NJ, where she became a successful real estate broker. She later lived in Harding and Rockaway Townships, while maintaining various homes in Boca Raton. Ethel led a very active life. She was an accomplished golfer and tennis player and enjoyed many hobbies, including ikebana, bridge, art collecting, and traveling. She read widely, maintaining an interest in world affairs and continuing her education at Florida Atlantic University through her 93rd year. She is survived by her daughter, Susanne Braham, of New York City; son, Brooks Sheifer (wife Darra) of Walnut Creek, California; three grandchildren, Howard Braham (wife Shruti), Diana Braham, and William Sheifer; and longtime caretaker and companion, Stella Irizarry.

SILVERMAN--Leon, 91, of Fair Lawn, NJ passed away on May 15, 2014. Beloved husband of Lillian, loving father of Elaine (Mike) and Natalie (Arthur), devoted grandfather of Justin, Rebecca, and Marc, proud great-grandfather of Isabella. Born in Lodz, Poland and a Holocaust survivor, Leon emigrated to the U.S. in 1949 and established several successful catering businesses. He was admired for his culinary talent and his lifelong pursuit of knowledge.

WOODS--Frank Montgomery Jr.,Frank Montgomery Woods, Jr., engaged life with enthusiasm. He was an active member of the Bohemian Club, The Pacific-Union Club, the California Tennis Club, the Guardsmen and San Francisco Golf Club. Frank was a passionate bridge player and a student of the game. Frank's life began 81 years ago, in Chattanooga, Tennessee, the eldest son of Josephine Roberts Woods and Frank Montgomery Woods. He spent his childhood in Birmingham, Alabama, and Nashville, Tennessee, then earned his bachelor's degree from Cornell University ('50-'54), in the School of Hotel Administration. He was a member of the Sigma Phi fraternity. Following graduation, Frank served in Korea. He was a U.S. Army Second Lieutenant in charge of a quartermaster depot. In 1956, Frank joined the advertising and marketing department of Proctor & Gamble in Cincinnati, Ohio. After five years at P&G, Frank moved to the Bay Area to launch his own company, Marketing Continental. An entrepreneur at heart, Frank's company was instrumental in developing and introducing products such as the Pine Mountain Log and the Shell No-Pest Strip. In the late 1960s, Frank, together with Cornell classmate Tom Reed, helped to develop the Four Seasons Ski Resort in Breckenridge, Colorado. In 1961, Frank met Kay Harrigan and they married in Mobile, Alabama, a year later. They lived in San Francisco and Healdsburg, and raised three children: Dorine Woods Towle (Griff), Frank Montgomery Woods (Anne Robinson) and Alexis Woods (Daniel Donahoe). They have six grandchildren: Spencer and Audrey Towle, Thea and Keira Donahoe, Ella and Montgomery Woods. Frank is survived by his brother, Bill Woods (Deborah Freedman), and his sister, Rhoda Reyner. His brother, Joseph Woods, predeceased him. In the early 1970s, Frank began his notable career in the wine business, co-founding the award-winning Clos du Bois winery in Sonoma County. From the beginning, Clos du Bois wines were designed to be as consumer friendly as an American wine and as elegant as a French wine, a combination that was unheard of at the time. Frank's marketing skills were innovative for the wine business and he quickly built Clos du Bois into a premium California wine. Frank was a tremendous advocate for the American wine industry. Over the years Frank was chairman of the Wine Institute, chairman of the American participation in the International Organization of Viticulturalists (OIV), and was on the boards of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, the Young Audiences of San Francisco, and the L.S.B. Leakey Foundation. In addition, he was a consultant to the wine industries in Bulgaria, Slovenia and Hungary under an agricultural project of the United States government. Frank also represented the US in various international wine negotiations with NAFTA and dealings with GATT in Geneva. Frank Woods passed away on Thursday, May 8, in San Francisco. There will be a memorial service for Frank on Monday, May 19 at 3:00pm at Grace Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, the Woods family requests that remembrances to the deceased be sent to: Gladstone Foundation, 1650 Owens Street, San Francisco, CA, 94158; or KIPP Bay Area Schools, 1404 Franklin Street Suite 500, Oakland, CA 94612; or UCSF Diabetes Teaching Center, UCSF Foundation, Lock Box 45339, San Francisco, CA 94145. www.halstedngray.com.

RATNER--Elinor. The partners of Hartman, Ule, Rose and Ratner, LLP extend our most sincere condolences to David Ratner, our partner, on his loss of his mother, Elinor Ratner, who died at home this week at the advanced age of 94. Elinor was a stalwart friend of this firm and our families since our formation in 1982 and was a role model for us and our children. WEISS--Gerald. August 3, 1922 May 12, 2014. Devoted husband, father and grandfather. Brilliant student, scholar and teacher. A man of passionate engagement in the world, deep commitment to community, and surpassing humility. www.memorialwebsites. legacy.com/GeraldWeiss The Weiss Family

WINTHROP--Beekman, 73, of Luray, SC, Washington, DC and North Haven, ME died on May 6, 2014 at his Washington, DC home of complications of metastatic kidney cancer. Born in Boston, the son of Serita Bartlett and Nathaniel Thayer Winthrop, Beekman was an 11th generation direct descendant of the first Massachusetts Bay Colony Governor, John Winthrop, and his namesake, a great uncle, was the first governor of Puerto Rico. He attended The Hill School in Pottstown, PA and went on to receive a BA from Columbia University and an MS in Urban Planning from Columbia School of Architecture. After a brief enrollment in the Harvard Divinity School, he left to pursue writing, inspired by the work of Robert Coles on race relations in the south. In 1971 he won the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award for Outstanding Coverage of the Problems of Poverty and Discrimination for a New South magazine article on intestinal parasites in poor black children on the developing resort island of Hilton Head. In 1972, concerned community members brought to his attention the murder of an 18-year-old black youth in a town near his family's South Carolina property. Beekman's persistence and partnership with the press to expose the injustice ultimately led to the indictment of two white men. His involvement was later highly fictionalized in a reporter's book and movie. Beekman went on to form a small investment advisory firm where he worked as a manager and trustee until his retirement, after which he continued work as a private investor. Beekman lived in Washington for 42 years following his 1969 marriage to Phoebe Jane Wood of Boulder, CO who survives him. Also surviving him are his son, Dudley (Jennifer) of Washington, DC, and two granddaughters, Kay Taylor and Serafina. He is also survived by three brothers, John (Elizabeth) of Charleston, SC, Nathaniel (Martha) of Montpelier, VT and Stephen (Jane Williamson) of Wayland, MA, and three sisters, Serita of Rhinebeck, NY and Lake Wales FL, Katharine of Bernardsville, NJ and Cornelia of New York City. Both of his parents and one brother, Matthew of Boston MA, predeceased him. A memorial service will be held June 13 at 11:30am at St. Alban's Church, 3100 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC. Services in Maine and South Carolina will follow later. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to North Haven Conservation Partners, PO Box 336, North Haven, ME 04853 or the charity of your choice.

WOLOVNICK--Arlene (nee Solomon), of Roslyn, NY, on May 11th, formerly of Ballen Isle, Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Old Westbury, NY. Much beloved wife and soul mate of Marvin Wolovnick (deceased), cherished mother of Jared Wolovnick (Julie) and Beth Alderman (Michael), sister of Dr. Sanford Solomon (Gail), devoted and loving Granny to Shana Teig Kantor (Rabbi Shalom Kantor), Benjamin Teig, Arielle Wolovnick Heller (Ben) and Diana Wolovnick and great-grandmother to Rena and Noam Kantor.
