JACOBS--Marshall, originally of Toledo, Ohio, passed away on April 26, 2014 in Palo Alto, California, weeks shy of his 95th birthday. For more than a half century, Marshall enjoyed a sophisticated legal practice in New York City, and was a founder of the Jacobs, Persinger & Parker law firm. An avid student of history and occasional owner of not very fast racehorses, Marshall lived a full and interesting life. Those who had the good fortune to know him were constantly touched by his decency, integrity, wise counsel and dry sense of humor. Marshall is survived by his loving wife, Kathy, his sons John and James, and his three grandchildren. He will be sorely missed by all. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Cancer Society.

HIRSCHLAG--Harold W. Our dear father, Harold W. Hirschlag passed away on Wednesday May 7th, just after his 98th birthday. He served his country as a soldier, he was a devoted husband, and a wonderful Dad. He was a partner at the accounting firm of Milton Rindler and Company, where he worked as a CPA for almost 60 years. He was also a tennis player, a sailor, an artist in wood sculpting and stained glass; and a craftsman par excellence. He designed and crafted (amongst many projects) a beautiful classical guitar and he built a precise grandfather clock completely out of wood, cutting each gear by hand - and it ran perfectly! While he was not a talker, he had a strong voice when it came to social injustice. He and his wife Gertrude openly demonstrated their convictions during the civil rights movement of the 1960s, and in the 1970s their group the Fair Lawn Committee for Peace in Vietnam organized efforts to end that war. They were even out on the picket line in their 90s to protest United States intervention in Iraq. He shared 69 years with our Mom, the love of his life. Our Dad could do anything. We love him dearly. Laura and Richard

POMERANTZ--Rita, The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow of the passing of Rita Pomerantz, beloved mother of our friend and Of Counsel, Mark F. Pomerantz. We express our deepest sympathies to Mark, Judy and to all other members of the family

HIDALGO--Dorothy Anne Nicholas, April 8, 1928 - May 8, 2014. Mrs. Hidalgo passed away after a prolonged and courageous battle with cancer. She was pre-deceased by her husband Alexander, a member of a prominent New York Real Estate family. Mrs. Hidalgo was born in Salisbury, NC, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Nicholas. She received her education in Salisbury and moved to New York City to pursue a career in fashion and advertising. She was Editorial Director for Vogue - Butterick and later Vice President - Account Executive at Grey Advertising. She joined her husband in the real estate business and, as Director, was responsible for the company's expansion in to property management. Mrs. Hidalgo received many awards for her civic activities. She served as President of the English Speaking Union of New York for 12 years and as an active Board Member of the Visiting Nurse Association of New York she chaired many successful programs designed to help the less fortunate. Donations to either of these organizations can be made in Mrs. Hidalgo's name. Mrs. Hidalgo is survived by her son Neal A. Hidalgo, her daughter Melene Nahodil and her husband Robert, her grandson Alexander Nahodil, and her grand-daughter Alesandra Nahodil. At the request of Mrs. Hidalgo a private, family only, service will be held at a later date.

MacDONALD--Robert Ian. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain are greatly saddened by the death of Robert Ian MacDonald in Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, on 12 May. Robert MacDonald had deep roots in England, Scotland, and America. His paternal great-grandfather, George MacDonald, was a well-known Scottish writer whose book The Light Princess was recently turned into a successful musical at the National Theatre in London. His maternal great-grandfather was Charles Pratt of Brooklyn, a director of Standard Oil and the founder of the Pratt Institute. Robert worked as an investor in London and as a lifelong dairy farmer on his family's estate in Devon. He also took a keen interest in the theatrical world in London and New York and backed a number of plays, including The Light Princess. Like his mother before him, Robert MacDonald was an ardent supporter of the American Museum. In 2011, during the Museum's fiftieth-anniversary year, he was presented with the Dallas Pratt Commemorative Medal, named after one of the Museum's co-founders, who was also a descendant of one of Standard Oil's founding families. Robert's wife, Carolyn MacDonald, served as Deputy Chair of the Museum's trustees and continues to serve as a director of the Halcyon Foundation in New York. His generosity, friendship and dry wit will be deeply missed. Richard Wendorf, FSA, Director, Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman, Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman, American Museum in Britain, Linda Hackett, President, Halcyon Foundation

POST--Michael A.,of Framingham, MA, died on April 26th. He was predeceased by his parents Seymour and Judith Post of New York City. He is survived by his sisters Deborah Radovsky and her partner Schuyler Crawford, Nancy Schecter and her husband Stephen, and Susan Lichtenstein and her husband Walter. Donations may be made in his memory to Advocates Inc., Framingham, MA.

GORDON--Florence Sonders, 91, passed away peacefully, May 13th, at Mt. Carmel East Hospital, Columbus, Ohio, with daughter Susan and son Randy present, following a short illness. Florence had the perfect end to a full life. Florence was preceded in death by her husband of 32 years, Bill Gordon. She is survived by her beloved brother, Dr. Lawrence J. Sonders, her three children, Dr. Michael Gordon, Randy Gordon, Susan Gordon, six grandchildren, and three great grandchildren. Florence maintained her characteristic energy, wit and engagement in civic affairs and political activism to the end. All her children are arranging celebrations of her life in New York, Georgia, Ohio and Washington, to permit her constellation of friends and family to celebrate her life. We love her and miss her. Contributions to the League of Women Voters (www.lwv.org) or Anti-Defamation League (ADL) (www.adl.org) would honor her values.

MacDONALD--Robert Ian, Robert Ian MacDonald, died quietly in Nassau, the Bahamas on May 12th. He left this world as he lived in it, with elegance, courage and humility. Born in 1928 in London to a life less ordinary, he had deep roots in England, America and Scotland. In addition to the Bahamas, he maintained residences in New York, London and Devon for more than eighty years. His paternal great-grandfather, George MacDonald, was the Victorian poet and author whose book, "The Light Princess", was recently turned into a successful musical at the National Theatre in London. His maternal great grandfather was Charles Pratt of Brooklyn, a partner in Standard Oil who also founded the Pratt Institute. His mother, Helen Babbott MacDonald and his father, Ian MacDonald, both served the cause of freedom during the Second World War in England. His father returned to the Army and was stationed in Churchill's London map room. Helen MacDonald was head of the Red Cross and Army Officer's Club in Salcombe while the allies prepared for the Normandy invasion on the beaches near Gullet, the family farm in Devon. During the war years, Robert was evacuated to America where he attended the Pomfret School and spent four happy years with his American cousins in Bernardsville, New Jersey. With the surrender of the Germans in 1945, he left school and returned to Britain with other evacuees on a Royal Navy battleship. He attended Millfield School in Somerset, England to prepare for the Royal Marines' exam and was granted his commission by King George VI. Following service to King and Country, he became the first trainee for the Mobil Oil Corporation in England. Later, he worked for Lloyds in the City of London and managed the family farm in Devon. As a lifelong dairy farmer, he especially prized his pedigree herd of Ayrshire cows. In later years, he would became the head of his family's New York based foundation. He was particularly interested in trans-Atlantic education, animal rights and conservation. He credited his good friend, Hoyle Jones (retired Chairman of the ASPCA), for persuading him to give up blood sports. "One is never too old to learn", he remarked at the time. Robert was never happier than in the company of his five grandsons (Jonathan MacDonald, Michael MacDonald, David MacDonald, Luke Harris (Emily) and Peter Harris) who succeed him, together with his son, Ian MacDonald (Cheryl) and daughter, Zara Harris, (Dan). In 1989 he married Carolyn Leslie-Leonard Bransford who survives him and resides in New York and the Bahamas. The family will be forever grateful to its dedicated staff, most especially Garry Godfrey of England and the Bahamas. A service of thanksgiving will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown (Locust Valley, New York) on May 23rd at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, it is the wish of the family that donations be made to The North Shore Land Alliance (Long Island, New York) or the Bahamas National Trust.

PANOFF--Aaron, beloved husband, father and grandfather. Born in Brooklyn, November 2, 1922 passed away peacefully in Florida on May 12th. He is survived by children Judy and Bill, granddaughter Rachel, and daughter and son-inlaw Audrey and Nick. He was a chess expert who loved the game. He will be dearly missed.

RATNER--Elinor Frances Goodfriend, died peacefully in her home in New York on May 15, 2014, aged 94. She was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania and received her Bachelor of Arts from Wellesley College in 1944. Shortly after her graduation she moved to Washington, DC., where she worked in the Office of War Information. Later she worked for the State Department in New York. Elinor Ratner had a lifetime commitment to social and civil projects. She was a passionate advocate for child welfare programs, principally with Day Care and Head Start in the Bronx. She was Vice President and Trustee of the Educational Alliance, a Co-Founder, former Secretary and Vice President and Board Member of Leake & Watts Children's Services and a co-founder and Board Member of the GO Project. She was an adviser to the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation and a founder of the Village Temple as well as a tireless supporter of the Temple's Soup Kitchen. In 1944 she married Robert S. Ratner (1918 1980) and after the war they moved to an apartment on lower Fifth Avenue where she continued to live until her death. She is survived by her two sons, Peter and David Ratner, her daughters-in-law Carol Walters and Dr. Laura Schiller and her beloved grandchildren, Molly, Sophie, Sacha, Suzanne, Erin, Simon and Frances and her great-grandchildren, Ezra, Lilith and Elinor. She held so many in her warm embrace and will be dearly missed. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, May 21 at 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the GO Project or the Educational Alliance.

FINN--Charles "Chic", passed away on April 8, 2014 in Concord, CA. Born on May 4, 1940 to Virginia "Jinny" Marvin and William "Al" Finn, Chic grew up in Bellport, NY and wrote about the village in his book, "Bellport: A Reminiscence". Chic graduated valedictorian of Bellport HS in 1957 and from Hamilton College in 1961. He was a member of Delta Upsilon Fraternity. Chic earned his JD at Duke Law School in 1964. He spent nearly 30 years at Cigna Corp. Following retirement he taught CFP courses at Oglethorpe University and volunteered at the Atlanta Botanical Gardens. Chic is survived by his children, David Finn (Mary) and Julia Holian (Bill); grandkids, Travis, John, Claire and Emma; and his sister, Barbara Bobby Finn. No services were held. In memory, please make donations to the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society.

NEWBURGER--Shirley Plehn "Gaby," passed away peacefully at home on Mother's Day surrounded by the love of her family and devoted dog - best pal Nicky. Her joie de vivre and larger than life personality gave joy to all that knew her. Beloved Mother of Patty and Brad (Wechsler); Teddy and Mindy (Pearce); Richard Newburger (Felix Calabrese). Adored and devoted "Gaby" to Samantha, Robert and David Wechsler; Andrew and Michael Pearce.

GOLDBERG--Daniel Louis, my beloved, passed away April 1, 2014 in New York City. He was 91 years old, four days short of his 92d birthday. He was born April 5, 1922 in Philadelphia, PA and later resided in New Jersey and New York, recently wintering in Florida. He was an exceptional person intellectually and a kind, compassionate caring human being. He was a WWII Veteran, a volunteer, in the US Army from 1942-1946, first an enlistee then a 90-day-wonder commissioned officer, forever proud of his military service. After Technical High School in Newark, NJ, he attended The New Jersey Institute of Technology receiving his BS and MS Degrees in Electrical Engineering, then becoming a registered Professional Engineer (PE) in New York and New Jersey. He also attended New York University's prestigious Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Daniel Goldberg was a brilliant Engineer. For 35 years, he was employed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and for 16 of those years, until his retirement in 1985, he was the Port Authority's Chief Electrical Engineer. Much of his electrical engineering design work involved New York City's Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, The George Washington Bridge, The Port Authority Bus Terminal, The Port Authority Trans Hudson (PATH), The World Trade Center, Kennedy International and LaGuardia Airports, and New Jersey's Newark International Airport, where he played a major role in a 1963 expansive redevelopment, construction and modernization program, and was the consultant for all the lighting and power facilities, receiving high recognition. Through the years he received many Port Authority accolades. In 1980, he was awarded the Port Authority's Distinguished Service Medal "For demonstrating an exceptional degree of good judgment, initiative and competence in his field of endeavor and sustained this record of outstanding or distinguished service over a number of years, at least 15 years of service." When retiring, his Port Authority plaque was inscribed "A Distinguishing Award To Daniel L. Goldberg, An Engineer A Gentleman A Friend." He was a life member of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) the world-wide largest professional society for the advancement of technology for humanity. In 1984, he was named Fellow, the highest level of membership, his citation "For innovative engineering of large transportation facilities." In 1974, he received an Achievement Award "For Leadership in Preparing and Publishing the 2nd Edition of Electrical Systems for Commercial Buildings." And in 1975, he received the Industrial and Commercial Power Systems Standards Medallion. He also contributed to the 1976, 1986, 1996 editions of the Red Book-Industrial Buildings, and the Bronze Book-Energy Conservation, and was on the Standards Board Review Committee 1982-1992. In 1993, he was the recipient of the Distinguished Service Award "In recognition of his dedication and distinguished service to the IEEE Industry Applications Society." He was involved with the Illuminating Engineering Society and wrote three electrical chapters for the McGraw Hill Handbook on Building Services. He was also an instructor for the IEEE, and held numerous other positions. The immensity of his ongoing contributions to the IEEE culminated in being awarded a special bronze medal inscripted "The IEEE Awards This Third Millennium Medal to Daniel L. Goldberg in 2000 for Outstanding Achievements and Contributions." Daniel was a child of "The Great Depression of the '30's," never forgetting the prevailing poverty, imbuing him with a lasting sense of empathy and philanthropy. For 40 years, he was a member and supporter of The American Technion Society, of The Technion Society of Israel, the leading Engineering and Science Institution, and in 2000 he received their Crystal Triangle, the highest award for being a PATRON. He was also a long time recognized supporter of the National Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC. And he was an Alma Mater supporter of the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Newark College of Engineering, "An Alumni Fellow Supporter For Significant Support to Engineering Education," these among so many others. Archeology was another of Daniel's interests. For many years he was a member of the Biblical Archeology Society, an international organization, taking him on several Middle East excavations, to dig sites of historical biblical importance, mainly to Israel. He was an inveterate traveler and had visited China, India, Egypt, Greece, Morocco, France, England, Germany, Ecuador, Argentina, Mexico, Alaska, and other places. He enjoyed music, and opera, and possessed a delightful sense of humor, wise and witty. His appreciation and knowledge of art and art history were boundless. He was a member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the past 40 years, and a long time Friend of The New York Public Library. And, in his characteristic modest, unassuming manner, he was a member of the American MENSA, the world-wide society for exceptionally high intelligence quotient individuals. After enduring prolonged suffering, David passed away from Parkinson's Disease, that still incurable illness. He is survived by a son, Alan Goldberg, a professor in California, and also a companion of long years, Irene Field, who he deeply loved, and to whom he was so deeply devoted. Daniel L. Goldberg was truly a special person, dedicated to Engineering, from childhood, and blessed with so many other fine attributes. He was loved and respected by all who knew him, and all whose lives he touched, and he will be greatly missed. With everlasting love. Irene

LICKDYKE--Jay Cary. December 10, 1931 - May 10, 2014. Born New York City to Helen Carey and John J. Lickdyke. Certified Seaman in Merchant Marines, 1946-1959. Worked on Oil Tankers. Graduate St. Bonaventure University 1958. City Desk and Religion Department George Murphy New York Times 58-59. Junior partner Clark Dodge & Co. 1961, broker/ Vice President at Kidder Peabody & Co., Vice President Gruntal & Co., Ingalls & Snyder. Sergeant and MP at US Army Arlington Hall, VA 1952-55. Wounded in Korea. Artist, carpenter, reader and great family man. Survived by wife Priscilla Cunningham, daughter Sarah Morissette (Garry), sisters Helene Lickdyke and Suzanne Varney. Brother Brian LickDyke, four grandchildren, one stepson, six nephews, devoted cousins and caregivers Anita Cadogan, Shirley Bannister and Myrna Glenn. Memorial Services at later date.

MILMAN--Jeffrey Owen, born July 23, 1943, in New York City, died unexpectedly Friday, May 9, 2014, in Cleveland, Ohio. With fond memories of growing up in Scarsdale, NY, Jeff graduated from Cornell University, where he was treasurer and reunion director of the WVBR radio station, and Stanford University Graduate School of Business. Choosing to volunteer in Vietnam, Jeff was commissioned as a 2nd Lieutenant in the US Army Medical Service Corps, serving as a hospital administrator in Chu Lai, and later rose to Captain. A CPA, Jeff worked as comptroller for several companies, his favorite being the former Ideal Toy Company, for which he still planned gatherings with other employees. He was an avid skier, scuba diver, and boating enthusiast. A member of the New York Military Affairs Symposium, Jeff was dedicated to military history, making many friends with others similarly inclined. Jeff spent the past nine months in Cleveland, Ohio, to be closer to his nephew's family; Justin and Lisa were endlessly and selflessly devoted to him until his untimely death. Jeff made lifelong friends wherever paths crossed, he as devoted to them as they to him; his incredible kindness and generosity will not be forgotten. Beloved son of the late Morton and Rosalind Eno Milman, Jeff is survived by his brother Stephen Milman (Evalyn) of Darien, Connecticut, and his sister Kathryn Havemann of Dayton, Ohio. Close relatives included the families of Richard and Janet Eno of Cabot, Vermont, Robert and Candice Eno of Bloomington, Indiana, his nieces and nephews (Douglas, Natalie, Nadia, and Stephen Milman of Oakton, Virginia; Andrew, Shanna, and Matthew Milman of New York City; Justin, Lisa, Eamon, and Mallerie Havemann of Rocky River, Ohio; Margaret, Jared, Josephine, Charlotte, and Lucille Scogna of Arlington, Virginia; Elizabeth, Michael, Caden, Lucas, and Jack Casanova of Kettering, Ohio; Catherine Havemann of Columbus, Ohio). A service with Military Honors will be held in Cleveland Thursday, May 15, 2014 (details at http://buschfuneral.tributes.com/obituary/photos/Jeffrey-Owen-Milman-101347109), followed by prayers/ interment Sunday, May 18, 2014, at 11:00am, Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale (Queens), New York. If desired, donations in Jeff's memory may be made to NAMI, P.O. Box 62596, Baltimore, MD 21264-2596, or online at www.nami.org. May his memory forever be a blessing.
NEWBURGER--Shirley Gabby, for reminding us all to always smell the roses and look up at the stars. Love, Janie, darling, Juliana and Isabella.

RATNER--Elinor G. The Leake & Watts Board of Directors and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of Elinor G. Ratner, a dedicated Board member for over 25 years. She was a true champion of high quality early education services for children of all backgrounds and of all income-levels. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her entire family.

GROSSI--Emilio, 87, on May 9, 2014. Photographer, painter, graphic designer, teacher. Educated Rhode Island School of Design and Yale. Art Director Metromedia and Fox Television; worked with I.M. Pei & Associates; taught at University of Pennsylvania, Cooper Union and the Cleveland Institute of Art. His work was selected by Edward Steichen for the Museum of Modern Art; represented at George Eastman House. He served proudly in the US Navy on submarines during World War II and Korea. Beloved husband of Marie and father of Peter, he will be sorely missed.

KISCH--Gloria. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Gloria Kisch the beloved daughter of the late revered Max Stern, z'l a YU Benefactor and long-time Vice Chairman of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, his late wife, Hilda, and step-daughter of Ghity Amiel Stern. She was the devoted mother of Rhona Kisch (Daniel Stamler) and Theo (Lisa) Kisch and the beloved sister of Leonard N. (Alison) Stern, and the late Stanley E. Stern, z'l (Marsha) Stern. She was also the cherished sister of Armand (Jean) Lindenbaum, Marcel (Belda) Lindenbaum, Maidy Jeger, the late Henry Lindenbaum, z'l (Ruth) and Susan (Charlie) Brown. Gloria Kisch was a doting grandmother of Natasha and Sam and was admired by her nieces and nephews. Active in many communal activities she became a cherished friend to all who worked with her in her noble endeavors. As a life-long artist of paintings she developed into an esteemed creator of large magnificent metal sculptures. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

MEREDITH--James B.,born January 14, 1920 in Pierce City, Missouri, died in New York City on May 13, 2014. James Meredith, a graduate of the University of Kansas and Harvard University, was an economist who worked a number of years for Exxon Corporation. James Meredith is survived by his wife, Lila Meredith. Funeral services will be held on May 22, 2014 at 12:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York City.

PELUSO--Frank, of New York, passed away suddenly of congestive heart failure, at home with his beloved wife Emi, at his side on May 14, 2014. An accomplished singer, Frank and Emi (nee) Yamamoto, met in a production of the opera, La Rondine, in which Frank was the starring tenor. Frank Peluso was born on May 16, 1937 into a loving Italian family, and raised in Brooklyn, NY. As a child, Frank was an exceptional tap dancer. He performed regularly in the Horn and Hardart Children's hour on major television networks. After graduating Magna Cum Laude from Princeton University in Mathematical Physics, Frank began his illustrious Wall Street career as a financial advisor. In addition to his wife, Emi, he is survived by his daughter, Desiree Hoffman, from a previous marriage, as well as four grandchildren, Christian, Ariel, Jean Luc, and Axel. Arrangements are pending.

GROSSMAN--Pearl, on May 13, 2014 at 95 years. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Loving mother of the late Robert and the late Lynn. Mother-in-law of Laura. Cherished grandmother of Sara and her husband Max Kane. Devoted great-grandmother of Ethan and Sydney.

KENNEDY--Hon. Cornelia Groefsema, of Grosse Pointe Woods, Michigan passed away on May 12, 2014. She died peacefully at home surrounded by her family. Judge Kennedy was born in Detroit on August 4, 1923. She earned a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Michigan; and, like her father, mother, and older sister, she attended the University of Michigan Law School, graduating in 1947. She subsequently clerked for the Honorable Harold W. Stephens, Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. She was the first woman to clerk for that court, which is considered second only to the Supreme Court of the United States. After 20 years in private practice in Detroit, she was elected to the Wayne County (Michigan) Circuit Court. In 1970 President Richard M. Nixon appointed her to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. She was the first woman to sit on that court, and in 1977 she became the first female chief judge of a federal district court in the United States. She was elevated to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit by President Jimmy Carter in 1979. She was the second woman to sit on that court, and she held that position until her retirement on June 30, 2012. At the time of her appointment, Judge Kennedy was jokingly given the hot plate on which the first female judge of the Sixth Circuit, the Honorable Florence E. Allen, had warmed her lunch. Judge Allen's fellow judges had belonged to an all male private club that did not admit women, thus precluding their female peer from eating with them. Judge Kennedy was eventually admitted as the first female member of that club although the maitre d' initially refused to seat her because he was unaware of the change in club policy and her subsequent membership. Judge Kennedy and her sister, the Honorable Margaret G. Schaeffer, were the first sister judges in the United States. Judge Schaeffer sat on the 47th District Court in Farmington Hills, Michigan from 1974 1992. Judge Kennedy was an avid traveler, visiting all seven continents, more than 80 countries, and 49 states. After her husband had died, she enjoyed traveling with her two sisters on University of Michigan tours with their husbands and on week-end getaways with their adult daughters. The granddaughter of Dutch immigrant farmers in Idaho, Judge Kennedy spent her week-ends gardening. She was also a passionate reader, especially enjoying historical non-fiction and British mysteries. Judge Kennedy was pre-deceased by her husband, Charles S. Kennedy, Jr.; her parents, Elmer H. and M. Blanche Gibbons Groefsema; and her sisters, Ann Jean Groefsema and Margaret G. Schaeffer. Judge Kennedy is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Charles S. and Angela Kennedy; her grandchildren, Elizabeth and Matthew; her sister, Dr. Christine G. Gram; and 28 nieces and nephews. Judge Kennedy was devoted to them all, and she will be remembered lovingly. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 27, 2014 at 11:00am at Grosse Pointe Congregational Church. A luncheon will follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to The Honorable Cornelia G. Kennedy Scholarship, c/o Alexandra Haddad, University of Michigan Law School, 701 S. State St., Suite 4000, Ann Arbor, MI 48109. Services handled by Chas. Verheyden Funeral Home, Inc. Light a candle and share a memory at: verheyden.org

MARKLE--Mary E. Passed away peacefully on Thursday, May 8, 2014 in Sun City, AZ at the age of 90. Beloved wife of Roger A. Markle, she is survived by her grandsons Michael Donofrio, Alan Dendinger, and Eric Dendinger and was predeceased by her daughters, Sandra D'Onofrio and Barbara Dendinger. Mary was one of a kind and lived life her own way with great optimism and zest. Her spirit and love will remain with us forever.

PATTERSON--Anne Hyde Choate, Died peacefully in her home in Hobe Sound, FL, on May 11, 2014, at the age of 95. Born in New York to Arthur Osgood Choate and Anne Hyde Clarke Choate, she attended St. Timothy's School and Columbia University. She and her husband of 64 years, Ellmore Clark Patterson, who died in 2004, lived in Westchester County, New York City, Fisher's Island, NY, and Hobe Sound, and raised five sons, Michael, Arthur, Robert, David and Thomas Patterson, who survive her along with their wives and fourteen grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren, of all of whom she was immensely proud. She will be remembered by her loving family and all who knew her as athletic, spunky, interested and smart, with a quick and challenging mind. Her family asks that you consider a contribution in her memory to Island Health Project, Fisher's Island, Inc., PO Box 344, Fisher's Island, NY 06390.

LEVIN--Gabrielle Rochelle, 78, of Manhattan, died May 11, 2014. Born August 14, 1935 in Magdeburg, Germany to Kurt and Edith Aronsohn, she grew up in Lancaster, PA and Miami Beach, FL. An alumna of the Charles E. Ellis School of Newton Square, PA, she attended the University of Miami at Coral Gables and the Dante Alighiere University in Rome. Always creatively artistic, she became an accomplished potter late in life. Former spouse of the late writer Ira Levin, she is survived by three sons, Adam Levin-Delson of Bothell WA, Jared Levin of Hastings-on-Hudson and Nicholas Levin of Manhattan, and four grandsons. Memorial service was held May 15 at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations to the ASPCA.

POLAK--Catharina "Ina" Soep. Ira and I would like to extend our deepest and most sincere condolences to Jack and the Polak family on their most tragic loss. Ina was the epitome of elegance, beauty, charm and wit. She represented all that was bright and hopeful. We considered her Dutch Royalty, a brave survivor and representative of the best that came to America. She was loved by all she met and will be missed by all. The Polak family has made a very big influence in our lives both legal and social. I idolized Ina and tried to comport myself the way Ina did. With heartfelt sympathy, Joan and Ira Berman

PINCUS--William, Passed away May 15, 2014 at age 94 and in the 74th year of his marriage to Elsa. William was the loving husband of Elsa, devoted father of Susan Rachel and Jillian Pincus and the late Lanni Tama, loving grandfather of Jordan Tama, and adoring great-grandfather of Amos and Jesse Tama and their mother Julia Tama, dedicated brother of the late Beatrice Levine, and admired uncle to his nieces and nephews. As a dedicated family man in good and bad times, he never missed a family rite of passage. He always "took care of everything" whenever needed. William had a big presence in life matched only by his love of life. He enjoyed traveling the world, investigating new cultures, and collecting art and cultural objects. Before any travel, he would read about the culture and area to be visited, often serving as his own travel guide. Fine food and wine were something to be savored. He loved theater, art, dancing, swimming (especially in the ocean), and knowledge in general. These loves were passed on to his appreciative family. William had the wonderful experience of seeing the natural beauty of the United States in the early 1950s as part of his work in the National Park Service; he wanted to share this experience with his family. Especially remembered are the two resulting cross-USA driving trips in 1953 and 1959 with his wife and three daughters to visit the National Parks -- quite a challenge back then. William was born on April 29, 1920 in Philadelphia and received a B.A. in Government from Brooklyn College (1940), an M.A. in Public Administration from American University (1948), and a J.D. from George Washington University (1953). William worked for the Federal Government from 1941 to 1957. His appointments there included advisory and managerial positions in the War Department (Lend Lease Depot), Bureau of the Budget, Bureau of Land Management, First and Second Hoover Commissions, and the U.S. Congress. Some of his government work resulted in major reorganization of government agencies. From 1957 to 1968, William worked in the government and law division of the Ford Foundation, responsible for making grants for new directions in legal education and for research to improve the administration of justice. His most lasting work as President of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibility (CLEPR) started in 1968, CLEPR was responsible for reforms in the system of legal education by starting the clinical movement in law school curriculums and providing law students with real-life professional responsibilities and exposure to the people-oriented aspect of the legal profession. Creative and pioneering CLEPR projects resulted in clinical programs existing in almost every U.S. law school and internationally. In his lifetime, William worked tirelessly to establish clinical legal education as an Important part of legal studies and as an especially effective means for teaching professional responsibility. Administration of clinical justice and the attainment of the ideal of equal justice under the law were of paramount importance to him. William's dedication to Justice and clinical education were recognized by many legal organizations. He was the recipient of the President's Medal from The Catholic University of America for his pioneering work in clinical legal education and he received an honorary doctorate of laws from Georgetown in Washington, DC. The Association of American Law Schools (AALS) clinical section yearly bestows The William Pincus Award in his honor to one or more Individuals or institutions that have effected outstanding contributions to the cause of clinical legal education. William is missed by his loving family. Services: Sunday, May 18, 2014 at 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

FIDLER--Sylvia Glick, passed peacefully this Shabbos. Loving and devoted mother to Elliot and Chris, Lewis and Robin, and Ronna and Seth; grandma to Ethan and Ilana, Jason, Melanie, Jaclyn, Max, Harry and Adam; devoted wife to the late Milton; doting great-grandmother to Jacob Seth and Mia Rose; daughter of the late Louis and Dora Glick. She will be loved and missed by all. She was our rock.

BALDUZZI--George Robert, age 74, of Palm City, FL, formerly of New York, NY and Short Hills, NJ, May 16, 2014. Wall Street institutional trader for 40 years. Managing Director of Institutional Sales Trading at Salomon Brothers. Director of the sales and trading desk of C.S. First Boston, a former investment banking division of the Credit Suisse Group. Chairman, Upstairs Traders Advisory Committee to the New York Stock Exchange Board of Directors. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School, New York, NY and the City College of New York, Baruch School of Business. Son of the late Mary Rizzo Balduzzi and the late Joseph Balduzzi. Brother of the late Marie Balduzzi Beck, Gloria Mileaf Sausville and Howard Mileaf. Beloved husband of Cindy Ellen Balduzzi of Palm City, FL. Adored father of Jennifer Balduzzi of Washingtonville, NY, Jessica Weissman of Plantation, FL and Julia May of New York, NY. Cherished grandfather of Jordan Alison Bowes, Jonathan George Bowes, Samantha Hayley Weiner and Roy Weissman. Respected father-in-law of Zeev Weissman and Ryan Patrick May. Private memorial services to be held in Palm City, FL and New York, NY. Gifts in his memory may be sent to Hope Rural School, 15929 S.W. 150th Street, Indiantown, FL 34956 or Habitat for Humanity http://www.habitat.org/support/giftfromtheheart.

ERICKSON--Mira Nikolic, 73, of Greenwich Village. Born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the daughter of Ratomir and Katarina Nikolic and sister of Rada Nikolic. Beloved wife of 43 years of Ken, and his best friend, companion in adventures, and fearless copyediting critic. Beloved mother of Ingrid. Loved sister-in-law of Peter R. Erickson. Studied first at the University of Belgrade, then graduated from Smith College. Creative and innovative teacher, mentor, administrator, and advocate of integrity in education and of the causes of immigrants and newcomers. Devoted her talents at the International Center of Catholic Charities in service of immigrants. As she summed it up, the Center's services enabled them to go "from newcomer to New Yorker." A memorial event to celebrate her life will be arranged for June. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Catholic Charities, for the International Center.

ADLER--Sol. May you be remembered for the nearly four decades of service to the 92nd St. Y, your commitment to the Jewish community, and the many kindnesses you bestowed on those around you. My heart and love to Debbie, Ron, Louis, Mathew, Doris, Anita and the entire family. Sol, may you rest in peace. Helaine Geismar Katz

DIVET--Andre Jean, born March 5, 1926 in Paris, France. At an early age he found his love of drawing. He applied and was accepted to the acclaimed Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris as one of the youngest students at the age of 14 years old. He stayed in Paris during the War, and recalled all that was going on at that time. His first job was at Publicis working in advertising. He moved to New York in 1952. During the 50's, 60's and 70's, he worked as a Creative Art Director at J. Walter Thompson, Sullivan, Stoffer, Colwell & Bayles (SSC&B), Damien Bisch and Partners, putting story boards together on accounts like Eastern Airlines, and then on to working as a freelance artist way into his 70's. He died on May 11, 2014 at the age of 88 years old. He is survived by his wife, Monique, his daughter Carole Divet Harting, granddaughter, Chloe and son-in-law, Bruce Harting.

EDELMAN--George, age 93, of Schroon Lake, NY and Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice; proud and loving father of Richard and Sara Edelman, Laurie Edelman, and Jamie and Mark Pollack; adoring grandfather of Jessica Pollack, Alison and A.J. Elbert, Max and Jill Edelman, and Aimee Anker; "Zaide George" to his beautiful great-grandchildren, Dexter and Samantha Edelman and Angelina Anker; devoted uncle to Jonathan Prenner and Stacey Prenner Harel and their families; treasured cousin to Sylvia and David Posner, Rachel Posner Warshauer and Raphael Posner and their families, and the Ingber, Fuks and Scheiner families, cherished friend to so many. He was a life-long educator and the Director of Camp Idylwold, who quietly mentored and guided his students, campers and counselors; a veteran of World War II; and a grateful alumnus of Brooklyn College, where he served on the Board of the Brooklyn College Alumni Association. Funeral Service Sunday, May 18, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

CONRAD--Julie Jacobs, Daughter of Susie and Philip Jacobs of Louisville, KY, lost her heroic battle of more than two years with appendix cancer on May 13, 2014. Jacobs, 53, is survived by her loving husband Eric Conrad, devoted sister and brother-in-law Marcie and Gary Klein, adoring nephew Brady Klein, and in-laws Ari and Betty Chisin. Her bravery and grace dealing with the daily challenges of her disease inspire and astound all who knew and loved her. Julie created a full, rich life in New York City as a communications professional, with a passion for committing her considerable intellect and compassion to improving the lives of others. She was a trusted advisor to the Skoll Foundation and the Wealth & Giving Forum. Julie's legacy will live on with Julie's Fund for Girls' Empowerment, a program of the Lerner Family Foundation (LFF), formed by her Uncle, Donald Lerner, to support nonprofits working in foster care. Donations may be made via The Lerner Family Foundation, 1545 Hillview Drive, Sarasota, FL 34239.

CASTENIR--Ralph. Born in Bradford, PA and died on May 15th, 2014 in New York City. Ralph, a graduate of Pratt Institute, was a talented graphic designer and beloved co-owner of New York's landmark restaurant Il Vagabondo for nearly 50 years. He is survived by his wife Betsy Castenir; a sister Gloria Hannan; sisters-in-law Carole Castenir and Amy Castenir and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for Wednesday, May 21st at 6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street, NYC.

CHESNEY--Carolyn Elizabeth, 86, died January 16, 2014 comforted by her caregivers and the loyal staff at The National Arts Club, her home of the past 50 years. She was born July 4, 1927 in Pittsfield, MA to Malcolm McKay and Helen Waldron Chesney. She is predeceased by her brothers Malcolm Jr. and Waldron W. Chesney. She is survived by her brother Robert W. Chesney in addition to nieces and nephews around the country. Carolyn was a graduate of the Walnut Hill School of Art in Natick, MA and continued to study art her entire life. In addition to being a prolific sketcher, her work included oil portraits, watercolor landscapes and sculpture. Professionally she was an editor at House Beautiful magazine. The Chesney family extends their deepest appreciation to the staff and members of The National Arts Club for their dedication and love in caring for our Aunt Carolyn.

BREEN--Dr. Timothy J.,a native of the borough of Manhattan, died in Redwood City, CA on September 29, 2013 after braving a debilitating illness. He was 60 years old. Dr. Breen is survived by his wife Rosemerrie, along with four siblings, Major Daniel Breen USAF Reserves, Richard Breen, Dr. Robert Breen, M.D. and Mrs. Patricia O'Lear. Dr. Breen is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Breen, formerly of Manhattan who now reside in Maryland. Dr. Breen, a former assistant professor of biostatistics at the Medical College of Virginia, worked as a published research author and statistician for the United Network of Organ Sharing (UNOS) prior to his career in South San Francisco at Genentech where he served as both a clinical scientist and as a medical director. A graduate of the SUNY at Stony Brook, Dr. Breen completed both his master and doctorate work at the University of Florida in 1983. Friends may gather for Dr. Breen's funeral mass on May 24, 2014 to be held at the Lady Chapel of The Church of Saint Ignatius Loyola at 5pm on Saturday evening. His widow will lay his body to rest at sea following an Irish celebration on Sunday afternoon. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Dr. Breen's memory to any chapter of the ASPCA is very much appreciated.

SEMLER--Evelyn Williams, a longtime New Yorker, died April 28 at the age of 92. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College and Columbia University, she worked at the Metropolitan Museum for many years. She was predeceased by her beloved husband George in 1997. They enjoyed music and extensive travels around the world and were both active members of St. James Episcopal Church, the Cosmopolitan Club and the Blue Hill Troupe. Survived by a nephew, Stewart Williams(swilliams@dfwefh.com), a niece, Deborah Brooks, many great-nieces and nephews and members of the Semler family. Services will be held May 31 at 2pm at the Crown Hill Memorial Park Chapel in Kirkland, NY near her hometown of Utica.

ABATE--Catherine Marie, on May 17, 2014. Beloved wife of Ronald Kliegerman. Devoted Mother of Kyle (Lisa) Kliegerman. Loving Sister of Joseph Abate. Fond Stepmother of Kip (Suzanne) Kliegerman. A service will take place at Frank E. Campbell- The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Wednesday 1:15pm. Mass of Christian Burial St. Jean Baptiste Church, East 76th Street and Lexington Ave, Thursday at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Catherine's name to Community Healthcare Network, 60 Madison Ave 5th floor, NY, NY 10010, designated for Holistic Center.

ROSOFF--Jeannie Isabelle, 1924--2014. Jeannie Rosoff of Chevy Chase, MD died peacefully on Monday May 12, 2014. She is lovingly remembered by her daughter Ann Rosoff-Cappelletti, son-in-law John Cappelletti, grandchildren Sara and Daniel, and long-time friends and colleagues. She dedicated much of her life to advancing women's reproductive health by shaping research and public policy over her many years with the Guttmacher Institute and Planned Parenthood (more on her life's work is found on www.guttmacher.org). In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to these organizations. In keeping with her wishes, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Online condolences and fond memories may be offered to the family through the New York Times online guestbook.

SHOPKORN--Edward, 67, of Chappaqua, NY passed away on May 18, 2014 surrounded by his adoring family. Beloved husband of Susan, proud father of Amy, Kate, Nicole and Danielle, respected father-in-law of Jennifer, Jason, Eric and Hayim, cherished Popi to Alison, Alex, Jack, Julia, Matthew and Olivia, and loyal brother to Stanley. Born in the Bronx and a life-long New York Giants and Yankees fan, Ed served as a First Lieutenant in the US Army prior to a long career as an institutional equities trader. Ed will be remembered for his generous spirit, sharp wit and unyielding love of sharing good times with those he loved. A private family service will be held on Tuesday, May 20.

ANTONACCIO--Charles. January 11, 1921-May 17, 2014. Beloved husband of Therese, cherished father of Carla and Maria. Visitation Beecher Flooks, Pleasantville, 2-4, 6-8 pm May 21; funeral 10 a.m. May 22, St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua NY

SAUERHOFF--Harriet, June 1, 1922 - May 15, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Irving for 66 years; devoted mother to Mitch (Ronna), Jeff (Naomi) and Claire; adored grandmother of Gabe (Lee), Alex, and Zach; loving great-grandmother to Quinn, Cade and Brody. She was proud of the Jewish home she created, and was more courageous and determined than many realized. There is a big hole in our hearts and in our family. Donations to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, NYC or Jericho Jewish Center.
DARVIN--Renee. Memories and love live on forever. Always, Jerry

ETRA--Marilyn, 90, wife of the late Mortimer U. Etra. Survived by daughters Susan Coleman and her husband Bill, and Caren Geberer and her husband Noah. Beloved grandmother of Rachel (Joseph), Nora, Reese, Jake, and Cole. Adored great-grandmother of Marc and Mia. Recently pre-deceased by her devoted sister Ruth Garfinkel. Lovingly cared for by Blossom Blair.

SCHULMAN--Carol, died peacefully at home May 18, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Marjorie, Nancy Soiefer and Rick and mother-in-law of Ross Smith, Andrew Soiefer and Debbie. Loving sister of Floyd Abrams. Cherished grandmother of Laura and Mark, Rebecca, Leland, Ben, Kayla, Spencer, and Austin and great-grandmother of Robert. Services Thursday 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Schulman Family Foundation, PMB 402, 275 Rte 10 E, Suite 220, Succasunna, NJ 07876-1358.

STORYK--Ruth G.,90, in Sarasota, FL on May 13. Survived by her husband Leslie, son John (Beth), and grandchildren Nadine Curtis, Keaton (Emma), Corbett, Elisa, great-grandson Pixley, and her friend of 75 years Richard Sussman of Palm Beach, FL. We will forever remember her smile, her always present optimism, and her love of life.

CASTENIR--Ralph. Born in Bradford, PA and died on May 15th, 2014 in New York City. Ralph, a graduate of Pratt Institute, was a talented graphic designer and beloved co-owner of New York's landmark restaurant Il Vagabondo for nearly 50 years. He is survived by his wife Betsy Castenir; a sister Gloria Hannan; sisters-in-law Carole Castenir and Amy Castenir; brother-in-law, Raymond Dombrowski and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for Wednesday, May 21st at 6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street, NYC.

ODELL--Ripley Scotten, Died peacefully at home on May 16, 2014 at the age of 64. Beloved husband of Kathy Schuman. Rip embraced all of life's great bounty with curiosity, boundless enthusiasm and humor, qualities also evident in his wonderful photography. Always focused on the positive, he approached each day with eager anticipation, and lived them all to the fullest, never complaining about life's setbacks. His great warmth, kindness and generosity made him a dear friend to many and inspired all who had the great fortune to know him. His spirit lives on in our hearts.

Shopkorn. Edward was very kind to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to Stanley Shopkorn and the entire Shopkorn family. KOCHMAN--Arlene Klarfeld, LCSW, 76, passed away suddenly early Friday morning on May, 16, 2014. Beloved wife of Lea Borenheim for 34 years, Mother to son Paul (his wife Patti), daughter Fran, son Tedd (and his wife Randi) and beloved grandmother to Justin, Millie, Adam, Lucy and Noah. Arlene was a practicing social worker for over 40 years. In 1985, after returning from Israel, where she was National Inspector For Family Treatment, Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs, Arlene became involved with SAGE and was Executive Director for twelve years. She was an advocate in the field of Aging and in Gay and Lesbian Aging in New York City and across the country. Her current work was with PATH through Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health at Callen-Lorde Community Health Center. Arlene was also a practicing psychotherapist with her own private practice. Arlene had a passion for the causes she worked for, was always positive and looked to where each experience would take her next. Arlene has affected all our lives. She will be missed dearly by many and will be remembered in our hearts forever.

SADOLF--Milton, 87, died on May 8, 2014 in New York City, of natural causes. A native New Yorker and a Veteran of World War II, Milton was a graduate of the City College of New York, the New York School of Interior Design and Pratt Institute. He was a librarian at the New York Public Library from 1960 to 1988, from 1968, in the Picture Collection at 42nd Street. He is survived by his wife, Judith Bartlett, his sister, Rosalind Reisman, of Jamesburg, NJ, a niece, Marlene Reisman, of New York City and his nephews, Stephen Reisman, of Nashville TN and David Reisman of Istanbul, Turkey. Milton was a sweet and gentle man; he will be sorely missed.

FEINSTEIN--Howard The Board of Trustees of the Sr. Rose Thering Fund, Seton Hall University, mourns the passing of Howard Feinstein of Marlboro, NJ. Our deepest condolences to his wife Susan, founder and vice chairman of the board, and their family.With heartfelt sympathy, David Bossman, Exec. Dir. Deborah Lerner Duane, Chairman Marilyn Zirl, Administrator

ROBERTS--Malvina (Mimi), at home on May 18, 2014.Beloved wife of the late Michael A., devoted motherof Alec and Barbara, Judy and Mark, adored grandmotherof Jessica, Molly and Benjamin. Service private.

ROSENTHAL--Doris L.,95 died May 17, 2014. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Karen Worchel (Herbert) and Ronnie Rosenthal. Devoted grandmother of Cori, Dana and Lauren. Great- grandmother of Lucas, Jacob, Sasha, Matthew and Chloe. Sister of Gloria Steinberg. Service today (Monday) 10:00am Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.
RAMSON--Murray, May 15, 2014, loving husband of Carlena, beloved father of Gamiel (Amy) and Seth, proud grandfather of Joelle, loving brother of Ruth (Harry) Federbush. Services private.

JACOBS--Marshall, originally of Toledo, Ohio, passed away on April 26, 2014 in Palo Alto, California, weeks shy of his 95th birthday. For more than a half century, Marshall enjoyed a sophisticated legal practice in New York City, and was a founder of the Jacobs, Persinger & Parker law firm. An avid student of history and occasional owner of not very fast racehorses, Marshall lived a full and interesting life. Those who had the good fortune to know him were constantly touched by his decency, integrity, wise counsel and dry sense of humor. Marshall is survived by his loving wife, Kathy, his sons John and James, and his three grandchildren. He will be sorely missed by all. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Cancer Society.

MacDONALD--Robert Ian. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain are greatly saddened by the death of Robert Ian MacDonald in Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, on 12 May. Robert MacDonald had deep roots in England, Scotland, and America. His paternal great-grandfather, George MacDonald, was a well-known Scottish writer whose book The Light Princess was recently turned into a successful musical at the National Theatre in London. His maternal great-grandfather was Charles Pratt of Brooklyn, a director of Standard Oil and the founder of the Pratt Institute. Robert worked as an investor in London and as a lifelong dairy farmer on his family's estate in Devon. He also took a keen interest in the theatrical world in London and New York and backed a number of plays, including The Light Princess. Like his mother before him, Robert MacDonald was an ardent supporter of the American Museum. In 2011, during the Museum's fiftieth-anniversary year, he was presented with the Dallas Pratt Commemorative Medal, named after one of the Museum's co-founders, who was also a descendant of one of Standard Oil's founding families. Robert's wife, Carolyn MacDonald, served as Deputy Chair of the Museum's trustees and continues to serve as a director of the Halcyon Foundation in New York. His generosity, friendship and dry wit will be deeply missed. Richard Wendorf, FSA, Director, Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman, Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman, American Museum in Britain, Linda Hackett, President, Halcyon Foundation

SCHULMAN--Carol, died peacefully at home May 18, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Marjorie, Nancy Soiefer and Rick and mother-in-law of Ross Smith, Andrew Soiefer and Debbie. Loving sister of Floyd Abrams. Cherished grandmother of Laura and Mark, Rebecca, Leland, Ben, Kayla, Spencer, and Austin and great-grandmother of Robert. Services Thursday 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Schulman Family Foundation, PMB 402, 275 Rte 10 E, Suite 220, Succasunna, NJ 07876-1358.

HIBBEN--Craig Rittenhouse, PhD, a longtime resident of Yorktown Heights, lost his battle with cancer on May 9, 2014. He was born May 25, 1930 in Montclair, NJ, to the late Samuel and Ruth Hibben. He leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Eleanor, son David R. Hibben of Stanley, NC, daughter Julie Hibben Diehl of Woodsboro, MD, nine grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. He is also survived by sister Eleanor Waddell of Dallas, TX and brother Stuart Hibben of Swarthmore, PA. Family and friends will celebrate Craig's life on Saturday, May 24th at the First Presbyterian Church of Yorktown at 2:00pm, followed by a reception in the fellowship hall. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the First Presbyterian Church of Yorktown endowment fund at 2880 Crompond Road, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598.

HEWITT--Roni. The trustees and staff of the Children's All Day School in New York City are deeply saddened by the death of Roni Hewitt, our Founder and Director for 39 years. Our beloved Roni passed away May 16th, 2014 after a long-term illness. She was an educator, an artist and a cherished friend who will be sorely missed by all who knew her. We will miss her wisdom, her compassion and her commitment to the children of CADS and to her faculty. We express our deepest sympathies to her loving husband Angelo Sakonas, to her children Kelly Borges and Cory Hewitt, and to all the cherished members of her family. Susan Birnbaum, Director The Board of Trustees

MEILMAN--Alayne, a 50-year resident of Scarsdale, passed away peacefully on May 18, 2014. Myron, her husband of 60 years, was by her side. She was a beloved mother to Jodi Andreozzi, Michelle Glick, and Clifford Meilman. Adoring grandmother to Tyler, Jesse, Zachary, Courtney, Erica, and Troy. She is survived by her sister, Gladys Coffino, of Coconut Creek, Florida. Alayne had a gentle, loving affect and unwavering devotion to her family. She lived a fulfilling 81 years, and touched many lives. Whether it was her role as a wife, mother, grandmother, sister, or aunt, she always made sure to give all her love to everyone. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, May 20, at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon NY. Her family will be sitting Shiva at the Meilman residence in Scarsdale.

ADAMS--Sophia, died peacefully on May 13. Born in St. Louis, Missouri on October 15, 1917 she lived a long and remarkable life. A gifted ballet teacher, she touched the lives of hundreds of children. She passionately loved the theatre and politics and was unendingly curious about the world. Proud mother of Jody Adams, mother-in-law of Carl Weisbrod, and grandmother of Bill Weisbrod. Predeceased by her sister, Victoria Mullen, and brother, Anthony Twaron, she is survived by many loving nieces and nephews and their families. Memorial to be announced.

BREEN--Dr. Timothy J.,a native of the borough of Manhattan, died in Redwood City, CA on September 29, 2013 after braving a debilitating illness. He was 60 years old. Dr. Breen is survived by his wife Rosemerrie, along with four siblings, Major Daniel Breen USAF Reserves, Richard Breen, Dr. Robert Breen, M.D. and Mrs. Patricia O'Lear. Dr. Breen is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Breen, formerly of Manhattan who now reside in Maryland. Dr. Breen, a former assistant professor of biostatistics at the Medical College of Virginia, worked as a published research author and statistician for the United Network of Organ Sharing (UNOS) prior to his career in South San Francisco at Genentech where he served as both a clinical scientist and as a medical director. A graduate of the SUNY at Stony Brook, Dr. Breen completed both his master and doctorate work at the University of Florida in 1983. Friends may gather for Dr. Breen's funeral mass on May 24, 2014 to be held at the Lady Chapel of The Church of Saint Ignatius Loyola at 5pm on Saturday evening. His widow will lay his body to rest at sea following an Irish celebration on Sunday afternoon. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Dr. Breen's memory to any chapter of the ASPCA is very much appreciated.

BLISS--Carmen C. "Cassie", (1982-2014) died on May 18, 2014. Born February 19, 1986. Predeceased by father, Richard Bliss and survived by mother, Alicia Bliss and siblings, Jackie, Rick, Steve, Laura, Alyssa, and Sara. She also leaves behind her beloved nieces and nephews, Clara, Tucker, Charlie, Sam, Julia, Ana, Ella, Elliott and Liv. Cassie was a graduate of Hunter College, and Ms. Porter's School. A loving and caring teacher at The International Preschool, Cassie was beloved by all and she will be greatly missed. Celebration of life to take place at the Church of St Thomas More, 65 East 89th St, at 10am Thursday, May 22nd.
CHAYT--Maurice, our good friend, lawyer, neighbor. We will miss you. Rhoda and Herb Kadison.
CHAYT--Maurice. Only a generous spirit could exceed your legal acumen. Good night sweet prince. Max

GUNTER--Phyllis E.,Ansonia Independent Democrats mourn the loss of their beloved colleague who died on May 18, 2014 in New York City. A long-time member, former President and District Leader of Ansonia; Community Board member, anti-violence, anti-war and dedicated activist of the Upper West Side always helping those in need. A staunch believer in equality and justice for all. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences to her family.

BUTCHER--Ernesto L. Calvary Hospital mourns the passing of Calvary Fund Board Director Ernesto L. Butcher. Ernesto joined the Board in 2007, and he soon became an active and dedicated Director. His service included thoughtful leadership as a member of the Fund's Governance Committee. We are grateful for Ernesto's calm and steady presence on the Fund Board, and for his devotion to Calvary's patients and their loved ones. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Kristen, and to his entire family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Steven J. Golub, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, President & CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund

HABER--Martin W.,on May 17, 2014. WWII Veteran. Loving husband to Ruth. Father to Lynn, Steven and Jeff. Grandfather to Lauren, Matthew, Jonathon and Maya. Brother to Herbert. Devoted to family and his life long passion for his garden. Services to be held on Tuesday, May 20 at 11:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels in Hewlett, NY.

ABATE--Catherine Marie, on May 17, 2014. Beloved wife of Ronald Kliegerman. Devoted Mother of Kyle (Lisa) Kliegerman. Loving Sister of Joseph Abate. Fond Stepmother of Kip (Suzanne) Kliegerman. A service will take place at Frank E. Campbell- The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Wednesday 1:15pm. Mass of Christian Burial St. Jean Baptiste Church, East 76th Street and Lexington Ave, Thursday at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Catherine's name to Community Healthcare Network, 60 Madison Ave 5th floor, NY, NY 10010, designated for Holistic Center.

HAVAS-DE SIMONE--Anna, 100. Beloved wife of the late Michael Havas, died peacefully on May 18, 2014. An Italian (Naples) by birth, and a proud U.S. citizen by marriage, she followed her husband in his assignments as top manager of movie companies in Latin America, France and U.K. Moved back to U.S.A. after her husband's retirement, first in Arizona, then in California, and finally in New York City. She is survived by her niece Serenella and her nephew Guido, both living in Italy.

GOODWIN--Richard Peter. Richard Peter Goodwin (Dick Goodwin) born November 13, 1928, died May 18, 2014 at home. Loved by his wife, Irene; praised by his children, Richard Jr. and Ellen; mimed by his grandsons, Richard III and John Pohmer; cared for by son-in-law Kurt Pohmer; brother of Robert, deceased; brother of Frank, deceased. Past Mayor of Brookville, 17 years; Past Police Commissioner of Old Brookville, seven years; President of Richard P. Goodwin Associates, 40 years; Director, American Community Bank; Past President, Garden City Rotary; Retired New York City Fireman; New York City Policeman, five years Veteran, Korean War; Parishioner, St. Paul the Apostle Church in Brookville, 30+ years; Enthusiastic family man. Avid golfer, squash player, tennis player, platform player, skier. Missed by all... so vital... so caring... so much fun... Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road; Syosset, 7-9pm Tuesday; 2-4pm, 7-9pm Wednesday; Mass at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Brookville, 10am, Thursday. The family is grateful for gifts in memory of Dick...to The Interfaith Nutrition Network (The INN, 211 Fulton St., Hempstead, NY 11550), to Mommas House (Mommas Inc., 1857 Wantagh Ave., Wantagh, NY 11793), to St. Paul the Apostle Church, to a favorite charity.

EDELMAN--Gerald M. The Trustees of Neurosciences Research Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of Gerald M. Edelman, who was the Foundation's President and leader for the last three decades. Under the aegis of the Foundation, he was the founding Director of The Neurosciences Institute, where he fostered interactions among scientists from multiple disciplines to increase our understanding of how we perceive and act upon the world, how we learn and remember, and how consciousness arises. His many experimental and theoretical contributions to biology in immunology, embryological development, molecular cell biology, and neuroscience will continue to benefit mankind and lead the way to future discoveries. He had an exemplary knowledge of science, music, literature, and the visual arts. A brilliant speaker, raconteur, wit, writer for both scientific and lay audiences, and observer of the human condition, he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, and friends.

ABATE--Catherine M.,The Board of Directors and staff of Community Healthcare Network (CHN) mourn the passing of our beloved and dynamic President and Chief Executive Officer. CHN was Catherine's passion, and we share her loss with the family, her husband Ron Kleigerman, son Kyle Kleigerman and his wife Lisa, and many dear friends to whom we extend our heartfelt condolences. She joined CHN 15 years ago following decades of work in the criminal justice field and after serving as the distinguished State Senator representing Chelsea and the West Village. She was a tremendous advocate for the health care needs of all those most at risk and a visionary and tenacious leader who always seemed able to marshal the resources for new and innovative programs. During her tenure, CHN quadrupled in size and moved from women's health services to offering a full range of primary care for individuals of all ages. Catherine wasn't satisfied with just being bigger, she inspired us all to want to be better. Thanks to her leadership, CHN pioneered successful new programs for teens, LGBT individuals and people with multiple chronic illnesses. She paved the way for all of CHN's clinics to receive FQHC status, Joint Commission accreditation and numerous other distinctions of quality and effectiveness. The CHN family remains committed to Catherine's lifelong dedication to social and economic justice in health care. Our loss is shared by all New Yorkers as we honor her invaluable contributions across a lifetime of public service.

EDELMAN--Dr. Gerald M. The Directors, officers and staff of General American Investors Company, Inc. are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Gerald M. Edelman, who served the Company with great dedication for more than 38 years as a Director. His wisdom, judgment and counsel were highly regarded by the Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Maxine, his children, other members of his family, colleagues and friends. Spencer Davidson Chairman, Board of Directors

ANTONACCIO--Charles. January 11, 1921-May 17, 2014. Beloved husband of Therese, cherished father of Carla and Maria. Visitation Beecher Flooks, Pleasantville, 2-4, 6-8 pm May 21; funeral 10 a.m. May 22, St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua NY

DRIER--Marilyn, 88, died May 18 in Deerfield Beach, FL. A proud graduate of Hunter College, class of 1946, she taught elementary school in the Poughkeepsie area. She was an active union member, world traveler, and devoted in retirement to the League of Women Voters in Palm Beach County. Married to Ed for 67 years, she outlived him by 10 months and she kept alive the memory of their dear daughter Janet for 62 years. Survived by sons Kenneth and Jeffrey and nieces Linda and Carol Greenhouse, along with generations of students whose minds she opened to the world. Sleep, sweet, sleep.

MacDONALD--Robert Ian, Robert Ian MacDonald, died quietly in Nassau, the Bahamas on May 12th. He left this world as he lived in it, with elegance, courage and humility. Born in 1928 in London to a life less ordinary, he had deep roots in England, America and Scotland. In addition to the Bahamas, he maintained residences in New York, London and Devon for more than eighty years. His paternal great-grandfather, George MacDonald, was the Victorian poet and author whose book, "The Light Princess", was recently turned into a successful musical at the National Theatre in London. His maternal great grandfather was Charles Pratt of Brooklyn, a partner in Standard Oil who also founded the Pratt Institute. His mother, Helen Babbott MacDonald and his father, Ian MacDonald, both served the cause of freedom during the Second World War in England. His father returned to the Army and was stationed in Churchill's London map room. Helen MacDonald was head of the Red Cross and Army Officer's Club in Salcombe while the allies prepared for the Normandy invasion on the beaches near Gullet, the family farm in Devon. During the war years, Robert was evacuated to America where he attended the Pomfret School and spent four happy years with his American cousins in Bernardsville, New Jersey. With the surrender of the Germans in 1945, he left school and returned to Britain with other evacuees on a Royal Navy battleship. He attended Millfield School in Somerset, England to prepare for the Royal Marines' exam and was granted his commission by King George VI. Following service to King and Country, he became the first trainee for the Mobil Oil Corporation in England. Later, he worked for Lloyds in the City of London and managed the family farm in Devon. As a lifelong dairy farmer, he especially prized his pedigree herd of Ayrshire cows. In later years, he would became the head of his family's New York based foundation. He was particularly interested in trans-Atlantic education, animal rights and conservation. He credited his good friend, Hoyle Jones (retired Chairman of the ASPCA), for persuading him to give up blood sports. "One is never too old to learn", he remarked at the time. Robert was never happier than in the company of his five grandsons (Jonathan MacDonald, Michael MacDonald, David MacDonald, Luke Harris (Emily) and Peter Harris) who succeed him, together with his son, Ian MacDonald (Cheryl) and daughter, Zara Harris, (Dan). In 1989 he married Carolyn Leslie-Leonard Bransford who survives him and resides in New York and the Bahamas. The family will be forever grateful to its dedicated staff, most especially Garry Godfrey of England and the Bahamas. A service of thanksgiving will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown (Locust Valley, New York) on May 23rd at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, it is the wish of the family that donations be made to The North Shore Land Alliance (Long Island, New York) or the Bahamas National Trust.

LEVINSOHN--Robert J.,Esq., 94, on May 19, 2014. Robert was a partner at the law firm Proskauer Rose LLP. He chaired the New York County Democratic Law Committee for over forty years and a member for many years of the executive committee of the New York State Bar Assoc. Tax Section. Distinguished both as an attorney and was a driving force behind the New York County Democratic Committee. His pioneering role in fostering a reform of the judicial culture, rendering it free of corruption and unwarranted partisan influence, is still widely recognized. Bob was an early member of the Democratic Party's reform movement. A lifelong activist devoted to the highest ideal of the democratic Party. Robert naturally assumed a series of important positions of leadership in the world of politics and public policy. It is his extraordinary success in reforming Manhattan's judicial and political culture that will undoubtedly be his most enduring legacy. A leader of Manhattan's postwar political reform movement. Robert helped spearhead the drive to remove the taint of political taint of political influence from the new York City judiciary. This was accomplished by establishing the process of selecting judicial nominees through the establishment of nonpartisan screening panels. He effectively removed partisan political considerations from the judicial nominating process. Robert leaves behind his loving wife Louise Katz, daughters Donna M. Levinsohn, Dorothy A. Laurence, grandson James Levinsohn. His love and caring for others will be missed. Service Friday, May 30, 2014, 11:45am, "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

MOREL--Evelyn, passed away peacefully at home on May 12, 2014 in her 101st year. Devoted mother of Jim (Eva) and loving grandmother of William Andrew, she was a witty, generous and sophisticated woman who enjoyed the arts and culture of New York City. She lived harmoniously, and had many friends during her exceptional life time. Those wishing to make contributions in her memory may contact the American Civil Liberties Union, The World Wildlife Fund or The Nature Conservancy. At her request, there will be no service.

LEVINSOHN--Robert J.,passed away on May 19, 2014 at the age of 94. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP mourn Bob's passing. Bob was our partner for more than 50 years and a devoted colleague and friend to several generations of lawyers. He will be remembered as a diligent and precise tax lawyer, whose clients included The New Yorker magazine, and who possessed an extraordinary legal memory, which was particularly useful to his partners in the pre-digital age. Bob was a graduate of Yale University and Columbia University School of Law where he was editor of the Columbia Law Review. A U.S. Army veteran of World War II, he joined Proskauer as an associate in 1952 and continued to come to the office until very recently. Beyond Proskauer, Bob was very active in the Democratic Party and leaves behind a remarkable legacy of reform which continues to benefit us all today. As a member of the New York County Democratic Law Committee, he was instrumental in establishing a judicial selection process free from political influence. He was also an advocate for gender equality on the bench in New York and his efforts helped lead to a significant increase in women judges. On May 1, 2014, the Lexington Democratic Club honored Bob with a Special Lifetime Achievement Award and he was recognized by the Honorable Carolyn B. Maloney on the floor of the House of Representatives in 2006 for his achievements in judicial reform. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Louise, his children and his family. He will be missed by all of us who knew him family, friends, colleagues and clients alike. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

EDELMAN--Dr. Gerald. NGN Capital LLC, mourns the passing of Dr. Gerald Edelman, the inspirational Chairman of its Advisory Board. We will greatly miss his sage advice and friendship. We convey our deepest condolences to his family.

EDELMAN--Dr. Gerald M. The Co-Founders, Directors, Officers and Staff of Promosome LLC mourn the loss of our scientific founder, inspirational leader, partner and dear friend, Dr Gerald M. Edelman. His vision, mentoring and support have enabled the company to make scientific and commercial breakthroughs that will enhance and extend the lives of patients everywhere, and his deep insights have helped set the course for Promosome's future endeavors. More personally, his wise counsel and kindnesses toward all will never be forgotten. Our condolences go out to his wife, Maxine, his children, Eric, David and Judith, and his colleagues around the world. We will miss him.

EDELMAN--Gerald M. The Trustees of Neurosciences Research Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of Gerald M. Edelman, who was the Foundation's President and leader for the last three decades. Under the aegis of the Foundation, he was the founding Director of The Neurosciences Institute, where he fostered interactions among scientists from multiple disciplines to increase our understanding of how we perceive and act upon the world, how we learn and remember, and how consciousness arises. His many experimental and theoretical contributions to biology in immunology, embryological development, molecular cell biology, and neuroscience will continue to benefit mankind and lead the way to future discoveries. He had an exemplary knowledge of science, music, literature, and the visual arts. A brilliant speaker, raconteur, wit, writer for both scientific and lay audiences, and observer of the human condition, he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, and friends.

DUNN--Richard M.,a vital and complex man who lead a life of ongoing reinvention, died comfortably on May 16, 2014 from complications of pancreatic cancer. He grew up in Larchmont, NY, was a graduate of Dartmouth and Yale, and had a varied professional life that eventually came full circle. Starting out as a Professor of French and Humanities, then spending 25 years in correspondent and international banking before finally returning to education as a much-loved teacher in East Hampton, NY where he had lived full-time since 2003. Richard was a man of multitudinous passions. His book and labor of love Geoffrey Scott and the Berenson Circle: Literary and Aesthetic Life in the Early 20th Century was published in 1998. He is survived by his partner, Ryan Loughlin, his sisters, Perry Hoffman and Joy (Doris) Dunn, colleagues, students, and many friends.

ABATE--Catherine M.,The Board of Directors and staff of Community Healthcare Network (CHN) mourn the passing of our beloved and dynamic President and Chief Executive Officer. CHN was Catherine's passion, and we share her loss with the family, her husband Ron Kliegerman, son Kyle Kliegerman and his wife Lisa, and many dear friends to whom we extend our heartfelt condolences. She joined CHN 15 years ago following decades of work in the criminal justice field and after serving as the distinguished State Senator representing Chelsea and the West Village. She was a tremendous advocate for the health care needs of all those most at risk and a visionary and tenacious leader who always seemed able to marshal the resources for new and innovative programs. During her tenure, CHN quadrupled in size and moved from women's health services to offering a full range of primary care for individuals of all ages. Catherine wasn't satisfied with just being bigger, she inspired us all to want to be better. Thanks to her leadership, CHN pioneered successful new programs for teens, LGBT individuals and people with multiple chronic illnesses. She paved the way for all of CHN's clinics to receive FQHC status, Joint Commission accreditation and numerous other distinctions of quality and effectiveness. The CHN family remains committed to Catherine's lifelong dedication to social and economic justice in health care. Our loss is shared by all New Yorkers as we honor her invaluable contributions across a lifetime of public service.
