EVANS--Barton "Bart" Jr.,passed away peacefully after a brave and always optimistic 19 month struggle with pancreatic cancer. Bart is survived by Harriet "Andrea" Neves, his loving wife and partner of nearly 35 years, his brother, Bruce Marshall Evans (Woodland Hills, California) and his sister, Barbara Ashwood Evans McDowell (Upper Saddle River, New Jersey). Bart was the son of Barton Evans, Sr. (1909-1979), born in Salem, Massachusetts, following a long line of Barton's dating back to John Barton, Sr. (1626-1690) of Huntingdon, England. A long succession of Barton's resided in Barton Square in Salem, Massachusetts. Bart was born on December 11, 1947 in Washington D.C. In 1952, the family moved to Pacific Palisades, California. He graduated from St. Matthew's School in 1960, and then completed his secondary education at Phillips Exeter Academy in 1966. Evans then entered the Management Engineering program at Claremont McKenna College (formerly Claremont Men's College). Completing the requirements for a Bachelor's degree in Economics, in 1969, he transferred to Stanford University where he graduated with Bachelors and Masters Degrees in Engineering in March, 1972. Upon graduation, Evans received his ROTC commission as a Second Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Signal Corps in March, 1972. He was assigned to the United States Army Strategic Communications Command-Europe in Mannheim, Germany where he served until release from active duty in January, 1975. In July, 1977, Evans joined Durrum Instrument Corporation (the parent of Dionex Corporation) as a senior engineer. He was advanced through a succession of engineering and executive positions until his retirement in 2003 from his position as the Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Dionex. During his 28-year career at Dionex, Evans developed the first dual-channel Ion Chromatograph. Evans holds a patent for "Conductivity Detector and Method" and has given several papers at the Pittsburg Conference in Analytical Chemistry and Applied Spectroscopy (PittCon), the most recent of which was an invitation to speak at the Twelfth Annual James L. Waters Annual Symposium, "recognizing pioneers in the development of analytical instrumentation." In parallel with his "civilian" career, Evans remained active in the U.S. Army Reserve. Following separation from active duty and return to the United States, Evans joined the 351st Civil Affairs Command in March, 1976, where he served in successive assignments. In March 1997, Colonel Evans became Chief, United States Army Pacific Support Team. His responsibilities were widened when he was assigned as Chief, Pacific Command Support Teams in January 1998, and later, and Chief of Staff in October 1998. In August, 2000 Colonel Evans became Deputy Commander, 351st Affairs Command, where he served until his retirement 30 April 2002 after over 30 plus years' military service. His awards and decorations include the Legion of Merit, Meritorious Service Medals, Army Commendation Medals, Army Achievement Medals, and Army Reserve Components Achievement Medals. In retirement, Evans was active in the volunteer arena. He was a trustee for Claremont McKenna College, serving on the Executive, Academic Affairs, Finance, Student Affairs Committees, and the Research Institutes sub-committee. He also chaired the President's Information Technology Advisory Board which was recently named the Evans ITAB. A supporter of the performing arts, Evans served as Secretary-Treasurer for the San Francisco Lyric Opera and was on the Board of Trustees for Opera San Jose. Evans was married to Dr. H. Andrea Neves, Professor of Education Emerita, Sonoma State University, and Lecturer, Stanford University School of Education. Evans and Neves resided in Hillsborough, California, and together they were active in philanthropy directed toward the support of education, public and private as well as the performing arts and social justice. To this end, they endowed the Barton Evans and H. Andrea Neves Professor of Literature chair at Claremont McKenna College; the Barton Evans and H. Andrea Neves Instructorship in Humanities) at Phillips Exeter Academy; the H. Andrea Neves and Barton Evans Fellowship Fund for Graduate Students in Education at Stanford University; and the H. Andrea Neves and Barton Evans Endowment Fund for the Neves-Evans Social Justice Lecture Series at Sonoma State University. They have also supported the construction of classrooms and teacher residences and have funded various secondary school and undergraduate scholarships in Tanzania, Africa. Finally, Bart and Andrea managed to travel to most of the world, all major civilization sites and continents. Donations in remembrance of Bart may be made to: Claremont McKenna College, c/o Evans ITAB, 400 N. Claremont Blvd. Claremont, CA, or Opera San Jose, San Jose, CA, or Neves-Evans Social Justice Lecture Program, Sonoma State University, Rohnert Park, CA. A celebration of his life will be held Saturday, June 14, at 5:00pm at the Peninsula Golf and Country Club, 701 Madera Drive, San Mateo, CA. Other memorial services will be held at Claremont-McKenna and St. Mathews Episcopal Church, Pacific Palisades, CA. Please consult www.ssofunerals.com for all service times and directions. Obituary is also listed.

EDELMAN--Gerald M. The Trustees of Neurosciences Research Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of Gerald M. Edelman, who was the Foundation's President and leader for the last three decades. Under the aegis of the Foundation, he was the founding Director of The Neurosciences Institute, where he fostered interactions among scientists from multiple disciplines to increase our understanding of how we perceive and act upon the world, how we learn and remember, and how consciousness arises. His many experimental and theoretical contributions to biology in immunology, embryological development, molecular cell biology, and neuroscience will continue to benefit mankind and lead the way to future discoveries. He had an exemplary knowledge of science, music, literature, and the visual arts. A brilliant speaker, raconteur, wit, writer for both scientific and lay audiences, and observer of the human condition, he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, and friends.

GELB--Arthur. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Arthur Gelb a visionary if there ever was one! He loved the arts, particularly the theater, and was an enthusiastic supporter of many theater companies in New York, including ours. We extend our sympathy to Barbara, Peter and the entire Gelb family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

SMALL--Robert Ira, died on May 15, 2014 at the age of 74. A resident of both Ross and Rancho Mirage, California, he was a 40-year veteran and visionary leader to the hospitality industry. Retired CEO and President of the Fairmount Hotels, he had been Executive Vice President of Walt Disney's World Resort Division and Vice President of Marriott's western region resorts. He was the recipient of numerous industry and community awards and was an inspiring mentor to young people in the industry. Born in the Bronx, raised in New Rochelle, he was a graduate of Rider University. He is survived by his wife, Carla, daughter Katie, son Michael, brother Stanley sister-in-law Amy and nieces. He will be missed greatly by his family, neighbors and friends world-wide. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the MD Anderson Cancer Center, P.O. Box 4486, Houston, Texas 77210-4486. A celebration of Bob's life will be held in the near future.

SHORE--Jerry. Died at age 88 on May 19th. He was born in Sea Gate, Brooklyn and lived with his family for many years in Sands Point, NY. He attended Brooklyn Tech High School and received a Bachelor's Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Purdue University in 1946 and a Master's Degree in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University in 1947. Jerry served in the US Navy Air Corps in WWII. In 1954, he founded Park Electrochemical Corporation (PKE), which is a multi-national company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Jerry served as Park's CEO until 1996, when he retired from the Company. He served as Chairman of the Board until 2004, when he retired from the Company's Board of Directors. Upon retiring, Jerry embarked on a new and prolific career as a professional sculptor. A true artist at heart, Jerry started Shore Sculpture, a large-format sculpture studio that was thoroughly embedded in the local community in Port Washington, NY. Major pieces of his have been featured in art exhibitions and are currently on display in sculpture gardens throughout the country. He leaves his wife Cecile of 65 years and his children, Brian, Robin and Peter and their spouses, Barbara, Laura and Jennifer as well as his beloved and adored grandchildren Ben, Sam and Mariah. Jerry is also survived by his brother Mel, of Sacramento, CA. For Jerry, love meant vigorously going to the ends of the earth to ensure the happiness of those he cared for. A life-long learner, Jerry was constantly striving to deepen his understanding of the world, while taking every opportunity to teach, guide, and mentor those around him. A man of simple needs, he devoted himself to improving the human condition as a humanitarian, philanthropist, and artist. Jerry was both the eternal patriarch and rebellious boy from Brooklyn, trousers torn and head held high. He will be dearly missed.

EDELMAN--Dr. Gerald. NGN Capital LLC, mourns the passing of Dr. Gerald Edelman, the inspirational Chairman of its Advisory Board. We will greatly miss his sage advice and friendship. We convey our deepest condolences to his family.

DUNN--Richard M.,a vital and complex man who lead a life of ongoing reinvention, died comfortably on May 16, 2014 from complications of pancreatic cancer. He grew up in Larchmont, NY, was a graduate of Dartmouth and Yale, and had a varied professional life that eventually came full circle. Starting out as a Professor of French and Humanities, then spending 25 years in correspondent and international banking before finally returning to education as a much-loved teacher in East Hampton, NY where he had lived full-time since 2003. Richard was a man of multitudinous passions. His book and labor of love Geoffrey Scott and the Berenson Circle: Literary and Aesthetic Life in the Early 20th Century was published in 1998. He is survived by his partner, Ryan Loughlin, his sisters, Perry Hoffman and Joy (Doris) Dunn, colleagues, students, and many friends.

DINHAM--Gwen Cynthia Warrior Queen, passed away May 16, 2014, at the age of 84. Mother and Hero to Julia Simone, grandmother to Nyah Jude, and mother-in-law to Jorge Ivan. Devoted Nurse. Lady of ladies. Had a laugh that could be heard for miles. We will hold you in our hearts and all that is good. Till we meet again.

CALACE-MOTTOLA--Joseph, on May 19th of Plandome, NY. Beloved husband of Anna. Dear father of Nina, Lisa and Kara. Loving brother of Janet and Pauline Calace-Mottola. Beloved grandfather of seven grandchildren. Calling hours at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Manhasset NY on Friday 7-9pm, with religious service at 7:30pm. Donations in his memory may be made to: Lead The Way fund, P.O. Box 281, Manhasset NY 11030 info@leadthewayfund.org

IFLAND--Paul "Peter". Beloved husband of Luce Cuvelier Ifland. Loving father of Jane Andrea Ifland, Joan Rewbridge Ifland and Roger Thomas Ifland (deceased). Grandfather of Claire Ifland Johnson and Camille Ifland Johnson. Passed away Tuesday, May 20, 2014 at the age of 87. Paul was an undergraduate of Texas Christian University and received his Doctorate from the University of Texas. He was a career executive in research and development for Procter and Gamble in Cincinnati, Ohio and Brussels, Belgium until his retirement in 1991. He was a Commander in the U.S. Navy Reserve. He is the author of Taking the Stars-Celestial Navigation Instruments from Argonauts to Astronauts, Published by The Mariner's Museum Newport News, Virginia. Sympathies may be expressed by a memorial donation to the Mariner's Museum (100 Museum Drive, Newport News, VA 23606.) Condolences may be made at www.springgrove.org.

GELB--Arthur. The Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers salutes the extraordinary man and friend of the theater, Arthur Gelb. New York theater would not have been the same without him. Our sympathies to his family. ATPAM

SHOPKORN--Edward. Eddie, In 5 short years we have created a lifetime of memories. From the Hamptons making your Florentine steak to living together during Hurricanes Sandy and Irene and all those wonderful times in between. You were always the warmest, caring and special friend. We will never forget you and don't worry, we will always take care of Susan. Love, Debi and Evan

LEINWAND--A. David, passed away on May 21, 2014 at the age of 81 from complications of myelodysplasia. Born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn on August 9, 1932, David graduated from Stuyvesant High School and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, class of '53. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend of 58 years, Carole (Kleinman), his adored children Andrea and Jeffrey Kaminsky, Laurie and Phillip Gildan, and Janet and Andrew Bein. He was predeceased by his son, James. He was a most proud papa to his eight grandchildren, Brett, Stephen, Tyler, Jacob, Warren, Jacqueline, Hannah and Alexander. He is also survived by two older brothers, Dr. Gerald Leinwand and Calvin Leinwand, two sisters-in-law, Harriet Dickman and Suzanne Cavalier (Mayer), and many nieces and nephews. David served in the U.S. Army 1953-1955, and was co-owner of Rosetta Electric Company for over 40 years with his brother, Calvin. In his retirement, David earned a master's degree in history from NYU. After volunteering at schools in Manhattan, he became an adjunct professor of history, primarily at Iona College. He loved opera at the Met, travel, tennis, reading non-fiction and was New York's number one Yankee fan. Services will be held on Friday, May 23 at 10:00am at Temple Israel in White Plains. Donations in David's name may be made to the James L. Leinwand Foundation, care of Westchester Community Foundation, 200 North Central Park Avenue, Suite 310, Hartsdale, New York, 10530. We loved David and will cherish his memory.
SHOPKORN--Edward, A glass of red and a spoonful of stuffing will be left for you every Thanksgiving. Richard, Suzie, Ali, Greg, Mikey & Jess

EDELMAN--Dr. Gerald M. The Co-Founders, Directors, Officers and Staff of Promosome LLC mourn the loss of our scientific founder, inspirational leader, partner and dear friend, Dr Gerald M. Edelman. His vision, mentoring and support have enabled the company to make scientific and commercial breakthroughs that will enhance and extend the lives of patients everywhere, and his deep insights have helped set the course for Promosome's future endeavors. More personally, his wise counsel and kindnesses toward all will never be forgotten. Our condolences go out to his wife, Maxine, his children, Eric, David and Judith, and his colleagues around the world. We will miss him.

SCHWARTZ--Selma Jobyna. November 2, 1912 - May 22, 2013. Dear Mommy, a year without your smile, your laughter, and the delight of your presence. As an old song says, "There will never ever be another you." Love, Estelle and Alan

EDELMAN--Gerald M. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the passing of our friend and former colleague Gerald M. Edelman. A trailblazing scientist who made foundational discoveries in immunology and neuroscience, he was a valued mentor, collaborator, and member of the campus community for nearly 35 years. He joined Rockefeller in 1957 as a doctoral student in the laboratory of Henry Kunkel, where he began the research that led him to decipher the chemical structure of an antibody. For this accomplishment and subsequent discoveries, he shared the 1972 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. After earning his Ph.D. in 1960, he remained at Rockefeller as assistant professor, associate professor, and then Vincent Astor Professor, until 1992, serving also as associate dean of graduate studies until 1966. The University was proud to award him an honorary degree in 2008. Trained in his youth as a concert violinist, he was also a passionate proponent of the arts, particularly music, and helped to organize the University's concert series for many years. His virtuosity was evident not only in the originality of his experiments, but also in his spectacular wit and prolific writing. He was among the rare individuals who are able to draw cogent connections across disciplines, not only within the sciences, but also with the arts and humanities. His unique blend of humor, creativity, and scientific brilliance will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Maxine, and his children, Eric, David, and Judith. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President

SHEPPARD--Claire Felice (Segal) November 15, 1928 died May 20, 2014. Beloved spouse of Herbert (deceased), loving mother of Jeffrey and Jill, proud grandmother of Elizabeth, Michael, Daniel, and Ryan, blessed mother-in-law of Robin and Bert. Donations to VNSNY-Hospice Care Unit.

ERICKSON--Mira Nikolic, 73, of Greenwich Village. Born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the daughter of Ratomir and Katarina Nikolic and sister of Rada Nikolic. Beloved wife of 43 years of Ken, and his best friend, companion in adventures, and fearless copyediting critic. Beloved mother of Ingrid. Loved sister-in-law of Peter R. Erickson. Studied first at the University of Belgrade, then graduated from Smith College. Creative and innovative teacher, mentor, administrator, and advocate of integrity in education and of the causes of immigrants and newcomers. Devoted her talents at the International Center of Catholic Charities in service of immigrants. As she summed it up, the Center's services enabled them to go "from newcomer to New Yorker." A memorial event to celebrate her life will be arranged for June. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Catholic Charities, for the International Center.

RITVO--Lucille Bernstein, Ph.D.,died May 3, 2014 at home, age 93. Born July 11, 1920 in Middle Village, NY, graduated Grover Cleveland High School, '35, Mt. Holyoke College, BA '40, Yale Ph.D. '72. Published A Tale of Two Sciences: Darwin's Influence on Freud, 1990. Lived in Woodbridge, CT for 54 years. Served as registrar of voters, justice of the peace and on the Connecticut Judicial Review Council. Devoted wife of Samuel Ritvo, M.D. for 67 years until his death in 2008. Loving mother of Jonathan (Joanne), David (Phyllis) and Rachel (Steven), generous grandmother of Emily (Andrew), Bennett, Louis, Jared, Alexis, Jacob and Alyse and great-grandmother of Aurora and Kalinda. Donations in her memory can be made to: The Samuel and Lucille Ritvo Lectureship Yale Medical School, Office of Development, YMS, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.
BAUMAN--Bernice. Devoted wife, loving mother and grandmother. In Atlanta, of natural causes.
Bender--Shirley (Meiselman). Beloved wife of Samuel, DVM, mother of Andrea (David), Joel (Wendy), and the late Mitchell. Grandmother of five, great-grandmother of five.

GELB--Arthur. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts mourn the passing of Arthur Gelb, a towering figure for 45 years at The New York Times as correspondent, critic, and editor. His work helped shape coverage of the arts as we know it today. We extend our sympathies to our Lincoln Center colleague and friend, his son, Peter Gelb, whose achievements as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera surely delighted his father, as well as to all of his family and many friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

ENDERS--Gaetana, The Board of Directors, staff and students of Casita Maria Center for Arts & Education mourn the passing of our beloved Board Member and founder of our Music Program. Gaetana was a passionate, irrepressible supporter of our work, and her Music program now serves hundreds of South Bronx children every year. We will all miss her commitment, energy and love.

LEINWAND--A. David, passed away on May 21, 2014 at the age of 81 from complications of myelodysplasia. Born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn on August 9, 1932, David graduated from Stuyvesant High School and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, class of '53. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend of 58 years, Carole (Kleinman), his adored children Andrea and Jeffrey Kaminsky, Laurie and Phillip Gildan, and Janet and Andrew Bein. He was predeceased by his son, James. He was a most proud papa to his eight grandchildren, Brett, Stephen, Tyler, Jacob, Warren, Jacqueline, Hannah and Alexander. He is also survived by two older brothers, Dr. Gerald Leinwand and Calvin Leinwand, two sisters-in-law, Harriet Dickman and Suzanne Cavalier (Mayer), and many nieces and nephews. David served in the U.S. Army 1953-1955, and was co-owner of Rosetta Electric Company for over 40 years with his brother, Calvin. In his retirement, David earned a master's degree in history from NYU. After volunteering at schools in Manhattan, he became an adjunct professor of history, primarily at Iona College. He loved opera at the Met, travel, tennis, reading non-fiction and was New York's number one Yankee fan. Services will be held on Friday, May 23 at 10:00am at Temple Israel in White Plains. Donations in David's name may be made to the James L. Leinwand Foundation, care of Westchester Community Foundation, 200 North Central Park Avenue, Suite 310, Hartsdale, New York, 10530. We loved David and will cherish his memory.
STORCH--George, Always in our hearts and thoughts. We miss you.

STEINGLASS--Rose, nee Feldbrill, died peacefully on May 20 at the age of 101. Rose led a remarkable and long life. She was born in Zawiercie, Poland on November 13, 1912 and immigrated to Toronto with her parents in 1920. In 1941, Rose married Sam and moved to New York City and then to Hewlett, NY where they raised their three sons Steven, Kenneth and Robert with devotion, pride and love. Rose is survived by her three sons; daughters-in-law Dianne, Jayne and Dolores; seven grandchildren Adam, Rachel, Amanda, Joshua, Jody, Barry and Aaron; and fourteen great-grandchildren. Funeral service will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 9:30am on Friday, May 23 after which she will be laid to rest beside her beloved Sam at Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be at the home of Kenneth and Jayne Steinglass at 300 E. 74 St, NY, NY on Friday from 4:00 to 7:00pm.

Tobias--Paul. Distinguished cellist and teacher died May 6, 2014 in New York City of injuries sustained in a fall. All who knew him will remember his quick wit and gentle soul. His family will hold private services.

DAY--David. The Board of Directors and the singers of the Schuyler Foundation for Career Bridges mourn the tragic loss of our beloved friend and Board member, David Day, who died in London, England May 18, 2014 79 years of age. David was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, and sponsor of the new "Ring" cycle at English National Opera.

STREETER--Tal, sculptor of "Endless Column" and author of The Art of the Japanese Kite passed away on April 17, 2014 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Streeter's art centered on the creation of large-scale steel sculptures, and large kites, both of which find their inspiration and home in the sky. A celebration of his life, work and legacy will be held in 2015 on the opening of the Dream of Flight Museum and Library, Santa Fe New Mexico, established by the non profit Friends of the Sky Foundation in 2012 to preserve Tal's vision, sculpture, sky related material, photographic and kite archives. He is survived by his wife, potter Romig Streeter, daughter Lissa Streeter, brother Ronald J. Streeter, collaborator Bruce George, and his Santa Fe family - David, Fiona and Tiger Wong-Wagner. To those that wish, all correspondence and donations may be made to : Friends of the Sky Foundation, 4007 Old Santa Fe Trail, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87505. "Rather than center himself in the American space as an Action Painter does, Streeter makes the surrounding lack of scale reveal itself; the endlessness is in the American sky." - Carter Ratcliff

SHORE--Jerry. We mourn the loss of our long time client and good friend. As the founder of Park Electrochemical Corp., Jerry Shore was highly respected and admired for his integrity as well as for his exceptional abilities, his vision and his leadership skills. He was also a talented sculptor, an interest he pursued with vigor upon retiring from Park, and many of his pieces remain on public display today. His thoughtfulness, compassion and generosity enabled him to make a significant difference in the lives of many. He will be missed. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Cecile, and to his children, Brian, Robin and Peter and their families. Troutman Sanders LLP

CALACE-MOTTOLA--Joseph, on May 19th of Plandome, NY. Beloved husband of Anna. Dear father of Nina, Lisa and Kara. Father-in-law of three. Loving brother of Janet and Pauline Calace-Mottola. BAGLEY--Herman. The Trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society mourn the passing of Herman Bagley, a true champion for all of New York City's youth. Across a 50-year career, Herman worked tirelessly to improve the welfare of children in some of the city's most disadvantaged neighborhoods. He retired in 2005 after serving as assistant executive director for community. Our hearts go out to his family. Bill Weisberg, Interim President and CEO, Mark Edmiston, Chairman.

RITVO--Lucille Bernstein, Ph.D.,died May 3, 2014 at home, age 93. Born July 11, 1920 in Middle Village, NY, graduated Grover Cleveland High School, '35, Mt. Holyoke College, BA '40, Yale Ph.D. '72. Published A Tale of Two Sciences: Darwin's Influence on Freud, 1990. Lived in Woodbridge, CT for 54 years. Served as registrar of voters, justice of the peace and on the Connecticut Judicial Review Council. Devoted wife of Samuel Ritvo, M.D. for 67 years until his death in 2008. Loving mother of Jonathan (Joanne), David (Phyllis) and Rachel (Steven), generous grandmother of Emily (Andrew), Bennett, Louis, Jared, Alexis, Jacob and Alyse and great-grandmother of Aurora and Kalinda. Donations in her memory can be made to: The Samuel and Lucille Ritvo Lectureship Yale Medical School, Office of Development, YMS, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

GELB--Arthur. The Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers salutes the extraordinary man and friend of the theater, Arthur Gelb. New York theater would not have been the same without him. Our sympathies to his family. ATPAM

SHORE--Jerry. Died at age 88 on May 19th. He was born in Sea Gate, Brooklyn and lived with his family for many years in Sands Point, NY. He attended Brooklyn Tech High School and received a Bachelor's Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Purdue University in 1946 and a Master's Degree in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University in 1947. Jerry served in the US Navy Air Corps in WWII. In 1954, he founded Park Electrochemical Corporation (PKE), which is a multi-national company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Jerry served as Park's CEO until 1996, when he retired from the Company. He served as Chairman of the Board until 2004, when he retired from the Company's Board of Directors. Upon retiring, Jerry embarked on a new and prolific career as a professional sculptor. A true artist at heart, Jerry started Shore Sculpture, a large-format sculpture studio that was thoroughly embedded in the local community in Port Washington, NY. Major pieces of his have been featured in art exhibitions and are currently on display in sculpture gardens throughout the country. He leaves his wife Cecile of 65 years and his children, Brian, Robin and Peter and their spouses, Barbara, Laura and Jennifer as well as his beloved and adored grandchildren Ben, Sam and Mariah. Jerry is also survived by his brother Mel, of Sacramento, CA. For Jerry, love meant vigorously going to the ends of the earth to ensure the happiness of those he cared for. A life-long learner, Jerry was constantly striving to deepen his understanding of the world, while taking every opportunity to teach, guide, and mentor those around him. A man of simple needs, he devoted himself to improving the human condition as a humanitarian, philanthropist, and artist. Jerry was both the eternal patriarch and rebellious boy from Brooklyn, trousers torn and head held high. He will be dearly missed.

GELB--Arthur. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Arthur Gelb a visionary if there ever was one! He loved the arts, particularly the theater, and was an enthusiastic supporter of many theater companies in New York, including ours. We extend our sympathy to Barbara, Peter and the entire Gelb family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

McNABB--John Martin, 43, died in New York City on May 19. John was born to Mary Rhoades Korby and Jerry Glenn McNabb in Greenville, Texas on December 2, 1970. He graduated from the Episcopal School of Dallas and attended the University of North Texas. John had a musical career spanning many years and many bandmates--from Dallas-based bands Texas Killers and Rumble to New York-based Dragmule to a solo career that included playing guitar with Ryan Adams on tour in the United States and in Europe, as well as on studio albums. In 1999 John founded and managed Peligro Audio in New York. John was also a talented photographer working in the fashion industry, and he founded and managed Indy Road Productions in 2005. With Indy Road Productions, John was instrumental in the production of photo shoots for Karl Lagerfeld, Chanel, Fendi, Vogue, and numerous others. He devoted himself to producing the epic Metiers d'Art with Chanel held in Dallas, Texas in December 2013. John was a loving, talented, generous, and kind man, whose work and varied interests took him around the world. He was a friend to so many in Texas, New York, and around the world. John's family and friends will miss him beyond measure. He is irreplaceable. John is survived by his mother Mary Korby, his father Jerry McNabb, his stepfather Steve Korby, his sister Sophie Dowling and her husband Charles, stepsisters Meg (Blake) Bassett and Melissa (Doug) Fordyce, and his loving nieces and nephews Henry, George, and Mary Dowling, Ellie, Caroline, and Brynn Bassett, and Abby and Sam Fordyce, and his aunt Cheri Rambeau. Funeral services will be held at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home in Dallas on Sunday, May 25 at 2:00pm. His family will receive visitors at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home from 4:00pm to 6:00pm on Saturday, May 24. A private burial will be held Monday. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Fender Music Foundation (fendermusicfounda tion.org) or Operation Kindness (www.operationkind ness.org) in memory of John.

MAZZOLA--Anthony T.,Former editor in chief of Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR, and the curator of Hearst Corporation's fine art collection, died May 21 in New York. He was 90. "Anthony Mazzola was a dynamic member of the Hearst Magazines family for more than 65 years," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. "Tony will be missed by everyone who had the pleasure of working with him." Frank A. Bennack, Jr., former CEO and now executive vice chairman of Hearst Corporation, added, "Tony Mazzola's contributions to Harper's BAZAAR and Town&Country have not only influenced those titles as they appear even today but our entire magazine business." Mazzola, the editor who defined affluence and style for millions of readers at the two magazines for 44 years, started his career at Hearst as an art director. In 1948, at the age of 25, Mazzola joined Town&Country as the youngest art director in the magazine's history. He held that post for nearly two decades, ultimately becoming editor in chief in 1965. Town&Country is the longest continuously published general-interest magazine in America, having been founded in 1846. "Tony Mazzola was one of the most creative editors I've known," said Hearst Corporation Director Gilbert C. Maurer. "A man of great personal style, he intuitively knew what good looked like and his work at Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR reflected that acute sensibility. Tony was a loyal friend as well as a valuable mentor to a generation of our younger talents." Building on what he once described as his "fascination with trends," Mazzola's Town&Country began to reflect the current events and social reorganization then affecting elite American society as the nation mourned the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and grappled with civil rights, the Vietnam War and the first stirrings of modern-day feminism. Mazzola said he was captivated "not by what's happening, but why." While still the magazine's art director in 1964, he published a tongue-in-cheek "It's Fun to Be Rich" issue. In 1966, his first year as Town&Country's editor in chief, he put the Rolling Stones on the cover of what was widely held to be the bible of conservative, blue-blooded America. The ensuing controversy prompted Hearst's executives to ask him, "Young man, do you know what you're doing?" "I think so," he replied. In fact, Mazzola did: By maintaining a meticulous balance between creating an exciting magazine and conveying the dignity of the subjects he presented, he broadened Town&Country's appeal and honored its audience. "People make fun of money," he once said, "but everyone forgets the good that money has done." In 1972, Mazzola was appointed editor in chief of Harper's BAZAAR and expanded his editorial style even further. He relished the opportunity to widen the magazine's scope, which he again did in 1983 by adapting its pages to reflect newly emerging trends such as the more mature, sophisticated fashions--and celebrities--of the time, and readers' increasing interest in lifestyle, as well as fashion, content. "We love the handle of being the fashion magazine with a little salt and pepper added," he said of BAZAAR in a 1983 interview. "We appeal to a woman with a very strong confidence level, who is sure of herself, not wishy-washy. She wants to know everything there is to know...and we have become the fashion and beauty book with personality, the one with heart." At the end of the decade, Mazzola again redesigned the magazine, this time to appeal to readers as they matured from trendy to classic tastes. Striving for what he called a "very unconventional, exciting visual product," Mazzola encouraged photographers such as Francesco Scavullo, Rico Puhlmann and Matthew Rolston to take dramatic, even abstract approaches to fashion. One result was a celebrated shot described by a writer as "a woman and a cabbage leaf facing off" to illustrate a story on vegetable dyes used in hair coloring. After he stepped down as editor in chief in 1992, Mazzola edited BAZAAR's 125th anniversary book in 1993. The project was both professionally and personally rewarding. "Reliving the history of this great magazine and knowing that I had a role in it is a great privilege," he said. In 1995, he was editorial director of Town&Country's two-volume 150th anniversary book. Mazzola was also the fine arts curator for Hearst Corporation, whose fine art collection emphasizes works on paper and emerging talents, many of whom have become household names since the collection was started. In addition to curating and cataloguing the collection, he produced many art and photography shows for Hearst Tower. Mazzola graduated from The Cooper Union with honors in 1948 and received The Cooper Union's distinguished alumni citation in 1992. After beginning study at The Cooper Union, he was drafted into World War II. His art background prompted an assignment to army intelligence, where he analyzed camouflage. He was awarded a Bronze Star for "meritorious achievement in connection with military operations against the enemy in Luzon, Philippine Islands." A recipient of numerous awards in the art direction and design fields, Mazzola was inducted as a Knight Officer of the Order of Merit by the Republic of Italy in 1967. He also served as a consultant and designer for such organizations as the United Nations Children's Fund, the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Princess Marcella Borghese, Inc., General Foods, Columbia Pictures, Inc. and the New York World's Fair of 1965. Mazzola is survived by his wife, Michele Morgan Mazzola, who worked with him at Hearst for over 45 years, and three children, Alisa Mazzola Mitchell, Marc Mazzola and Tony Mazzola. He is also survived by five grandchildren. There will be a private funeral in Indiana, and a memorial in New York at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 or http://www.mskcc.org/giving).

DiTIERI--Jeffrey Raymond, age 58, of Staten Island on May 19, 2014, after a long illness. Devoted husband of Debra nee Kronowitz. Loving father of Jonathan, Kyle, Forrest, Amethyst and Haile Montana. Grandfather to Aiden. Beloved son of Remo and Inge. Brother of Lorinda, Christy and John. An uncle of many nieces and nephews. Visitation and memorial service will be held on Saturday, 2-4pm at the Casey McCullum Rice Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Ave., Staten Island, NY 10308. Donations may be made to: American Stroke Association, PO Box 417005, Boston, MA 02241-7005.

HELLER--Dorothy, born March 26, 1939, died from complications from Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma on May 17, 2014. Born in Beacon, New York, she resided with her Husband for over twenty-five years in Sands Point, New York, before they relocated to Boca Raton, Florida to be near their grandchildren. Beloved wife of more than 56 years to Edwin Heller (a retired corporate partner of Fried Frank), proud mother of daughter, Dr. Dana A. Heller (Galina Tsoy), Eminent Scholar and Chair of the Department of English at Old Dominion University, and son, William P. Heller, Esq. (Allison), a partner in the firm of Akerman LLP and Chair of the firm's National Consumer Finance Litigation and Compliance Practice Group. Dorothy was a devoted grandmother to her three grandchildren: Ryan, Samantha and Lindsey. When she died the world lost one of its most beautiful and gracious angels. As was said at her 75th birthday, attended by her entire family, there are no words sufficient to express appreciation for the love and joy that she inspired and the enhancement of the lives of all who were blessed to know her. Dorothy had a heart transplant in May 2009 and all admired her courage and strong character. She was at risk for Lymphoma because she, and many organ recipients are required to take drugs that appreciably decrease the immune system. Memorial Donations may be made payable to University of Maryland Balitmore Foundation (UMBF, Inc.). Donations together with the Dorothy and Edwin Heller Heart Transplant Research Fund at University of Maryland School of Medicine will be used to support research to reduce dependency on immunosuppressant drugs following an organ transplant. Mailing address: UMSOM Development, 31 S. Greene Street, Suite 300, Baltimore MD 21201. Attn: K Hussey or online at www.fundformedicine.org.

CHOOK--Paul H.,of Forest Hills, NY passed away on May 23, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY. Paul's professional career spanned a period of over 40 years in the advertising and publishing business. He specialized in marketing and advertising research to guide planners in media evaluation and advertising development. Paul served as President of Alfred Politz Media Studies, President of W.R. Simmons Research, Vice President of Young & Rubicam, and Executive Vice President of Ziff-Davis Publishing and the CBS Magazine Division. Paul was a Director and Board Chairman of the Advertising Research Foundation, a member of the Market Research Council and was elected to the MRC Hall of Fame. He is an alumnus of Columbia University in (Graduate School of Business) and of the City College of New York (Baruch School) where he also taught undergraduate and graduate courses in statistical methods and analysis over a period of 12 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 25, 2014 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76 Road) Forest Hills, NY.

CROAKE--Elizabeth Ann, born January 28, 1931 in Plattsburgh NY; died May 20, 2014, in Bradenton FL. Brown & Sons Funeral Homes & Crematory, 26th Street Chapel of Bradenton, FL is in charge of services.

SHORE--Jerry. Died at age 88 on May 19th. He was born in Sea Gate, Brooklyn and lived with his family for many years in Sands Point, NY. He attended Brooklyn Tech High School and received a Bachelor's Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Purdue University in 1946 and a Master's Degree in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University in 1947. Jerry served in the US Navy Air Corps in WWII. In 1954, he founded Park Electrochemical Corporation (PKE), which is a multi-national company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Jerry served as Park's CEO until 1996, when he retired from the Company. He served as Chairman of the Board until 2004, when he retired from the Company's Board of Directors. Upon retiring, Jerry embarked on a new and prolific career as a professional sculptor. A true artist at heart, Jerry started Shore Sculpture, a large-format sculpture studio that was thoroughly embedded in the local community in Port Washington, NY. Major pieces of his have been featured in art exhibitions and are currently on display in sculpture gardens throughout the country. He leaves his wife Cecile of 65 years and his children, Brian, Robin and Peter and their spouses, Barbara, Laura and Jennifer as well as his beloved and adored grandchildren Ben, Sam and Mariah. Jerry is also survived by his brother Mel, of Sacramento, CA. For Jerry, love meant vigorously going to the ends of the earth to ensure the happiness of those he cared for. A life-long learner, Jerry was constantly striving to deepen his understanding of the world, while taking every opportunity to teach, guide, and mentor those around him. A man of simple needs, he devoted himself to improving the human condition as a humanitarian, philanthropist, and artist. Jerry was both the eternal patriarch and rebellious boy from Brooklyn, trousers torn and head held high. He will be dearly missed.
DAY--David, The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, David Day. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

Tobias--Paul. Distinguished cellist and teacher died May 6, 2014 in New York City of injuries sustained in a fall. All who knew him will remember his quick wit and gentle soul. His family will hold private services.
EGAN--Harold G. August 14, 2014-May 21, 2014. Cooper Union '37 muralist. Industrial designer and sculptor. Beloved uncle and friend.
BROWN--Sidney. 4/8/1919 - 5/24/1989. Economist, Professor, Gentleman, Loyal Friend, Loving Husband and Father. Loved, Remembered and Missed. Daughter, Hara and son-in-law, Ken

ENDERS--Gaetana, died peacefully Wednesday, May 21, 2014 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Born in Tangier, Morocco, the youngest of four daughters of Elena Atzori and Giuseppe Marchegiano, General Counsel of the Supreme Court of Italy and Administrator for Judicial Affairs for the International Zone of Tangier. She and Thomas Ostrom Enders of Hartford, Connecticut met in 1953 in Tangier, married in 1955, and together had four children. As the wife of a career diplomat and Ambassador, Gaetana worked to facilitate humanitarian and cultural relations in their international posts including Sweden, Yugoslavia, Cambodia, the European Community, Canada, and Spain. In Cambodia during the war in 1970-4 she established refugee camps and subsequently served on President Gerald Ford's panel supervising the settlement of Indochina refugees. When her husband left the Foreign Service in 1986 Gaetana began a new career as a journalist. From 1986 through 2013 she was International Editor for Hola and Hello magazines, sourcing and authoring interviews with personalities including Presidents Bush Sr., Gorbachev, Salinas, Fox, and Arias; Mstislav Rostropovich, Hilary Clinton, the Queens of Norway and Sweden, the Lauder Family, and Mayor Michael Bloomberg, amongst many others. Gaetana Enders served as a member of the Board of the Casita Maria Center for Arts & Education since 2007 and in 2010 she founded the Casita Maria Music Program. She served on the Boards of the Mexican Cultural Institute, the Salzburg Festival Society, and the Thomas Enders Endowment of ACSUS which promotes Canada US relations. She is a Dama di Commenda of the Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus of Savoy Orders. Gaetana was a Dame of Magisterial Grace in the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. She has been honored with the medal of the Americas Society for her contributions to Latin America, The Ellis Island Medal of Honor, the Women Together Award, and the Sociedad International de Valores de Arte Mexicano. She will be honored as a humanitarian with the James Parks Morton Award at the Interfaith Center of New York this June. An international traveler, she will be greatly missed by her many friends around the world. Gaetana is survived by her loving children Domitilla, Claire, Alice, and Thomas, her grandchildren Heloise, Cecilia, Thomas, and Benedict, and her beloved sisters Liliana, Gianella, and Maria Grazia, of Rome. The funeral Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, on Monday, June 2, 2014 at 9:30am. Donations in Gaetana's memory may be made to Casita Maria Music Program at www.casitamaria.org/donate

McNABB--John Martin, 43, died in New York City on May 19. John was born to Mary Rhoades Korby and Jerry Glenn McNabb in Greenville, Texas on December 2, 1970. He graduated from the Episcopal School of Dallas and attended the University of North Texas. John had a musical career spanning many years and many bandmates--from Dallas-based bands Texas Killers and Rumble to New York-based Dragmule to a solo career that included playing guitar with Ryan Adams on tour in the United States and in Europe, as well as on studio albums. In 1999 John founded and managed Peligro Audio in New York. John was also a talented photographer working in the fashion industry, and he founded and managed Indy Road Productions in 2005. With Indy Road Productions, John was instrumental in the production of photo shoots for Karl Lagerfeld, Chanel, Fendi, Vogue, and numerous others. He devoted himself to producing the epic Metiers d'Art with Chanel held in Dallas, Texas in December 2013. John was a loving, talented, generous, and kind man, whose work and varied interests took him around the world. He was a friend to so many in Texas, New York, and around the world. John's family and friends will miss him beyond measure. He is irreplaceable. John is survived by his mother Mary Korby, his father Jerry McNabb, his stepfather Steve Korby, his sister Sophie Dowling and her husband Charles, stepsisters Meg (Blake) Bassett and Melissa (Doug) Fordyce, and his loving nieces and nephews Henry, George, and Mary Dowling, Ellie, Caroline, and Brynn Bassett, and Abby and Sam Fordyce, and his aunt Cheri Rambeau. Funeral services will be held at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home in Dallas on Sunday, May 25 at 2:00pm. His family will receive visitors at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home from 4:00pm to 6:00pm on Saturday, May 24. A private burial will be held Monday. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Fender Music Foundation (fendermusicfounda tion.org) or Operation Kindness (www.operationkind ness.org) in memory of John.

RATTNER--Warren N.,passed away on May 19, 2014. He was a loving and loyal father, husband, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend. A supreme "triple threat" athlete, and passionate democrat, he will always be remembered with the utmost love and respect.

HELLER--Dorothy, born March 26, 1939, died from complications from Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma on May 17, 2014. Born in Beacon, New York, she resided with her Husband for over twenty-five years in Sands Point, New York, before they relocated to Boca Raton, Florida to be near their grandchildren. Beloved wife of more than 56 years to Edwin Heller (a retired corporate partner of Fried Frank), proud mother of daughter, Dr. Dana A. Heller (Galina Tsoy), Eminent Scholar and Chair of the Department of English at Old Dominion University, and son, William P. Heller, Esq. (Allison), a partner in the firm of Akerman LLP and Chair of the firm's National Consumer Finance Litigation and Compliance Practice Group. Dorothy was a devoted grandmother to her three grandchildren: Ryan, Samantha and Lindsey. When she died the world lost one of its most beautiful and gracious angels. As was said at her 75th birthday, attended by her entire family, there are no words sufficient to express appreciation for the love and joy that she inspired and the enhancement of the lives of all who were blessed to know her. Dorothy had a heart transplant in May 2009 and all admired her courage and strong character. She was at risk for Lymphoma because she, and many organ recipients are required to take drugs that appreciably decrease the immune system. Memorial Donations may be made payable to University of Maryland Balitmore Foundation (UMBF, Inc.). Donations together with the Dorothy and Edwin Heller Heart Transplant Research Fund at University of Maryland School of Medicine will be used to support research to reduce dependency on immunosuppressant drugs following an organ transplant. Mailing address: UMSOM Development, 31 S. Greene Street, Suite 300, Baltimore MD 21201. Attn: K Hussey or online at www.fundformedicine.org.

RECKSEIT--Ronnie. A light has gone out. Ronnie Reckseit, businessman, comedian and magician passed away in New York on May 22 at the age of 82, Ronnie was predeceased by his loving sons Marc and David and leaves behind his beloved family: wife Jackie, daughter Phoebe, stepdaughters Patrice and Isa, daughters-in-Iaw Jennifer and Michelle, granddaughters Rachel and Madyson and many loving nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and nephews. Ronnie will be greatly missed by his loving family and many friends. Funeral services at Shaarei Tikvah in Scarsdale, NY on Sunday at 11am, followed by burial at Wellwood Cemetery in Farmingdale, L.I. Shiva will be observed at the home of Patrice Gordon, 27 Soundview Dr., Eastchester, NY from Sunday following the burial through Friday morning.

SICKLE--Luke, became a casualty in life's battle on Friday, May 16, 2014, at age 77. An Ohio childhood, followed by military service and university training paved his way to a brief teaching stint before his lights (neon) lured him into an entertainment career. Theater, cinema and television were fertile fields for his creativity. A boisterous love of life was detected in his easy smile and ready chuckle. In later years, having assumed the role of curmudgeon, apt barbs were delivered when appropriate. Surviving are his sister-in-law, Betty Sickle; three nephews, Gary, Bruce and Mark Sickle; and the love of his life, Susan Schwirck.

WIGGINS--Clarence A. Age 54, died on May 20th 2014 in New York, NY. Clarence, fondly known as Tony, was born in Norfolk, Virginia but raised in Rocky Mount, North Carolina. He graduated from the US Naval Academy and served as a Qualified Surface Warfare Officer where he was deployed globally. He held a Juris Doctor from the University of Detroit, School of Law and went on to work for a series of major corporations and governmental agencies. Clarence was passionate about collectibles, music, food, and culture. He was predeceased by his father, Clarence Wiggins and is survived by his son, Brennan, mother, Gladys, two sisters, Valerie, Sonya (Troy) niece, Zora, nephew, Langston, and numerous relatives in NC, VA, and CT. Services will be Saturday May 31st at 11am at Mt Pisgah Presbyterian Church, Rocky Mount, NC 27801. Memorial Donations can be made to the APS Foundation of America, in memory of Clarence Wiggins (pulmonary embolism).

SHORE--Jerry. Died at age 88 on May 19th. He was born in Sea Gate, Brooklyn and lived with his family for many years in Sands Point, NY. He attended Brooklyn Tech High School and received a Bachelor's Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Purdue University in 1946 and a Master's Degree in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University in 1947. Jerry served in the US Navy Air Corps in WWII. In 1954, he founded Park Electrochemical Corporation (PKE), which is a multi-national company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Jerry served as Park's CEO until 1996, when he retired from the Company. He served as Chairman of the Board until 2004, when he retired from the Company's Board of Directors. Upon retiring, Jerry embarked on a new and prolific career as a professional sculptor. A true artist at heart, Jerry started Shore Sculpture, a large-format sculpture studio that was thoroughly embedded in the local community in Port Washington, NY. Major pieces of his have been featured in art exhibitions and are currently on display in sculpture gardens throughout the country. He leaves his wife Cecile of 65 years and his children, Brian, Robin and Peter and their spouses, Barbara, Laura and Jennifer as well as his beloved and adored grandchildren Ben, Sam and Mariah. Jerry is also survived by his brother Mel, of Sacramento, CA. For Jerry, love meant vigorously going to the ends of the earth to ensure the happiness of those he cared for. A life-long learner, Jerry was constantly striving to deepen his understanding of the world, while taking every opportunity to teach, guide, and mentor those around him. A man of simple needs, he devoted himself to improving the human condition as a humanitarian, philanthropist, and artist. Jerry was both the eternal patriarch and rebellious boy from Brooklyn, trousers torn and head held high. He will be dearly missed.
SHORE--Jerry. Bob, Willa, Betsy and Sue Bernhard treasure our very long relationship with Jerry Shore and family. He was a remarkable man and a dear friend. We mourn his death.
FRIED--Arthur K. May 25, 1935. Beloved Husband, Father and Saba. Lovingly remembered today and every day.

GRANT--Stanley R. 1/24/18 - 5/25/93 You are in my heart always. Not a day goes by that we don't talk. Love, Joan

ROGERS--Howland P. Howland Pendleton ("Pen") Rogers passed away peacefully on Monday, May 19, 2014, at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. Born in New York City on July 11, 1922, to Henry Pendleton Rogers, Jr. and Gladys Pell, he grew up in New York City and Tuxedo Park, New York. His ancestors included Elbridge T. Gerry, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and fifth Vice President of the United States; Nathaniel Pendleton, an officer in the Continental Army who was Alexander Hamilton's second in his duel with Aaron Burr; and Albert Gallatin, who, as Secretary of the Treasury under Thomas Jefferson, financed the Lewis & Clark Expedition and later was a founder of New York University. A graduate of the Brooks School and Harvard University, Pen joined the Army in 1944; a member of the 32nd Infantry Division serving in the Pacific, he was honorably discharged with the rank of Captain. Returning to Tuxedo Park after the war, he helped revitalize the community, assuming key roles including Mayor and Police Commissioner of the Village of Tuxedo Park and President of the Board of Trustees of the Tuxedo Park School. An avid golfer, he was active in building the new golf course at the Tuxedo Club in the 1950s; other club memberships included the Seminole Golf Club and U.S. Seniors Golf Association. He later made his home in Hobe Sound, Florida, where he served as President of the Jupiter Island Club. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Zosia Rogers; their daughter, Susan Moehlmann; his daughter, Lisa Taylor, and son, Henry P. Rogers, from an earlier marriage; his step-daughter, Sandra Penati; and six granddaughters. In lieu of flowers, consider donations to the Hobe Sound Community Chest (hobesoundcommunitychest.org) or Wounded Warrior Project (woundedwarriorproject.org).
ROBERTS--Malvina. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to her family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

ROBINSON--Charles W. Save Venice Inc. extends its condolences to former Board member Mara Robinson and her family on the passing of her beloved husband. Like the Mangia Onda boat he designed for Venice, Chuck changed the world without making waves.

PALLADINO--Tony. May 14, 2014. The Art Directors Club sadly, but with great pride, honors Tony Palladino, a pioneering designer and art director, one of the greatest ever inducted into our Art Directors Hall of Fame. Love of images and words, inspired by his talent and humanity, were the essence of his incredibly innovative oeuvre. Through his work, Tony Palladino will live forever.

ROBERTS--Malvina (Mimi), died at home in NYC on May 18th, less than two weeks after the passing of her beloved husband of 67 years, Mike. Mimi loved business, politics and art, but most of all her family and friends. She supported the feminist movement in its early years, working to elect female judges, and was a fundraiser for U.S. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who became a friend. She traveled extensively, spoke four languages, and worked in mergers and acquisitions in the '70's and '80's and as a commodities trader in more recent years. Mimi and Mike strongly supported Israel as both were Jewish refugees--Mike from Bolshevism in Russia and Mimi from the rise of Nazism in Europe. Mimi arrived in New York City on the last cruise ship to leave France prior to WWII with her mother and father. They had planned a short vacation to the 1939 World's Fair when war was declared during the voyage. Mimi is survived by her son Alec and spouse Barbara, daughter Judy and spouse Mark Tarlov, and three beloved grandchildren Jessie, Molly, and Benjamin.

MYERS--Carole Ann, (nee Jones), 69, of Summit, NJ, died May 21, 2014, at home after a long illness that she bore with patience and consideration for others. She requested no funeral service. Born in Philadelphia, she lived in Ambler, PA, and attended Upper Dublin High School, Fort Washington, PA. She was a 1966 graduate of Carroll College, Waukesha, WI, majoring in history. Carole met her husband, Andrew, while training for the U.S. Peace Corps. They taught school and did community development on Kuttu Island in Micronesia. She retired in 2013 due to illness after 25 years at Drew University Library, Madison, NJ, where she was Head of Circulation. A camper and backpacker, Carole loved nature, especially the woods and mountains. She hiked the Sierras and the Appalachian Trail and spent many summers with her family at Forked Lake in the Adirondacks. After her tour in Micronesia, she and her husband traveled west around the world and visited Southeast Asia, India, Iran, Cyprus, Greece, Europe and England. In recent years they chartered a sailing voyage in the Caribbean and visited Egypt, Belize, Yucatan, Peru and Kenya. Surviving are her husband, Andrew B., two children, Jason C. and Melissa A., two grandchildren, Madeline J. and Benjamin J. Ermisch, and her brother, Harry W. Jones of Mountainview, CA. A memorial service will be held in the future. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Sierra Club, the Yosemite Conservancy or the Appalachian Mountain Club.

RATTNER--Warren N.,passed away on May 19, 2014. He was a loving and loyal father, husband, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend. A supreme "triple threat" athlete, and passionate democrat, he will always be remembered with the utmost love and respect.

MOREINES--Harold "Harry" Moreines, of Springfield, NJ passed away at HCR ManorCare in New Providence on Wednesday, May 21, 2014 at the age of 90. The funeral will begin at Paul Ippolito Berkeley Memorial, 646 Springfield Ave., Berkeley Hts., NJ on Friday, May 23rd, at 11:00 a.m. followed by the funeral service to begin at 11:45 a.m. in the funeral home. Interment will follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin. For directions or to send condolences please visit www.ippolitofuneral homes.com. Harold was born in New York City and lived in Newark and Hillside before moving to Springfield 55 years ago. He graduated from Arts High School in Newark, where he nurtured his artistic talents. He then went on to graduate from Newark College of Engineering and earned a Master's degree in Engineering from Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken and an MBA from Fairleigh Dickinson University. Harold was an Army veteran of World War II. During his service he was present in Tokyo Bay at Japan's official surrender and was a part of General MacArthur's administrative support staff during the US occupation of Japan after the war. Harold was employed as an aeronautical engineer at Bendix Aviation Corporation (which was later Allied Signal then Honeywell Corp.) in Teterboro, NJ, where he served as Reliability Manager for the Bendix Guidance System Division. During his tenure at Bendix Harold was awarded several aerospace patents. He also was a key member of the team that designed the braking system for the Apollo Lunar Landing Module. Harold was a member of the IEEE and the Honeywell/Allied Signal Retired Employees' Association, where he was also on the Board of Directors. He is survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Lee (nee Kamen). Loving father of Dr. Robert Moreines and his wife, Susan Levine, of West Orange and Sherri Buchanan and her husband, James, of Berkeley Heights. Cherished grandfather of Jared and Lara Moreines and Brett, Erin, Scott, and Diana Buchanan. Dear brother of the late Madeline Stein and Daniel Moreines. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to SAGE Eldercare, 290 Broad St., Summit, NJ 07901 or Alzheimer's Association Greater New Jersey, 400 Morris Avenue, Suite 251, Denville, NJ 07834.

POLEMENI--Dr. Anthony John, of West Orange, NJ, passed away peacefully at home on Thursday, May 22 surrounded by his loving family. Dr. Polemeni served as vice president for Touro College's graduate schools of education, psychology, and social work, and dean of its School of Education and Psychology, Graduate Division. Dr. Polemeni joined Touro in 2001, after 20 years working for the New York State Education Department, which was followed by a highly successful career in international business. He is survived by his wife of fifty years and love of his life, Martha; his four children, Madeleine (Brian Hegarty), Mark (Pamela), Danielle (Sean McGovern), and Anthony; ten beautiful grandchildren; and his sister, Eugenia Paras. The viewing will be held at Caggiano Memorial Home in Montclair, NJ on Sunday, May 25 from 7:00 - 9:00pm and Monday, May 26 from 2:00 - 4:00pm and 7:00 - 9:00pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Cassian Church on Tuesday, May 27 at 10:00am followed by interment at Immaculate Conception Cemetery. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers, to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, lls.org, or to The American Cancer Society, acs.org, would be appreciated.

BEHR--Andrew Jay, passed away Wednesday in Bonita Springs, FL after a short but brave fight with cancer. He was 73. He was born on June 15, 1940 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Brooklyn Prep, Fairfield University and Harvard University PMD. He was an executive in the food industry for 42 years, most recently with Nabisco prior to retiring in 2005. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Claire M. Behr, and two children, Jeanine B. Getz and Andrew J. Behr, and three grandchildren, Millicent Getz, Andrew Behr and Harper Behr. A memorial service will be held on June 12th at 11am at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Richmond, VA. CHRISTY--Dr. Nicholas P.,90, of Westerly, RI and Niantic, CT, former Professor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died peacefully Saturday, April 26, 2014 at The Westerly Nursing Home. Born in Morristown, NJ, June 18, 1923, he moved to New York City after his graduation from Yale University and lived there until his retirement in 1994. Dr. Christy received his medical degree from Columbia University College of P & S in 1951, concluding his post-graduate studies in biochemistry at Columbia in 1959. He served in the USNR from 1942 to 1946. Concentrating in endocrinology at Columbia, Dr. Christy won awards for undergraduate research, scholarship in the medical sciences and meritorious post-graduate research. He was Editor-In-Chief of the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism from 1963 until 1967, and an Associate and Consulting Editor of the Cecil-Loeb Textbook of Medicine from 1967 to 1978. He authored or contributed to over one hundred papers published in the New England Journal of Medicine, the American Journal of Medicine, the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology, the Journal of the American Medical Association and others. He was the editor and co-author of The Human Adrenal Cortex published by Harper & Row in 1971. Dr. Christy was Director of the Department of Medicine at Roosevelt Hospital, NYC from 1965 to 1979. He was Chief of Staff at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY from 1979 to 1988. Dr. Christy was a member of the American Clinical and Climatological Association, the Endocrine Society and the Mahler Society. He was a lifetime member of the Century Association, NYC and president from 1987 1990, during which time he presided over the admission of women to that formerly all-male institution. He married Beverly Morris in 1947, who pre-deceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife of fifteen years, the former Caroline P. Adams, son and daughter-in-law, Nicholas, Jr. and Sonya M. Christy, daughter, Martha V. Christy, and three grandchildren, Nicholas III, Luke, and Beverly. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, May 31 at 11am at Christ Church in Westerly, RI. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Endocrine Society trainee and fellowship awards program, 2055 L Street, Ste.600, Washington, D.C., c/o Amy Woodward.

BEM--Sandra Lipsitz. Emerita Professor of Psychology at Cornell, past director of Cornell's Women's Studies Program, and a psychotherapist, peacefully ended her own life at her home in Ithaca on May 20, 2014, one month before her 70th birthday. She had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease in 2010, and made known at that time her intention to end her life while she could still do so without assistance if and when the disease became too debilitating for a meaningful quality of life. Sandra was born and raised in Pittsburgh, PA, and received her bachelor's degree in psychology from Pittsburgh's Carnegie Institute of Technology in 1965-now Carnegie-Mellon University (CMU). During her senior year, she met and married Daryl Bem, a new assistant professor there. In 1967, she received her PhD in psychology from the University of Michigan and joined Daryl on the faculty at CMU. In 1969, they joined the Psychology Department of Stanford University, where Sandra initiated her research on gender. In 1978, she was hired by Cornell University as Professor of Psychology and Director of the Women's Studies Program. She and Daryl remained on the Cornell faculty until their respective retirements in 2010 and 2007. Sandra received several honors for her scholarly work. She received the American Psychological Association's Distinguished Scientific Award for an Early Contribution to Psychology (1976), the Association for Women in Psychology's Distinguished Publication Award (1977), and the American Association of University Women's Young Scholar Award (1980). Her 1993 book, The Lenses of Gender: Transforming the Debate on Sexual Inequality, was honored by the Association of American Publishers as the Best Book in Psychology for that year. In 1998, she published An Unconventional Family, a memoir of her marriage to Daryl and their strategies for raising their two children to be as free of the society's gender constraints as possible. Both Sandra and Daryl were activists in the feminist movement and frequently spoke together publicly on sex roles in contemporary America. Sandra served as an expert witness in two notable sex discrimination cases: one filed by the National Organization for Women (NOW) against the Pittsburgh Press for segregating classified job listings into "Male Help Wanted" and "Female Help wanted" columns. The Press lost the case and appealed the decision all the way to the Supreme Court, which ruled 5-4 in favor of NOW. Sandy also appeared with Daryl as an expert witness in a hearing before the Federal Communications Commission in 1972, which had charged AT&T of discriminating against women. In a widely publicized settlement, AT&T agreed to modify several of its practices. The Bems' testimony is described in detail in Stockford's 2004 book, The Bellwomen: The Story of the Landmark AT&T Sex Discrimination Case. In 1997, Sandra enrolled in Rutgers' Psy.D program and, in 1980, received her license to practice psychotherapy in New York State. She then opened a part-time psychotherapy practice in Ithaca. Sandra was predeceased by her parents, Peter and Lillian Lipsitz. In addition to Daryl, her husband of 49 years, Sandra's survivors include her daughter Emily Bem (Julius Viksne and their 17-month-old son Felix Viksne Bem), son Jeremy Bem, sister Beverly Lipsitz (Roz Basin and their son Ben Basin), brother-in-law Barry Bem and sister-in-law Robyn Bem. Her final months were considerably brightened by her delight with her new grandson, Felix. In lieu of a funeral or memorial service, the family met as a group with Sandra two days prior to her death to share their thoughts, feelings, and reminiscences with her and each other.

ENDERS--Gaetana, died peacefully Wednesday, May 21, 2014 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Born in Tangier, Morocco, the youngest of four daughters of Elena Atzori and Giuseppe Marchegiano, General Counsel of the Supreme Court of Italy and Administrator for Judicial Affairs for the International Zone of Tangier. She and Thomas Ostrom Enders of Hartford, Connecticut met in 1953 in Tangier, married in 1955, and together had four children. As the wife of a career diplomat and Ambassador, Gaetana worked to facilitate humanitarian and cultural relations in their international posts including Sweden, Yugoslavia, Cambodia, the European Community, Canada, and Spain. In Cambodia during the war in 1970-4 she established refugee camps and subsequently served on President Gerald Ford's panel supervising the settlement of Indochina refugees. When her husband left the Foreign Service in 1986 Gaetana began a new career as a journalist. From 1986 through 2013 she was International Editor for Hola and Hello magazines, sourcing and authoring interviews with personalities including Presidents Bush Sr., Gorbachev, Salinas, Fox, and Arias; Mstislav Rostropovich, Hilary Clinton, the Queens of Norway and Sweden, the Lauder Family, and Mayor Michael Bloomberg, amongst many others. Gaetana Enders served as a member of the Board of the Casita Maria Center for Arts & Education since 2007 and in 2010 she founded the Casita Maria Music Program. She served on the Boards of the Mexican Cultural Institute, the Salzburg Festival Society, and the Thomas Enders Endowment of ACSUS which promotes Canada US relations. She is a Dama di Commenda of the Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus of Savoy Orders. Gaetana was a Dame of Magisterial Grace in the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. She has been honored with the medal of the Americas Society for her contributions to Latin America, The Ellis Island Medal of Honor, the Women Together Award, and the Sociedad International de Valores de Arte Mexicano. She will be honored as a humanitarian with the James Parks Morton Award at the Interfaith Center of New York this June. An international traveler, she will be greatly missed by her many friends around the world. Gaetana is survived by her loving children Domitilla, Claire, Alice, and Thomas, her grandchildren Heloise, Cecilia, Thomas, and Benedict, and her beloved sisters Liliana, Gianella, and Maria Grazia, of Rome. The funeral Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, on Monday, June 2, 2014 at 9:30am. Donations in Gaetana's memory may be made to Casita Maria Music Program at www.casitamaria.org/donate

CHOOK--Paul H.,of Forest Hills, NY passed away on May 23, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY. Paul's professional career spanned a period of over 40 years in the advertising and publishing business. He specialized in marketing and advertising research to guide planners in media evaluation and advertising development. Paul served as President of Alfred Politz Media Studies, President of W.R. Simmons Research, Vice President of Young & Rubicam, and Executive Vice President of Ziff-Davis Publishing and the CBS Magazine Division. Paul was a Director and Board Chairman of the Advertising Research Foundation, a member of the Market Research Council and was elected to the MRC Hall of Fame. He is an alumnus of Columbia University in (Graduate School of Business) and of the City College of New York (Baruch School) where he also taught undergraduate and graduate courses in statistical methods and analysis over a period of 12 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 25, 2014 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76 Road) Forest Hills, NY.

FISS--Jeanette S, Ph.D.,psychologist, activist, and pioneer in Women's Studies transformed people's lives. Jenny died peacefully May 16, 2014. Born June 26, 1923 to S. Scherer and A. Feffer, Brooklyn. Jenny graduated valedictorian, Jefferson High School, 1940, University of Chicago, 1950, MA, and Yeshiva University, Ph.D., 1972. She founded the Women's Studies Program at Ramapo College, NJ. Honored by Rockland County feminists and NOW. Married Murray Fiss, artist.
