HAMMOND--Patricia (Patsy) Dempsey, of Summit, NJ passed away peacefully surrounded by her family on May 19, 2014, after courageously battling the effects of Lupus and Rheumatoid Arthritis for most of her life. She was the beloved wife of William (Bill) H. Hammond, Jr. and loving mother of Kathryn (Katie) Fox Hammond. Born on July 13, 1958, Patsy grew up in Wilmette and Kenilworth, Illinois. She attended Duke University and double-majored in Economics and French, graduating in 1980. From 1980 to 2001, she worked in various executive capacities at J.P. Morgan in New York, NY, rising to the level of Vice President. Patsy was selected to staff the Office of the Chairman under Sir Dennis Weatherstone, a two-year position that was a high honor. Patsy was a recognized leader in the field of work/life management, pioneering initiatives in support of working parents, women, and people with special needs. She developed and managed training programs for the investment bank and introduced one of the first on-line job posting systems on Wall Street. From 2002 to 2014, Patsy established and managed her own work/life management-consulting firm where she coached individuals on their careers and developed and delivered training to help employees with the work/life balance. Patsy found joy in creating networks for people, enabling them to make better career and life choices. One of Patsy's passions was volunteerism. She served Duke in many capacities following her graduation as a member of the Duke Alumni Association Board of Directors and the Annual Fund Reunion Committee. She also Chaired the Alumni Admissions Advisory Committee and was President of the Duke University Metropolitan Alumni Association. In 1990, she was awarded the C.A. Dukes Award for Outstanding Volunteer Service to Duke. From 1988 to 2008, Patsy was one of the leaders of the Arthritis Foundation, New York Chapter, serving on the Board of Governors for all twenty years. She also was a member of the Patient Services Committee of the Board of Governors and was a Certified Instructor of the Arthritis Foundation Self-Help Course and a strong Patient Advocate. In honor of the 50th Anniversary of the Arthritis Foundation in 1998, Patsy was named one of its 50 National Heroes Overcoming Arthritis. Patsy was also dedicated to Katie's school and served as the President of the Kent Place School Parents' Association, a committee member, Class Mom, Star Mom and established and led the Girl Scout Troop at the school. Additionally, Patsy volunteered at the churches she attended, most recently serving at Christ Church on the Youth Group Volunteer Team, the Miss Representation Team and providing staff training. Patsy was a member of the Junior League of Summit since 1996. She received the Active Volunteer of the Year Award for 2002-2003 and was known for her training expertise, which she generously shared during her service as an Active member and, most recently, as a Sustaining member. Her greatest passion and love was her family, especially her wonderful daughter Katie. In addition to Katie and Bill, she is survived by Maryann and Jeffrey Sedlack, Kathleen and George Malhame, Louis and Maria Dempsey, and Thomas and Melinda Dempsey. She was a loving aunt to Will, Anne, Meg, Charlie, Mary, Luke, Jack, Colin, Hannah, Maeve and Mark. The family will celebrate Patsy's remarkable life at Bradley, Brough & Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ on Wednesday, May 28 from 3:00 to 5:00pm and from 7:00 to 9:00pm. The funeral service will be held at Christ Church, 561 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ on Thursday, May 29th at 10:00am. The web site for the funeral home is bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Patricia Dempsey Hammond Financial Aid Fund at The Kent Place School, 42 Norwood Avenue, Summit, New Jersey 07901.

HELLER--Dorothy, born March 26, 1939, died from complications from Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma on May 17, 2014. Born in Beacon, New York, she resided with her Husband for over twenty-five years in Sands Point, New York, before they relocated to Boca Raton, Florida to be near their grandchildren. Beloved wife of more than 56 years to Edwin Heller (a retired corporate partner of Fried Frank), proud mother of daughter, Dr. Dana A. Heller (Galina Tsoy), Eminent Scholar and Chair of the Department of English at Old Dominion University, and son, William P. Heller, Esq. (Allison), a partner in the firm of Akerman LLP and Chair of the firm's National Consumer Finance Litigation and Compliance Practice Group. Dorothy was a devoted grandmother to her three grandchildren: Ryan, Samantha and Lindsey. When she died the world lost one of its most beautiful and gracious angels. As was said at her 75th birthday, attended by her entire family, there are no words sufficient to express appreciation for the love and joy that she inspired and the enhancement of the lives of all who were blessed to know her. Dorothy had a heart transplant in May 2009 and all admired her courage and strong character. She was at risk for Lymphoma because she, and many organ recipients are required to take drugs that appreciably decrease the immune system. Memorial Donations may be made payable to University of Maryland Balitmore Foundation (UMBF, Inc.). Donations together with the Dorothy and Edwin Heller Heart Transplant Research Fund at University of Maryland School of Medicine will be used to support research to reduce dependency on immunosuppressant drugs following an organ transplant. Mailing address: UMSOM Development, 31 S. Greene Street, Suite 300, Baltimore MD 21201. Attn: K Hussey or online at www.fundformedicine.org.

Services Monday, May 26, 11:30am at The Conservative Synagogue, 30 Hillspoint Rd. Westport CT, 203-454-4673. Interment following at Willowbrook Cemetery in Westport.

GOLDSTEIN--Herbert "Herb", 85, died May 19, 2014. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 25, 1928 to the parentage of Nathan and Ida Goldstein. He received his Bachelor Degree from Brooklyn College in Brooklyn, NY. He was a reporter at The New York Post during the 1960's. He retired from the United Nations in New York in 1986. Survivors are his devoted and caring wife, Delores Goldstein; one son; one daughter; two grandsons, a supportive brother-in-law, Kenneth Schwartz (Dolores); a special nephew, Sheron Cloyd (Ahtis), and other family and friends. Respecting his wishes, Services will be private.

ABATE--Catherine M.,The Board of Directors and staff of Community Healthcare Network (CHN) mourn the passing of our beloved and dynamic President and Chief Executive Officer. CHN was Catherine's passion, and we share her loss with the family, her husband Ron Kliegerman, son Kyle Kliegerman and his wife Lisa, and many dear friends to whom we extend our heartfelt condolences. She joined CHN 15 years ago following decades of work in the criminal justice field and after serving as the distinguished State Senator representing Chelsea and the West Village. She was a tremendous advocate for the health care needs of all those most at risk and a visionary and tenacious leader who always seemed able to marshal the resources for new and innovative programs. During her tenure, CHN quadrupled in size and moved from women's health services to offering a full range of primary care for individuals of all ages. Catherine wasn't satisfied with just being bigger, she inspired us all to want to be better. Thanks to her leadership, CHN pioneered successful new programs for teens, LGBT individuals and people with multiple chronic illnesses. She paved the way for all of CHN's clinics to receive FQHC status, Joint Commission accreditation and numerous other distinctions of quality and effectiveness. The CHN family remains committed to Catherine's lifelong dedication to social and economic justice in health care. Our loss is shared by all New Yorkers as we honor her invaluable contributions across a lifetime of public service.
KENIGSBERG--Dr. Herbert S. Colonel, U.S. Army, retired. Dearly loved, a true mensch. Rest in well deserved peace after a long, valiant battle. Helen and Jules Kornblau

LANDIS--Dr. Bernard, a longtime New York psychoanalyst who once taught with Erich Fromm, returned to school at 70 for a degree in painting, played piobaireachd--the earliest Scottish bagpipe music--and was an ardent bicyclist and early practitioner of tai chi, died Tuesday in his home in Sleepy Hollow. He was 88. Dr. Landis's doctoral thesis, Ego Boundaries, a study of the differentiation between the self and the external world, was published in 1970. He was a clinical associate professor of psychology in psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College, an assistant attending psychologist at Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic, and an associate professor of psychology at SUNY Purchase. Dr. Landis was also co-editor, with Dr. Edward S. Tauber, of In the Name of Life: Essays in Honor of Erich Fromm. Dr. Landis and Dr. Fromm, the psychoanalyst and philosopher, taught a series of seminars in Locarno, Switzerland, in 1974. More recently he coauthored three papers with Dr. Patricia Romano on the effects of biofeedback on respiratory diseases. He will be deeply missed by his wife of 59 years, Erica Landis; his daughter, Dylan Landis Baquet; his sister, Elaine Breiger; and his grandson, Ari Baquet. Contributions in his memory may be made to www.CurePSP.org or www.TheNation.com. Memorial to be announced.

MAZZOLA--Anthony T.,Former editor in chief of Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR, and the curator of Hearst Corporation's fine art collection, died May 21 in New York. He was 90. "Anthony Mazzola was a dynamic member of the Hearst Magazines family for more than 65 years," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. "Tony will be missed by everyone who had the pleasure of working with him." Frank A. Bennack, Jr., former CEO and now executive vice chairman of Hearst Corporation, added, "Tony Mazzola's contributions to Harper's BAZAAR and Town&Country have not only influenced those titles as they appear even today but our entire magazine business." Mazzola, the editor who defined affluence and style for millions of readers at the two magazines for 44 years, started his career at Hearst as an art director. In 1948, at the age of 25, Mazzola joined Town&Country as the youngest art director in the magazine's history. He held that post for nearly two decades, ultimately becoming editor in chief in 1965. Town&Country is the longest continuously published general-interest magazine in America, having been founded in 1846. "Tony Mazzola was one of the most creative editors I've known," said Hearst Corporation Director Gilbert C. Maurer. "A man of great personal style, he intuitively knew what good looked like and his work at Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR reflected that acute sensibility. Tony was a loyal friend as well as a valuable mentor to a generation of our younger talents." Building on what he once described as his "fascination with trends," Mazzola's Town&Country began to reflect the current events and social reorganization then affecting elite American society as the nation mourned the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and grappled with civil rights, the Vietnam War and the first stirrings of modern-day feminism. Mazzola said he was captivated "not by what's happening, but why." While still the magazine's art director in 1964, he published a tongue-in-cheek "It's Fun to Be Rich" issue. In 1966, his first year as Town&Country's editor in chief, he put the Rolling Stones on the cover of what was widely held to be the bible of conservative, blue-blooded America. The ensuing controversy prompted Hearst's executives to ask him, "Young man, do you know what you're doing?" "I think so," he replied. In fact, Mazzola did: By maintaining a meticulous balance between creating an exciting magazine and conveying the dignity of the subjects he presented, he broadened Town&Country's appeal and honored its audience. "People make fun of money," he once said, "but everyone forgets the good that money has done." In 1972, Mazzola was appointed editor in chief of Harper's BAZAAR and expanded his editorial style even further. He relished the opportunity to widen the magazine's scope, which he again did in 1983 by adapting its pages to reflect newly emerging trends such as the more mature, sophisticated fashions--and celebrities--of the time, and readers' increasing interest in lifestyle, as well as fashion, content. "We love the handle of being the fashion magazine with a little salt and pepper added," he said of BAZAAR in a 1983 interview. "We appeal to a woman with a very strong confidence level, who is sure of herself, not wishy-washy. She wants to know everything there is to know...and we have become the fashion and beauty book with personality, the one with heart." At the end of the decade, Mazzola again redesigned the magazine, this time to appeal to readers as they matured from trendy to classic tastes. Striving for what he called a "very unconventional, exciting visual product," Mazzola encouraged photographers such as Francesco Scavullo, Rico Puhlmann and Matthew Rolston to take dramatic, even abstract approaches to fashion. One result was a celebrated shot described by a writer as "a woman and a cabbage leaf facing off" to illustrate a story on vegetable dyes used in hair coloring. After he stepped down as editor in chief in 1992, Mazzola edited BAZAAR's 125th anniversary book in 1993. The project was both professionally and personally rewarding. "Reliving the history of this great magazine and knowing that I had a role in it is a great privilege," he said. In 1995, he was editorial director of Town&Country's two-volume 150th anniversary book. Mazzola was also the fine arts curator for Hearst Corporation, whose fine art collection emphasizes works on paper and emerging talents, many of whom have become household names since the collection was started. In addition to curating and cataloguing the collection, he produced many art and photography shows for Hearst Tower. Mazzola graduated from The Cooper Union with honors in 1948 and received The Cooper Union's distinguished alumni citation in 1992. After beginning study at The Cooper Union, he was drafted into World War II. His art background prompted an assignment to army intelligence, where he analyzed camouflage. He was awarded a Bronze Star for "meritorious achievement in connection with military operations against the enemy in Luzon, Philippine Islands." A recipient of numerous awards in the art direction and design fields, Mazzola was inducted as a Knight Officer of the Order of Merit by the Republic of Italy in 1967. He also served as a consultant and designer for such organizations as the United Nations Children's Fund, the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Princess Marcella Borghese, Inc., General Foods, Columbia Pictures, Inc. and the New York World's Fair of 1965. Mazzola is survived by his wife, Michele Morgan Mazzola, who worked with him at Hearst for over 45 years, and three children, Alisa Mazzola Mitchell, Marc Mazzola and Tony Mazzola. He is also survived by five grandchildren. There will be a private funeral in Indiana, and a memorial in New York at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 or http://www.mskcc.org/giving).

LEBOWICH--Edith Weinberg, of Pompano Beach, FL passed away on May 18, 2014, just 10 days after her 95th birthday. Survived by daughter Marcia Begel Dickerson and son-in-law Richard. Predeceased by daughter Barbara "Babs" Begel; and husbands Ben B, Begel and William E. Lebowich. Contributions in her memory may be made to Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 10 Brookline Place West, Brookline, MA 02445.

LEVINSOHN--Robert J.,Esq., 94, on May 19, 2014. Robert was a partner at the law firm Proskauer Rose LLP. A driving force behind the New York County Democratic Committee, he chaired its Law Committee for over forty years. A distinguished attorney, he was on the executive committee of the New York State Bar Association Tax Section. His pioneering role in fostering a reform of the judicial culture, rendering it free of corruption and unwarranted partisan influence, is still widely recognized. A lifelong activist devoted to the highest ideal of the Democratic Party, Robert was an early member of the Lexington Democratic Club. He naturally assumed a series of important positions of leadership in the world of politics and public policy. As a leader of Manhattan's postwar political reform movement, Robert helped spearhead the drive to remove the taint of political influence from the New York City judiciary and effectively removed partisan political considerations from the judicial nominating process. It is his extrodinary success in reforming Manhattan's judicial and political culture that will dundoubtedly be his most enduring legacy. Robert leaves behind his loving wife Louise Katz, daughters Donna M. Levinsohn and Dorothy A. Laurence, and grandson James Levinsohn. His love and caring for others will be missed. In lieu, of flowers, contributions to The Coalition for the Homeless. Memorial Friday, May 30, 2014, 11:45am, "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEVINE--William F.,January 14, 2014. Loving husband of Pamela Sharpe; cherished father of Julia, Elizabeth, Steven and Paul. A passionate and intellectually formidable lawyer, loved and respected by all who knew him. Former President of the Nassau County Bar Association and recipient of its Distinguished Service Medallion. His integrity, generosity, boundless sense of humor and kind heart touched everyone he met. He is greatly missed.

Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 25, 2014.

SALVATORE--Joseph J. ESQ.,Born May 15, 1926. Died May 17, 2012. We miss you! Loving husband to Frieda for 60 years, dad to Paul, John, William, Thomas, and Elissa Harvey. Grandpa to ten. Preceded in death by parents Professor Paul and Mrs. Angelina Salvatore; sister Evelyn Barbieri. Trusts and Estates Attorney at firms of Satterlee, Warfield & Stephens; Krause, Hirsch & Gross; Davis, Polk & Wardwell; Cahn, Wishod & Lamb. Admitted to the US Supreme Court in 1986. WWII veteran. LLM at NYU Law School 1955, LLB Fordham Law 1951, BA Columbia 1948. An honest, generous, good humored man, whose favorite moments were with family and friends.

ROGERS--Howland P. Howland Pendleton ("Pen") Rogers passed away peacefully on Monday, May 19, 2014, at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. Born in New York City on July 11, 1922, to Henry Pendleton Rogers, Jr. and Gladys Pell, he grew up in New York City and Tuxedo Park, New York. His ancestors included Elbridge T. Gerry, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and fifth Vice President of the United States; Nathaniel Pendleton, an officer in the Continental Army who was Alexander Hamilton's second in his duel with Aaron Burr; and Albert Gallatin, who, as Secretary of the Treasury under Thomas Jefferson, financed the Lewis & Clark Expedition and later was a founder of New York University. A graduate of the Brooks School and Harvard University, Pen joined the Army in 1944; a member of the 32nd Infantry Division serving in the Pacific, he was honorably discharged with the rank of Captain. Returning to Tuxedo Park after the war, he helped revitalize the community, assuming key roles including Mayor and Police Commissioner of the Village of Tuxedo Park and President of the Board of Trustees of the Tuxedo Park School. An avid golfer, he was active in building the new golf course at the Tuxedo Club in the 1950s; other club memberships included the Seminole Golf Club and U.S. Seniors Golf Association. He later made his home in Hobe Sound, Florida, where he served as President of the Jupiter Island Club. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Zosia Rogers; their daughter, Susan Moehlmann; his daughter, Lisa Taylor, and son, Henry P. Rogers, from an earlier marriage; his step-daughter, Sandra Penati; and six granddaughters. In lieu of flowers, consider donations to the Hobe Sound Community Chest (hobesoundcommunitychest.org) or Wounded Warrior Project (woundedwarriorproject.org).

HAMMOND--Patricia (Patsy) Dempsey, of Summit, NJ passed away peacefully surrounded by her family on May 19, 2014, after courageously battling the effects of Lupus and Rheumatoid Arthritis for most of her life. She was the beloved wife of William (Bill) H. Hammond, Jr. and loving mother of Kathryn (Katie) Fox Hammond. Born on July 13, 1958, Patsy grew up in Wilmette and Kenilworth, Illinois. She attended Duke University and double-majored in Economics and French, graduating in 1980. From 1980 to 2001, she worked in various executive capacities at J.P. Morgan in New York, NY, rising to the level of Vice President. Patsy was selected to staff the Office of the Chairman under Sir Dennis Weatherstone, a two-year position that was a high honor. Patsy was a recognized leader in the field of work/life management, pioneering initiatives in support of working parents, women, and people with special needs. She developed and managed training programs for the investment bank and introduced one of the first on-line job posting systems on Wall Street. From 2002 to 2014, Patsy established and managed her own work/life management-consulting firm where she coached individuals on their careers and developed and delivered training to help employees with the work/life balance. Patsy found joy in creating networks for people, enabling them to make better career and life choices. One of Patsy's passions was volunteerism. She served Duke in many capacities following her graduation as a member of the Duke Alumni Association Board of Directors and the Annual Fund Reunion Committee. She also Chaired the Alumni Admissions Advisory Committee and was President of the Duke University Metropolitan Alumni Association. In 1990, she was awarded the C.A. Dukes Award for Outstanding Volunteer Service to Duke. From 1988 to 2008, Patsy was one of the leaders of the Arthritis Foundation, New York Chapter, serving on the Board of Governors for all twenty years. She also was a member of the Patient Services Committee of the Board of Governors and was a Certified Instructor of the Arthritis Foundation Self-Help Course and a strong Patient Advocate. In honor of the 50th Anniversary of the Arthritis Foundation in 1998, Patsy was named one of its 50 National Heroes Overcoming Arthritis. Patsy was also dedicated to Katie's school and served as the President of the Kent Place School Parents' Association, a committee member, Class Mom, Star Mom and established and led the Girl Scout Troop at the school. Additionally, Patsy volunteered at the churches she attended, most recently serving at Christ Church on the Youth Group Volunteer Team, the Miss Representation Team and providing staff training. Patsy was a member of the Junior League of Summit since 1996. She received the Active Volunteer of the Year Award for 2002-2003 and was known for her training expertise, which she generously shared during her service as an Active member and, most recently, as a Sustaining member. Her greatest passion and love was her family, especially her wonderful daughter Katie. In addition to Katie and Bill, she is survived by Maryann and Jeffrey Sedlack, Kathleen and George Malhame, Louis and Maria Dempsey, and Thomas and Melinda Dempsey. She was a loving aunt to Will, Anne, Meg, Charlie, Mary, Luke, Jack, Colin, Hannah, Maeve and Mark. ROGERS--Howland P. Howland Pendleton ("Pen") Rogers passed away peacefully on Monday, May 19, 2014, at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. Born in New York City on July 11, 1922, to Henry Pendleton Rogers, Jr. and Gladys Pell, he grew up in New York City and Tuxedo Park, New York. His ancestors included Elbridge T. Gerry, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and fifth Vice President of the United States; Nathaniel Pendleton, an officer in the Continental Army who was Alexander Hamilton's second in his duel with Aaron Burr; and Albert Gallatin, who, as Secretary of the Treasury under Thomas Jefferson, financed the Lewis & Clark Expedition and later was a founder of New York University. A graduate of the Brooks School and Harvard University, Pen joined the Army in 1944; a member of the 32nd Infantry Division serving in the Pacific, he was honorably discharged with the rank of Captain. Returning to Tuxedo Park after the war, he helped revitalize the community, assuming key roles including Mayor and Police Commissioner of the Village of Tuxedo Park and President of the Board of Trustees of the Tuxedo Park School. An avid golfer, he was active in building the new golf course at the Tuxedo Club in the 1950s; other club memberships included the Seminole Golf Club and U.S. Seniors Golf Association. He later made his home in Hobe Sound, Florida, where he served as President of the Jupiter Island Club. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Zosia Rogers; their daughter, Susan Moehlmann; his daughter, Lisa Taylor, and son, Henry P. Rogers, from an earlier marriage; his step-daughter, Sandra Penati; and six granddaughters. In lieu of flowers, consider donations to the Hobe Sound Community Chest (hobesoundcommunitychest.org) or Wounded Warrior Project (woundedwarriorproject.org).

GOLD--Melvin Leonard, one of the nation's foremost actuaries, died at his Teaneck home on Memorial Day after a well-fought battle with Parkinson's. He was 88. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, May 28, at 11am at Robert Schoem's Memorial Chapel, 150 New Jersey 4, in Paramus, NJ, followed by burial in Union, NJ. Born February 10, 1926, in Philadelphia to Reba (formerly Kligman) and Phillip, Mel grew up during the Depression as the only child of his older immigrant parents and the half-brother of Al, Edith, Norma, Rose, and Sylvia. A brilliant student, he made his own way in the world. Mel earned a full scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania and although his studies were interrupted for U.S. Navy service during World War II, he graduated in 1947 with a bachelor's in Mathematics. He became an actuary at The Prudential in Newark and passed the stringent actuarial exams on the first try. After marrying Shifra "Sherry" Gerber, they moved to Israel, where Mel worked for Migdal Insurance. When they returned to the States, they settled in West Orange, NJ, and he later founded Melvin L. Gold & Associates, a leading actuarial consultancy. He was instrumental in the growth of several insurance companies, most notably Presidential Life, and served on the board for years. Mel was ahead of his time on an array of professional, social, and health issues. For example, almost 20 years ago, in a Letter to the Editor of The New York Times he took to task an article about Social Security reform that did not discuss what he believed was a "clear solution" promptly raising the retirement age to 70, and then beyond as life expectancies increased. In another favorite letter in The New York Times, he suggested all election ballots include an option for voters to select, "None of the above." Mel liked being unconventional. In college, he proactively partnered with a black bridge player when others wouldn't consider it. Despite being excluded from numerous tournaments because of race, the duo became nationally ranked college champions. When Best's Review insurance magazine wanted to put him on the cover, they asked for a photo. Instead of a headshot, he sent one showing him jogging past the ancient pyramids in Egypt. Mel also took his health very seriously and in his 40s, realized that food has a profound impact on well-being. He shunned salt, red meat, alcohol, coffee, desserts, and fats. His signature drink became hot water. In philanthropy, he was most passionate about Israel and Judaism, strongly supporting Yiddish culture and Young Judaea. Mel was a world traveler, sculptor, and athlete. He ran the Jersey Shore Marathon in middle age and loved sailing on Bantam Lake, CT, where he summered for the last 50 years. He had gusto for life unmatched except by his loving wife and partner-in-adventure for 64 years. They loved to sing and dance, and Mel was expected to belt out "Tum Balalaika" and dance the kazatske at every family celebration. Mel is survived by Shifra; his four children Charles of New York, NY, and his wife, Anne Kohn; Neil of Fair Lawn, NJ; Ronald of Saddle River, NJ, and his wife, Betsy August Gold; and Nina of Fair Lawn, NJ, and her husband, Raviv Ron; and his seven grandchildren Stephanie, Jacqueline, Alexandra, Samuel, and Jacob Gold, and Avital and Maya Ron. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to Young Judaea, 575 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY, 10018, or The National Yiddish Theatre -- Folksbiene, 90 John Street, New York, NY, 10038.

ASCHER--Celia, art curator, advisor, collector, wife and friend, age 93, passed away peacefully on April 8, 2014 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale. Celia was born in Berlin, Germany on April 20, 1920. At a young age she escaped the Nazis and became a refugee in London where she met her future husband, Joseph Ascher. She married Mr. Ascher on New Year's Day as German 'bombs were falling' on the city of London. After World War II, the Aschers immigrated to the United States and made their home in New York City. When Celia arrived in New York and saw Times Square she felt she had literally moved out of the darkness of London and into the light. Throughout her life, Celia was devoted to the arts. Even as a child in Berlin, when given the opportunity Celia would choose to spend her spare time looking at art rather than indulging in typical child's play with the other children. She could often be found touring art galleries, visiting artist's studios, taking in concerts, studying music and visiting museums. Celia had a great love for art in all forms; visual arts, performing arts and classical music. She had an insatiable appetite for knowledge and always wanted to remain relevant and up-to-date. In her professional life, Celia worked tirelessly as curator to the business tycoon, Meshulam Riklis, and his corporation to build the McCrory Corporation Collection of Constructive Art. That collection was later donated by the corporation primarily to the Museum of Modern Art, New York. Celia also was an advisor to many art collectors and had a unique understanding of the point of view of the artists whom she knew and loved. Celia had a quick, assured eye and an uncompromising demand for quality, which she relied on in building her own collection, the Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection. Celia became a friend to the Juilliard School after taking part in many classes in the Evening Division and endowing the Celia and Joseph Ascher Fund for Piano in 2008. Celia had a particular affection for the piano having played in Berlin prior to fleeing. Celia also was a subscriber of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center and to several classical series at Carnegie Hall for more than 50 years. Celia is preceded in death by her husband in 1979 and is survived by friends and several nieces and nephews. She also is survived by her beloved paintings--which she referred to as "her children". The Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection will live on at the Louisiana Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark, and Celia's memory will live on in the hearts of those who loved her. William D. Zabel, the Executor of Celia's Estate, said the memorial service for Celia will take place at 5pm on June 18th at the Juilliard School, 155 West 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Celia's memory to the Juilliard School, the Louisiana Museum or an arts institution of one's choosing.

CHRISTY--Dr. Nicholas P.,90, of Westerly, RI and Niantic, CT, former Professor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died peacefully Saturday, April 26, 2014 at The Westerly Nursing Home. Born in Morristown, NJ, June 18, 1923, he moved to New York City after his graduation from Yale University and lived there until his retirement in 1994. Dr. Christy received his medical degree from Columbia University College of P & S in 1951, concluding his post-graduate studies in biochemistry at Columbia in 1959. He served in the USNR from 1942 to 1946. Concentrating in endocrinology at Columbia, Dr. Christy won awards for undergraduate research, scholarship in the medical sciences and meritorious post-graduate research. He was Editor-In-Chief of the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism from 1963 until 1967, and an Associate and Consulting Editor of the Cecil-Loeb Textbook of Medicine from 1967 to 1978. He authored or contributed to over one hundred papers published in the New England Journal of Medicine, the American Journal of Medicine, the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology, the Journal of the American Medical Association and others. He was the editor and co-author of The Human Adrenal Cortex published by Harper & Row in 1971. Dr. Christy was Director of the Department of Medicine at Roosevelt Hospital, NYC from 1965 to 1979. He was Chief of Staff at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY from 1979 to 1988. Dr. Christy was a member of the American Clinical and Climatological Association, the Endocrine Society and the Mahler Society. He was a lifetime member of the Century Association, NYC and president from 1987 1990, during which time he presided over the admission of women to that formerly all-male institution. He married Beverly Morris in 1947, who pre-deceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife of fifteen years, the former Caroline P. Adams, son and daughter-in-law, Nicholas, Jr. and Sonya M. Christy, daughter, Martha V. Christy, and three grandchildren, Nicholas III, Luke, and Beverly. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, May 31 at 11am at Christ Church in Westerly, RI. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Endocrine Society trainee and fellowship awards program, 2055 L Street, Ste.600, Washington, D.C., c/o Amy Woodward.

SEADER--Richard. The Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers mourns the passing on May 24 of Richard Seader, whose dedication and devotion to this organization was shown in his many years of service on the Board of Governors and also as a Trustee to the Benefit Funds. ACKERMAN--Jack Rossin, passed away peacefully on May 27 from Parkinson's Disease at the age of 83. He was born to Florence and Robert Ackerman in NYC. He graduated from Berkshire School, Harvard College '53, Harvard Business School '55. Jack began his career as an investment banker at Bache & Company where he worked for 25 years before going to Drexel Burnham and then starting Bondreview. He was a member of numerous corporate boards. Jack was a dedicated trustee of the Jewish Board of Family & Children's Service and the Jewish Foundation for the Education for Women. Jack will be remembered as a kind, gentle and caring person with the highest integrity. He was happiest while skiing, playing golf at Century and tennis in his "old men's" game. He had a passion for the theater, museums, concerts and the New York City Ballet. The time he spent in his garden in Pound Ridge brought him the greatest pleasure. Jack is survived by his beloved wife Dana of 39 years; cherished father of Ellen Miller (Peter) of Wayne, PA, Jay Ackerman (Elizabeth) of Bronxville and Robin Foley (Paul) of New Canaan. His son Bradley predeceased him. He also leaves his 10 grandchildren, Avery Eyre Lovejoy, Ashley, Toby and Libby Eyre, Brendan and Eamon Foley, Alexa Ackerman, James, Peter and Cooper Ackerman and a great-granddaughter Lila. A sister Jean Ackerman Thies also survives him. Donations in Jack's memory may be made to: JBFCS, 135 West 50th St., 6th Floor, NYC, NY 10020. The family will be receiving at the Frank Campbell Funereal Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, May 29th, 5:30 - 7:30pm.

LEVINE--Rebecca-Sue (nee Kurash), a fiercely honest and honorable attorney died Monday, May 26, 2014. She is survived by her sister Amy-Beth Hanover and brother-in-law Norman, nephews Lawrence (Carol) and Justin (Tara). Funeral Services Thursday, May 29, 2014, 1pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

PETERS--Athena, of Bayside Queens, passed away on Monday, May 26, 2014 after a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer. Athena was born in New York City. She completed both her Baccalaureate and Master's work at Columbia University. She was employed for many years at the career counseling office at Columbia University, eventually becoming Director of Career Services. During her time there, she helped to guide and launch the careers of New York City's best and brightest scholars. Throughout her life, and into her retirement, she was a tireless volunteer for many charitable causes; most especially North Shore University Hospital and her beloved St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing, NY. For her entire life, Athena served as an inspiration to those around her. She always encouraged stepping out, trying new adventures, and taking the path that may have been less traveled, but always held the promise of fabulous destinations. Always present through all of Athena's adventures were her love of and faith in Christ and her steadfast dedication to her family. She is survived by her sister, Chrissie Arlis and her brother-in-law Anthony Arlis, of Port Washington, NY, as well as by her niece Stephanie Arlis-Mayor and godson Rowland Mayor, and their children Michael, Chrysanthi and Athena Mayor. She was pre-deceased by her loving nephew Harry Arlis. A wake will be held on Wednesday, May 28 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frederick Funeral Home in Flushing, NY. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 29 at 11:30am at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing, NY. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Athena's memory to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, www.lustgarten.org.

FANNING--Dorothy Mary, died May 24, 2014 in New York at the age of 87 following a long illness. A retired nurse, after spending over 40 years in Florida, she returned to New York in October to be closer to her family. Dorothy, the daughter of Edward and Catherine Kern, was the youngest of six children all of whom predeceased her. She is survived by her son and daughter James and Kathy Fanning, and grandchildren Brian Fanning and Marlene Yolango, their spouses Lindsay and Frank, and six great- grandchildren: Owen, Patrick, Samantha, Anna, Megan and Kaitlyn. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at Handmaids of Mary Convent, 15 West 124th St., New York, NY 10027, 10am on Friday, May 30. Dorothy will be interred at Arlington National Cemetery with her husband of nearly 50 years, James, a World War II Veteran. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to The Shirley Goodman & Hilman Brown Hospice, 1844 Second Ave., NY, NY 10128, or the Lewy Body Association (www.lbda.org).

LENNEY--Ronald J.,born in the Bronx May 18, 1927 to Joseph and Ella Farkas Lenney. WWll Veteran. Graduate of Lehigh, lawyer, accountant, mentor to many, wise leader and friend. Respected and loved by his family: Dinah Lenney and Fred Mills (Eliza and Jake); Joseph P. Lenney (Charlotte and Sam); Andrew D. Lenney; and Julia K. Lenney. Husband for 53 years of Leah. Loving, strong, truly a man for all seasons. Services today 11am, May 28, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

REVESZ--Nora. Born June 12, 1922 in Bucharest, Romania. Died peacefully May 26, 2014 in New York, NY. Proud mother of Richard Revesz, mother-in-law of Vicki Been, and grandmother of Joshua and Sarah Revesz. Displaced by World War II, she lived in Paris and Buenos Aires before moving to New York in 1976. Following her retirement as vice president and head of private banking at Banque Nationale de Paris, she devoted herself to her family and to volunteer work at the New York Philharmonic and Lighthouse International. Fluent in six languages, she loved travel, classical music, and art.

LEVINSOHN--Robert J.,Esq., 94, on May 19, 2014. Bob was a partner at the law firm Proskauer Rose LLP. He chaired the New York County Democratic Law Committee for more than 40 years and was a long-time member of the executive committee of the New York State Bar Association Tax Section. Bob was an early member of Manhattan's postwar political reform movement, long-time member of the Lexington Democratic Club and a driving force behind the New York County Democratic Committee. His extraordinary success in reforming Manhattan's judicial and political culture will undoubtedly be his most enduring legacy. He effectively removed partisan political considerations from the judicial nominating process in Manhattan by establishing nonpartisan screening panels. His pioneering role in fostering a judicial culture less tainted by corruption and unwarranted partisan influence is still widely recognized as a model. A lifelong activist devoted to the highest ideals of the Democratic Party, Bob naturally assumed a series of important leadership positions in politics and public policy. Bob leaves behind his wife, Louise Katz; daughters, Donna M. Levinsohn and Dorothy A. Laurence; grandson, James Levinsohn. His love and caring for others will be missed. Memorial Service Friday, May 30, 2014, 11:45am, "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to www.autismspeaks.org in honor of Robert J. Levinsohn.

LACOMBE--Patricia, age 61, a former New York Times employee, passed away on May 22, peacefully at her home in New City, NY after a two year battle with ALS. She is survived by her husband of 39 years, Peter, and her two children, Danielle and Michael.

FISHMAN--Dr. Melvin I.,May 25, at age 86, A psychoanalyst in NYC and Great Neck for over 50 years. Husband of the late Alice Fishman, beloved father of Barry (Bryan) and Charles (Nancy), grandfather of Alexa and Kimberly. Funeral May 29, 11 a.m. Nassau North Chapel Great Neck.

GOODY--Eleanore Hack, of Forest Hills, NY, May 25, died of complications of a stroke after a long loving life. Born in 1928 to Frederick and Eleanore, devoted sister of Frederick and Frances, who both predeceased her, she was a 1946 graduate of Villa Maria in Lima Peru. She was the beloved wife of Lawrence Goody who died in 1985. Survived by daughter Carol and son-in-law Herman Gabora; son Ken and partner Todd Moffett; and grandchildren Keith and Amanda Gabora, she was a person of strong and passionate beliefs and was a deeply loving mother and grandmother, aunt and friend. Visitation and services on Wednesday and Thursday at Bartholomew Funeral Home, Bellmore, NY

MAIDENBAUM--Howard, Beloved husband of Eppie (nee Epstein) passed away May 27, 2014. Devoted father of Jeffrey (Marla), Jody Berman (Michael). Loving grandfather to Daria, Keith, Harris and Niki. "Our Miracle Man." Services today, 1pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, LI.

ASCHER--Celia, art curator, advisor, collector, wife and friend, age 93, passed away peacefully on April 8, 2014 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale. Celia was born in Berlin, Germany on April 20, 1920. At a young age she escaped the Nazis and became a refugee in London where she met her future husband, Joseph Ascher. She married Mr. Ascher on New Year's Day as German 'bombs were falling' on the city of London. After World War II, the Aschers immigrated to the United States and made their home in New York City. When Celia arrived in New York and saw Times Square she felt she had literally moved out of the darkness of London and into the light. Throughout her life, Celia was devoted to the arts. Even as a child in Berlin, when given the opportunity Celia would choose to spend her spare time looking at art rather than indulging in typical child's play with the other children. She could often be found touring art galleries, visiting artist's studios, taking in concerts, studying music and visiting museums. Celia had a great love for art in all forms; visual arts, performing arts and classical music. She had an insatiable appetite for knowledge and always wanted to remain relevant and up-to-date. In her professional life, Celia worked tirelessly as curator to the business tycoon, Meshulam Riklis, and his corporation to build the McCrory Corporation Collection of Constructive Art. That collection was later donated by the corporation primarily to the Museum of Modern Art, New York. Celia also was an advisor to many art collectors and had a unique understanding of the point of view of the artists whom she knew and loved. Celia had a quick, assured eye and an uncompromising demand for quality, which she relied on in building her own collection, the Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection. Celia became a friend to the Juilliard School after taking part in many classes in the Evening Division and endowing the Celia and Joseph Ascher Fund for Piano in 2008. Celia had a particular affection for the piano having played in Berlin prior to fleeing. Celia also was a subscriber of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center and to several classical series at Carnegie Hall for more than 50 years. Celia is preceded in death by her husband in 1979 and is survived by friends and several nieces and nephews. She also is survived by her beloved paintings--which she referred to as "her children". The Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection will live on at the Louisiana Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark, and Celia's memory will live on in the hearts of those who loved her. William D. Zabel, the Executor of Celia's Estate, said the memorial service for Celia will take place at 5pm on June 18th at the Juilliard School, 155 West 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Celia's memory to the Juilliard School, the Louisiana Museum or an arts institution of one's choosing.

CASTELLANI--Norman W.,89, of West Gale Street, Edenton, and of South Virginia Dare Trail in Nags Head, passed away on Friday, May 23, 2014. For complete service arrangements, please visit www.millerfhc.com.

SHEEHAN--Dr. Peter. An internationally respected force in the field of diabetes, died on May 16. He was 60 years old and was in health care management discussions with the government of Jamaica at the time of his death. The son of Dr. George Sheehan and Mary Jane Sheehan, Peter pioneered a multi-disciplinary approach to the treatment of diabetes, focusing on diet, exercise, and life-style changes. He graduated from Antioch College and received his MD from SUNY Downstate School of Medicine. He also completed a fellowship in endocrinology at the Yale University School of Medicine. After serving as Director of the Diabetes Treatment Center at Staten Island University Hospital, he became Medical Director of a new Diabetes Foot and Ankle Clinic at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York City and then was a senior faculty member at the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. He was appointed to the Board of directors of the American Diabetes Association and became the President of the New York City board which partnered with Mayor Michael Bloomberg in the City's first anti-obesity campaign. He called diabetes "the Hurricane Katrina of American healthcare." Dr. Sheehan had founded Sheehan Health Management, a consulting firm which emphasized the comprehensive interdisciplinary approach to diabetes. He helped develop the world class diabetes clinic at Sanford Health Center at USD in Sioux Falls South Dakota. Peter Sheehan was a beloved human being with an infectious sense of humor and a deep understanding of and affection for people from all walks of life. His friends and family loved his razor like wit and his jokes. He is survived by his wife Nadege and their son Patrick and three children from a previous marriage, Caitlin, Peter, and Nora, and all of his six brothers and five sisters. Friends may call at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. on Thursday and Friday from 2-4pm and 6-9pm. Funeral services are on Saturday at 10am at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, 184 East 76th St, New York.

CHRISTON--Theodora, August 8, 1925 - May 15, 2014. Dora "Teddy" Christon, a Hunter High School and College graduate, passed away quietly on May 15, 2014. She received her MS from NYU in Biochemistry and worked as a chemist for Dr. James Ducey. A great lover of the arts, she was a social secretary to the ballerina Dame Margot Fontaine. She also volunteered at the Museum of Natural History in her retirement.

GOLD--Melvin Leonard, one of the nation's foremost actuaries, died at his Teaneck home on Memorial Day after a well-fought battle with Parkinson's. He was 88. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, May 28, at 11am at Robert Schoem's Memorial Chapel, 150 New Jersey 4, in Paramus, NJ, followed by burial in Union, NJ. Born February 10, 1926, in Philadelphia to Reba (formerly Kligman) and Phillip, Mel grew up during the Depression as the only child of his older immigrant parents and the half-brother of Al, Edith, Norma, Rose, and Sylvia. A brilliant student, he made his own way in the world. Mel earned a full scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania and although his studies were interrupted for U.S. Navy service during World War II, he graduated in 1947 with a bachelor's in Mathematics. He became an actuary at The Prudential in Newark and passed the stringent actuarial exams on the first try. After marrying Shifra "Sherry" Gerber, they moved to Israel, where Mel worked for Migdal Insurance. When they returned to the States, they settled in West Orange, NJ, and he later founded Melvin L. Gold & Associates, a leading actuarial consultancy. He was instrumental in the growth of several insurance companies, most notably Presidential Life, and served on the board for years. Mel was ahead of his time on an array of professional, social, and health issues. For example, almost 20 years ago, in a Letter to the Editor of The New York Times he took to task an article about Social Security reform that did not discuss what he believed was a "clear solution" promptly raising the retirement age to 70, and then beyond as life expectancies increased. In another favorite letter in The New York Times, he suggested all election ballots include an option for voters to select, "None of the above." Mel liked being unconventional. In college, he proactively partnered with a black bridge player when others wouldn't consider it. Despite being excluded from numerous tournaments because of race, the duo became nationally ranked college champions. When Best's Review insurance magazine wanted to put him on the cover, they asked for a photo. Instead of a headshot, he sent one showing him jogging past the ancient pyramids in Egypt. Mel also took his health very seriously and in his 40s, realized that food has a profound impact on well-being. He shunned salt, red meat, alcohol, coffee, desserts, and fats. His signature drink became hot water. In philanthropy, he was most passionate about Israel and Judaism, strongly supporting Yiddish culture and Young Judaea. Mel was a world traveler, sculptor, and athlete. He ran the Jersey Shore Marathon in middle age and loved sailing on Bantam Lake, CT, where he summered for the last 50 years. He had gusto for life unmatched except by his loving wife and partner-in-adventure for 64 years. They loved to sing and dance, and Mel was expected to belt out "Tum Balalaika" and dance the kazatske at every family celebration. Mel is survived by Shifra; his four children Charles of New York, NY, and his wife, Anne Kohn; Neil of Fair Lawn, NJ; Ronald of Saddle River, NJ, and his wife, Betsy August Gold; and Nina of Fair Lawn, NJ, and her husband, Raviv Ron; and his seven grandchildren Stephanie, Jacqueline, Alexandra, Samuel, and Jacob Gold, and Avital and Maya Ron. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to Young Judaea, 575 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY, 10018, or The National Yiddish Theatre -- Folksbiene, 90 John Street, New York, NY, 10038.

SCHNELL--Nancy T.,of New York and Easthampton, NY, passed away on May 25, 2014. She was born July 16, 1952 to the late Lillian A. and Eugene A. Schnell. Graduated from Barlow School, Boston University, Columbia Business School and Parsons School of Design. Nancy lived in Brookline, MA, then returned to New York City. She worked as a Special Investment Officer at the Office of the New York State Controller. She was a member of The Dessoff Choirs and The National Arts Club for many years. Nancy is survived by her sister, Vicki L. Schnell and brother Eric A. Schnell and will be missed by her many relatives and friends. Donations in her memory may be made to The Dessoff Choirs, P.O. Box 1337, New York, NY 10028. Please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel for information about services, 212-362-6600.

CHRISTY--Dr. Nicholas P.,90, of Westerly, RI and Niantic, CT, former Professor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died peacefully Saturday, April 26, 2014 at The Westerly Nursing Home. Born in Morristown, NJ, June 18, 1923, he moved to New York City after his graduation from Yale University and lived there until his retirement in 1994. Dr. Christy received his medical degree from Columbia University College of P & S in 1951, concluding his post-graduate studies in biochemistry at Columbia in 1959. He served in the USNR from 1942 to 1946. Concentrating in endocrinology at Columbia, Dr. Christy won awards for undergraduate research, scholarship in the medical sciences and meritorious post-graduate research. He was Editor-In-Chief of the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism from 1963 until 1967, and an Associate and Consulting Editor of the Cecil-Loeb Textbook of Medicine from 1967 to 1978. He authored or contributed to over one hundred papers published in the New England Journal of Medicine, the American Journal of Medicine, the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology, the Journal of the American Medical Association and others. He was the editor and co-author of The Human Adrenal Cortex published by Harper & Row in 1971. Dr. Christy was Director of the Department of Medicine at Roosevelt Hospital, NYC from 1965 to 1979. He was Chief of Staff at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY from 1979 to 1988. Dr. Christy was a member of the American Clinical and Climatological Association, the Endocrine Society and the Mahler Society. He was a lifetime member of the Century Association, NYC and president from 1987 1990, during which time he presided over the admission of women to that formerly all-male institution. He married Beverly Morris in 1947, who pre-deceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife of fifteen years, the former Caroline P. Adams, son and daughter-in-law, Nicholas, Jr. and Sonya M. Christy, daughter, Martha V. Christy, and three grandchildren, Nicholas III, Luke, and Beverly. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, May 31 at 11am at Christ Church in Westerly, RI. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Endocrine Society trainee and fellowship awards program, 2055 L Street, Ste.600, Washington, D.C., c/o Amy Woodward.

COLAHAN--Anne Gibson, of Mount Pleasant Road in York, passed away May 27, 2014. She was born August 11, 1927 in Brooklyn and was raised in Manhattan and Westchester County. She was predeceased by her parents, Samuel P. and Annabel Flower Gibson, brothers, Robert and James Gibson. She is survived by her husband of 64 years, Thomas Seery Colahan, daughters, Alexandra Colahan of Fairport, Charity (Aaron) Donnan of Piffard, grandchildren, Seery, Gibson and Ingrid Donnan, close friend, Elizabeth Crowder. She was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend. "Tho' the pyramids crumble, Gibraltar may tumble. They're only made of clay. But our love is here to stay, forever another day." To share a memory, please visit: Rector-HicksFuneralHome.com.

LASSAW--Michael, DDS, passed away on Tuesday. Beloved husband of Janet, devoted father of Casey and Jake, dear brother of Robert (Debra) and brother-in-law of Lenny. MORFOGEN--Zachary Paul, 85, of Palm Beach, FL died Tuesday, May 27, 2014. He was the son of the late Paul and Anna (Landis) Morfogen. Zachary was born in New York on September 29, 1928. He graduated from Boonton High School and was inducted into their Hall of Fame. He went on to graduate from Brown University and received his Bachelor of Arts degree and was the recipient of the Brown Bear Award for outstanding service. Following Brown University he was a Sergeant Major in the US Army and a Veteran of the Korean War. He married his Boonton High School classmate, Marilyn in 1956 and had two children Ann and Paul. They lived for a short time in the Netherlands before settling down in Boonton and finally moving to Palm Beach Florida in 1998. Zach Morfogen's full and energetic career began as a promotion director of LIFE magazine; European manager of Time/ LIFE books; managing director of Time Inc.'s Books and Arts Associates; and director of Time Inc.'s Corporate Cultural Affairs department. He was founding Chairman Emeritus of the National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization and the National Hospice Foundation, and a member of the board of directors of the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute. Morfogen received the William Rogers Award from Brown University honoring an alumnus whose professional work and service to humanity exemplifies the charge of the Brown University Charter to its students to live a life of "usefulness and reputation." Upon retiring from Time in 1987, he and his wife, Marilyn, formed Morfogen Associates, a consulting company for corporations and cultural institutions and launched "News" a newsletter of arts events worldwide. Zach was also an accomplished painter and playwright. His latest book, Dealing with Death Free From Fear was published this month. He embraced life with the following words: care, appreciate, expand, reach, and celebrate. He is survived by his two children, Ann M., wife of George S. Weaver III, of Lancaster, PA, and Paul A. Morfogen, husband of Megan, of Boonton Township, NJ. seven grandchildren, Cary, Cullen, Helen, George IV, Zachary, Augustus, and Matthew, and two great- grandchildren, Jack and Freddie. He is also survived by one sister, Vivian Geaneas Morfogen, of Denville, NJ. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday, May 31, 2014 at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Catholic Church, 910 Birch Street, Boonton, NJ 07005 at 10am. A viewing will be held the morning of Mass from 8:30-9:30am at Dangler, Lewis & Carey Funeral Home 312 W. Main St. Boonton, NJ 07005. A viewing will also be held on Friday, May 30 at the Charles F. Snyder Funeral Home & Crematory 441 N. George St. Millersville, PA 17551 from 4-6pm. Interment will be held in St. Mary's Cemetery, Boonton, NJ. Additionally a Memorial Service will be held in honor of his Greek heritage 40 days following the burial at the Century Club in New York. Details in development. Memorial contributions may be made in his memory to The National Hospice Foundation, 1731 King Street, Alexandria, VA 22314 or The Roosevelt Institute, 570 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10022. To send the family online condolences, please visit SnyderFuneral Home.com Charles F. Snyder, Funeral Home & Crematory 717-872-5041

ACKERMAN--Jack Rossin, passed away peacefully on May 27 from Parkinson's Disease at the age of 83. He was born to Florence and Robert Ackerman in NYC. He graduated from Berkshire School, Harvard College '53, Harvard Business School '55. Jack began his career as an investment banker at Bache & Company where he worked for 25 years before going to Drexel Burnham and then starting Bondreview. He was a member of numerous corporate boards. Jack was a dedicated trustee of the Jewish Board of Family & Children's Service and the Jewish Foundation for the Education for Women. Jack will be remembered as a kind, gentle and caring person with the highest integrity. He was happiest while skiing, playing golf at Century and tennis in his "old men's" game. He had a passion for the theater, museums, concerts and the New York City Ballet. The time he spent in his garden in Pound Ridge brought him the greatest pleasure. Jack is survived by his beloved wife Dana of 39 years; cherished father of Ellen Miller (Peter) of Wayne, PA, Jay Ackerman (Elizabeth) of Bronxville and Robin Foley (Paul) of New Canaan. His son Bradley predeceased him. He also leaves his 10 grandchildren, Avery Eyre Lovejoy, Ashley, Toby and Libby Eyre, Brendan and Eamon Foley, Alexa Ackerman, James, Peter and Cooper Ackerman and a great-granddaughter Lila. A sister Jean Ackerman Thies also survives him. Donations in Jack's memory may be made to: JBFCS, 135 West 50th St., 6th Floor, NYC, NY 10020. The family will be receiving at the Frank Campbell Funereal Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, May 29th, 5:30 - 7:30pm.

In his spare time he enjoyed doing crossword puzzles, playing golf and watching TV; especially Jeopardy, C-SPAN, golf, baseball and football. Beloved father of Marie (Lennon), Patricia (Edwards) and Joseph Kavanagh Jr. Joe was an extremely proud grandfather ("Poppi" or "Hampa") of Patrick Lennon, Alexa Edwards, Lindsey Lennon, Elisa Lennon and Michael Lennon. Family and friends may visit at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, on Friday, 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. Mass on Saturday 9:30am at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington, NY. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery.

MELMAN--JoAnne Medalie, of Manhattan, NY, passed away peacefully at her home on May 28, 2014. Born June 11, 1930, in Buffalo, NY, to the late Benjamin Meyer and Eva Lippman, JoAnne grew up in Perry, NY, and is survived by her sister, Judy Sadkin. YOUNG--Patricia Ann, died suddenly after a brief illness on May 23, 2014 at the age of 66. Beloved daughter of Elizabeth and the late David Young, loving sister of Kathleen (William) Finneran, devoted Aunt to Lesley and John Finneran. Pat graduated with a BA from the University of Michigan and remained a passionate Wolverine. She went on to complete a Masters of Library Sciences from Simmons College and a MA from Brooklyn College. Pat was very proud of her long career as a librarian. She began her career at the Charles Warren Center for American History at Harvard University followed by a position at Wilmington Institute (Public) Library in Wilmington, DE. She then moved to work for Special Collections at the Ohio Historical Society in Columbus, OH, as Assistant Librarian for Technical Services. Subsequently, she moved to Brooklyn to work as a cataloger and then Access Services Librarian at Brooklyn College Library, Brooklyn, NY. Her career continued as she advanced to The City University of New York central office to work as the assistant Director for Library Automation Systems. Pat was instrumental in the development of the integrated library systems known as CUNY+. She enjoyed her long career in the Office of Library Systems at CUNY. Before she retired, Pat was the Director of Library Systems at CUNY and after retiring she continued to work as an Adjunct Systems Librarian in the same department. She also maintained strong professional connections with the national and local library organizations including NUGM, the American Library Association and of the New York Technical Services Librarians. Pat was an avid New York theater supporter and she cared deeply for her Brooklyn community. Pat will be remembered for her sharp intellect, mischievous sense of humor and her devotion to her dogs, Vincent, Rose and JoJo. Pat will be missed dearly by her family and friends and will remain in our hearts forever. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Brooklyn College Library.

ASCHER--Celia, art curator, advisor, collector, wife and friend, age 93, passed away peacefully on April 8, 2014 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale. Celia was born in Berlin, Germany on April 20, 1920. At a young age she escaped the Nazis and became a refugee in London where she met her future husband, Joseph Ascher. She married Mr. Ascher on New Year's Day as German 'bombs were falling' on the city of London. After World War II, the Aschers immigrated to the United States and made their home in New York City. When Celia arrived in New York and saw Times Square she felt she had literally moved out of the darkness of London and into the light. Throughout her life, Celia was devoted to the arts. Even as a child in Berlin, when given the opportunity Celia would choose to spend her spare time looking at art rather than indulging in typical child's play with the other children. She could often be found touring art galleries, visiting artist's studios, taking in concerts, studying music and visiting museums. Celia had a great love for art in all forms; visual arts, performing arts and classical music. She had an insatiable appetite for knowledge and always wanted to remain relevant and up-to-date. In her professional life, Celia worked tirelessly as curator to the business tycoon, Meshulam Riklis, and his corporation to build the McCrory Corporation Collection of Constructive Art. That collection was later donated by the corporation primarily to the Museum of Modern Art, New York. Celia also was an advisor to many art collectors and had a unique understanding of the point of view of the artists whom she knew and loved. Celia had a quick, assured eye and an uncompromising demand for quality, which she relied on in building her own collection, the Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection. Celia became a friend to the Juilliard School after taking part in many classes in the Evening Division and endowing the Celia and Joseph Ascher Fund for Piano in 2008. Celia had a particular affection for the piano having played in Berlin prior to fleeing. Celia also was a subscriber of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center and to several classical series at Carnegie Hall for more than 50 years. Celia is preceded in death by her husband in 1979 and is survived by friends and several nieces and nephews. She also is survived by her beloved paintings--which she referred to as "her children". The Celia and Joseph Ascher Collection will live on at the Louisiana Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark, and Celia's memory will live on in the hearts of those who loved her. William D. Zabel, the Executor of Celia's Estate, said the memorial service for Celia will take place at 5pm on June 18th at the Juilliard School, 155 West 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Celia's memory to the Juilliard School, the Louisiana Museum or an arts institution of one's choosing.

Box 1337, New York, NY 10028. Please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel for information about services, 212-362-6600.

REVESZ--Nora. Born June 12, 1922 in Bucharest, Romania. Died peacefully May 26, 2014 in New York, NY. Proud mother of Richard Revesz, mother-in-law of Vicki Been, and grandmother of Joshua and Sarah Revesz. Displaced by World War II, she lived in Paris and Buenos Aires before moving to New York in 1976. Following her retirement as vice president and head of private banking at Banque Nationale de Paris, she devoted herself to her family and to volunteer work at the New York Philharmonic and Lighthouse International. Fluent in six languages, she loved travel, classical music, and art.

SCHLOSS--Frances Anne, a life-long resident of Brooklyn and Queens, passed away at the age of 91. She was the devoted wife of the late Harold W. Schloss, daughter of Sylvia Plotnick Kavon and Isadore Kavon, and sister of the late Ida, Joseph, Morris and Paul Kavon. Active in many philanthropic activities, Frances was a dedicated volunteer and past-chairperson of the Women's Interboro Division of UJA-Federation of New York. She was a member of the Jewish Women's Caucus, a life member of Hadassah and NCJW, and served on the Board of the Kingsbay YM-YWHA and as a trustee of East Midwood Jewish Center. Frances Schloss is survived by her children Robert J. Schloss of Briarcliff Manor and Linda D. Schloss of Manhattan, daughter-in-law Emily M Sack, grandson Daniel Z. Schloss of Brooklyn, sister-in-law Devorah Kavon of Sunrise, FL and nieces and nephews Martin Kavon, Judy and Maurice Stein, Herbert, David and Susie Kavon, Shira and Burt Grossman, Aliza and Maurice Deray, Eli and Mayira Kavon. Donations in her memory may be made to UJA-Federation of New York or East Midwood Jewish Center. Services today, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", W. 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

de QUADROS--Ciro, M.D. Led efforts to vaccinate world's poor. The Trustees, Officers and staff of the Sabin Vaccine Institute note with great sorrow the passing of our friend, colleague and Executive Vice President, Dr. Ciro de Quadros, aged 74, who passed away peacefully at home in Washington, DC on May 28, 2014, surrounded by his family. He is survived by his loving wife, Susana; daughters Julia and Cristina; and stepsons Marcelo and Alvaro Boggio. Dr. de Quadros was born and raised in Brazil, where he completed his medical and public health studies. He dedicated his life to championing health as a fundamental human right and worked tirelessly on behalf of the world's poorest populations to increase access to life-saving vaccines. For more than a decade, Dr. de Quadros led our advocacy efforts, encouraging low- and middle-income countries to prioritize and sustain financing for vaccine programs, particularly those focused on protecting children. Prior to joining Sabin, Dr. de Quadros was Director of the Division of Vaccines and Immunization of the World Health Organization and the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO), where he helped avert thousands of deaths by leading efforts to eradicate polio and measles from the Western Hemisphere, and smallpox from Ethiopia. His forward-thinking vision, optimism and tenacity to overcome the seemingly impossible, coupled with his conviction that all countries, no matter their economic status, must invest in the well-being of their own people, helped transform modern day public health programs. A man of deep integrity, humility and compassion, Dr. de Quadros was a mentor to many within the global health community, and was lauded for his many accomplishments. Among the more than 36 prestigious honors and awards presented to him, he received PAHO's Public Health Hero of the Americas Award, bestowed upon individuals who have made extraordinary contributions to improving the health and well-being of the peoples of the Western Hemisphere (2014); the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award of Development Cooperation for contributions to global development through his work with disease eradication and control (2012); the Albert B. Sabin Gold Medal award (2000); and the highest civil award presented by the Government of Brazil, the Order of Rio Branco (1999). He was a giant in his field, passionately committed to his crusade of eliminating vaccine-preventable diseases. He will be greatly missed by his colleagues and many friends throughout the world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Morton P. Hyman Chairman of the Board Philip K. Russell, M.D. Immediate Past Chairman Michael W. Marine Chief Executive Officer Peter J. Hotez, M.D. President

ISHKANIAN--Lucy. Internationally recognized pianist who performed in the major concert halls around the world to great acclaim, died in a hospital in New York City on April 20. She was 80. Her nine tours from 1962 to 1979 throughout the former Soviet Union was part of the "Special Prize" award she received from the jury of the Second International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. She also was sent on tour by the US Department of State Cultural Program and performed throughout the Middle East, Southeast Asia, Western Europe, Argentina, and the United States under the management of impresario Sol Hurok. In 1971, she was presented by Hurok at her debut at Philharmonic Hall (now Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.) A native New Yorker of Armenian descent, she gave her first recital at age seven, two years after becoming the youngest student ever accepted to the Juilliard School Preparatory Division. She continued her education there as a scholarship winner for 15 years, and graduated with both Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees. She also completed requirements for a PH.D degree at Columbia University. Among her teachers were Beveridge Webster and Rosina Lhevinne. She also coached with some of the greatest musicians, including pianists Mieczeslaw Horszowski, Yakov Fliere, Emil Gilels, and composer Aram Khachaturian who entrusted her with the American premiere of his Piano Sonata. Among her greatest achievements was the foundation of the Juilliard-Komitas friendship program in 1992, enabling gifted students from the Komitas Conservatory in Yerevan, Armenia to be admitted to The Juilliard School in New York to continue their musical education. Ms. Ishkanian was an honorary professor at the Komitas Conservatory, and served as president of the jury for the graduation examinations. Ms. Ishkanian also was a distinguished member of international piano competition juries around the world, including the First International Aram Khachaturian Piano Competition in Yerevan in 1997, the First International Rachmaninoff Piano Competition in Los Angeles, CA in 2002, as well as the Dorothy MacKenzie Artist Recognition Awards at the International Keyboard Institute and Festival in New York City. Ms. Ishkanian is survived by her husband, Hagop Tankian. A brother, Vahe, predeceased her. There will be a 40th day requiem service on Sunday at the St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral, located at 221 East 27th Street in New York City, starting at 11:30am, after which there will be a musical tribute and a reception. Donations in her memory may be made to the Armenian Scholarship Fund at The Juilliard School.

Preceded in death by husband, Pryor, and sisters, Sara Ingga and Wilberta. Visitation Sunday, June 1st 4:00-6:00pm at The Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st and Madison. KLEIN--Lillian. Passed May 28, 2014 in New York City. Daughter of Julius and Sarah Klein. Predeceased by siblings Toby Klein Peller and Samuel David Klein. Survived by sister Anna Klein Taylor. Donations to American Jewish Congress.

AISENSON--Milton, died at home at the age of 97 on May 27, 2014. He is survived by his devoted wife of 65 years, Bernice. He graduated from NYU Medical School in the class of 1940, and was in practice as a pediatrician in Little Neck and Flushing, Queens for many years. Milton is also survived by his sister Rhoda, brother Allen and sister-in-law Emily, son Neil and daughter-in-law Jaime, daughter Tami and son-in-law Kevan, grandchildren Alyssa, Rachel, Lyle, Austin, and son-in-law Jason. He loved spending time with his children and grandchildren, and loved caring for the medical needs of children in his practice.

IMMERMAN--Elaine. Our beloved mother, Elaine Immerman, passed away peacefully at home in New York City on May 27, 2014 after a valiant fight with pancreatic cancer. Born Elaine Levy to Rose and Max Levy on May 14, 1925. She cherished her late brother Stanley H. Levy. Graduated Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, NY '38 "Always happy and full of fun, and always sweet to everyone". B.A. in Political Science from Brooklyn College '46. Married Dr. Samuel Gelband in 1965 (she had three sons from a previous marriage and Dr. Gelband had four children from a previous marriage, a son Les Gelband and daughters Myra, Barbara and Helen Gelband). Elaine was a brilliant, talented and accomplished award winning artist, and a member of the National Association of Women Artists. Past President, Patchogue Chapter, Brandeis University National Women's Committee '70-'72. She was a dedicated bridge player at The Regency Whist Club. She loved painting, golf, theatre, museums, concerts and travel. She will be remembered as a kind, gentle and caring person with the highest integrity. Elaine is survived by her sons Marc Sklar (DeeDee), Paul Sklar (Amy), and Daniel Sklar (Denise), grandsons Jacob, Maxfield, Samuel, Mason and Daron Sklar, sister-in-law Gloria Levy, nephews, Steven Levy (Leora) and Peter Levy (Nan), Joyce and Jack Brauns, nieces Bishop Gerry Wolf and Barbara Cooper, grandnephews David, Michael, Benjamin, Maxwell and Richard Levy and two of her best friends Carol Gross and Eve Wald. Donations in Elaine's memory may be made to the Israel Cancer Research Fund (ICRF), 295 Madison Ave, Ste. 1030, NY, NY 10017. Graveside service at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY will be observed on Thursday, May 29, 2014 at 11:30am with Rabbi David Gelfand of Temple Israel of New York. Shiva will be at the home of Paul and Amy Sklar, 50 East 79th Street, 17B, on Thursday May 29, 2014 from 4pm to 9pm Minyan 7:30pm and Saturday May 31, 2014 at 7:30pm to 9pm, Minyan at 7:30pm.

ANGELOU--Maya. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Maya Angelou, one of the most extraordinary figures of 20th- and 21st-century culture. She was a passionate advocate for our Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and served as the national membership chair for our Schomburg Society since 2000. She appeared in numerous programs presented by the Schomburg Center, and, over the years, she made many personal gifts of rare and unique historical materials to the Center, including letters of W. E. B. Du Bois, Booker T. Washington, and Frederick Douglass. We are deeply honored that she chose the Schomburg Center as the permanent repository of her extensive personal archive of manuscripts, letters, and other papers that document her brilliant literary and cultural legacy. Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Anthony W. Marx, President Khalil Gibran Muhammad, Director, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture

RUBIN--Israel "Russ", Former Justice on the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Department. Funeral services were held Sunday, May 25 for Israel "Russ" Rubin who served as Co-Chair of the National Appellate Practice Group at Greenberg Traurig in the firm's New York City office. Rubin passed away unexpectedly on Friday, May 23. He was 87. Prior to joining the firm in 2003, Rubin spent 14 years as a Justice on the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Department. Prior to that time, he served in many judicial capacities including Administrative Judge of The Civil Court of The City of New York, Justice of The Supreme Court of The State of New York, Acting Surrogate of Kings County, Judge of The Civil Court and Assistant Corporation Counsel of The City of New York in charge of The Penalties Division. Rubin was part of the American Bar Association's (ABA) Division of the Judiciary and the sections of the Appellate Judges Conference, Judicial Administration, and the Conference of State Trial Judges. In 2010, he was appointed Vice-Chair of the ABA's Alternative Dispute Resolution Committee. He had also been an adjunct professor of law at St. Johns University School of Law. Rubin received his JD and an Honorary Doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He is survived by his wife Roslyn; three daughters, Lisa, Janet and Gail; and eight grandchildren. Memorial gifts can be made to breast cancer research.
