RUBIN--Israel "Russ", Former Justice on the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Department. Funeral services were held Sunday, May 25 for Israel "Russ" Rubin who served as Co-Chair of the National Appellate Practice Group at Greenberg Traurig in the firm's New York City office. Rubin passed away unexpectedly on Friday, May 23. He was 87. Prior to joining the firm in 2003, Rubin spent 14 years as a Justice on the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Department. Prior to that time, he served in many judicial capacities including Administrative Judge of The Civil Court of The City of New York, Justice of The Supreme Court of The State of New York, Acting Surrogate of Kings County, Judge of The Civil Court and Assistant Corporation Counsel of The City of New York in charge of The Penalties Division. Rubin was part of the American Bar Association's (ABA) Division of the Judiciary and the sections of the Appellate Judges Conference, Judicial Administration, and the Conference of State Trial Judges. In 2010, he was appointed Vice-Chair of the ABA's Alternative Dispute Resolution Committee. He had also been an adjunct professor of law at St. Johns University School of Law. Rubin received his JD and an Honorary Doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He is survived by his wife Roslyn; three daughters, Lisa, Janet and Gail; and eight grandchildren. Memorial gifts can be made to breast cancer research.

HERRMANN--Susan Bogart, died at the age of 79 on Thursday, May 29, in New York City, of complications from a hemorrhagic stroke. Susan was the mother of Andrew, Peter and Nicholas; grandmother of Jake, Dillon, Jaden, Joseph, and Taylor; sister of Laura; and aunt of James and Emily. Susan's funeral will take place on Sunday, June 1 at 11am at Congregation Emanu-El of West- chester, 2125 Westchester Ave. East, Rye, NY 10580. The family will sit Shiva Sunday after the services until 7pm, and Monday and Tuesday from 5pm to 9pm at 30 West 15th St, Apt. 10-S, Manhattan.

MAYER--Margery (Voutsas), acclaimed opera singer with New York City and Chicago Opera Companies, died May 12, 2014 in Cupertino, California. She was 96. Survived by sons, Lynn Steen and wife, Mary of Northfield, Minnesota, and Richard Steen and wife, Robin Cameron of New York, New York, two granddaughters and six great-grandsons. Predeceased by husbands, Dietrich George Berthold, Sigvart J. Steen, and George Voutsas. Family requests memorials may be sent to the Margery Mayer and Sigvart Steen Music Awards at Wagner College, New York.

CALLAN--Eugene J. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Eugene J. Callan, who was a member of Mutual of America's Board of Directors from February 1980 to February 1992. Mr. Callan enjoyed a long and distinguished career in banking: he worked for 30 years at Citibank before being named President and Chief Executive Officer of the New York Bank for Savings, followed by his appointment as President of the Richmond Hill Savings Bank, now North Side Savings Bank in New York City. During his 12 years on the Board of Directors of Mutual of America, Mr. Callan served as Chairman of the Product and Marketing Committee as well as a member of the Audit, Investment, Long-Range Planning and Executive Committees. Mr. Callan's depth of character and professional expertise contributed greatly to the Company's growth. Our sincere condolences to his family. William J. Flynn, Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran, Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

GOLD--Melvin "Mel". Young Judaea mourns the passing of our beloved friend Melvin "Mel" Gold. Mel was the proud patriarch of a three generation Judaean family and he, along with wife, Shifra, are generous supporters of Young Judaea, Camp Sprout Lake, and Camp Tel Yehudah. Our hearts go out to his family: loving wife Shifra; his four children, Charles (Anne Kohn), Neil, Ronald (Betsy August Gold), and Nina (Raviv Ron); and his seven grandchildren, Stephanie, Jacqueline, Alexandra, Samuel, Jacob, Avital, and Maya. His legacy lives on through his family and through his generosity. May his memory be a blessing.

WAXLER--Barbara Cushman, beloved wife, sister, mother, and daughter, died peacefully on June 3, 2013, surrounded by loved ones. An attorney for more than 50 years, she had been a resident of Ardmore, Pennsylvania, where she practiced trusts and estates law. Barbara was raised in Brooklyn and, later, Larchmont, New York. She attended the Ethical Culture School and graduated from Adelphi Academy. She received her B.A. in Economics from Connecticut College for Women, where she graduated Phi Beta Kappa, and received her LL.B. from Columbia University Law School, where she was one of the youngest graduates in the school's history. Following Columbia, she practiced law, was a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and attended medical school in New York City. She married Dr. Edward Bernard Waxler in June 1965. They lived in New York, Philadelphia, and, then, in Waycross, Georgia, where Dr. Waxler was a partner in a cardiology practice. Following her husband's death in 1977 at the young age of 37, Barbara relocated to the Main Line suburbs of Philadelphia with her two children, Andrew and Caroline. She was admitted to the bar in Pennsylvania. She is survived by her son, Dr. Andrew Reed Waxler (Laurie); grandchildren, Eric, Abigail, and Emily Waxler; daughter, Caroline Waxler Levitt (Michael); and sister, Joan Rosenberg. She was predeceased by her parents, Dr. Meyer and Beatrice Molinsky, of Larchmont, New York, and her husband, Dr. Edward Bernard Waxler. The interment took place at West Laurel Hill Cemetery. Barbara is sorely missed by her numerous friends and family.

MELLON--Giles, of Brooklyn, New York and Lakeville, Connecticut died at home in Brooklyn just one year ago today at age 82. Giles was a husband, a father, a grandfather, a father-in-law, a brother-in-law, an uncle, a brother, a friend, and a colleague. His passions were deep: literature, history, music, art, and above all, his family. Giles's sense of play was ever present and so touching. A rare spirit with both a heart and intellect larger than life, Giles is missed and remembered every day. We all love him so deeply. Kate Josh, Mathilde, and Xavier Chris, Elizabeth, and Lucy Jonathan

LEVY--Dr. Barnet M.,died March 7, 2014 at the age of 97 of respiratory failure. Born Jan. 17, 1913 in Scranton, PA. He received his AB and DDS from the University of Pennsylvania and his MS in Bacteriology and Pathology from the University of Virginia. He was on the faculty at the Medical College of Virginia, Washington University (St. Louis), Columbia University, University of Texas in Houston, Texas A&M University. After retiring from the University of Texas at age 70 he taught at the University of California - San Francisco, University of California - San Diego, and Universidad National Autonoma de Mexico. He was considered a mentor by many of his students who went on to be professors themselves including at least two who became deans of dental schools. He was an accomplished artist. He did wood-carvings and mosaics and a stained glass window for a small synagogue in Houston. At an age when most people limit their physical activities, Bar was just getting started. While at the University of California - San Francisco he took up hang-gliding. When he was 75 he hiked the entire Appalachian Trail from Georgia to Maine and at the age of 78 he climbed Mt. Kilmanjaro. In his 80's he took hiking trips in Scotland and Italy. Pre-deceased by his wife Henrietta, he is survived by Jeffery, his daughter-in-law Toni Doktor, grandchildren Benjamin, Nolan and Ryan Doktor, nieces, nephews and cousins. He was a warm and generous man who was universally loved by all who came in contact with him and will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service will be held on Sunday June 8, 2014 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 189 Gill lane in Iselin, NJ.

MacGRATH--Edward Wardlaw, age 83, died May 30, 2014 after a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife, Cynthia Chandler MacGrath, his daughter, Dana Chandler MacGrath, and her husband Anthony Mathias Candido, and two grandchildren, Nico Chandler Candido and Harry Edward Candido. Born November 29, 1930 in Berkeley, California to Robert Wardlaw MacGrath and Claire Friedmann, he grew up in South Orange, New Jersey. He was a graduate of Lehigh University and received his Masters Degree from New Jersey Institute of Technology. His career in facilities engineering and construction management included positions with American Airlines, Marriott Corporation, Fordham University, Pan American World Airways, and Pace University. He was a lover of travel, boating, cooking, and classical music, a longtime volunteer helping New York City's needy people, and enjoyed many summers with family and friends at Point O' Woods, NY. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church Chapel on Friday, June 6, 2014 at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Carnegie Hill Neighbors or to a charity of your choice.

MAYER--Margery (Voutsas), acclaimed opera singer with New York City and Chicago Opera Companies, died May 12, 2014 in Cupertino, California. She was 96. Survived by sons, Lynn Steen and wife, Mary of Northfield, Minnesota, and Richard Steen and wife, Robin Cameron of New York, New York, two granddaughters and six great-grandsons. Predeceased by husbands, Dietrich George Berthold, Sigvart J. Steen, and George Voutsas. Family requests memorials may be sent to the Margery Mayer and Sigvart Steen Music Awards at Wagner College, New York.

McNEAL--Philip Webster, beloved husband, father, son and friend, passed away on May 27, 2014. Philip was born in St. Louis, Missouri on December 6, 1953. The only child of the late Senator Theodore McNeal and his wife Virgie, Philip was named after American labor movement giants A. Philip Randolph and Milton Webster. The elder McNeal worked with both men to organize the International Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, the most prominent predominantly black labor union of its day. In 1976 Philip graduated with a BS in mechanical engineering from University of Missouri, Rolla, and began his career at Exxon Mobil as a project engineer. In 1984, Philip joined J.P. Morgan as an investment banker in the firm's Natural Resources and Power Group, and later, Managing Director and Senior Client Advisor. Philip met his true love Glenda Goodly and they married in 1989. They enjoyed a rare, enviable partnership of equals who not only loved but also truly respected each other. They were blessed with two wonderful children - daughter Sydney and son Carter. Despite his demanding career, Philip was active in his community, serving as a longtime board chair of the Montclair Human Needs Food Pantry, former trustee of Montclair Kimberley Academy, and trustee of Newark Academy. But at the very center of his life, was his devotion to Glenda, Sydney and Carter. He cherished each of them and their time together as a family. Philip found absolute contentment immersed in a finite set of passions: St. Barths, boating, Long Beach Island, and his circle of extended family and friends. They comprised an endless stream of precious memories punctuated by the unforgettable expression on Philip's face when Glenda surprised him with a 60th birthday party in January 2014. Soon after, Philip was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Philip's battle to the end with this devastating disease was marked by the same integrity, clarity, and steadiness of spirit he embodied in his work and personal life. Philip passed away at home, surrounded by those he loved most on the eve of his and Glenda's 25th wedding anniversary. Thoughtful and generous to his core, Philip would want the battle against pancreatic cancer to continue in the form of funding research so that others might be spared what he endured. A fund has been established in his honor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He is survived by Glenda, Sydney and Carter; his mother Virgie, half-brother Theodore McNeal Jr., and an extended family that loved him dearly. Few are as stellar in life as they are claimed to be in memory; Philip McNeal was, and he will remain so in our hearts, forever. Memorial service will be held on Monday, June 2nd at 6pm at the Morgan Library, 235 Madison Avenue, New York, New York.

STEIN--Michael, my partner, friend and confidant. You inspired us to be the best of the best and to serve our clients with character, intellect, passion, reason and all of our professional skills. We will remember you and you will live in our hearts and minds. Bill and Jeannie Aaron and family David, Stephen, Jenny and Julie

SCHAFFER--Susan Gyory. Survived by husband Jerry, children Judi, Steven and Michael. Auschwitz survivor, Manager of Crazy Glue. Loved her many grandchildren. Services Friday, 11am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SOBIN--Vera L.,88, Born Tientsin, China. Died New York City, May 9, 2014. Beloved wife of Dr. Allan Sobin. Dear mother of Rodney (Rebecca), Joseph (Robin), James Baker (Nancy). Loving grandmother of Ethan and Amelia. Rest in peace. Donations in Vera's memory may be made to Town & Village Synagogue, 334 E. 14 St., NY, NY 10003.

PEARSON--Clarence E.,An entrepreneurial global health and management consultant and networker extraordinaire whose career spanned 60 years, died peacefully at home in New York on May 24, 2014 at 89 from a rare form of cancer. His wife and professional partner, Laurie Norris, survives him. Born in Chicago, Clarence credited his WWII US Army medical corps service and GI Bill of Rights-funded master of public health degree from the University of North Carolina/Chapel Hill as the start of his career. He was the Founding President and CEO of the National Center for Health Education, the outcome of a Presidential Commission. He served as Senior Advisor to the World Health Organization's Office at the United Nations. As Vice President and Director of Health and Safety Education for MetLife, he was the first person Met hired who was trained in public health education and promotion. He also was key in establishing the MetLife Foundation. He served as Vice President of the former Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management. Clarence created and served as Executive Editor for a series of books on global health issues (Jossey-Bass/John Wiley), including Global Health & Global Aging. His honors include the Gold Medal for Distinguished Service to Education from Columbia University; International Health Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Public Health Association; Advocacy Award, American Federation for Aging Research and the Distinguished Alumni Award from the School of Public Health, University of North Carolina/Chapel Hill. Clarence loved to help people in transition, from students to seasoned colleagues. He served on the boards of AARP, American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR), International Federation on Ageing, and the Board of Overseers of the Dartmouth Medical School's C. Everett Koop Institute. He was a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine, a member of the Roundtable on Health Literacy, Institute of Medicine, National Academy of Sciences and a member of the Vitality Institute Commission. He directed a management training program in Moscow, New Leaders of Russia, and served as a public health consultant in the former Yugoslavia and Central America for US government agencies and NGOs. Clarence's son Scott and first wife June Wahlde predeceased him. His parents, Irene Silander and Edward Pearson, emigrated from Sweden, where Clarence's ashes will be interred. Clarence's legacy is the people he mentored and advised during his multifaceted life, including interns he and Laurie support through patient advocacy and worldview internships. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to AFAR/Clarence Pearson Internship Fund, c/o AFAR, 55 West 39 St., 16th Fl., New York, NY 10018.

Donald's charm and good humor will be missed by many including his children Amy Friedricks (Bruce), Jill Ravitch, John Ravitch (Adisa) and grandchildren Emily and Henry Friedricks. He will also be remembered by Patricia's children Susan Mald (Lance), Fred Baron (Nancy), John Baron (Betsy) and his step-grandchildren Max and Sara Mald, and Katie, Maggie, Oliver, and Andrew Baron. STEIN--Michael R. (1939-2014). Founder Executive Monetary Management, LLC It is with great sadness that the partners and employees of Executive Monetary Management, LLC ("EMM") mourn the loss of one of our founders, Michael Stein. In 1968 Michael, William Aaron and John Gold founded EMM with a simple but revolutionary idea "to provide comprehensive wealth management for individuals and their families, by putting the clients needs and goals first and becoming the personal financial advocate for their clients." For nearly five decades Michael dedicated his professional life to just that, becoming more then a financial advisor to those he serviced but a trusted friend dedicated to his clients and EMM. Michael proudly walked the halls of EMM stopping by his colleagues desk to discuss client and firm matters, he paid particular attention to the details of his employees work environment and was always happy to share an anecdote from his life experiences which could provide humor, a life or business lesson, a unique perspective on an issue or a combination of all of these. "Nobody thought like Michael" said Bill Aaron a Co-Founder and Co-CEO of EMM, "He could immediately process information and come up with issues and solutions from a perspective nobody else in the room was coming from, all for the benefit of his clients." We at EMM have lost a great leader and dear friend. Michael has left a legacy at EMM and with its professionals, many of whom have worked with Michael for decades, and will mourn his loss and continue his vision of dedicated service and advocacy to his clients. Michael is survived by his wife Eileen, son Andrew and daughter Jennifer. He was the proud "granpy" to his grandchildren Alyssa, Jacob and Jackson.

TRAUTMAN--William Arthur, A classical architect with a lifelong commitment to justice, civil liberties and democratic principles, died May 23, 2014 at home in Sandwich, MA. Born July 21, 1928 in Clifton Springs, NY, he was raised in nearby Palmyra. Until retiring to Cape Cod, Mr. Trautman resided almost 50 years in a Manhattan townhouse ("Farewell to a Vertical Village" New York Times, November 13, 2005). A 1950 graduate of Cornell University, School of Architecture, he served in the US Air Force during the Korean War. With a master's degree in architecture from Harvard Graduate School of Design 1954, he joined the Boston firm of Shepley Bulfinch Richardson & Abbott. In New York City, Mr. Trautman associated with Carson Lundin & Shaw Architects and Irving Trust, designing executive offices, boardrooms and banking rooms. He was the principal designer of the 21 E 70th St art gallery for Knoedler & Co, later occupied by Hirschl & Adler, and numerous private residences. Mr. Trautman was a life member of Royal Oak, the New England Society of NYC, ICAA and the Society of Architectural Historians. He was a retired, life member of the Fire Island Pines New York Volunteer Fire Dept. A memorial tribute will be scheduled at a later date. Mr. Trautman is survived by his devoted partner of 27 years, Edward B. Morgan, Linda Kieseling (Holland Township, NJ), Barbara Church Stern (Maisons Laffitte, FR) and many friends.

Our prayers and love to Lella, Valentina, Luca and the family. Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu

LESNICK--Joel David. Our beloved husband, father, uncle, and grandfather passed away at home in Bedford Corners, New York on Wednesday, May 28 at age 82 of complications from colon cancer. Born to Elizabeth Rybakoff and Harry J. Lesnick, M.D. in the Bronx on April 6, 1932, Joel attended the Barnard-Horace Mann School and received a B.S. in Chemistry from The Johns Hopkins University in 1953 and a Masters in Business Administration from the New York University School of Business. Joel served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy from 1953 to 1957 and subsequently founded and led his own Certified Public Accounting firm in White Plains for over 40 years. As a long-time Scarsdale, New York resident, Joel served as a member of the Scarsdale Board of Education for six years, including two years as president. He was also an active Johns Hopkins alumnus and fundraiser, serving on the University Advisory Council and Alumni Council. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Helaine, his children Elizabeth (Jonathan Gross) and Matthew (Kim Moran), his grandchildren Beattie and Quinn Lesnick and Rebecca Gross, his sister Lila Scherl, his nieces Ellen and Nancy Scherl and his nephew David Scherl, and his sister-in-law Judith Lewittes (David) and his nephew Michael Lewittes and niece Deborah Lewittes. Donations in Joel's memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, New York, NY 10163-4777.

LYLE--W. Gordon, Jr.,died peacefully in Charleston, SC on May 11th. Born in New York City in 1920, he attended St. Paul's School and Harvard. After serving in the Navy during WWII, he spent his career as an investment advisor and fund manager on Wall Street and in Connecticut. He was divorced from Helen Niblack and predeceased by his second wife, Constance Brewer Kilgore Lyle. He is survived by a daughter, Lucy Lyle Tower; two grandchildren, Aurora and Alfred Tower; a sister, Tina Lyle Harrower; and four stepchildren, John, Ralph and Robert Kilgore and Constance Kilgore Utter. Donations may be made to: The B.G. Employee Assistance Fund, 1 Gadsden Way, Charleston, SC 29412.

LANIN--Mike. President of Howard Lanin Productions passed away in New York on April 14, 2014 at age 90. In 1952 Mike hired a 22-year old conductor for a nationwide Gershwin concert tour that ran for two seasons (1952-54) and played in 170 cities. His name: Lorin Maazel. It was the only orchestra in history dedicated exclusively to the music of one composer. Mike pursued his interest in George Gershwin in collaboration with Michael Feinstein. Mike, a well-known producer of shows for large corporations (IBM, Coca Cola, CBS, AT&T) hired star performers such as Harry Belafonte, Tony Bennett, Liza Minnelli, Diahann Carroll, Leslie Huggams, Lena Horne, Bob Hope, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Bolger, Doc Severinsen and Bill Cosby among others. Memorable productions Mike presented include The Royal Danish Ballet in its US debut and The Conservatory Without Walls, a glittering event in honor of the country's greatest Afro-American musicians which launched the Duke Ellington Fellowship Fund at Yale University. Mike also served on the board of The Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. Mike Lanin was born in Philadelphia on March, 8, 1924, the son of the band leader Howard Lanin and the nephew of Lester Lanin, the internationally known society band leader. During World War II he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps. At that time he discovered a young and talented pianist, still unknown, Bobby Short. They became friends for the rest of their lives. Mike was a graduate of Yale University where he was an imaginative caricaturist for the Yale Record. He is also remembered for his fond portrayal of Orson Welles' Citizen Kane. Mike was an elegant man both in appearance and in spirit. He was always courteous, soft spoken, never one to boast of his many achievements and of his friendships with famous artists. He was a loyal friend, a witty but considerate companion with a dry sense of humor. He was an entertaining guest. Mike has been called "the dean of entertainment who pioneered the theme party, the pops concert, the anniversary revue and the multimedia production." He was an avid reader and traveler. He kept homes in New York and Paris. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, the love of his life, Yvonne Constant-Lanin, a performer herself and a frequent guest (45 times) on the Johnny Carson Show. It was always a pleasure to see how much Mike enjoyed his wife's performances. He was proud of her interpretations of French and American songs. At her recitals he would greet friends with a radiant smile. He was also proud of Yvonne having been named "Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres", an important French cultural award. Other immediate survivors include his sister, Suzanne Lande, his adopted daughter Kristina Stufano from a previous marriage, his stepson, Gerard Pinguet and numerous grandchildren.

SHAPIRO--Elaine. Born July 25, 1925 in New York City nee Schlaffer. Died peacefully May 23, 2014. Beloved mother of Peter, Moira and Kaethe, mother-in-law of Robin, Michael and Gordon, grandmother of Laura, Elisa, Paige, Aidan, Kyle and Mireya. Graduate of City College and Ph.D in psychology from University of Chicago. Worked alongside her late husband Arthur for many years studying Tourette's Syndrome and treating Tourette's patients and families, and also studying the placebo effect while maintaining a private practice. Co-author of two books on those subjects. Survived also by three siblings, including her dear twin sister Lucille. Gifts can be made in her memory to the Tourette's Syndrome Association, tsa-usa.org, designated for research.

KORWIN--Yala Helen. Born February 7, 1933, Lvov, Poland, died May 30, 2014. Artist, teacher, poet, and author. Over 400 paintings and sculptures, some in museums including Holocaust Museum, Washington, DC. Holocaust Survivor, after WWII settled in Paris and married Paul Korwin, two children, Danielle and Robert. Moved to Queens in 1956. Three grandchildren, Devin, Zachary and Joshua. Master's degree Summa Cum Laude Queens College, Authored six books, Holocaust poetry published in Haggadah for Passover, textbooks, and set to classical music. Yala will be buried on Sunday, services at Beth Moses in Farmingdale at 11:30am. Donate in her name to the Holocaust Museum, Washington DC.
KAYE--Peter B.,passed on May 25, 2014. Peter was the greatest guy and we loved him dearly. We will miss him terribly. Aunt Adley, cousins Jon & Karen, Andrew & Keren, Amy & Jay, and children

JABLONSKI--Joseph J. Born March 19, 1948, died at New York Presbyterian Hospital May 24, 2014. Joe and Darlyn, his wife of 43 years, married in Nebraska, resided in Portland, OR since 1989. Joe was born in Burwell, Nebraska, second of 10 children from Robert and Marcella Jablonski. The family was raised in Loup City, NE. Robert, as well as Joe's younger brother, Bob, preceded him in death. Joe is survived by Darlyn and four children, Peter of Mill Valley CA, Tasha Miller, and Anna Jablonski, both of Portland, OR, and Katerina Gleeson of Wilsonville, OR, and grandchildren, William, Francesca, Aleksei, Walter, and Isira, Joe's mother, Marcella Jablonski of Loup City, NE, siblings, Linda Schmaderer of St. Paul NE, Rebecca Mudgett of Ft. Collins, CO, Tom Jablonski of Atlanta, GA, John Jablonski of Hood River, OR, Marsanne Howard of Loveland, CO, David Jablonski of Sioux Falls, IA, Jerilyn Jablonski, and Michael Jablonski, both of White Salmon, WA. Joe graduated from the US Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point NY 1970 and earned an MIM from Portland State University. Joe's life became a triangle of family, maritime industry and literary/art circles. Joe's work at sea began in 1970 and he sailed Captain of APL's President Kennedy for the final eight years of his seagoing career. Early on Darlyn and Joe owned seven consecutive Volkswagon vans, lived in Houston, Baltimore, New Orleans, Vancouver, WA, Loup City and Ord, NE, Point Arena CA, and Ft. Collins, CO before moving to Portland. In Portland, Joe supported literary and arts organizations and often traveled to New York to oversee his Harlem properties. Joe was a published writer: Three Star Fix in 2002, and a Private Lives article in The New York Times titled Pirate Nights, 2013. Services: Saturday, June 7, 2014 at Cerimon House, 5131 NE 23rd Ave at 3pm with reception at 4:30pm. Memorial donations in Joe's name may be made to Cerimon House.

ISHKANIAN--Lucy. Internationally recognized pianist who performed in the major concert halls around the world to great acclaim, died in a hospital in New York City on April 20. She was 80. Her nine tours from 1962 to 1979 throughout the former Soviet Union was part of the "Special Prize" award she received from the jury of the Second International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. She also was sent on tour by the US Department of State Cultural Program and performed throughout the Middle East, Southeast Asia, Western Europe, Argentina, and the United States under the management of impresario Sol Hurok. In 1971, she was presented by Hurok at her debut at Philharmonic Hall (now Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.) A native New Yorker of Armenian descent, she gave her first recital at age seven, two years after becoming the youngest student ever accepted to the Juilliard School Preparatory Division. She continued her education there as a scholarship winner for 15 years, and graduated with both Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees. She also completed requirements for a PH.D degree at Columbia University. Among her teachers were Beveridge Webster and Rosina Lhevinne. She also coached with some of the greatest musicians, including pianists Mieczeslaw Horszowski, Yakov Fliere, Emil Gilels, and composer Aram Khachaturian who entrusted her with the American premiere of his Piano Sonata. Among her greatest achievements was the foundation of the Juilliard-Komitas friendship program in 1992, enabling gifted students from the Komitas Conservatory in Yerevan, Armenia to be admitted to The Juilliard School in New York to continue their musical education. Ms. Ishkanian was an honorary professor at the Komitas Conservatory, and served as president of the jury for the graduation examinations. Ms. Ishkanian also was a distinguished member of international piano competition juries around the world, including the First International Aram Khachaturian Piano Competition in Yerevan in 1997, the First International Rachmaninoff Piano Competition in Los Angeles, CA in 2002, as well as the Dorothy MacKenzie Artist Recognition Awards at the International Keyboard Institute and Festival in New York City. Ms. Ishkanian is survived by her husband, Hagop Tankian. A brother, Vahe, predeceased her. There will be a 40th day requiem service on Sunday at the St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral, located at 221 East 27th Street in New York City, starting at 11:30am, after which there will be a musical tribute and a reception. Donations in her memory may be made to the Armenian Scholarship Fund at The Juilliard School.

ACKERMAN--Jack. The Board, staff, and clients of Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services have lost a friend, ally, and agency leader of legendary importance. First joining the Board in 1966, Jack served as Trustee and Treasurer for many years. The importance of his leadership and sage advice at critical junctures in our history, including the merger of Jewish Family Service and Jewish Board of Guardians in the 1970s and the fiscal crisis of the 1990s, cannot be overstated. All of us mourn his loss deeply alongside his wife Dana, their children, and many friends. His memory will surely be a blessing at JBFCS.

GREENE--Maxine. The President, Trustees and extended Teachers College community mourn Maxine Greene, philosopher, author, professor emerita and touchstone for generations of TC faculty, alumni and students, as well as for scholars and artists around the world. Maxine was an extraordinary mind and spirit embodying what is best and most essential about our mission and work. She was an ardent feminist and a crusader against anti-Semitism. Her belief that art is a means to awaken each of us to how we respond to the world will endure as her greatest legacy. Through her many books and essays; through her passionate teaching in TC's classrooms, at Lincoln Center and in the famed salons she held in her apartment; and through her mentoring of eager minds of all generations and across an array of disciplines, Maxine exhorted us to "look at things as if they could be otherwise" and championed the arts as a catalyst to "wide-awakeness." In spirit, thought and deed, she stood as a bulwark against what she termed "the feelings of powerlessness" occasioned by modern society, arguing that only as people "learn to make sense of what is happening... can they develop the sense of agency required for living a moral life." Maxine's influence is both deep and wide-ranging. Beyond her writings, she served as president of all the leading professional societies in the education field and as editor of prestigious journals, and she received countless awards. Her ultimate measure is perhaps best summed up by her own standard for excellence in teaching. "There are," she wrote, "young persons in the inner cities, the ones lashed by 'savage inequalities' the ones whose very schools are made sick by the social problems the young bring in from without. Here, more frequently than not, are the real tests of 'teaching as possibility' in the face of what looks like an impossible social reality at a time when few adults seem to care." We extend our condolences to Maxine's son, Timothy Greene; her sister, Jeanne Shinefield; her step-daughter, Elizabeth Greene; her daughter-in-law, Constance Gemson; and her grandson, Daniel Greene; and we salute the memory of her brother, Joseph Meyer, her sister, Carol Meyer, and her daughter, Linda Lechner. Those wishing to donate in Maxine Greene's memory may give to the Maxine Greene Scholarship in Philosophy and Education, which supports students in the College's Philosophy and Education program. Send to Louis Lo Re, Box 306, Teachers College, 525 West 120th Street, New York, NY 10027. Susan H. Fuhrman, President Thomas James, Provost/Dean

ACKERMAN--Jack Rossin, passed away peacefully on May 27 from Parkinson's Disease at the age of 83. He was born to Florence and Robert Ackerman in NYC. He graduated from Berkshire School, Harvard College '53, Harvard Business School '55. Jack began his career as an investment banker at Bache & Company where he worked for 25 years before going to Drexel Burnham and then starting Bondreview. He was a member of numerous corporate boards. Jack was a dedicated trustee of the Jewish Board of Family & Children's Service and the Jewish Foundation for the Education for Women. Jack will be remembered as a kind, gentle and caring person with the highest integrity. He was happiest while skiing, playing golf at Century and tennis in his "old men's" game. He had a passion for the theater, museums, concerts and the New York City Ballet. The time he spent in his garden in Pound Ridge brought him the greatest pleasure. Jack is survived by his beloved wife Dana of 39 years; cherished father of Ellen Miller (Peter) of Wayne, PA, Jay Ackerman (Elizabeth) of Bronxville and Robin Foley (Paul) of New Canaan. His son Bradley predeceased him. He also leaves his 10 grandchildren, Avery Eyre Lovejoy, Ashley, Toby and Libby Eyre, Brendan and Eamon Foley, Alexa Ackerman, James, Peter and Cooper Ackerman and a great-granddaughter Lila. A sister Jean Ackerman Thies also survives him. Donations in Jack's memory may be made to: JBFCS, 135 West 50th St., 6th Floor, NYC, NY 10020. The family will be receiving at the Frank Campbell Funereal Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, May 29th, 5:30 - 7:30pm.

ENSIGN--Tod, (Thomas Decatur). Director of Citizen Soldier, writer, activist, lawyer, lover of all things beautiful. Mourning profoundly are Francine Smilen, their daughter Rachel, sisters Natalie Cunningham and Deborah, nephews Dr. Kenneth and Scott Cunningham, and many devoted friends and comrades. We will continue the fight. Donations to Center for Constitutional Rights (ccrjustice.org).

GLASER--Peter E.,of Lexington, MA, on May 29, 2014. Mr. Glaser is a survivor of the Holocaust. Beloved husband of Eva (Graf) Glaser. Devoted father of David Glaser (Debra Stone), Steven Glaser (Roxanne), Susan Goodman (Robert). Dear grandfather of Daniel, Sarah, Ruby, Emily, Dixie, Joshua, Annie and Eliana. Services at Temple Emunah, 9 Piper Road, Lexington, MA on Monday, June 2 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, DC 20024 or to Temple Emunah, 9 Piper Road, Lexington, MA 02421. Services by Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA.

BERGER--Anna, well known actress with a multitude of Broadway, film, and television credits, passed away on Monday, May 26, 2014. Her credits include a lifetime of extraordinary work which include originating the role of Golda in 'Tevya and his Daughters', which later became the musical 'Fiddler on the Roof'. Anna was a great influence on many young actors, and had the respect of the industry. In a career that spanned over 75 years, her work included such films as Woody Allen's 'Crimes and Misdemeanors' and the original 'Taking of Pelham 123'. Among her many television credits were guest star appearances on 'Philco Playhouse', 'The Goldbergs', 'The Sopranoes', and 'Everybody Loves Raymond'. Her Broadway career included 'Gideon', 'Unlikely Heroes', and she starred alongside Mae West in 'Diamond Lil', as well as with John Garfield in 'Golden boy'. Ms. Berger was an early member of The Dramatic Workshop, and later was a lifetime member of The Actors Studio where she developed the one women show and film 'Absolutely Anna', which is the culmination of her illustrious career. She is survived by her husband Robert Malatzky, and her daughters Susan Malatzky and Joanna Sanchez. New York City has lost one of it's best.

BANNERMAN--Jane Campbell. We mourn the death of our cherished friend, Jane. The Barasch Family.

BOKOR--Bruce, died unexpectedly on May 28th in Northampton, MA. A graduate of Dartmouth College, Bruce was a scholar, a gifted athlete and a great humanitarian. Bruce travelled a dark and difficult path for much of his life. After many troubled years, he became an educator, devoted to the children he taught. Cherished by his parents. Gail and Gene, he is also survived by his sister, Jill and her husband, Sanford Smith, his brother Peter and his wife Jeannie Blaustein, a nephew, Luc Bokor-Smith and two nieces Sophie and Livia Bokor. Interment will be private. Information about tribute gifts to a charity in Bruce's name will be forthcoming. The family would like to thank all the wonderful people who helped and cared for Bruce.

GREENE--Dr Maxine. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and its educational cornerstone, Lincoln Center Education, mourn the passing of Dr. Maxine Greene, a towering figure in the field of education and a pioneer in arts education. Maxine was a member of the visionary founding team of Lincoln Center Education's precursor, the Lincoln Center Institute, in 1974, and served as its Philosopher in Residence and later its Philosopher Emerita. Through her dedicated and passionate work with Lincoln Center, educators worldwide incorporated her philosophy in aesthetic education which encouraged students "to see the world as if it could be otherwise." We join the education community in extending our sympathies to her family and friends, and to the legions of lives she influenced, informed and changed through her many contributions. Katherine Farley, Chair, Lincoln Center Jed Bernstein, President, Lincoln Center Ann Unterberg, Chair, Lincoln Center Education Russell Granet, Executive Director, Lincoln Center Education

BAER--Harold Jr. His fellow Assistants under U.S. Attorney Robert Morgenthau deeply mourn the untimely loss of our distinguished colleague. A lifelong human rights supporter, Harold was the exemplar for a hard-working, fair-minded and effective jurist both as a Justice of the New York State Supreme Court and Judge of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife Suzanne and their two daughters.

BAKER--Bruce E.,79 of Long Island, NY and Wilmington, DE. Devoted husband of Judie. He was truly loved by all for his sense of humor, kindness and loving disposition. Bruce was proud of his many years of work with Big Brothers/Big Sisters (New York Tristate Area). A graveside service will be held 10:00am, Sunday, June 1, 2014, at the Jewish Community Cemetery 401 Foulk Road, Wilmington, DE 19803. Shiva will be observed 8:00 pm, Sunday, June 1 and Monday, June 2 at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the North Shore Animal League or Siegel JCC Wilmington, DE. Schoenberg Memorial Chapel.

ASCHHEIM--Ilse C. (Kastner), of Concord, MA, formerly of Somers, NY and Brewster, NY, May 27. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Mother of Frances of Lincoln, MA and the late David of Washington, D.C. Grandmother of Alexandra Feld. Funeral private. For obituary visit: www.deefunerahome.com.

BAER--Harold, on May 27, 2014. Devoted husband, father, grandfather and Public servant. Services Sunday 1:15pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva at Metropolitan Tower, 146 West 57 St., New York City, Sunday and Monday 4-6pm. Contributions to New York Lawyers for the Public Interest or The Osborne Association (prisoner services).

ANDERSON--James R. Artist. Teacher. Born August 25, 1935 in Gary, IN. Preceded in death by nine older brothers and sisters, died May 28th 2014. Husband of Robert G. Betke Jr., uncle of Patricia Wisniewski, Nancy Dumay, Edward Yoko, Joanne Johnson and Elizabeth Skelskie, and many grandnieces and nephews, and great-grand nieces and nephews. Jim was loved by many, many friends. He held two Master's Degrees from Indiana University where he also obtained his undergraduate degree in Education. While at Indiana University he rode in the Little 500 on two occasions. He was the recipient of a Fulbright Scholarship. He had work in The Whitney Biennial and he has paintings in major museum collections as well as private collections. There will be no service. A celebration of his life will be held at some point in the near future. Please, if you wish to make donations in his name to: The North Shore Animal League, 25 Davis Avenue, Port Washington Long Island, NY 11050 or go to http://www.animalleague.org/-memorial donations.

BANNERMAN--Jane C.,an artist, decorator, community volunteer, gracious and generous host, and consummate New Yorker, died at her home on May 25, 2014, at age 104. Born March 15, 1910 in Elizabeth, NJ, the daughter of Pauline Darrach and Edward Campbell, she attended Vail-Deane School and Parsons School of Design. Jane apprenticed with the artist, Lucien Bernhard, and worked for Delineator Magazine and McMillan, Inc., and her own interior decorating firm. She studied Chinese painting with C.C. Wang and was a prolific watercolorist, creating scores of water color sketchbooks while traveling to almost every corner of the earth, all available for viewing at The New York Historical Society. She was married to Charles S. Bannerman, Esq., from 1938 until his death in 1976. For more than half a century, Jane volunteered at the library for the Hospital for Special Surgery and sponsored children throughout the world through Plan USA. She was a board member of the Bannerman Castle Trust, an organization dedicated to preserving the Hudson River landmark. Jane is survived by her daughter, Ann B. Bowes, of Danbury, NH, Ann's partner, Guy Stoye, and many cousins. Her brother, Bradford D. Campbell, predeceased her. The family thanks Jane's caregivers, particularly Shelly Watson, for their loving care. Donations may be made to the Bannerman Castle Trust or Plan USA.

KAYE--Peter Borden, on May 25, 2014 in NYC. Born NYC December 9, 1955. He was a life long New Yorker. A graduate of Lafayette College, class of 1977. He worked in his family's real estate business. He was an avid supporter of the arts and many charities. Peter loved sports, especially his New York teams. He was a participant as well as a fan. He was a loving husband to Mary. Cherished son of Mary Ellen and Morley, devoted brother to James and Jodi, and awesome uncle to Matthew and Allison. His love, caring and generosity for others as well as his infectious sense of humor and warmth will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Tuesday, June 3, at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or charity of your choice will be appreciated.

STEIN--Michael, my partner, friend and confidant. You inspired us to be the best of the best and to serve our clients with character, intellect, passion, reason and all of our professional skills. McNEAL--Philip Webster, beloved husband, father, son and friend, passed away on May 27, 2014. Philip was born in St. Louis, Missouri on December 6, 1953. The only child of the late Senator Theodore McNeal and his wife Virgie, Philip was named after American labor movement giants A. Philip Randolph and Milton Webster. The elder McNeal worked with both men to organize the International Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, the most prominent predominantly black labor union of its day. In 1976 Philip graduated with a BS in mechanical engineering from University of Missouri, Rolla, and began his career at Exxon Mobil as a project engineer. In 1984, Philip joined J.P. Morgan as an investment banker in the firm's Natural Resources and Power Group, and later, Managing Director and Senior Client Advisor. Philip met his true love Glenda Goodly and they married in 1989. They enjoyed a rare, enviable partnership of equals who not only loved but also truly respected each other. They were blessed with two wonderful children - daughter Sydney and son Carter. Despite his demanding career, Philip was active in his community, serving as a longtime board chair of the Montclair Human Needs Food Pantry, former trustee of Montclair Kimberley Academy, and trustee of Newark Academy. But at the very center of his life, was his devotion to Glenda, Sydney and Carter. He cherished each of them and their time together as a family. Philip found absolute contentment immersed in a finite set of passions: St. Barths, boating, Long Beach Island, and his circle of extended family and friends. They comprised an endless stream of precious memories punctuated by the unforgettable expression on Philip's face when Glenda surprised him with a 60th birthday party in January 2014. Soon after, Philip was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Philip's battle to the end with this devastating disease was marked by the same integrity, clarity, and steadiness of spirit he embodied in his work and personal life. Philip passed away at home, surrounded by those he loved most on the eve of his and Glenda's 25th wedding anniversary. Thoughtful and generous to his core, Philip would want the battle against pancreatic cancer to continue in the form of funding research so that others might be spared what he endured. A fund has been established in his honor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He is survived by Glenda, Sydney and Carter; his mother Virgie, half-brother Theodore McNeal Jr., and an extended family that loved him dearly. Few are as stellar in life as they are claimed to be in memory; Philip McNeal was, and he will remain so in our hearts, forever. Memorial service will be held on Monday, June 2nd at 6pm at the Morgan Library, 235 Madison Avenue, New York, New York.

RANDALL--James Kirtland (JK), died at home in Princeton, NJ on May 28th, 2014, aged 84. Professor Emeritus of Music at Princeton University, he was a composer, music theorist, writer, and animal lover. A pioneer in the field of electronic music, he was also a founder of the journals Open Space and Perspectives of New Music. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Ruth Hochheimer Randall, three children, and seven grandchildren.

KATZ--Lewis. Columbia University Medical Center's Division of Cardiology mourns the passing of Lewis Katz, trusted Medical Center Board of Advisor member, generous benefactor and special friend. Mr. Katz, along with his deceased wife, Marjorie, was an ardent supporter of Columbia's Cardiac Programs. Most recently, he named and supported the Lewis and Marjorie Katz Cardiology Patient Care Suite, the first space to be named at Columbia Doctors Midtown. Almost a decade ago, Mr. Katz established the Katz Prizes in Cardiovascular Research, highlighting the contributions of leading cardiovascular researchers nationally, and driving innovative research through his support of junior investigators at the dawn of their careers. Mr. Katz was loved and admired by those who knew him, especially his children and grandchildren who survive him. At a recent University event, he gathered his grandchildren together to expound upon the importance of philanthropy and giving back to the community. Our hearts go out to his children, Drew, and his wife Rachel, Melissa, and her husband, Steven, and his grandchildren, Ethan, Brooke, Taryn, and Remi. As we are saddened by his untimely loss, we will continue to be thankful for all that he has left behind. Allan Schwartz, M.D. Seymour Milstein and Harold Ames Hatch Professor of Medicine Chief of the Division of Cardiology

PATTERSON--Jean Kenny, on May 30, 2014 in Columbia, MD. Lived many happy years and raised a family in East Rockaway. Long-time teacher in New York public schools. Predeceased by her husband George (Ed) and daughters Anne and Joan. Survived by sons Bob and Brian, six grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Services in Columbia, MD. Burial at Holy Rood.

STEIN--Michael R. (1939-2014). Founder Executive Monetary Management, LLC It is with great sadness that the partners and employees of Executive Monetary Management, LLC ("EMM") mourn the loss of one of our founders, Michael Stein. In 1968 Michael, William Aaron and John Gold founded EMM with a simple but revolutionary idea "to provide comprehensive wealth management for individuals and their families, by putting the clients needs and goals first and becoming the personal financial advocate for their clients." For nearly five decades Michael dedicated his professional life to just that, becoming more then a financial advisor to those he serviced but a trusted friend dedicated to his clients and EMM. Michael proudly walked the halls of EMM stopping by his colleagues desk to discuss client and firm matters, he paid particular attention to the details of his employees work environment and was always happy to share an anecdote from his life experiences which could provide humor, a life or business lesson, a unique perspective on an issue or a combination of all of these. "Nobody thought like Michael" said Bill Aaron a Co-Founder and Co-CEO of EMM, "He could immediately process information and come up with issues and solutions from a perspective nobody else in the room was coming from, all for the benefit of his clients." We at EMM have lost a great leader and dear friend. Michael has left a legacy at EMM and with its professionals, many of whom have worked with Michael for decades, and will mourn his loss and continue his vision of dedicated service and advocacy to his clients. Michael is survived by his wife Eileen, son Andrew and daughter Jennifer. He was the proud "granpy" to his grandchildren Alyssa, Jacob and Jackson.
NADIEN--David, was an outstanding violinist and a gracious gentleman. Our good friend for over 40 years. Our condolences to his wife, Margot Nadien. The Rausnitz Family

ROTHBERG--Morton J.,95, of New York, on Saturday, May 31st. Beloved husband of Claire Rothberg for 69 joyous years; devoted father of Marcia Lustgarten (Marc) and Phyllis Koenig (Neil); cherished grandfather of Andy Lustgarten (Rachel), Jessica Lustgarten, Rebecca Berrebi (Jason), and Gabrielle Koenig; and adored great-grandfather of Charlotte, Marcus, Asher and Vivienne. He is also survived by his sister, Blanche Wager (Stanley). His greatest passions were his wife and family, friends, and travel. He was particularly proud of his service during WWII as Master Sergeant for the Judge Advocate General. His quick wit, charming personality and "joie de vivre" will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 2 at 1pm at Plaza Funeral Home at 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

STEIN--Michael. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long-time member Michael Stein. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi

TURCHIN--Gilbert "Speh-Speh", died suddenly on Thursday, May 29 at the age of 68. Gil was predeceased by his parents, Murray and Greta (Lindner) Turchin, and his sister, Carole Shirey. Gil is survived by his partner of 24 years, Indigo Koebel, and their "special blessing" Jerae Dawson. Gil is also survived by his nephew, Kenneth Portacio, his wife Maria (Javier) Portacio, and their sons, Ryan and Justin; cousins Lois Shoenfeld, Barbara Wieder, Arlene Weiss, Bruce Lindner, Ira Lindner, Steven Lindner, Maddy Bradford, Lori Lindner, Janet Spielberg, their spouses and children. Gil was a beloved husband, brother, uncle, cousin and friend, who cared deeply for others, especially children in need. He spent his entire professional life helping countless children and raising millions on their behalf. Memorial gifts can be made to the Metropolitan Opera, Gil's other great passion. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

SULAM--Sondra. Mom, You are missed every day but never forgotten. We love and miss you, Don; Glen and Debra, Luke, Jack and William; and Marc

KATZ--Lewis. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our friend and benefactor Lewis Katz, whose extraordinary philanthropy has transformed our Division of Cardiology. The Katz Prizes in Cardiovascular Research, awarded annually by Columbia, celebrate and honor the contributions of cardiovascular researchers nationally; the newly opened Lewis and Marjorie Katz Cardiology Patient Care Suite ensures that our patients receive the very best care, in an empathic, state-of-the-art space. All of us at Columbia will miss his generosity of spirit, and we extend our condolences to his children, grandchildren, and the extended Katz family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University

HERTER--Raymond, on May 31, 2014. Beloved husband of Aileen. Loving father of Melanie (Jeff) Bendavid, David and the late Richard. Cherished grandfather of Jacob, Sasha, Gabriel and Isaac. Services 1pm, Today at Riverside Nassau North Chapels; 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021.

BUCHMAN--Sylvan "Buck", passed away on May 28, 2014, in Palm Beach, Florida at a vibrant and astute 95. Buck is survived by Shirley, his college sweetheart and wife of 72 years and his two loving sons, Peter and John. Born May 22, 1919 to Irving and Tillie in Seagate, Brooklyn, NY. Adored by his mom and twin sisters. the late Ruth James and Irene Weinberg. He was the oral family historian, a humorist, and a steadfast friend. Buck was a snow bird of Palm Beach and Greenwich, CT. A World Traveler and a geographer. A would-be golfer and a beloved Member of Fairview Country Club, Greenwich, CT. He attended The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, '40. Served as a Captain in the US Army Corp of Engineers for five years and was Deployed in the Pacific. He was Chairman of The L. Buchman Co., Inc. (est 1917); a Board Member of The Checker Motors Corp; an Industrial Realtor, At James H. Burns Co. (Now Douglas Elliman). Interment is on Thursday, June 5 at 10am, Beth El Cemetery, 8012 Cypress Hills St, Ridgewood, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Southern Poverty Law Center in Buck's name.

BUCHMAN--Sylvan. The L. Buchman Co.,Inc. honors Its chief executive of over fifty years. His leadership brought honor to his name. The firm was established in 1917 by Sylvan's grandfather. The firm was a premier manufacturer of bedding products, including pillows, comforters, sleeping bags, back rests, and decorative pillows designed by David Evins. Goods were sold nationwide including at Bloomingdales. Its signature product was the "Sylvan" goose down filled pillow. The company supplied sleeping bags to the US Government during the Korean War, outfitted Admiral Byrd's expedition to the North Pole and supplied Generalissimo Chiang Kai Shek, Leader of the Republic of China. Operations were discontinued in 1955. Currently the company is completing Its adaptive reuse of its old manufacturing facility in Greenpoint, Brooklyn which is now known as The Morgan Fine Arts and Film Center.
BUCHMAN--Sylvan. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

GREENE--Dr Maxine. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and its educational cornerstone, Lincoln Center Education, mourn the passing of Dr. Maxine Greene, a towering figure in the field of education and a pioneer in arts education. Maxine was a member of the visionary founding team of Lincoln Center Education's precursor, the Lincoln Center Institute, in 1974, and served as its Philosopher in Residence and later its Philosopher Emerita. Through her dedicated and passionate work with Lincoln Center, educators worldwide incorporated her philosophy in aesthetic education which encouraged students "to see the world as if it could be otherwise." We join the education community in extending our sympathies to her family and friends, and to the legions of lives she influenced, informed and changed through her many contributions. Katherine Farley, Chair, Lincoln Center Jed Bernstein, President, Lincoln Center Ann Unterberg, Chair, Lincoln Center Education Russell Granet, Executive Director, Lincoln Center Education

BOKOR--Bruce, died unexpectedly on May 28th in Northampton, MA. A graduate of Dartmouth College, Bruce was a scholar, a gifted athlete and a great humanitarian. Bruce travelled a dark and difficult path for much of his life. After many troubled years, he became an educator, devoted to the children he taught. Cherished by his parents. Gail and Gene, he is also survived by his sister, Jill and her husband, Sanford Smith, his brother Peter and his wife Jeannie Blaustein, a nephew, Luc Bokor-Smith and two nieces Sophie and Livia Bokor. Interment will be private. Information about tribute gifts to a charity in Bruce's name will be forthcoming. The family would like to thank all the wonderful people who helped and cared for Bruce.

STATON--Stuart A. 10/10/50 - 06/03/13. Beloved husband, father, son, brother and loyal friend. Loved, remembered and missed.
FELSEN--David & Esther. Missed, remembered and loved every day. The Sokol & Felsen Families, and newest member Lev Efroni
Strauss--Ruth. The Summer Camp community remembers our longtime friend and mother of Liz Strauss, our president-elect. We send our sincere condolences to the Strauss and Gruber families.
STEIN--Michael. Our hearts are broken at the loss of our very dear friend, Michael. Our prayers and love to Eileen and family. Nina and Neil

PATTERSON--Jean Kenny, on May 30, 2014 in Columbia, MD. Lived many happy years and raised a family in East Rockaway. Long-time teacher in New York public schools. Predeceased by her husband George (Ed) and daughters Anne and Joan. Survived by sons Bob and Brian, six grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Services in Columbia, MD. Burial at Holy Rood.

ROTHBERG--Morton J.,95, of New York, on Saturday, May 31st. Beloved husband of Claire Rothberg for 69 joyous years; devoted father of Marcia Lustgarten (Marc) and Phyllis Koenig (Neil); cherished grandfather of Andy Lustgarten (Rachel), Jessica Lustgarten, Rebecca Berrebi (Jason), and Gabrielle Koenig; and adored great-grandfather of Charlotte, Marcus, Asher and Vivienne. He is also survived by his sister, Blanche Wager (Stanley). His greatest passions were his wife and family, friends, and travel. He was particularly proud of his service during WWII as Master Sergeant for the Judge Advocate General. His quick wit, charming personality and "joie de vivre" will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 2 at 1pm at Plaza Funeral Home at 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

KATZ--Lewis. We deeply mourn the untimely passing of our cherished friend and partner. We love you dearly Lewis. Our hearts go out to Melissa, Stephen, Drew, Rachel and the entire Katz family. Love, Linda, Alan, Scott and Amy Landis and Dana and Eric Birnbaum

SCHEUER--Steven H.,pioneering television critic, author and broadcast journalist. Survived by his wife, Alida; former wife, Nikki; children Evan, Abigail, Marc and Eve, daughter-in-law Julia; grandchildren Ella, Cecelia, Lucas; sister Amy. Burial private. Memorial service to be announced.

KATZ--Lewis. The Board and staff of Starlight Children's Foundation NY*NJ*CT are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our dear friend and board member. We will miss his spirit, his devotion and his passion. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family.

SCHWARTZ--Rona Sidelle, peacefully passed away while surrounded by loved ones on Saturday, May 31st, 2014 at the age of 87. Treasured teacher, guidance counselor, and social worker, she was an avid supporter of the arts and passionately loved to travel. Preceded in death by her beloved husband, Marvin Schwartz, she is survived by her sister - Sheila Rosen, children - Dan and Martha, daughter-in-law Kitty, and grandchildren - David and Cara and many devoted friends. A graduate of Syracuse University, she dedicated her career to working for the New York City public school system. Her last 25 years were spent in Great Neck, with most of her family residing in the area. She will always be remembered for her kindness, sense of humor and curiosity, and taught us all to live up to our greatest potential and to never be afraid to fight for what we believe in.

PEARSON--Clarence E. The New York Academy of Medicine (NYAM) extends our condolences to our dear friend Laurie Norris, on the passing of her beloved husband, Clarence E. Pearson, a lifetime Fellow and champion of NYAM. As a writer, consummate networker and generous friend and colleague, he eagerly shared his expertise in global health and aging in support of NYAM's work promoting urban health and spreading Age-Friendly Cities worldwide. We will miss him. Dr. Jo Ivey Boufford, President

SHERMAN--Bernard, of Ardsley, NY, died on May 31st at the age of 89 after a long illness. Son of Sol and Lena Sherman, he is survived by his sons Leonard and Eric, daughter-in-law Betsy and four grandchildren, Andrew, Gillian, Emily and Sarah. He was the devoted husband of Edith who preceded him in death. He was a dentist in private practice in both the Bronx and Westchester and was on the faculty of Columbia University, teaching residents at North Central Bronx Hospital. Funeral services will be held Thursday, June 5th at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 9am.

Roob--Richard. On June 2, 2014, age 81, of New York City died peacefully at home. A tall, gentle soul, Richard was deeply devoted to Rona, his beloved wife of 52 years. Richard enhanced the lives everyone who was privileged to know him and brought great joy to his two daughters and their husbands, Nancy Roob and Lukas Weinstein and Helen and Marc Jerome, and his five grandchildren: Hanna, Ella, Sophie, Lucy and Sam. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Richard was a lifelong learner who loved nothing more than reading, the arts and spending time with his family. A graduate of Poly Prep, Hamilton College and Columbia Law School, he joined Benjamin Moore & Co. as general counsel in 1976 and was elected Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1984, retiring in 2000. He also served as board member and Chairman of Studio in a School from 1996 until 2014. Services will take place on Thursday, June 5 at 3:00 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Studio in a School or the Wellin Museum of Art at Hamilton College.
STEIN--Michael. You were a wonderful friend. You will be missed by us and so many others. Love, Robin and John
KATZ--Lewis. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Lewis Katz. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

KATZ--Lewis. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the sudden passing of our dear friend and colleague Lewis Katz. Lew was a true humanitarian who cared deeply about kids, and gave so much to so many, including to Boys & Girls Clubs across the country through his longtime active service on the BGCA Board of Governors. He founded the Boys & Girls Clubs in his beloved hometown of Camden, NJ, and was currently playing a leading role in supporting the Boys & Girls Club of Atlantic City. Lew's generosity of spirit will always be remembered by all who had the privilege to know him. Our heartfelt condolences and prayers go out to his children Drew and Melissa, and all of Lew's family and friends. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President

FEIGIN--Annette, age 89, died peacefully June 1, 2014 after a long illness. Devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Married for 50 years to Dr. Simeon Lubell Feigin, who pre-deceased her in 2004. Graduate of Queens College, long time resident of Scarsdale and White Plains. Is survived by her brother David Tilson, her children Cynthia, Laura, Andrew, and Gerald and her grandchildren Lindsay, Amanda, Jennifer, Madeleine, Daniel, and Audrey.

BUCHMAN--Sylvan "Buck", passed away on May 28, 2014, in Palm Beach, Florida at a vibrant and astute 95. Buck is survived by Shirley, his college sweetheart and wife of 72 years and his two loving sons, Peter and John. Born May 22, 1919 to Irving and Tillie in Seagate, Brooklyn, NY. Adored by his mom and twin sisters. the late Ruth James and Irene Weinberg. He was the oral family historian, a humorist, and a steadfast friend. Buck was a snow bird of Palm Beach and Greenwich, CT. A World Traveler and a geographer. A would-be golfer and a beloved Member of Fairview Country Club, Greenwich, CT. He attended The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, '40. Served as a Captain in the US Army Corp of Engineers for five years and was Deployed in the Pacific. He was Chairman of The L. Buchman Co., Inc. (est 1917); a Board Member of The Checker Motors Corp; an Industrial Realtor, At James H. Burns Co. (Now Douglas Elliman). Interment is on Thursday, June 5 at 10am, Beth El Cemetery, 8012 Cypress Hills St, Ridgewood, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Southern Poverty Law Center in Buck's name.

BYRNES-GOODE--Dorothy Rose (October 22, 1917 - May 31, 2014) Harlemite. Retired in 1982 after 42 years of administrative service within NYC's Housing Authority, Police Department, and H.R.A. She is survived by her son Michael Goode, her nephew, Mustafa Ahmed and countless nieces, nephews and cousins.

KATZ--Lewis. Columbia University Medical Center's Division of Cardiology mourns the passing of Lewis Katz, trusted Medical Center Board of Advisor member, generous benefactor and special friend. Mr. Katz, along with his deceased wife, Marjorie, was an ardent supporter of Columbia's Cardiac Programs. Most recently, he named and supported the Lewis and Marjorie Katz Cardiology Patient Care Suite, the first space to be named at Columbia Doctors Midtown. Almost a decade ago, Mr. Katz established the Katz Prizes in Cardiovascular Research, highlighting the contributions of leading cardiovascular researchers nationally, and driving innovative research through his support of junior investigators at the dawn of their careers. Mr. Katz was loved and admired by those who knew him, especially his children and grandchildren who survive him. At a recent University event, he gathered his grandchildren together to expound upon the importance of philanthropy and giving back to the community. Our hearts go out to his children, Drew, and his wife Rachel, Melissa, and her husband, Steven, and his grandchildren, Ethan, Brooke, Taryn, and Remi. As we are saddened by his untimely loss, we will continue to be thankful for all that he has left behind. Allan Schwartz, M.D. Seymour Milstein and Harold Ames Hatch Professor of Medicine Chief of the Division of Cardiology

ALPERT--Esther Racoosin, of Larchmont, NY. Daughter of Abram Racoosin and Rebecca Cohen Racoosin. Wife of the late Dr. Seymour Alpert. Mother of Beth, Abbe and Amy; their husbands Farzad, Steve and Rob. Grandmother of Natalie, Mandana, Hannah and Saul. Sister of Bill Racoosin. Funeral Thursday, 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Shiva at home. Services Thursday and Sunday at 7pm.

KATZ--Lewis, LeFrak Family extend their deepest condolences to Lewis' son Drew, daughter Melissa, and the Katz family on Lewis' sudden and tragic passing. He was a dear friend and business associate of many years. Generous, warm-hearted, and charming, Lewis will live in our hearts and minds forever. He will be missed by all who knew him.

HEFT--Catherine M. (nee Ogilvie), Formerly of Nyack, NY, Danville CA, and Sunnyside, Queens, she died on May 31, 2014. Born in New York City on July 22, 1931, she was the daughter of Catherine and James Ogilvie. She was predeceased by her husband, Robert E. Heft, a stepson, Robert and two sisters, Helen Viehmann and Joan Powers. Catherine attended the College of Notre Dame on Staten Island, graduating in 1953. She worked in the 1950s through the 1970s at Time Inc., and Sports Illustrated Magazine. She leaves a stepdaughter, Lorchen Heft-Neal and her family and many nieces and nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday at 10am at St. Ann's RC Church in Nyack. Visiting will be on Tuesday from 4pm until 8pm at the Hannemann Funeral Home, Inc., 88 So. Broadway Nyack, NY 10960 (845) 358-0573.
