ABRAHAM--Gerard S. Adored one, I am withering away without your love. Your Lover

VALE--Norman. After a brave five-year fight against multiple myeloma, Norman Vale passed away peacefully on June 3, 2014, surrounded by loved ones. Born on January 19, 1930 to Henry and Evelyn Feldman in New York City, he graduated from the Bronx High School of Science and City College of New York. He served in the United States Army in Europe during the Korean War. Norman had a distinguished career in the advertising business, having been the Managing Director International of Grey Advertising. He later served as the Director General of the International Advertising Association. Norman's life was filled with worldwide travel, running, skiing, swimming, rooting for the New York Giants and his beloved Fire Island. He served on the Dunewood Property Owners Association and the Dunewood Fire District for many years. Norman was a special man who touched many people's lives. He had a gift for making everyone he met feel important. He is survived by his wife Irene, daughters Maggi and Jennifer, grandchildren Sarah Nasoff, Kate Nasoff, Max Lazerwitz and Harry Lazerwitz, and brother Philip Vale; and the three sons he never had Michael Nasoff, Larry Lazerwitz and Jeff Goldberg. There will be no funeral. Arrangements for a celebration of Norman's life will be announced shortly by the family. Donations can be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation or the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, Greater New York Chapter.

BANNERMAN--Jane C. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy for the passing of Jane C. Bannerman. Jane was an esteemed volunteer at the Hospital for 52 years dedicating more than 10,000 hours of service in the Patients' Library. Her kindness and generosity toward HSS patients throughout the years and her contributions to the Hospital will have a lasting impact. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Kendrick R. Wilson III, Chair, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO, Hospital for Special Surgery

KATZ--Lewis, We honor the life and legacy of our friend Lewis Katz--a leader, philanthropist and dear friend for whom success meant working to help others gain access to education and opportunity. His humble beginnings never far from his mind, Lewis never saw financial success as an end in itself, but a means to generate the most opportunity for the greatest number. Lewis had a great business mind, but more importantly, he had a big heart which touched everyone. The care and love for his family, his daughter Melissa, his son Drew, his grandchildren and his many friends was always first for Lewis. He leaves behind a world improved by his efforts and his life of good deeds. We will all miss you Lewis. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and friends at this time. Bruce Ratner and the Forest City Ratner Companies Family

PEARSON--Clarence E. The officers and Board of Directors of the American Federation for Aging Research deeply mourn the loss of its longtime dedicated board member. Joining the board in 2002, he served as an active member of numerous committees. We are grateful for his long standing commitment to aging research, health promotion and global health. William J. Lipton, Chair; Stephanie Lederman, Executive Director

ROOB--Richard. The Studio in a School Board of Directors, President & CEO Thomas Cahill, and staff mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Richard, Board member since 1996 and Chair for ten years. He believed in giving his time, energy, and business acumen for the benefit of others. His kindness, thoughtfulness, generosity, and devotion to bringing visual art to New York City public school students will be greatly missed. His commitment to extending Studio in a School's work through scholarships was paramount. In our sadness and loss we offer condolences to his beloved wife Rona, daughters Nancy and Helen, and extended family.

RHETT--Robert Goodwyn, "Goody", Charleston, SC, age 93. Graduate of EHS and Yale 1942; US Navy LtJG; mining executive; wed to Joan Morgan 63 years; father of Anita, Robert, Amy, John, Peter. Service June 7, Magnolia Cemetery, 2pm.

SCHEUER--Steven H.,pioneering television critic, author and broadcast journalist. Survived by his wife, Alida; former wife, Nikki; children Evan, Abigail, Marc and Eve, daughter-in-law Julia; grandchildren Ella, Cecelia, Lucas; sister Amy. Burial private. Memorial service to be announced.

ROOB--Richard. The Board of 14 East 90th Street express with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed Board member, who for twenty years served with professionalism, care and dedication. Richard and Rona Roob have been respected members of our co-op community for over forty years. Richard was a true gentleman, a wonderful neighbor and he will be missed by all. The staff and all who reside here extend to Rona and her family our deepest condolences.
Strauss--Ruth. The Summer Camp community remembers our longtime friend and mother of Liz Strauss, our president-elect. We send our sincere condolences to the Strauss and Gruber families.

LEWIS--Lawrence "Larry", longtime talent agency administrative and financial corporate executive and consultant passed away on May 30th at the age of 89 years. Born in the Bronx, NY; during WWII he served in combat in Europe and received three battle stars, the Bronze Star, the Croix de Guerre with Palm awarded by General De Gaulle to 88th Infantry Division Members, in addition to other medals. His experiences are part of the Veterans History Project of the Library of Congress. After WWII, he attended Columbia University where he received a degree in economics and accounting. When he joined the William Morris Agency, Variety magazine stated "Lewis has been regarded as one of the top financial administrators in the ranks of talent agencies. He had been assistant controller of MCA prior to coming to General Artists Corp. which later became CMA. Lewis will become the only man who has been in high level administration posts at the three largest show biz agencies." Lewis worked with major talent, TV, film and music executives and managers, in addition to many famous stars over the years. He has been a supporter of Jewish and other charities, on his own, and through Foundations in which he was an officer. Beloved husband of Elinor (nee Posen). Loving father of Barbara Lewis Marco, Andy Lewis (Kari Sagin-Lewis), and Susan Lewis-Sadoun (Philippe). Devoted "grandpop" to Jesse Marco, Jackson Lewis and Gabriel and Julian Sadoun. Dear brother of Cookie Marks, and uncle to Patrice and Jeffrey. Adored uncle of Robin Silverman (David Goldberg), and grand-nephews Brian and Tyler.

Roob--Richard. On June 2, 2014, age 81, of New York City died peacefully at home. A tall, gentle soul, Richard was deeply devoted to Rona, his beloved wife of 52 years. Richard enhanced the lives everyone who was privileged to know him and brought great joy to his two daughters and their husbands, Nancy Roob and Lukas Weinstein and Helen and Marc Jerome, and his five grandchildren: Hanna, Ella, Sophie, Lucy and Sam. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Richard was a lifelong learner who loved nothing more than reading, the arts and spending time with his family. A graduate of Poly Prep, Hamilton College and Columbia Law School, he joined Benjamin Moore & Co. as general counsel in 1976 and was elected Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1984, retiring in 2000. He also served as board member and Chairman of Studio in a School from 1996 until 2014. Services will take place on Thursday, June 5 at 3:00 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Studio in a School or the Wellin Museum of Art at Hamilton College.

SUMMA--Sylvia J.,(nee Caraturo) born July 13, 1939 Brooklyn, New York; died May 28, 2014 Rome, Italy. Beloved wife of the late Anthony Nicholas Summa; dear mother of Don and Lisa; mother-in-law of Billy Finnegan. Sister of Julie Pallotta, Frank Caraturo; sister-in-law of Anthony Pallotta, Sue Caraturo. Beloved aunt, great-aunt, godmother, cousin. Survived by countless family members, friends, and colleagues who loved and admired her. Career New York City teacher and early childhood administrator. Order Sons of Italy in America national, state, and local officer. Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church (Williamsburg) lifelong volunteer and leader. Local Area Policy Board member. Educator. Volunteer. Humanitarian. Community Leader. Elected official. Lifetime Brooklynite. She lived a life of extraordinary service and achievement, and of supreme dedication to family, friends, church, community, and country. Funeral information:www.banastasio.frontrunnerpro.com.

JARETZKI--Alfred III, MD. 94, of New York City and Essex, CT, died on May 29. Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery and Special Lecturer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Revered for his integrity both as clinician and mentor, Fred's long and distinguished career in the Department of Surgery began in 1944 and continued until his retirement in 1992. Early in his career he co-authored with Drs. Arthur Voorhees and Arthur Blakemore the seminal paper on the development of synthetic vascular grafts. This work initiated the modern era of aortic aneur- ysm surgery. After a decade at the Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY, Fred returned to Columbia, where he redefined the anatomy of the thymus gland and the importance of its complete removal in the surgical therapy for myasthenia gravis. This earned him an international reputation which continues to this day. His multiple publications on thymectomy lead to his appointment, at age 85, as co-investigator of the NIH funded Recommendations for Clinical Research undertaken by the Myasthenia Gravis Task Force. Fred's long and elegant life included being Captain of the Junior Varsity Football Team at Harvard and Treasurer of the Lampoon, skiing the Headwall at Tuckerman Ravine, winning the New York State Star Class Championship, being a founding member of the Cooperstown Planning Commission, President of the New York Thoracic Society, Practitioner of the Year, Medical Director of the Operating Rooms from 1992-1996, and co-authoring "A Proud Heritage: an Informal History of Surgery at Columbia," with Drs. Frederic P. Herter and Kenneth A. Forde. He is survived by his sister Josie Lipman, his children Alfred IV, Lasell Bartlett, Alexander and Sumner, his stepson Adam Isles and his wife Hannah and their children Nina and Peter, and his loving wife Alexandra. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 18 at 5pm at the Knickerbocker Club in New York. Contributions in Fred's memory can be made to the "Alfred Jaretzki III MD Endowment Fund" which supports the research of junior faculty in the area of thoracic surgery at Columbia University Medical Center. Department of Surgery Finance Office, Attn: Trisha J. Hargaden, 21 Audubon Avenue, Room 209, New York, NY 10032 (212-305-2735).
ROSEN--Hobart E. Former Director Point O' Pines Camp. Died peacefully on May 19, 2014. Memorial Service Sunday, June 8 2pm, Hyatt Regency, Old Greenwich, CT.

GORMAN--Richard W.,of Northport on May 31, 2014, 67 years of age. Devoted husband of Cynthia. Beloved father of Kimberly and Christian. Cherished son of Josephine and the late William. Loving brother of Patricia Rowan (Joseph), William (Dorothy) and Marilyn Entwistle (Paul Dinter). Dear son in-law of Douglas and Janice Cromer and brother in-law of Julia Stanford (John) and John D. Cromer (Joan), also loved by many nieces and nephews. Rich retired as Vice president of LIU, and also served the United Ways of Tri State and Greater Cincinnati, Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau, UNICEF and the New School University during his career. Visiting Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Saturday 11:00am at the First Presbyterian Church of Northport, 330 Main Street, the Rev. Dr. Timothy Hoyt Duncan officiating. The family suggests contributions to Rich's alma mater, Marist College, in lieu of flowers. www.nthfh.com
KATZ--Lewis. Barclays Center and the Brooklyn Nets are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our dear friend. Our hearts go out to Lewis' children Drew and Melissa and the Katz family.

KATZ--Lewis. Dan and Abbe Klores and the Board of Directors of the New Renaissance Basketball Association extend their deeply felt condolences to the family of our friend and mentor Lewis Katz. We have loved you, Drew and Melissa for many, many years. Lewis made us smile, laugh and think. His wisdom and generosity, his sense of giving, his understated support for the underdog made him unique.

MERRILL--Julia, died June 1st, 2014. A proud graduate of Brooklyn College, class of 1940. The smartest, kindest sister, mother, grandmother and aunt we could have wanted. We will love and miss you always. Steven, Mary Ann, Abby, Sammi, David, Nancy, Lizanne, Samy, Gracie, Clara, Jesse and Madison

SPIEGEL--Gail Hoch, age 78, resident of Palm Beach, FL, Weston, CT and New York City, passed away on June 3, 2014 of complications of Alzheimer's and colon cancer. She leaves behind her husband of 48 years Robert, her son Richard, her aid Marjette Ebanks. She will be sorely missed by them as well as her many friends. She was a kind and lovely lady.

KATZ--Lewis. We deeply mourn the untimely passing of our cherished friend and partner. We love you dearly Lewis. Our hearts go out to Melissa, Stephen, Drew, Rachel and the entire Katz family. Love, Linda, Alan, Scott and Amy Landis and Dana and Eric Birnbaum

KING--Charles, The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, senior staff and membership mourn the passing of AHRC New York City Board Member, Charles King, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. Charles was a member of AHRC since 1964 and became a member of the Board of Directors in 1971. During those years he served in a variety of important leadership positions, was the chair of multiple Board Committees and served as a member on other committees. Charles was on the NYSARC Inc. Board of Governors for 18 years and was active on NYSARC Committees being presented with NYSARC Inc. Volunteer of the Year Award in 2012. As President in the 1980's Charles was a strong supporter of changing the AHRC culture from one of being a "parents only" group to a family group that recognized the essential role of siblings and other family members in the lives of their loved ones and the organization. He was always very proud that his daughter, Caroline Luna, was a volunteer worker at AHRC Sib Shops. We offer our sincere condolences to his family his daughter Caroline Luna of New York, son Peter of Washington D.C., and his daughter Buffy who resides in an AHRC New York City residence in Brooklyn. Charles wife Betsey, a special education teacher and Charles' life-partner, passed away four years ago. Charles will be remembered by his "AHRC family" and will be greatly missed. Laura J. Kennedy, President AHRC New York City Gary Lind, Executive Director, AHRC New York City

KATZ--Lewis. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the sudden passing of our dear friend and colleague Lewis Katz. Lew was a true humanitarian who cared deeply about kids, and gave so much to so many, including to Boys & Girls Clubs across the country through his longtime active service on the BGCA Board of Governors. He founded the Boys & Girls Clubs in his beloved hometown of Camden, NJ, and was currently playing a leading role in supporting the Boys & Girls Club of Atlantic City. Lew's generosity of spirit will always be remembered by all who had the privilege to know him. Our heartfelt condolences and prayers go out to his children Drew and Melissa, and all of Lew's family and friends. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President

KATZ--Lewis. We deeply mourn the untimely passing of our cherished friend and partner. We love you dearly Lewis. Our hearts go out to Melissa, Stephen, Drew, Rachel and the entire Katz family. Love, Linda, Alan, Scott and Amy Landis and Dana and Eric Birnbaum

WILEY--Lovejoy. Lovejoy (Joy) Skinner Wiley, 76, died on June 1, 2014, at her Sea Island Home surrounded by her loving family and friends. She was born in Waynesboro, GA on December 11, 1937 to Charles W., Jr., and Henrietta Boyer Skinner. She graduated from Waynesboro High school in 1955, and went on to earn a BA in English History from Brenau College. Joy and her husband Spencer met in New York City where they settled down and spent many loving years raising a family. She is preceded in death by her parents Charles and Henrietta. She is survived by her spouse Spencer L. Wiley, daughter Henrietta (Rhetta) L. Wiley (Mary), Step-daughter Anne (Irin) Alphonso, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Joy was a long standing member of the Junior League of New York and Alpha Delta Pi Sorority. She was an avid reader and served on the board of the St. Simons Library. Joy was also involved with a variety of clubs and charitable organizations on St. Simons, in Brunswick, and in New York. A memorial Service will be held in New York in the near future. Burial will take place at a later time at the Magnolia Cemetery in Waynesboro, GA. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in memory of Lovejoy Wiley to: "Dry Macular Degeneration Research at the Mayo Clinic". Gifts can be mailed to: Mayo Clinic, Department of Development, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, MN 55905.

RABINOWITZ--Ruth, nee Lapidus, born June 2, 1926, died June 3, 2014. Daughter of immigrants, graduated City College of New York 1948, teacher at public schools in the Bronx, wife of 66 years to Jacob, mother of David, Naomi and Jesse, grandmother of Emily, Jonah and Aaron, great-grandmother of Charlotte. Her legacy is in her students, her family and in the part she played in the great flow of Eastern European Jews who have enriched New York and America.

JACOX--Leroy C. "Jay," 92, died peacefully on May 23, 2014, in Redding, CT. We mourn the loss of a man of great integrity and humor, a cherished husband, father, grandfather and friend. Born in Fort Morgan, CO, Jay earned degrees from the University of Colorado and Columbia. He served as a captain in the United States Army Air Corps, and was employed by New York area companies, retiring from Doubleday as senior Vice President. An active member of the Wilton community, he served the Kiwanis, the Ogden House Board, and St. Matthew's Episcopal Church. He was a beloved member of the Davis Park Fire Island Community. Devoted husband of Shirley Agnes Solinger, his wife of 57 years, he is survived by his children, Christiane, Susan, and Robert; grandchildren, Rosalind, Katherine, Joseph, Mattie, Jack, John, and Augusta; and great-grandchild, Gunner. Services will be held on Saturday, June 7, 2014, 10am, St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Wilton, Connecticut. Donations can be made to Doctors without Borders.

GOODMAN--Roy. The Liberal Party of New York will miss Roy Goodman, a unique man and a courageous and loyal friend. There's been no one like him. Jack Olchin, Chairman Martin I. Hassner, CEO

GOODMAN--Roy. Beloved Pal. Dalia and I mourn the passing of my best friend Roy Goodman. Our friendship spanned 79 years from our childhood in the playgrounds of Central Park and school days at the Hunter Model School until yesterday when your courageous battle against Parkinson's Disease finally ended. During most of these years, there were few days we did not converse. A lifetime of friendship for two men who perhaps became closer than the brothers we never had. Roy was my brother in life. Roy was strong, intelligent, elegant, of infinite integrity with an amazing sense of humor and gift of oratory--second to none on the New York political scene. After college and graduate school, we served together as land-based Naval officers here in the City. Marriage came soon, and we served as ushers, reciprocating in each other's wedding ceremonies, and after that, Roy became the godfather of my three children, and I of his wonderful children: Claire, Leslie, and Randy. Roy was a born leader. I do not think he ever passed a year at any school without being elected president of the class. A decade after graduating from Harvard College and Harvard Business School, he successfully continued his electoral career winning 17 consecutive races for the New York State Senate. His only defeat during that time was when he ran for the mayoralty of New York City in 1977. Roy was a magnificent human being--a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. He was compassionate and kind. Roy and I spent much of our lives together, including many trips around the world. Roy--I miss you so much and will think of you every day. You were my hero at age six and still are today. Dalia sends love. Larry
PHILLIPS--Lorelle. There is a big hole in our lives, but she left a gorgeous legacy to fill it. Skippy & Manny

PHILLIPS--Lorelle Marcus,born in the Bronx on February 3, 1937, daughter of Ina and Albert Marcus, died on June 3, 2014 after an eight year battle with cancer. Attended PS 106, Herman Ritter Jr High School, High School of Music and Art, Mamaroneck High School 1953, Bard College (BA) 1957, Bank Street College (MA) 1980. Founded and taught the Program for Twos and Parents at Sarah Lawrence College Early Childhood Center, which she based on the work of Dr. Margaret Mahler, 1979 to 2007. Married Roger Phillips in 1957 who survives her. They lived in Larchmont, NY for 35 years; then New York City and Stuyvesant, NY. Also survived by her sister Bonnie Marcus and brother-in-law Ted O'Neill; her children, their spouses and her grandchildren: John Phillips (Nicholas, Charlotte and George); Sarah and John Mathews (Susannah and Noah); David and Julie Phillips (Chloe and Ruby Lorelle); and Matthew and Jo Phillips (Anabelle and Evan). Her sister Sydna died in 2002. She was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother; gifted teacher, painter, avid traveler... and forever feisty. Memorial Service Sunday, June 8th, 1pm, at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538. Contributions in her honor may be sent to Sarah Lawrence College Early Childhood Center Discretionary Fund, One Meadway, Bronxville, NY 10708.

KOVATS--Maria (Mady), passed away peacefully in her sleep on June 3, 2014 at DeWitt Nursing Home in New York City. Maria was predeceased by her father, Peter, her much beloved mother, Theresa, and her sister Nuschi Anna Schmidt Piper (nee Kovats). The Kovats settled in the Yorkville section of New York City after emigrating from Eastern Europe. Maria expressed a life-long avocation for the Arts, as a fine art collector. She was retired from a career at Chemical Bank. Countess Maria is survived by her grandniece Patricia Collins, who enjoyed the music and laughter of their visits together. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday June 6, 2014 at St Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th Street, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. For further information please contact Krtil Funeral Home, Inc at 212-744-3084.

GOODMAN--Roy M. Hunter College mourns the loss of Roy M. Goodman, 1941 Hunter College Elementary School alum and tireless supporter of public education from kindergarten through college. He was a lifelong friend of and frequent visitor to--the College and its Campus Schools. In 1972, when the Hunter College High School and Elementary School were nearly closed amid a budget battle in Albany, it was Senator Goodman who lobbied Governor Nelson Rockefeller to keep the schools open. The Roy M. Goodman Hunter College Elementary School Library was named in the Senator's honor. Hunter College will always be grateful to Senator Goodman for his friendship and support.

FRIEDMAN--Morton B. Mary C. Boyce, Dean of Columbia Engineering, and the faculty and staff of Columbia University's Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science mourn the passing of long-time professor and senior vice dean emeritus Morton B. Friedman. Mort, as he was known to everyone at the School and at the University, joined the Engineering faculty in 1956 and spent the next seven decades becoming the heart, soul, and collective memory of the School. Mort, an aerospace engineer and mathematician, received his BS, MS, and EngScD degrees from New York University. After a brief appointment at NYU as a research associate, he moved to Columbia Engineering, where he advanced through the academic ranks in the Department of Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, appointed as full professor in 1966. In 1995, he was appointed vice dean, senior vice dean in 2010, and senior vice dean emeritus in 2012. Mort founded the Division of Mathematical Methods, the precursor to the applied mathematics component of what is now the Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics, where he held a joint appointment. One of his earliest students in this program was Nobel Laureate Robert C. Merton BS'66. Mort was a brilliant mathematician with major contributions in the development of accelerated quadrature methods of linear integral equations, accelerated spectral analysis of compact operators, accelerated projection methods, and uniform asymptotic solutions of differential equations with an almost periodic coefficient. He and his students were the earliest developers of the boundary element method that has later found widespread application in many engineering and applied science disciplines. Mort had performed research for the National Science Foundation in variational methods for fluids; for NASA in the SST sonic boom; and for DARPA in large scaled computations. He had been a consultant to North Star Construction, Hudson Institute and Computer Usage Corp. for numerical analysis; Weidlinger Associates and Christensen, Inc., for applied mechanics; and Inference Corporation for Artificial Intelligence software. As vice dean, he was in the vanguard of engineering education leaders and helped shape the curriculum for many decades, from bringing engineering education into the first-year curriculum with project-based design and discipline-specific professional courses to creating a minors program in more than 20 liberal arts subjects, and from encouraging service learning to providing research opportunities for undergraduates with junior and senior faculty. Mort diligently served as mentor for a long line of faculty in various departments, a service of truly major importance to the school. He was also widely respected across the University for his insight, providing wise counsel on navigating the many complexities of a university. From 1981 to 1995, he served as chair of the Department of Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics and, from 1980 to 1991, also held the post of associate dean for instruction and research. In addition, he chaired the Executive Committee of the University Senate for several years. A former Fulbright Professor in applied mathematics and Field Instrumentation Scholar for the American Institute for Physics, he was recognized for his outstanding teaching by the Society of Columbia Graduates, which honored him with its Great Teacher Award in 1978. In 2012, the School recognized Mort for his lifelong devotion as a professor and senior vice dean, dedicating the conference room where he led so many meetings as the Morton B. Friedman Conference Room. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, his devoted and treasured wife of 58 years, Sandy; his loving children, Robert (Linda) and Lori (Jim Goldfinger); and his three beloved grandchildren, Chason, Asher, and Daden Goldfinger. To recognize Mort's lasting impact on Columbia and Columbia Engineering, a public memorial service is planned in the fall at St. Paul's Chapel. Mary Cunningham Boyce Dean of Engineering Morris A. and Alma Schapiro Professor

SEIDEN--Barbara, The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Barbara Seiden, spouse of our devoted trustee, Norman, and mother of trustee, Mark. Barbara and Norman have cared deeply about humankind and about repairing the world. Barbara had a keen sense of justice and interest in people in all walks of life. Together, Barbara and Norman have championed excellence and compassion in health care, among many other humanitarian causes. Their enumerable contributions to the Gold Foundation to improve the health of people worldwide have made a difference. We extend our sympathies and love to our dear friend and trustee, Norman Seiden; his children, Stephen and Sharon; Mark and Diane; and Pearl, and to his 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO

SAHN--Jack G. The family of Jack G. Sahn, "Jake" to many, sadly records the peaceful passing of our beloved and respected husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and patriarch on June 3, 2014, at home, at age 90. The building blocks of his life are best described by the words honesty, integrity, service, dedication and devotion. He served his Country in the Army Air Corps in the CBI in World War II, and served his community as a Trustee of the Village of Lake Success for 12 years, and then as Village Mayor for eight years. He was a dedicated member of Temple Israel of Great Neck, served on its Board of Trustees and the Nominating Committee. He was a proud graduate of The University of Michigan, where he also earned his MBA. He was the devoted husband of Thelma, his wife of 65 years. He was the role model for his children, Michael, David and Billy (Brian), and their wives, Linda, Lisa and Emilya, to whom he gave his unconditional love. He loved and adored his grandchildren, Sam, and his wife Sandy, Ben and his wife Rachel, Rebecca and her husband Josh, Alexander, Lily, Emma, Chloe and Annie, whose achievements he admired every day. He loved and took great joy from his great-grandchildren, Isaac, Brett and Hannah. He was the beloved brother of Chester and Arthur, who predeceased him. We celebrate his full and remarkable life.
FRIEDLANDER--Kurt A. You were such a wonderful person; we miss your big smile, humor and all your kind- heartedness. Always remembered and loved. Love, Pie and Poohsie

WILEY--Lovejoy. Lovejoy (Joy) Skinner Wiley, 76, died on June 1, 2014, at her Sea Island Home surrounded by her loving family and friends. She was born in Waynesboro, GA on December 11, 1937 to Charles W., Jr., and Henrietta Boyer Skinner. She graduated from Waynesboro High school in 1955, and went on to earn a BA in English History from Brenau College. Joy and her husband Spencer met in New York City where they settled down and spent many loving years raising a family. She is preceded in death by her parents Charles and Henrietta. She is survived by her spouse Spencer L. Wiley, daughter Henrietta (Rhetta) L. Wiley (Mary), Step-daughter Anne (Irin) Alphonso, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Joy was a long standing member of the Junior League of New York and Alpha Delta Pi Sorority. She was an avid reader and served on the board of the St. Simons Library. Joy was also involved with a variety of clubs and charitable organizations on St. Simons, in Brunswick, and in New York. A memorial Service will be held in New York in the near future. Burial will take place at a later time at the Magnolia Cemetery in Waynesboro, GA. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in memory of Lovejoy Wiley to: "Dry Macular Degeneration Research at the Mayo Clinic". Gifts can be mailed to: Mayo Clinic, Department of Development, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, MN 55905.

VALE--Norman. The Dunwood Board of Fire Commissioners is saddened by the death of Past Commissioner Norman Vale. Norman was the District's first Fire Commissioner and it was through his many years of leadership and dedicated service that the Dunewood community is currently protected by Fire Island's most comprehensive Fire and E.M.S medical service. He will be surely missed. The Dunewood Board of Fire Commissioners

RAVITCH--Donald, died peacefully on May 27, 2014 in San Francisco surrounded by his family. He was born in New York and educated at Horace Mann and Georgia Tech. In 1960 he moved to California with his wife Gloria Moskin to become President and later Chairman of Sherman Clay & Co. the keyboard retail chain. In 1985 he married Patricia Baron of New York. Donald's charm and good humor will be missed by many including his children Amy Friedricks (Bruce), Jill Ravitch, John Ravitch (Adisa) and grandchildren Emily and Henry Friedricks. He will also be remembered by Patricia's children Susan Mald (Lance), Fred Baron (Nancy), John Baron (Betsy) and his step-grandchildren Max and Sara Mald, and Katie, Maggie, Oliver, and Andrew Baron. Memorial services will be Friday, June 13 In San Francisco. For more information contact ravmoto@mac.com.

GOODMAN--Roy M. Died at age 84, June 3, 2014. New York State Senator for 33 years "Statesman of the State Senate," former Chairman of the Senate Committee on Investigations, Taxation and Government Operations, former New York City Director of Finance, Chairman New York Republican County Committee, and President and CEO of the UNDC. Passionate advocate for the arts and education. Extraordinary human being and philanthropist, lifelong public servant who touched the lives of so many. Beloved husband of 50 years to Barbara, devoted father of Claire, Leslie, Randy and grandfather of Ricky, Danny, Nicole, Erika, Thomas and Kaitlyn; father-in-law of Rusty and Molly; brother-in-law of John and Lou Furrer. Your life inspires us to live each day to the fullest, make the world a better place, give more than you receive, and live by your motto: "Happiness is a way of travel, not a destination." Funeral services Monday, June 16, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. Condolence visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81st St. on Sunday, June 15th from 6pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to "Harvard Kennedy School/Roy M. Goodman Fund," 79 JFK St., Cambridge, MA 02138 or "City Parks Foundation/Roy M. Goodman Fund," 830 Fifth Ave, NYC 10065-7001.

LANIN--Mike. President of Howard Lanin Productions passed away in New York on April 14, 2014 at age 90. In 1952 Mike hired a 22-year old conductor for a nationwide Gershwin concert tour that ran for two seasons (1952-54) and played in 170 cities. His name: Lorin Maazel. It was the only orchestra in history dedicated exclusively to the music of one composer. Mike pursued his interest in George Gershwin in collaboration with Michael Feinstein. Mike, a well-known producer of shows for large corporations (IBM, Coca Cola, CBS, AT&T) hired star performers such as Harry Belafonte, Tony Bennett, Liza Minnelli, Diahann Carroll, Leslie Huggams, Lena Horne, Bob Hope, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Bolger, Doc Severinsen and Bill Cosby among others. Memorable productions Mike presented include The Royal Danish Ballet in its US debut and The Conservatory Without Walls, a glittering event in honor of the country's greatest Afro-American musicians which launched the Duke Ellington Fellowship Fund at Yale University. Mike also served on the board of The Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. Mike Lanin was born in Philadelphia on March, 8, 1924, the son of the band leader Howard Lanin and the nephew of Lester Lanin, the internationally known society band leader. During World War II he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps. At that time he discovered a young and talented pianist, still unknown, Bobby Short. They became friends for the rest of their lives. Mike was a graduate of Yale University where he was an imaginative caricaturist for the Yale Record. He is also remembered for his fond portrayal of Orson Welles' Citizen Kane. Mike was an elegant man both in appearance and in spirit. He was always courteous, soft spoken, never one to boast of his many achievements and of his friendships with famous artists. He was a loyal friend, a witty but considerate companion with a dry sense of humor. He was an entertaining guest. Mike has been called "the dean of entertainment who pioneered the theme party, the pops concert, the anniversary revue and the multimedia production." He was an avid reader and traveler. He kept homes in New York and Paris. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, the love of his life, Yvonne Constant-Lanin, a performer herself and a frequent guest (45 times) on the Johnny Carson Show. It was always a pleasure to see how much Mike enjoyed his wife's performances. He was proud of her interpretations of French and American songs. At her recitals he would greet friends with a radiant smile. He was also proud of Yvonne having been named "Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres", an important French cultural award. Other immediate survivors include his sister, Suzanne Lande, his adopted daughter Kristina Stufano from a previous marriage, his stepson, Gerard Pinguet and numerous grandchildren.

FRIEDMAN--Morton B. The Society of Columbia Graduates mourns the passing of friend, advisor and recipient of the Great Teacher Award, Senior Vice Dean of Columbia School of Engineering Morton B. Friedman.

LUSTGARTEN--Leonard S, MD. Physician and Author. New York City/ Westhampton, NY and North Palm Beach, FL. Len passed on June 2, 2014 of Parkinson's Disease related respiratory failure at his home in North Palm Beach. He was very happy until the end and died peacefully in his sleep. He is survived by his loving wife Lesley and his sons, Eric and Todd. At 19 years of age, Len was a very proud graduate of Harvard University's class of 1948. He went on to Albany Medical School. Len Lustgarten was a renowned Doctor of Internal Medicine in Manhattan for over 40 years with legions of adoring patients and friends. His one man internal medical practice was legendary. Len became Chief Resident of Lenox Hill Hospital in 1960. He went on to be widely recognized by his peers. His patients included many from the worlds of art, society, finance and, of course, some far more interesting characters. Len was named "Best Doctor" by New York Magazine during the 1990's in his area of specialty for consecutive years. He is credited for having started the practices and careers of many of todays top physicians in their respective fields. He was one of the first physicians to encounter AIDS and fought to educate the public as to its truths and fallacies. As the editor of The Medical Tribune and the Medical Director of several large pharmaceutical advertising agencies, he was at the forefront of a changing era. Dr. Lustgarten also taught Evolutionary Biology at Palm Beach Community College in Florida later in life. Len Lustgarten's Novel "EUNUCH" received overwhelming praise when it was released in 2008/ 2009 and was hailed as a groundbreaking fictional epic. It has since been recognized as an exceptional work of unique proportions, exploring previously uncharted territory. It is the author's message to the world and the embodiment of all that he believed and experienced in life. Most importantly, it is his gift to the future. It is his tribute to Darwin. As per Len's wishes, there will no funeral or services. However, there will be a party later this Summer so that we may all hoist a glass and laugh as we remember him and tell the stories. He would have felt right at home with all of you whom he loved. Our father embodied the Hippocratic Oath "First Do No Harm". That is his legacy. In lieu of flowers or gifts, charitable contributions may be made to the following Charities: The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. The Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer and The Democratic National Committee. Please go to "EUNUCH NOVEL" at Facebook.com. All information, condolences, comments and donation details may be found there.

FRANKEL--Benjamin, formerly of Philadelphia, resided and died in Jupiter, Florida June 3, 2014. The son of Ephraim Jay and Zerline Topkis Frankel, Ben was born June 21, 1932 in Wilmington, Delaware. He grew up in Lower Merion and graduated from Lower Merion High School. In 1954, Ben graduated with honors from The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania where he was a member of Zeta Beta Tau fraternity. With his brothers, Leonard and William, Ben expanded EJ Frankel Enterprises into a large real estate development company which was founded by his father in the mid 1930's. In Philadelphia they built Parkway House, William Penn House, Kennedy House, 220 West Rittenhouse Square, The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Building at 1845 Walnut Street, The Hilton Hotel at 34th and Civic Center Boulevard and the Oakhill Apartment Complex in Gladwyne. They bought and renovated the Wellington apartments and the Warwick Hotel in Center City. In addition, the company developed buildings in Delaware, New Jersey, and Florida. In 1968 they built the 1162 unit Roney Plaza in Miami Beach. At the time of construction, it was the largest apartment building in the world under one roof. Ben's proudest achievements were Boca Lago, Hunters Run, and Admirals Cove, three golf course communities he developed in Florida with his brother Leonard and his nephew Thomas. A man of principal and integrity, Ben supported a variety of charities in both Pennsylvania and Florida. In Philadelphia he was a former trustee of Congregation Rodeph Shalom and a former member of the Board of Philmont Country Club. Ben will be mourned and missed by his beloved wife of 59 years Linda (Leventon), his devoted daughters Jane Frankel (Mathew), Gerry Frankel, Jennifer Zobl (Mark), and his adoring grandchildren Max, Zachary, and EJ Frankel, Lauren and Timothy Zobl. He is survived by his brother William, eight nieces and nephews and a host of friends. He was predeceased by his brother Leonard. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 615 N Broad Street, Philadelphia on Sunday June 8th at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation Rodeph Shalom or the charity of the donor's choice. Funeral services by Joseph Levine & Sons (www.levinefuneral.com)

FRIEDMAN--Morton B. Mary C. Boyce, Dean of Columbia Engineering, and the faculty and staff of Columbia University's Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science mourn the passing of long-time professor and senior vice dean emeritus Morton B. Friedman. Mort, as he was known to everyone at the School and at the University, joined the Engineering faculty in 1956 and spent the next seven decades becoming the heart, soul, and collective memory of the School. Mort, an aerospace engineer and mathematician, received his BS, MS, and EngScD degrees from New York University. After a brief appointment at NYU as a research associate, he moved to Columbia Engineering, where he advanced through the academic ranks in the Department of Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, appointed as full professor in 1966. In 1995, he was appointed vice dean, senior vice dean in 2010, and senior vice dean emeritus in 2012. Mort founded the Division of Mathematical Methods, the precursor to the applied mathematics component of what is now the Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics, where he held a joint appointment. One of his earliest students in this program was Nobel Laureate Robert C. Merton BS'66. Mort was a brilliant mathematician with major contributions in the development of accelerated quadrature methods of linear integral equations, accelerated spectral analysis of compact operators, accelerated projection methods, and uniform asymptotic solutions of differential equations with an almost periodic coefficient. He and his students were the earliest developers of the boundary element method that has later found widespread application in many engineering and applied science disciplines. Mort had performed research for the National Science Foundation in variational methods for fluids; for NASA in the SST sonic boom; and for DARPA in large scaled computations. He had been a consultant to North Star Construction, Hudson Institute and Computer Usage Corp. for numerical analysis; Weidlinger Associates and Christensen, Inc., for applied mechanics; and Inference Corporation for Artificial Intelligence software. As vice dean, he was in the vanguard of engineering education leaders and helped shape the curriculum for many decades, from bringing engineering education into the first-year curriculum with project-based design and discipline-specific professional courses to creating a minors program in more than 20 liberal arts subjects, and from encouraging service learning to providing research opportunities for undergraduates with junior and senior faculty. Mort diligently served as mentor for a long line of faculty in various departments, a service of truly major importance to the school. He was also widely respected across the University for his insight, providing wise counsel on navigating the many complexities of a university. From 1981 to 1995, he served as chair of the Department of Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics and, from 1980 to 1991, also held the post of associate dean for instruction and research. In addition, he chaired the Executive Committee of the University Senate for several years. A former Fulbright Professor in applied mathematics and Field Instrumentation Scholar for the American Institute for Physics, he was recognized for his outstanding teaching by the Society of Columbia Graduates, which honored him with its Great Teacher Award in 1978. In 2012, the School recognized Mort for his lifelong devotion as a professor and senior vice dean, dedicating the conference room where he led so many meetings as the Morton B. Friedman Conference Room. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, his devoted and treasured wife of 58 years, Sandy; his loving children, Robert (Linda) and Lori (Jim Goldfinger); and his three beloved grandchildren, Chason, Asher, and Daden Goldfinger. To recognize Mort's lasting impact on Columbia and Columbia Engineering, a public memorial service is planned in the fall at St. Paul's Chapel. Mary Cunningham Boyce Dean of Engineering Morris A. and Alma Schapiro Professor

GOODMAN--Roy M. We honor the life and legacy of dear family friend Roy M. Goodman, devoted husband, father, grandfather, steadfast friend, authentic New Yorker, and passionate State Senator. Roy's generosity, sparkling humor, deep love of family and loyalty to his many friends will endure. Love to Roy and Barbara's wonderful children and grandchildren. The Slusser Family

GOODMAN--The Hon. Roy M. With sadness and a profound sense of loss, Congregation Emanu-El oft the City of New York records the death of our devoted and distinguished member, the Honorable Roy M. Goodman. The beautiful qualities of his life, and his legacy of leadership shall endure. To his loved ones we express our deepest sympathies. The Temple Emanu-EI Family

GOODMAN--Roy M. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Senator Roy M. Goodman. A strong advocate of the arts, Senator Goodman joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1965. As a New York State Senator from 19682002, he worked tirelessly to increase public access to New York's cultural institutions, notably advocating for the renovation of Isaac Stern Auditorium and Joan and Sanford I. Weill Recital Hall to improve universal access, as well as for the creation of Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, which has enabled Carnegie Hall to reach new audiences around the world through a broad spectrum of concert and educational programming. Senator Goodman's eloquent remarks over the years inspired Carnegie Hall's Board of Trustees, business leaders, and elected officials to cooperate in a public-private partnership that underscored the importance of culture in the economic life of the region. All of us at Carnegie Hall will miss Senator Goodman's sound guidance and wisdom, and we express our heartfelt condolences to his three children, Leslie, Randolph, and Claire, and to the entire Goodman family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

OFFNER--Eric Delmonte, born in Vienna, Austria in 1928, founder of the jazz organization, The Sidney Bechet Society, son of Sigmund and Kathe Offner, died in his home in Manhasset Hills, New York, on June 3, 2014. Mr. Offner was twice widowed, having lost his beloved Julie Cosentino in 1959 and Carol Marcus in 1981, and divorced from Barbara Shotton. In 1938 he escaped with his immediate family to London. He was evacuated to Northhampton during the blitz under the care of the Halsey family. He immigrated with his biological family to Rio de Janeiro before settling in New York. Mr. Offner received his B.B.A. City College, 1949, and his JD, Cornell Law School, 1952. He is the author of numerous books on trademark law, including "International Trademark Protection." He lectured at George Washington University Law School, 1968-1972 and was a professor at Hofstra University Law School. He helped represent the American Bar Association with respect to the Trademark Registration Treaty, 1969-1973. He was a partner at the law firm of Hazeltine, Lake & Waters and later founded Offner & Kuhn, which represented leading brands like Canada Dry, CBS, and Mitsubishi on trademark law. In the late 1970's before its recognition by the US, Mr. Offner was a state guest of China to lecture on international trademark law. Mr. Offner was a soccer fanatic and was outside counsel to the US Soccer Federation in the 1970s and 80s. He helped sign Pele to wear Pony shoes upon Pele's arrival in the United States to play for the New York Cosmos in 1975. He was also counsel to celebrities including Liberace, Ernest Borgnine, and Dawn Steel. At the Sidney Bechet Society, Mr. Offner produced live jazz concerts for 17 seasons with leading musicians like Evan Christopher and Bob Wilber. Mr. Offner is survived by his son Gary Offner, his daughter-in-law Kathy Offner, and his two grandchildren, Grant (age 10), Kelly Rose (age three) and predeceased by his granddaughter Avery Grace. A memorial will be held on Sunday, June 8, 1:30pm at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset, NY, 11030. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Reach the Children, 14 Chesham Way, Fairport, NY 14450. Please note Eric Offner's name on any donation.

JARETZKI--Alfred III, MD. 94, of New York City and Essex, CT, died on May 29. Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery and Special Lecturer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Revered for his integrity both as clinician and mentor, Fred's long and distinguished career in the Department of Surgery began in 1944 and continued until his retirement in 1992. Early in his career he co-authored with Drs. Arthur Voorhees and Arthur Blakemore the seminal paper on the development of synthetic vascular grafts. This work initiated the modern era of aortic aneur- ysm surgery. After a decade at the Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY, Fred returned to Columbia, where he redefined the anatomy of the thymus gland and the importance of its complete removal in the surgical therapy for myasthenia gravis. This earned him an international reputation which continues to this day. His multiple publications on thymectomy lead to his appointment, at age 85, as co-investigator of the NIH funded Recommendations for Clinical Research undertaken by the Myasthenia Gravis Task Force. Fred's long and elegant life included being Captain of the Junior Varsity Football Team at Harvard and Treasurer of the Lampoon, skiing the Headwall at Tuckerman Ravine, winning the New York State Star Class Championship, being a founding member of the Cooperstown Planning Commission, President of the New York Thoracic Society, Practitioner of the Year, Medical Director of the Operating Rooms from 1992-1996, and co-authoring "A Proud Heritage: an Informal History of Surgery at Columbia," with Drs. Frederic P. Herter and Kenneth A. Forde. He is survived by his sister Josie Lipman, his children Alfred IV, Lasell Bartlett, Alexander and Sumner, his stepson Adam Isles and his wife Hannah and their children Nina and Peter, and his loving wife Alexandra. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 18 at 5pm at the Knickerbocker Club in New York. Contributions in Fred's memory can be made to the "Alfred Jaretzki III MD Endowment Fund" which supports the research of junior faculty in the area of thoracic surgery at Columbia University Medical Center. Department of Surgery Finance Office, Attn: Trisha J. Hargaden, 21 Audubon Avenue, Room 209, New York, NY 10032 (212-305-2735).

PONICHTERA--Jim. Stroock & Stroock & Lavan is deeply saddened to announce the passing of Jim Ponichtera, the firm's long-time Marketing Director, Communications. Ponichtera, 46, passed away on June 2. He received his J.D., cum laude, from Hastings College of Law of the University of California, where he was an editor of the Hastings Law Journal, and his B.A. from Yale University. Our thoughts go out to his wife, Gena Pogorzelski, son Harry, 11, and family. Visitation hours will be Sunday, June 8, from 1:30 to 4pm at Bradley-Braviak Funeral Home, 49 Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ, followed by a memorial service there. MARTIN--Marjorie C.,died peacefully at home on Friday, May 23rd, 2014 at the age of 90. She had a career as a singer and Broadway Casting Director which spanned more than 60 years. She is survived by her husband, Producer Elliot Martin, two children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Marble Collegiate Church Music Ministry 1 West 29th St., NY, NY 10001.

SEIDEN--Barbara Cohen. Surrounded by her loved ones, Barbara Cohen Seiden, the beloved matriarch of the Seiden Family, passed away at home at age 90 on Thursday, June, 6th. Daughter of Mildred and Herman Cohen, Barbara was born and raised in South Bend, IN. She graduated from Purdue University with a BS in mathematics. There she met and later married Norman Seiden, the love of her life, raising three children in Tenafly, NJ. Married for 68 years, they were life partners in family, business and philanthropic endeavors. Barbara's concern for the quality of life for people, both locally and nationally, is demonstrated through her support of such institutions as Englewood Hospital, The Kaplen JCC on the Palisades, The Jewish Home at Rockleigh, The Arnold P. Gold Foundation and the American Technion Society. She was a life member of NCJW, Hadassah and ORT. Together with her husband, her name is identified in Israel through the building of 13 kindergartens and day care centers, a community center and a tennis center. Thirty-eight years ago, when a life-threatening accident suddenly changed her life, she faced her challenges with great strength, courage and optimism. Barbara was a role model for her love and dedication to her family. We will miss her, her beautiful smile and special hugs. She is survived by her husband Norman, her son Stephen (Sharon), daughter Pearl, son Mark (Diane), 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. The family requests that donations be made to The Arnold P. Gold Foundation, 619 E. Palisades Ave., Englewood Cliffs, NJ 07632. The funeral will be held Sunday, June 8 at 10am at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ.

KATZ--Lewis. We deeply mourn the untimely passing of our cherished friend and partner. We love you dearly Lewis. Our hearts go out to Melissa, Stephen, Drew, Rachel and the entire Katz family. Love, Linda, Alan, Scott and Amy Landis and Dana and Eric Birnbaum

SEIDEN--Barbara. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are deeply saddened at the loss of Barbara Seiden of Tenafly, NJ. Together with her beloved husband Norman, a member of the ATS National Board of Directors and Deputy Chairman of the Technion International Board of Governors, Mrs. Seiden was a steadfast supporter of the Technion and Israel, and a Technion Guardian, a distinction reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. She was a Life Trustee, and past national Board Member, of the ATS Women's Division, of which she was a leading supporter. Among the significant Technion projects the couple funded are the Barbara and Norman Seiden Nanoelectronics Processing Laboratory, and the Barbara and Norman Seiden/New York Metropolitan Region Center for Advanced Opto-Electronics. They also established several academic chairs, including ones in the names of each of their children. We extend our deepest sympathy to Norman, children Stephen, Pearl and Mark, and the entire Seiden family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn. H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus
TOLLMAN--Annabel Sarah, 6 Jun. 13. Fairy Tale Princess. Daughter of Christine & Raymond Tollman. Sister to Melissa. Aunt to Sofia & Dahlia Gilani. Raymond Tollman

SEIDEN--Barbara. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of Barbara Seiden, a founding member and staunch supporter of the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. Barbara's life was characterized by her devotion to her family, her commitment to global Jewish causes, and her generous spirit. A loving wife and mother, Barbara received the first JCC Lifetime Achievement Award together with her beloved husband Norman in recognition of their unwavering commitment to the JCC. Her contributions to our community were monumental. Among the many gifts Barbara and Norman bestowed on the JCC were the Seiden Health & Wellness Center as well as endowments in support of the arts, culture, and senior and special needs programming. We were blessed to have Barbara as an integral part of our JCC family. Her legacy will continue to shape and guide our future endeavors. She was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Norman, her children Stephen, Pearl, and Mark, and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May her memory be for a blessing. Tina Guberman, President Avi A. Lewinson, CEO

SEIDEN--Barbara, The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Barbara Seiden, spouse of our devoted trustee, Norman, and mother of trustee, Mark. Barbara and Norman have cared deeply about humankind and about repairing the world. Barbara had a keen sense of justice and interest in people in all walks of life. Together, Barbara and Norman have championed excellence and compassion in health care, among many other humanitarian causes. Their innumerable contributions to the Gold Foundation to improve the health of people worldwide have made a difference. We extend our sympathies and love to our dear friend and trustee, Norman Seiden; his children, Stephen and Sharon; Mark and Diane; and Pearl, and to his 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO

SCHMIDT--Doral, passed away on the morning of June 5, 2014. Born in Rockaway Beach, Queens, she was the daughter of Louis and Minna Granirer. She is survived by her loving children, Paul and Heddy Schmidt, sister's Sarah Milstein and Martha Barotz and her brother Samuel Granirer. Doral went to Beaver College in Pennsylvania and worked as a highly respected medical secretary before becoming a homemaker. She was the most devoted mother and she and her daughter Heddy shared a very special loving bond. Doral was adored and respected for her strength and resilience by all who knew her, especially at Sarah Neuman Nursing home, where she lived a courageous life for 33 years up until the very end. She will be so very missed by all. A Chapel service is scheduled for Sunday, June 8, 2014 at 10:00am at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place in New Rochelle, NY. A private burial with family will be held at Maimonides Cemetery.

DICK--Marion Pokoik. In memory of my darling mother, thinking of you, as always, on your birthday. Always remembered, I cherish your zest for life and your beautiful smile. Your daughter, Gail

GOODMAN--Roy M. Senator The Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Senator Roy Goodman. Senator Goodman aided in initiating the hospital's Dr. Leon Root Pediatric Outreach Program which recently celebrated its 27th year and has conducted orthopedic screenings for 27,000 children in New York City. We are grateful for all the support Senator Goodman has given HSS and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Thomas P. JUSTUS Henry. The Associates of PVH CORP note with great sadness the passing of their former colleague. We will miss his warmth and wisdom, and send our condolences to his beloved Barbara Dundee, son David, daughter Alison and two grandchildren.

HESS--Wilda D.,a resident of White Plains, NY for more than 30 years, died Wednesday at King Street Nursing Home. She was 81. She was born August 18, 1932, to Lawrence Delmont and Margaret Layton Downey in Mona (Granville), WV. Mrs. Hess received a bachelor's degree in French and a Juris Doctor from West Virginia University. She worked in various positions as an attorney and administrator for the City and State of New York, most recently with the NYS Organized Crime Task Force. She retired in 1995. In 1953, she married James William Hess, who predeceased her in 1991. Surviving is her son, Eric (Debra) Hess, two granddaughters, Helen and Mariana, all of White Plains, NY, and a brother-in-law, Albert (Pauline) Hess of Shrewsbury, MA. Services are being handled by Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains.

JARETZKI--Dr. Alfred III. Dr. Craig R. Smith and the Columbia University Department of Surgery mourn the passing of Dr. Alfred Jaretzki lll, our esteemed colleague and mentor. Dr. Jaretzki started his surgical residency at Presbyterian Hospital in 1944. After an interruption for military service, he completed his chief residency in 1954 and followed up with training in chest surgery at both Presbyterian and Lenox Hill hospitals. As a leader in the field of surgical therapy for myasthenia gravis, he had numerous publications on thymectomy, led the Myasthenia Gravis Task Force that published Recommendations for Clinical Research, and was a co-investigator on an NIH grant (awarded at age 85). His early research with Drs. Blakemore and Voorhees helped to develop prosthetic arterial tube grafts. In his own words, Dr. Jaretzki stated, "My own goals were to have considerable patient contact and deal in some fashion with the health and physiology of the entire patient." Dr. Jaretzki's wisdom, mentorship, and surgical brilliance will be missed by all. Department of Surgery Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Craig R. Smith, MD Chairman and Surgeon-in-Chief

TRAINOR--John B.,Jr., of Pelham Manor passed away June 6, 2014 at age 73 years. John was born in Manhattan and went to high school at St. Helena's in the Bronx before graduating with a Bachelors Degree at Wheeling Jesuit College in West Virginia. He is predeceased by his wife, Anita. John and Anita met on a boat ride around Manhattan and then married in 1972. He was blessed with three wonderful daughters, Stacey and her husband Glenn, Sandra and her husband Paul, and AnneMarie and her husband Matthew. John was a loving grandfather to eight grandchildren, Charles, Colin, Christopher, Courtney, Paul, Peter, Jackson and Patrick. John retired as Executive Vice President of Helmsley Spear in 2006 where he reported directly to Leona and Harry Helmsley. Calling hours will be on Monday, June 9th at the Pelham Funeral Home from 12-2pm and 4-8pm. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham Manor, NY on Tuesday, June 10 at 12:45pm. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. www.pelhamfuneral.com.
SMALLMAN--Jeffrey M. 7/9/54 - 6/6/94 "And death shall have no dominion." -Dylan Thomas Never forget. Never surrender. Always remembered. Your loving brother, David B. Smallman, Esq.

STEWART--Ruth Ann. Ruth Ann Stewart, beloved wife of thirty years of historian David Levering Lewis, died of ovarian cancer on Friday morning, May 30. After three and half heroic years of struggle largely shielded from public awareness, Ruth chose to enter palliative/hospice care at our home rather than to undergo yet another chemotherapy cycle. She suffered minimal pain. She remained vitally engaged, responding to many written messages, receiving family, friends, professional colleagues, and sharing firm views about the state of our world and how to make it better, until her spirit waned in the last few days. A month earlier, three generations of Stewart family members shared her 72nd birthday. On Mother's Day, daughter Allegra and two generations of Lewises took her on a carriage ride through Central Park. She planned to attend both Wheaton College's commencement in Massachusetts, of which she was alumna and former trustee, and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's annual Sakura Matsuri festival, whose devoted trustee she was also. From modest origins in Chicago's Hyde Park, where parents Elmer and Ann Stewart nurtured discipline and ambition, Ruth Ann (as she was invariably called by everyone except her husband) traveled remarkable distances geographically and professionally on the wings of high adventure, intelligence, administrative genius, and a personality that stunned her husband forever. From Chicago to her bachelors degree at Wheaton College, to an M.S. from Columbia University's school of library science, to associate director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, to assistant director of publications of the New York Public Library during the transformative days of Vartan Gregorian, to Washington as Assistant Librarian of Congress for National Programs until Librarian Daniel Boorstin's retirement, after which she served as senior policy analyst in arts, humanities and social legislation at the Congressional Research Service. Recognized as a pioneer in the field of public arts policy, Rutgers University invited her to serve as clinical professor in its new Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. During a decade of service as clinical professor of Public Policy at NYU's Robert F. Wagner's School of Public Service, she co-edited Understanding the Creative Sector in the United States (Rutgers 2008), now a benchmark in the field. Her life of Booker T. Washington's daughter, Portia (Doubleday 1977), contributed meaningfully to feminist biography. Ruth served as board member of the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. She is survived by husband David, daughter Allegra Stewart, brother Donald and sister-in-law Isabel Stewart of Chicago, nephews Jay of Washington and Carter Stewart of Columbus, Ohio, stepsons Eric of Berwyn, PA, and Jason Lewis of San Diego, CA, stepdaughter Allison Lewis of Washington and granddaughters Marissa and Natalie Wilson, and Stewart great nieces and nephews Nicole, Corinne, Jonathan, and Ulyses. Paternal aunt Yolande Bustos resides in California. Donations may be made in her name to Wheaton College and Brooklyn Botanic Garden. A bronze memorial plaque identifies Ruth's scarlet oak in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The place and date of her memorial service will be announced soon.

SEIDEN--Barbara, The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Barbara Seiden, spouse of our devoted trustee, Norman, and mother of trustee, Mark. Barbara and Norman have cared deeply about humankind and about repairing the world. Barbara had a keen sense of justice and interest in people in all walks of life. Together, Barbara and Norman have championed excellence and compassion in health care, among many other humanitarian causes. Their innumerable contributions to the Gold Foundation to improve the health of people worldwide have made a difference. We extend our sympathies and love to our dear friend and trustee, Norman Seiden; his children, Stephen and Sharon; Mark and Diane; and Pearl, and to his 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO

NOVAK--Bernice, (nee Kletter). Died peacefully on June 3, 2014, at age 88. She is survived by her children, Mara, Jeremy, and Steven, and her beloved granddaughters, Miranda, Arielle, Jami, and Cordelia. Born and bred in New York, a graduate of Hunter College, an avid folk dancer, and long-time resident of the Upper West Side, she lived vigorously and independently until her last weeks.

LUSTGARTEN--Leonard S, MD. Physician and Author. New York City/ Westhampton, NY and North Palm Beach, FL. Len passed on June 2, 2014 of Parkinson's Disease related respiratory failure at his home in North Palm Beach. He was very happy until the end and died peacefully in his sleep. He is survived by his loving wife Lesley and his sons, Eric and Todd. At 19 years of age, Len was a very proud graduate of Harvard University's class of 1948. He went on to Albany Medical School. Len Lustgarten was a renowned Doctor of Internal Medicine in Manhattan for over 40 years with legions of adoring patients and friends. His one man internal medical practice was legendary. Len became Chief Resident of Lenox Hill Hospital in 1960. He went on to be widely recognized by his peers. His patients included many from the worlds of art, society, finance and, of course, some far more interesting characters. Len was named "Best Doctor" by New York Magazine during the 1990's in his area of specialty for consecutive years. He is credited for having started the practices and careers of many of todays top physicians in their respective fields. He was one of the first physicians to encounter AIDS and fought to educate the public as to its truths and fallacies. As the editor of The Medical Tribune and the Medical Director of several large pharmaceutical advertising agencies, he was at the forefront of a changing era. Dr. Lustgarten also taught Evolutionary Biology at Palm Beach Community College in Florida later in life. Len Lustgarten's Novel "EUNUCH" received overwhelming praise when it was released in 2008/ 2009 and was hailed as a groundbreaking fictional epic. It has since been recognized as an exceptional work of unique proportions, exploring previously uncharted territory. It is the author's message to the world and the embodiment of all that he believed and experienced in life. Most importantly, it is his gift to the future. It is his tribute to Darwin. As per Len's wishes, there will no funeral or services. However, there will be a party later this Summer so that we may all hoist a glass and laugh as we remember him and tell the stories. He would have felt right at home with all of you whom he loved. Our father embodied the Hippocratic Oath "First Do No Harm". That is his legacy. In lieu of flowers or gifts, charitable contributions may be made to the following Charities: The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. The Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer and The Democratic National Committee. Please go to "EUNUCH NOVEL" at Facebook.com. All information, condolences, comments and donation details may be found there.

RABINOWITZ--Ruth, nee Lapidus, born June 2, 1926, died June 3, 2014. Daughter of immigrants, graduated City College of New York 1948, teacher at public schools in the Bronx, wife of 66 years to Jacob, mother of David, Naomi and Jesse, grandmother of Emily, Jonah and Aaron, great-grandmother of Charlotte. Her legacy is in her students, her family and in the part she played in the great flow of Eastern European Jews who have enriched New York and America.

SEIDEN--Barbara. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of Barbara Seiden, a founding member and staunch supporter of the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. Barbara's life was characterized by her devotion to her family, her commitment to global Jewish causes, and her generous spirit. A loving wife and mother, Barbara received the first JCC Lifetime Achievement Award together with her beloved husband Norman in recognition of their unwavering commitment to the JCC. Her contributions to our community were monumental. Among the many gifts Barbara and Norman bestowed on the JCC were the Seiden Health & Wellness Center as well as endowments in support of the arts, culture, and senior and special needs programming. We were blessed to have Barbara as an integral part of our JCC family. Her legacy will continue to shape and guide our future endeavors. She was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Norman, her children Stephen, Pearl, and Mark, and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May her memory be for a blessing. Tina Guberman, President Avi A. Lewinson, CEO

Wlazlo, beloved father of our friend and partner, Mark B. Wlazlo. We express our deepest sympathies to Mark, Irem and to all other members of the family.

MARTIN--Marjorie C.,died peacefully at home on Friday, May 23rd, 2014 at the age of 90. She had a career as a singer and Broadway Casting Director which spanned more than 60 years. She is survived by her husband, Producer Elliot Martin, two children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Marble Collegiate Church Music Ministry 1 West 29th St., NY, NY 10001.

SEED--Dr. William Tripler. Of Vero Beach, FL and Beaver Creek, CO died June 3, 2014 in Vero Beach after a long illness. Born November 17, 1930 in New York City, Dr. Seed spent his formative years in Minneapolis, MN, where he attended The Blake School. He graduated from The Chaote School and from Williams College, where he was a member of the Lambda Chapter of St. Anthony Hall. While at Williams College, Dr. Seed enrolled in the United States Air Force ROTC program. Upon graduation, and as a commissioned officer, he was assigned to active duty at the Ernest Harmon Air Force Base in St. Anthony, Newfoundland, where he met Dr. Gordon Thomas, the Director of the Grenfell Mission. It was Dr. Thomas' influence that directed Dr. Seed towards his life-long dedication in the field of pediatric medicine. Dr. Seed entered Cornell Medical School in 1958, earning his medical degree in 1962. He completed his internship and residencies at The New York Hospital, where he served as Chief Resident of Pediatrics. Dr. Seed entered private practice in New York City, retiring in 2001. Dr. Seed also served as an associate attending pediatrician at The New York Hospital and a Clinical Associate Professor at The Cornell Medical College. New York Magazine recognized Dr. Seed as one of New York's top pediatricians. Dr. Seed was a man graced with a keen interest in life, as well as an abiding dedication to the well-being of others. He was affectionately known as "Doc." Dr. Seed is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Dorsey Smith; son William T. Seed, Jr., daughter Stephanie W. Seed and their mother, Barbara Buchanan Seed; stepchildren Nelson Smith, and Betsy Smith Starratt; grandchildren, Cameron, Elle and Kenley; brother Peter Seed, and sister Eva Auchincloss; cousins George Matthews, William Matthews and G.F. Robert Hanke; and by numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. He is preceded in death by his parents, Eva and Allen Seed, Jr; a brother Allen Hartley Seed III; and Aunt, Jean Flagler Matthews. A Memorial Service will be held 1pm on Saturday June 14, 2014, St. Augustine of Canterbury Episcopal Church in Vero Beach with Rev. Michael Goldberg officiating. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

SEIDEN--Barbara. Our hearts are broken with the passing of Barbara. May her extraordinarily devoted spouse, Norman, and children feel that their love made her many uncomfortable years as easy as possible. She will be missed by many. May she rest in peace. Elaine and Myron Adler
