SEIDEN--Barbara Cohen. Surrounded by her loved ones, Barbara Cohen Seiden, the beloved matriarch of the Seiden Family, passed away at home at age 90 on Thursday, June, 6th. Daughter of Mildred and Herman Cohen, Barbara was born and raised in South Bend, IN. She graduated from Purdue University with a BS in mathematics. There she met and later married Norman Seiden, the love of her life, raising three children in Tenafly, NJ. Married for 68 years, they were life partners in family, business and philanthropic endeavors. Barbara's concern for the quality of life for people, both locally and nationally, is demonstrated through her support of such institutions as Englewood Hospital, The Kaplen JCC on the Palisades, The Jewish Home at Rockleigh, The Arnold P. Gold Foundation and the American Technion Society. She was a life member of NCJW, Hadassah and ORT. Together with her husband, her name is identified in Israel through the building of 13 kindergartens and day care centers, a community center and a tennis center. Thirty-eight years ago, when a life-threatening accident suddenly changed her life, she faced her challenges with great strength, courage and optimism. Barbara was a role model for her love and dedication to her family. We will miss her, her beautiful smile and special hugs. She is survived by her husband Norman, her son Stephen (Sharon), daughter Pearl, son Mark (Diane), 11 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. The family requests that donations be made to The Arnold P. Gold Foundation, 619 E. Palisades Ave., Englewood Cliffs, NJ 07632. The funeral will be held Sunday, June 8 at 10am at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ.

MUDGE--Arthur Warren, age 84, died on Friday, May 23, at Kendal in Hanover. Born in Andover, MA, Arthur attended Choate school, (class of 1947) then Princeton University (class of 1951). While preparing for war service in Korea he met Mary Ann Cadwell, a Minnesota schoolteacher working for Senator Hubert Humphrey. They married upon his return in 1953. After graduating from Harvard Law School in 1956, Arthur practiced law in New Hampshire for ten years, including serving as a clerk for federal appellate judge Peter Woodbury, and as a partner with Sulloway and Hollis of Concord. Arthur joined the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) in 1966, overseeing economic development assistance programs in Panama, Peru, Bolivia, Guyana, Nicaragua and Sudan, serving as USAID mission director in the last three posts. In 1979 he was invited to serve as a fellow at the Harvard Center for International Affairs. In 1984 he resumed his law practice in Hanover, NH, and served as an international consultant in Africa, Latin America and the former Soviet Union. In his retirement, Arthur provided pro bono legal work and served on boards of educational and environmental organizations. In his spare time, Arthur hiked mountain ranges all over the world (Andes, Appalachians, Himalayas and Mount Kilimanjaro). He was also a dedicated bird watcher. Arthur is survived by his wife, Mary Cadwell Mudge of Kendal; his sister Nancy Mudge Sycamore and Hubert Sycamore of Hebron, NH; and his daughters and sons-in-law: Becca Mudge of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; Susanna Mudge and Raul Sanguinetti of Bethesda, MD; Sarah Mudge and Clarke Havener of Arnold, MD; and Katy Mudge and Arturo Valenzuela of Washington, DC. Arthur was adored by his five grandchildren: Noah, Mariah, Ari, Ethan and Adelina as well as his step-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews and will be greatly missed. Two memorial services will be held: The first in the Gathering Room at Kendal, 80 Lyme Road, Hanover, NH at 2pm on Saturday, June 21, 2014; A second service is scheduled for Monday, August 4, 2014, Alumni Hall, 75 Court St., Haverhill, NH at 11am. Memorial donations may be made to: New Hampshire Audubon, 84 Silk Farm Road, Concord, NH 03301; the Circle of Hope Scholarship Fund at Camp Onaway, P.O. Box 4064, Albany, NY 12204.

SEGAL--Martin, of Teaneck, NJ and Boca Raton, FL passed away at the age of 89 on May 30, 2014. Mr. Segal was the sole surviving son of Louis Segal, the prominent Farband leader. He is survived by his loving wife of 65 years, Paya, his son Gil of Ocean View, NJ (Susan) his daughters Jona of Douglassville, PA and Abbe Rice (Joseph) of St. Augustine, FL. Also survived by granddaughters Jessica Segal-Hassy (Mark) of Medford, MA and Alicia Walters (Joseph) of Beesleys Point, NJ and his great-granddaughter Aubrey Walters. Funeral Services are private.
NADIEN--David, was an outstanding violinist and a gracious gentleman. Our good friend for over 40 years. Our condolences to his wife, Margot Nadien. The Rausnitz Family

SPIEGEL--Gail Hoch, age 78, resident of Palm Beach, FL, Weston, CT and New York City, passed away on June 3, 2014 of complications of Alzheimer's and colon cancer. She leaves behind her husband of 48 years Robert, her son Richard, her aid Marjette Ebanks. She will be sorely missed by them as well as her many friends. She was a kind and lovely lady.

PINCUS--Joseph. The wonderful "Mr. P," died on May 21, 2014, at the age of 79, after a short but intense illness. He was the devoted husband of Debra Pincus and the dear friend of Hal Witt. He served as the librarian of the School of Architecture of the University of British Columbia for eight years, during which time he revamped the library and installed the Dewey Decimal System. He attended the Music & Arts High School in Manhattan and the University of Chicago. His only degree was a high school certificate, but he was a life-long student of everything that came his way, and in the course of things, came to develop a special interest in late medieval and Renaissance Venice. We always knew him in the established "Mr. P" attire jeans, a clean white shirt (grudgingly, in later years, patterned) and one of his favorite Paul Stuart sweaters. He leaves behind a host of friends who cherished him for his wit, his thoughtful intelligence, his impeccable taste, and his kind, honest presence.

SEIDEN--Barbara, The officers and members of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Home Family boards, our residents and our staff note with profound sorrow the passing of our long devoted supporter, very dear friend, and wife of our JHRC past president and board chair, Norman Seiden. Alongside her beloved devoted husband Norman, Barbara was a critical driving force in the development of the Jewish Homes. Together, their strong belief to involve others in our mission of providing for elders in our community resulted in the creation of our Homes. A woman loved by all, who exhibited a profound commitment to countless organizations and causes in the local, national and international Jewish communities; she will be missed by many. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Norman, her children Stephen, Pearl, and Mark, her grandchildren and great-grandchildren and her entire family. Barbara's legacy includes the many fine institutions that along with her lifelong partner Norman, conceived, founded, stewarded, and generously and tirelessly supported. May her memory be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairperson of the Board Charles P. Berkowitz, Executive Vice President

LEWIS--Lawrence "Larry", longtime talent agency administrative and financial corporate executive and consultant passed away on May 30th at the age of 89 years. Born in the Bronx, NY; during WWII he served in combat in Europe and received three battle stars, the Bronze Star, the Croix de Guerre with Palm awarded by General De Gaulle to 88th Infantry Division Members, in addition to other medals. His experiences are part of the Veterans History Project of the Library of Congress. After WWII, he attended Columbia University where he received a degree in economics and accounting. When he joined the William Morris Agency, Variety magazine stated "Lewis has been regarded as one of the top financial administrators in the ranks of talent agencies. He had been assistant controller of MCA prior to coming to General Artists Corp. which later became CMA. Lewis will become the only man who has been in high level administration posts at the three largest show biz agencies." Lewis worked with major talent, TV, film and music executives and managers, in addition to many famous stars over the years. He has been a supporter of Jewish and other charities, on his own, and through Foundations in which he was an officer. Beloved husband of Elinor (nee Posen). Loving father of Barbara Lewis Marco, Andy Lewis (Kari Sagin-Lewis), and Susan Lewis-Sadoun (Philippe). Devoted "grandpop" to Jesse Marco, Jackson Lewis and Gabriel and Julian Sadoun. Dear brother of Cookie Marks, and uncle to Patrice and Jeffrey. Adored uncle of Robin Silverman (David Goldberg), and grand-nephews Brian and Tyler.

MALKIN--Sidney, on June 6, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis for 58 years. Loving father of Lisa and Robert Spatt and grandfather of Mark Spatt. Brother of Francis Rothenstein and the late Sophia Lieberman. His life was devoted to his family and friends. Services Tuesday, 11am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the "Hospice at Home" program at Calvary Hospital.
Abramson--Stanley. April 9, 1936 - June 8, 2013. Dear brother, sorely missed, always loved, never to be forgotten. Norman and Carreen

THEOFAN--Charles, 61, a Nassau Deputy County Executive and former Long Beach city manager, died Thursday. He is survived by his wife Gale and son Henry. The funeral is June 9 at the Christopher Jordan Funeral Home, Island Park, NY.

TURKEL--Thelma Friedricks. Died Friday, May 30, 2014 at the age of 89, with her husband and her daughters by her side. She was the life force to her family and a cherished friend to all who knew her. An accomplished interior decorator for more than 40 years, she drew great pride and strength from having attended Ethical Culture and Fieldston. She leaves behind in grief her husband Mel, her daughters Ann and Jane Turkel, son-in-law Randy Paradise, and two grandchildren Deborah and Jonathan, as she goes to join her son Robert.

CACIOPPO--Annabella Jo, 14, passed away on June 3rd 2014. She was an 8th grade student at Marymount School of New York. She is survived by her parents Jennifer and James Cacioppo, and her three brothers, James Jr, J. George II and Richard Albert. A funeral service will be held today (Friday) June 6th at 4pm at St. James' Church on Madison Avenue at 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: "Annabella's Fund" In care of Hume Steyer, Seward Kissel, LLC, 1 Battery Park Plaza 21st floor New York, NY 10004 212-574-1310.

ABRAMS--Florence, of Riverhead, on June 7 at age 89. She retired from Town of Riverhead in 1970's as a secretary for the Board of Zoning Appeals and in the Supervisor's office. She then worked part-time and retired from Riverhead Free Library in late 1990's. She was very active with Temple Israel of Riverhead. Her late husband Irwin B Abrams was an English Teacher at Riverhead High School until 1975 and William Floyd School District when he retired 1982. She is survived by her son Harley (Riverhead and Roslyn Heights) and daughter Colorado State Senator Evie (Evanne) Hudak, Denver, CO. and one granddaughter. Funeral services Monday, June 9, 10am, Temple Israel, Riverhead, NY.

CARLIN--William Bayard (Bill), of Inverness, CA and Old Black Point, Niantic, CT passed away peacefully at home. Born November 7, 1927 in New York City, he attended, Buckley, Brooks School, University of CA at Berkeley, receiving an MA in musical composition from Princeton. He served as Director of Third Street Music School and Director of Development for The Nature Conservancy and later World Wildlife Fund. Survived by his wife, Betty Anne; daughter, Lisa (Thomas Quinn); son, Bayard; granddaughter, Jessica (Daniel Larkin) and great- grandson, Gavin Larkin. Memorial contributions to The Weir Farm Historic Site (www.nps.gov/wefa).

GOLDMAN--Irving C, passed away June 5, 2014, at age 91. Beloved husband of Muriel, devoted dad of Ellen (Brian), and Elissa (David z"l), adored grandpa of Jason (Jaclyn), Lauren, Samantha and Erika. Service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:00am on Sunday, June 8.

ALEXANDER--Larry, 91, of Bloomfield, CT, died on June 5th, 2014 after a long illness. Survived by his loving wife Ruth, his beloved children: Miriam Karacek of Houston, David Alexander of Chappaqua, Barbara Alexander of San Diego and Elizabeth Brown of Melrose Park, PA; his stepchildren Eric Fitch of Westborough, MA and Karen Voellmann of Acton, MA; his grandchildren Rachel Sonia, Jackie and Molly Alexander, Sarah Thomas and Jacob Brown, and step grandchildren Kimberly and Justin Voellmann and Ross Fitch. Born in Brooklyn, Larry survived the front lines at the Battle of the Bulge, graduated from Wesleyan University and Columbia School of Law. He raised his four children with his first wife Colleen Alexander of Philadelphia, where he was an executive in a family business before returning to the law as a Pennsylvania Assistant Attorney General, and later as an Appellate Court Administrative Attorney for the State of Connecticut after marrying Ruth. Larry will always be remembered by the many who loved him as a passionate sports fan who excelled in golf and tennis, an avid reader, theatre, concert and movie goer, and a lifelong advocate for social justice and peace. He was invariably kind to everyone who knew him, and we are grateful for the many tributes we have received from friends and relatives. We will always treasure the memories of his smile, his humor and his decency. The family will receive visitors at the home of Fran and David Alexander, 59 Cowdin La., Chappaqua, NY, on Sunday 4-8pm and Monday 5-9pm. A memorial service will be held July 19 at Wesleyan University. Contributions is his honor may be sent to the American Civil Liberties Union and Wesleyan University.

DOUGLAS--Alan, international music and film producer, died peacefully at home in Paris on June 7, 2014. He is known for his work with many legendary artists such as The Last Poets, Eric Dolphy, Duke Ellington and more, as well as for his posthumous productions for Jimi Hendrix, including most recently, Starting At Zero.

FORER--Bruce, 66. Writer and entrepreneur, died May 21, in New York City after a brief illness. Born in Jersey City, NJ, he attended Blair Academy and Rutgers College, and earned an M.A. in English from NYU. He taught at CUNY and Metropolitan State University of Denver, and reviewed films regularly for New York Newsday, Entertainment Weekly, and several Denver papers. While living in L.A., he wrote for various television shows, most notably Quincy. Later, he worked at IBM, where he helped develop content and design for Prodigy, one of the earliest online services. He co-edited two books (both with Robert Atwan), Why We Write and Bedside Hollywood: Great Scenes from Movie Memoirs. A principal in EF Capital and many other investment properties, Bruce helped administer Time Equities' non-Real Estate investments. He particularly loved the art of deal making. Whether driving a New York taxi, teaching tennis, or digging ditches for the highway department with his good friend Richard Andersen, he never lost his love of literature, especially Samuel Johnson and Robert Frost. He is survived by his cousins Dr. Harry Boltin and Alan S. Boltin, his close business partner, Glenn Erikson, Rhona Selkowitz, his two godchildren, Gregory and Emily Atwan, and numerous long-term friends and business associates like Francis Greenburger. A memorial gathering will be held in Manhattan on June 13; contact bruceforermemorial@ gmail.com for details.

DOUGLAS--Alan, international music and film producer, died peacefully at home in Paris on June 7, 2014. He is known for his work with many legendary artists such as The Last Poets, Eric Dolphy, Duke Ellington and more, as well as for his posthumous productions for Jimi Hendrix, including most recently, Starting At Zero.

JARETZKI--Alfred III, MD. 94, of New York City and Essex, CT, died on May 29. Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery and Special Lecturer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Revered for his integrity both as clinician and mentor, Fred's long and distinguished career in the Department of Surgery began in 1944 and continued until his retirement in 1992. Early in his career he co-authored with Drs. Arthur Voorhees and Arthur Blakemore the seminal paper on the development of synthetic vascular grafts. This work initiated the modern era of aortic aneur- ysm surgery. After a decade at the Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY, Fred returned to Columbia, where he redefined the anatomy of the thymus gland and the importance of its complete removal in the surgical therapy for myasthenia gravis. This earned him an international reputation which continues to this day. His multiple publications on thymectomy lead to his appointment, at age 85, as co-investigator of the NIH funded Recommendations for Clinical Research undertaken by the Myasthenia Gravis Task Force. Fred's long and elegant life included being Captain of the Junior Varsity Football Team at Harvard and Treasurer of the Lampoon, skiing the Headwall at Tuckerman Ravine, winning the New York State Star Class Championship, being a founding member of the Cooperstown Planning Commission, President of the New York Thoracic Society, Practitioner of the Year, Medical Director of the Operating Rooms from 1992-1996, and co-authoring "A Proud Heritage: an Informal History of Surgery at Columbia," with Drs. Frederic P. Herter and Kenneth A. Forde. He is survived by his sister Josie Lipman, his children Alfred IV, Lasell Bartlett, Alexander and Sumner, his stepson Adam Isles and his wife Hannah and their children Nina and Peter, and his loving wife Alexandra. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 18 at 5pm at the Knickerbocker Club in New York. Contributions in Fred's memory can be made to the "Alfred Jaretzki III MD Endowment Fund" which supports the research of junior faculty in the area of thoracic surgery at Columbia University Medical Center. Department of Surgery Finance Office, Attn: Trisha J. Hargaden, 21 Audubon Avenue, Room 209, New York, NY 10032 (212-305-2735).

FROST--David C. (1936-2014), who worked for Macmillan, Grosset & Dunlap, and Simon & Schuster, died May 29 in Friendship, ME. He spent nine months in San Clemente, CA copyediting RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon. He loved opera. He is survived by David Hovell and one brother.

KATZ--Lewis. We deeply mourn the untimely passing of our cherished friend and partner. We love you dearly Lewis. Our hearts go out to Melissa, Stephen, Drew, Rachel and the entire Katz family. Love, Linda, Alan, Scott and Amy Landis and Dana and Eric Birnbaum

GARDINER--Henry, May 27, 2014. Peacefully at home Hightstown, New Jersey. Hank was born in Schenectady, NY in 1916 to Henry (Happy) and Marion Gardiner. Predeceased by his brother John 1957. Princeton 1938, BA Art History. Married Winifred Wylie, daughter of Dr. Robert Wylie 1940. U.S. Air Force 1942 - 1945. Institute of Design, Chicago, BA Visual Design. Assistant to Herbert Bayer, Aspen Colorado 1949 - 1953. American Museum of National History, NYC, Exhibition Design 1954 - 1978. Father to two surviving sons, Henry and John and niece, Margaret. Leave memories at http://memorialwebsites.legacy.com/hankgardiner. In lieu of flowers, gifts to the Quogue Wildlife Refuge, Box 492, Quogue NY 11959.

KOLB--Erik Britton, died May 28, 2014 climbing Mt. Rainier. Born May 18, 1980. Loved by all, Erik spread his generous spirit and warmth to everyone. He resided in Brooklyn with adoring wife Lisa, and is also survived by loving parents David and Pamela Kolb, sister Kirsten, and family. Memorial to be held at 1:00 p.m., June 17, 2014 at Echo Lake Country Club, Westfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the Erik Britton Kolb Memorial Scholarship, Lafayette College, 307 Markle Hall, Easton, PA 18042.

GLASSER--Evelyn, died peacefully on May 31 at the age of 93. The adored mother of Farrell and Kerry, beloved mother-in-law of Carol, cherished grandmother of Lauren Weintraub (Brian) and Samantha and great-grandmother of Cayla. A woman of true beauty, grace and dignity, Evelyn enjoyed her life in New York City having graduated from NYU in 1942. She traveled the world and gave her time to philanthropic and fund raising activities. To know her is to love her.

HAMMOND--Marie Mahar. Died at 90, peacefully on May 25th in Westhampton Beach, NY with her husband holding her hand. Marie was born in Brooklyn, NY to attorney William Joseph Mahar and registered nurse Marie Byrne Mahar. Working as a registered nurse in New York while studying at The Art Student's League, Marie was discovered by a modeling agent. Marie went on to have an illustrious career as a fashion model with the Ford Modeling Agency and later as a photographer whose editorial work appeared in Glamour Magazine. In 1953 she married Bernard Clinton Hammond, an advertising executive in Our Ladies Chapel in Saint Patrick's Cathedral, New York. Marie continued working in photography and painting throughout her life. She was a devoted mother and grandmother. Much loved by her two children, Dore Hammond Normile, Bedford Corners, NY, and the late Bernard Clinton Hammond Jr., and her grandchildren, Daniel Francis, Francesca Marie and Nora Ann Normile, Brooklyn, NY. She was admired not only for her beauty and fun-loving spirit, but also for her unending kindness to those in need. Marie is survived by her husband B. Clinton Hammond, daughter Dore Hammond Normile, grandchildren Daniel Francis, Fran- cesca Marie, Nora Ann Normile, her sister Jean Mahar Walsh of Fort Pierce, FL and brother Robert Mahar of Millbrook, NY. Her brother William Mahar predeceased her. A memorial service will be held at The Immaculate Conception Church, Westhampton, New York on June 21st at 9am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Cradle Society, 2049 Ridge Ave., Evanston Il 60201.

KING--Daniel, beloved husband of Marilyn, loving father to Heidi, brother of Deborah and devoted uncle to many nieces and nephews. Dan did it all: skiing, sailing, martial arts, carpentry, master model-making and gourmet cooking. A gentle soul with a keen intellect. Dan enjoyed telling stories. He appreciated what life offers and was very happy with his own. Contributions may be made in his name to the Arthur D. Heller, MD Scholarship Foundation at Weill Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave, Box 314 NY, NY 10065 or CHEST Foundation (chestnet.org).

HALL--Raney D.,M.D The family of Raney Dewey Hall, M.D., mourns his passing on April 23, 2014 in Umpqua, OR. He was 55 years old. He was born in Mt. Vernon, WA and grew up in California, attending schools in the San Francisco Bay area, high school in Watsonville, CA, and receiving his Bachelor's degree from the University of Santa Cruz. He graduated from the University of Southern California (USC) Medical School in 1985. During his career as a physician, he received Board Certifications in Internal Medicine and Pediatrics. Dr. Hall served as an emergency room physician in hospitals throughout the west, including hospitals in California, New Mexico, Texas, Washington and Oregon, giving compassionate care to those in need. A colleague from emergency medicine commented "He was a wonderful man with a heart of gold." Raney was loved by his patients for he gave generously of his time, and both listened and provided skilled medical attention. Raney traveled widely, and loved languages and other cultures. He was fluent in both Spanish and Russian, having studied medicine in Mexico before returning to the United States to complete his medical education at USC. During his life he lived in Mexico, Turkey, and Russia, and traveled in Central and South America including Argentina, Chile, Columbia, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Panama, and Ecuador. Other journeys included India, Bahrain, Thailand, and the Philippines. Raney loved nature, animals, movies, and music. In high school and college he was an avid soccer player and long distance runner. Recently, he made his home in Umpqua, OR, where his favorite pastime was walking along the river with his Border Collie, Sasha. Raney was preceded in death by his father Dr. William Hall, and his stepmother, Cindy Richards, both of Palo Alto, CA. Raney is survived by his mother Dr. Clara Johns, sisters Diana Hall (Tim), Mt. View, CA, Dr. Linda Hall (Quentin), Walnut Creek, CA, and Dr. Marcia Hall (Donald), Umpqua, OR, brother Jeff Hall, JD of Santa Cruz, cousins Dr. Sandra Drake (Ray), Menlo Park, CA, and Karl Drake, (Carol), Palo Alto and Poughkeepsie, NY, nephews and nieces Nicholas Noble (Melia), of Umpqua, OR., Ian and Sara Hall of Santa Cruz, CA., Elise Hall, of New Zealand, and their mother, Wendy Molin, of Santa Cruz, CA. His intelligence, gentle nature, sensitivity, and quirky humor will be terribly missed by all who knew him. He was a gentle and truly kind human being. Memorial contributions can be made in his name to Doctors Without Borders or the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Memorial Services are pending. Please contact: marciah@jeffnet.org

KOPET--Sidney J. "Jack", M.D. 103, died peacefully on June 1, 2014 at this home in Manhattan, New York surrounded by loving family members. He is survived by his and his pre-deceased wife, Judy's children, Ronald Kopet (Elena), Robyn Kopet Lehman (Stanley) and Rebecca Randy Marder, his wife, Adelle Gaev Kopet, his grandchildren, David Marder, Jessica Kopet, Jennifer Lacey Wolski (Matthew), Emily Lehman and Andrew Lehman and Dr. Bennett N. Gaev (Lilly), Gloria Gaev, Leo Gaev and Samara Gaev. Jack was a family physician in Kew Gardens, NY and a talented violinist. He was a founder of Health Insurance Plan of New York (HIP). During World War II he served in North Africa and Italy as an Army Battle Surgeon and was awarded the Legion of Merit medal by General Eisenhower. All will miss him. Contributions in his memory can be made to Doctors Without Borders.

GOODMAN--Roy. Beloved Pal. Dalia and I mourn the passing of my best friend Roy Goodman. Our friendship spanned 79 years from our childhood in the playgrounds of Central Park and school days at the Hunter Model School until yesterday when your courageous battle against Parkinson's Disease finally ended. During most of these years, there were few days we did not converse. A lifetime of friendship for two men who perhaps became closer than the brothers we never had. Roy was my brother in life. Roy was strong, intelligent, elegant, of infinite integrity with an amazing sense of humor and gift of oratory--second to none on the New York political scene. After college and graduate school, we served together as land-based Naval officers here in the City. Marriage came soon, and we served as ushers, reciprocating in each other's wedding ceremonies, and after that, Roy became the godfather of my three children, and I of his wonderful children: Claire, Leslie, and Randy. Roy was a born leader. I do not think he ever passed a year at any school without being elected president of the class. A decade after graduating from Harvard College and Harvard Business School, he successfully continued his electoral career winning 17 consecutive races for the New York State Senate. His only defeat during that time was when he ran for the mayoralty of New York City in 1977. Roy was a magnificent human being--a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. He was compassionate and kind. Roy and I spent much of our lives together, including many trips around the world. Roy--I miss you so much and will think of you every day. You were my hero at age six and still are today. Dalia sends love. Larry
ASHER--Dr. John, 93; OBGYN, Practiced on Long Island. Survived by wife Evelyn, daughters Eileen and Robin and their families.

GOODMAN--Roy M. The United Nations Development Corporation's Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Senator Roy M. Goodman former President and CEO of UNDC (2002 to 2007). During his tenure, he was a tireless supporter and advocate of the United Nations as an important entity in New York City. The Corporation will cherish his dedication, achievements and valuable contributions and will fondly remember Roy for his passion, humor and his witty speeches. His legacy to us will be his commitment to public service and his leadership. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children and his grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. George Klein, Chairman; Jeffrey Feldman, President and CEO; Board of Directors and Staff United Nations Development Corporation

Horowitz--Steven Jay. Devoted husband, beloved father, dedicated friend. Your kindness and generosity knew no bounds. Your love is eternal. Service Monday, 11:30am at Temple Emanuel 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

GOODMAN--Roy M. Died at age 84, June 3, 2014. New York State Senator for 33 years "Statesman of the State Senate," former Chairman of the Senate Committee on Investigations, Taxation and Government Operations, former New York City Director of Finance, Chairman New York Republican County Committee, and President and CEO of the UNDC. Passionate advocate for the arts and education. Extraordinary human being and philanthropist, lifelong public servant who touched the lives of so many. Beloved husband of 50 years to Barbara, devoted father of Claire, Leslie, Randy and grandfather of Ricky, Danny, Nicole, Erika, Thomas and Kaitlyn; father-in-law of Rusty and Molly; brother-in-law of John and Lou Furrer. Your life inspires us to live each day to the fullest, make the world a better place, give more than you receive, and live by your motto: "Happiness is a way of travel, not a destination." Funeral services Monday, June 16, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. Condolence visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81st St. on Sunday, June 15th from 6pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to "Harvard Kennedy School/Roy M. Goodman Fund," 79 JFK St., Cambridge, MA 02138 or "City Parks Foundation/Roy M. Goodman Fund," 830 Fifth Ave, NYC 10065-7001.

HOROWITZ--Jay, 71, of Golden, CO, died from complications of cancer. He was a prominent attorney with a varied and unconventional career. Born in Philadelphia; a Rufus Choate Scholar at Dartmouth College, graduating Phi Beta Kappa, Magna Cum Laude from the University of Pennsylvania, and graduating from Harvard Law School in 1967, while taking courses in African Studies at Boston University. Clerk for the Honorable Thomas Masterson, US District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; Assistant US Attorney starting under Robert Morgenthau in the Southern District of New York; Assistant Special Prosecutor on the Watergate Special Prosecution Force starting under Archibald Cox, leading numerous investigations in the course of which he deposed Mr. Nixon and contributed to the conviction of several of Nixon's associates. A principal at several small firms in Denver, handling a vast range of federal and state legal matters, from corporate litigation to criminal defense to appellate practice, including extensive pro-bono work; a supporter of myriad non-profit and arts organizations; a teacher at the University of Denver Law School and at continuing legal education programs; chosen as one of the four lawyers other Colorado lawyers would retain to represent them personally. Proud of his Jewish heritage, yet tenacious in his representation of a client defamed as anti-semitic, successfully winning an unprecedented verdict sustained on appeal against the Anti-Defamation League. Husband of Elizabeth Hardin of Golden, CO, father of Alexandra Horowitz and Damon Horowitz, and grandfather of Ogden Horowitz Shea, of New York City. Jay was dynamic, creative, engaged, principled, and generous; a trusted friend and advisor to his many clients and associates; deeply loved and dearly missed by his family.

COREN--Rita, nee Marcus, born June 28, 1927, died June 3, 2014. Daughter of Isidor (Irving) and Tessie Marcus. Rita graduated from City College and had a long and distinguished career as a teacher, guidance counselor, and assistant principal in New York City Public Schools. Pre-deceased by her devoted husband, Mel, Rita is survived by her two daughters, Gale Keiter and Cindy Glick, their husbands, Dale Keiter and John Glick, grandchildren Jonathan and Laura Keiter, sister Sandy Gabe, brother Joel Marcus, and her large extended family and friends who dearly loved her. Donations in her memory may be made to the Taub Institute at Columbia University.

HESS--Wilda D.,a resident of White Plains, NY for more than 30 years, died Wednesday at King Street Nursing Home. She was 81. She was born August 18, 1932, to Lawrence Delmont and Margaret Layton Downey in Mona (Granville), WV. Mrs. Hess received a bachelor's degree in French and a Juris Doctor from West Virginia University. She worked in various positions as an attorney and administrator for the City and State of New York, most recently with the NYS Organized Crime Task Force. She retired in 1995. In 1953, she married James William Hess, who predeceased her in 1991. Surviving is her son, Eric (Debra) Hess, two granddaughters, Helen and Mariana, all of White Plains, NY, and a brother-in-law, Albert (Pauline) Hess of Shrewsbury, MA. Services are being handled by Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains.

CHESTER--Ruth Krach, 94, Raised in Ridgewood, Queens, and raised her family in Bayside. She and her late husband were later residents of Spring Lake, NJ. She is survived by her children - Paul of Manhattan, David of Winston-Salem, NC, Frances of Chatham, NJ and Elizabeth of Washington, DC. A memorial Mass will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Franciscan Bread for the Poor, Inc. 135 West 31st Street, New York, NY, 10001. www.stfrancisbreadline.org. Services were under the care of Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, Madison, NJ.

Coburn, an owner of California Chrome, said horses shouldn’t be allowed to skip the Kentucky Derby to stay fresh for the Belmont Stakes.

The captain of Brazil’s 2006 FIFA Club World Cup champions, Fernando Lúcio da Costa, better known as Fernandão, died early Saturday in a helicopter crash, his former team said.

SHUKAT--Peter Stephen, April 20, 1945-June 7, 2014 Beloved Husband, Father, Grandfather, Entertainment Lawyer. Passed peacefully after a brave, valiant, and purposefully private 10 year battle with prostate cancer. He fought his battle with strength, humility, courage, dignity, and conviction, always maintaining normalcy and hope in his life, being the unwavering family patriarch and consummate business person. He was a man who led his own path with honesty and conviction. He was a leader amongst his peers and most of all he was an extraordinary role model to his children and grandkids. He had a sensibility for knowing how to make things happen with great success and tenacity. He lived his life to the fullest. His legacy will live on in the lives he touched and he will be greatly missed by all.He is survived by his wife Yvette, his children: Justin/ Keri, Josh/ Lauren, Michael/ Susy, Jenn/ Ira and his nine adored grandkids - Julia, Emma, Ryan, Andrew, Skylar, Max, Regan, Samson, and Greyson. A celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, June 10, 11:00am, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, NY. I will miss Peter's strong presence and unfaltering love forever,we were partners in life. Yvette Glick Shukat

GOODMAN--Roy M. The President and Trustees of Teachers College mourn former State Senator Roy M. Goodman, husband of our late Trustee Emerita and former Board Chair, Barbara Goodman. During his 33 years in the New York State Senate and prior to that as a pivotal player in New York City politics, Mr. Goodman served as a peacemaker, bridge-builder and force for civility and decency who invariably looked past questions of party affiliation to serve all his constituents. The Goodman's were staunch champions of public education and access to higher education, and, at the College, early and visionary supporters of education technology. Senator Goodman's voice and spirit will be greatly missed. Susan Fuhrman, President John W. Hyland, William Rueckert, Co-Chairs of the Board of Trustees
SCHEIBE--Judith Rose. Uncommon, witty and kind. Friend forever. Sally & Ellen

KOLB--Erik Britton, died May 28, 2014 climbing Mt. Rainier. Born May 18, 1980. Loved by all, Erik spread his generous spirit and warmth to everyone. BERNSTEIN--Dr. Karl E. Surrounded by his wife and daughters, Dr. Karl E. Bernstein died on Saturday, June 7th after a brave and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer, six weeks short of his 80th birthday. Adored husband of Gail (Eiseman), beloved father of Amy Feldman (Steven), Jan Rosenblum (Michael) and cherished brother of Karen Goldstein and the late Maj. Ivan H. Bernstein. Loving and fun Pampa to Rachel and Brooke Rosenblum and Harris Feldman and a nephew, uncle, cousin and friend to many. Puccini lover, train enthusiast and educator extraordinaire, he worked his entire 32 year career at Meyer Levin Junior High School as both a legendary science teacher and revered assistant principal. As an Eagle Scout and Silver Beaver award recipient, Karl was devoted for more than 68 years to Brooklyn Boy scouting, Ten Mile River Scout Camps and his brothers of the Order of the Arrow. Loved by all who knew him, always ready with a smile, handshake and a joke. Contributions may be sent to The Ten Mile River Scout Camp c/o Greater NY Councils, Boy Scouts of America 350 5th Ave, NY, NY 10118 Memorial Service Tuesday June 10th at 1pm Boulevard-Riverside Chapel Hewlett, NY.

LEWIS--Geneva H.,of New York, NY, passed away on June 3, 2014 in Dacula, GA, where she was cared for by her devoted nephew and niece, Jeff and Sharon Waldon. She was preceded in death by her loving husband of 51 years, George W. Lewis, her parents Robert and Rosa Hewitt. Siblings: Herbert, Lawrence, Pauline, Robert Jr., Evelyn and Neportia. Mrs. Lewis was born in Jenkinjones, West Virginia. She graduated from Kimball High School and West Virginia State University where she was President of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority. She taught English and Music at Elkhorn High in Elkhorn, West Virginia for several years. Mrs. Lewis moved to New York City to continue her education and received a Master's Degree in Education from City College of The City University of New York. Other survivors include one brother, J. Samuel Hewitt of Raleigh, NC, a host of nieces and nephews and one very special friend Nona Smith. Memorial Service is scheduled for Friday, June 13, 2014 from 12:00 noon to 2:00pm in the Stateroom of Flanigan Funeral Home. To express condolences, please sign our online guest book at www.flaniganfuneralhome.com. Services by: Junior E. Flanigan of Flanigan Funeral Home and Crematory, Buford, GA, 770-932-1133.

ALEXANDER--Larry, 91, of Bloomfield, CT, died on June 5th, 2014 after a long illness. Survived by his loving wife Ruth, his beloved children: Miriam Karacek of Houston, David Alexander of Chappaqua, Barbara Alexander of San Diego and Elizabeth Brown of Melrose Park, PA; his stepchildren Eric Fitch of Westborough, MA and Karen Voellmann of Acton, MA; his grandchildren Rachel Sonia, Jackie and Molly Alexander, Sarah Thomas and Jacob Brown, and step grandchildren Kimberly and Justin Voellmann and Ross Fitch. Born in Brooklyn, Larry survived the front lines at the Battle of the Bulge, graduated from Wesleyan University and Columbia School of Law. He raised his four children with his first wife Colleen Alexander of Philadelphia, where he was an executive in a family business before returning to the law as a Pennsylvania Assistant Attorney General, and later as an Appellate Court Administrative Attorney for the State of Connecticut after marrying Ruth. Larry will always be remembered by the many who loved him as a passionate sports fan who excelled in golf and tennis, an avid reader, theatre, concert and movie goer, and a lifelong advocate for social justice and peace. He was invariably kind to everyone who knew him, and we are grateful for the many tributes we have received from friends and relatives. We will always treasure the memories of his smile, his humor and his decency. The family will receive visitors at the home of Fran and David Alexander, 59 Cowdin La., Chappaqua, NY, on Sunday 4-8pm and Monday 5-9pm. A memorial service will be held July 19 at Wesleyan University. Contributions is his honor may be sent to the American Civil Liberties Union and Wesleyan University.

ABRAMS--Florence, of Riverhead, on June 7 at age 89. She retired from Town of Riverhead in 1970's as a secretary for the Board of Zoning Appeals and in the Supervisor's office. She then worked part-time and retired from Riverhead Free Library in late 1990's. She was very active with Temple Israel of Riverhead. Her late husband Irwin B Abrams was an English Teacher at Riverhead High School until 1975 and William Floyd School District when he retired 1982. She is survived by her son Harley (Riverhead and Roslyn Heights) and daughter Colorado State Senator Evie (Evanne) Hudak, Denver, CO. and one granddaughter. Funeral services Monday, June 9, 10am, Temple Israel, Riverhead, NY.

SHUKAT--Peter Stephen. It is with profound sorrow that we record the passing of our founder, partner, mentor and dear friend, Peter Shukat. Peter was a one-of-a-kind individual and a once-in-a-lifetime friend. He was unfailingly generous with his wisdom, time, and warmth. Everyone who crossed his path was the better for having known him, having had a chance to learn from him, and having been able to call him a friend. We will miss his presence every day. The Partners and Staff of Shukat Arrow Hafer Weber & Herbsman, LLP

PANERO--Julius (1929-2014). He was known as "Julie" and was an architect, interior designer, teacher and author. He died on June 6, 2014. He was 85 years old. He was intelligent, creative and had a dry sarcastic wit. Mr. Panero was a professor of interior design at the Fashion Institute of Technology for 30 year. He was a revered teacher and mentor to many students. He was a principal in Panero Zelnik Associates, Architects/Interior Designers, where he worked with his life long friend Martin Zelnik for 45 years. Julius Cesare Panero was born on January 29, 1929 in NYC. His parents, Giacomo Mario Panero from Bard, Italy and mother Concetta DiNapoli, moved from Foggia, Italy to NYC in 1918. He was the youngest of five children. He attended Dewitt Clinton High School, Pratt Institute (Bachelor of Architecture) and Columbia University (MA Urban Planning). He served in the Army just before the Korean War. He married Renee Rubin on January 19, 1952 and had four sons. They divorced in 1984. He shared the rest of his life with his muse and partner Monica DiGeronimo until her death in 2011. He lived in Union City, NJ, and survived by his four sons: Hugh, Doug, Jamie and Rick Panero and eight grandchildren: Julian, Isabella, Sofia, Liam, Tessa, Cara, Mia and Anabel Panero. A family visitation will be held at Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home located at 415 Morris Ave., Springfield, NJ, Thursday, June 12, 2014 from 6:30pm-9:00pm with brief family comments at 7:30pm. In lieu of flowers the family asks that a donation be made to the FIT Foundation (note on the check: For Panero Zelnik Scholarship Fund). FIT Foundation, 7th Ave at 27th Street, Rm C204, NY, NY 10001-5992. Credit card gifts can be made at 212-217-4100.
SHUKAT--Peter. We mourn the loss of our beloved Peter. He fought a long hard battle with courage and dignity. Our heartfelt condolences to our dear Yvette and the entire family. Marilyn and Steve

STEWART--Ruth Ann. The Board of Trustees, Staff, and Auxiliary of Brooklyn Botanic Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and Trustee Ruth Ann Stewart. An inspired and passionate leader, Ruth Ann gave 15 years of dedicated Trustee service to the Garden. Her kindness; love of nature, the arts, and humanities; belief in the importance of cultural organizations as vibrant and necessary resources for the broader community; and unending commitment to the Garden will be truly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, David, and her entire family. Frederick Bland, Board Chairman Scot Medbury, President Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President

ZOOGMAN--Carla, (November 29, 1947-June 7, 2014), grew up on a farm in Divine Corners, NY. With her husband Nick of 44 years, Carla raised their children, Sarah and Peter, in Morningside Heights, NY, while she taught for almost four decades at the American Language Program of Columbia University. Sister of Gene and Amy; devotee of film and literature; admired by family, friends, colleagues, students; fond of bringing joy to those around her. PALISI--Joan A. (nee Policano), formerly Sister Mary Charles of the Sisters of Mercy, Brooklyn, NY. Joan passed away peacefully in the loving care of family and friends. Born into a working class family, she lived a story book life first as a teenaged novice, as a professed nun, as a social worker and a wife. As a Sister of Mercy, she taught in Brooklyn Catholic schools and then in the Canal Zone and later as a missionary sister in rural Panama. After years in Panama, she left the Sisters of Mercy and became a social worker in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn where she met her former professor at St. Francis College, Dr. Joseph Palisi, an academic and the Borough Historian of Brooklyn. They married in 1979. He died in 1993. During their marriage, Joan returned to teaching in Catholic schools from which she retired. She was also predeceased by her parents, Angelo (Charles) and Marie Policano, brother Patrick and sister Madelaine. Joan is survived by her brother Joseph Policano (wife Kathleen), cousin Joseph Galardi (wife Sherri), nieces, Pamela Cabibi, Adrienne Goodman (Alex), Cory Harper(John), Lisa Pearson (Matthew); nephews, Charles Pulcano (Debbie), Christopher Policano, Matthew Policano as well as adored grandnieces, nephews and cousins. Visiting Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday 9:45am at St. Andrew the Apostle Church.

JACOBS--Bertrand Russell, M.D.,died peacefully and surrounded by family at home in Manhattan on June 9, 2014, six days before his 87th birthday. Born in Philadelphia, he excelled at academics, had a distinguished career as a psychiatrist in private practice and assistant professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and was a passionate and accomplished amateur violinist. Married for almost 47 years to Veronica Leigh Jacobs, a violist and pianist. Their Upper East Side apartment, with its large library of works by obscure composers, became a center for chamber music players from around the world. He is survived by his wife, Veronica; his sister, Frances; his son, Adam; his daughter, Alexandra and three grandchildren.

GOLDSTEIN--Joseph, died peacefully at home on May, 29, 2014. Born April 25, 2016 to Benjamin and Pauline Goldstein, he was a graduate of City College and Brooklyn Law School. Mr. Goldstein practiced law in New York City until he was 92. A fixture on the handball courts of the Westside YMCA he was a national handball champion known for his "take no prisoners" style. Mr. Goldstein cherished his family. He is survived by his children Ann Gifford (John), Daniel Goldstein, David Goldstein (Faye DiLeo), nine grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and many loving nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his devoted wife of 70 years Bernice, his daughter-in-law Lisa Goldstein and his brother Harry Goldstein. Mr. Goldstein loved life and lived it well for 98 years.

FORTUNOFF--Murray, died Friday, June 6, 2014 at age 83. He was the devoted husband of almost sixty beautiful years to Lenore (deceased), beloved father of Sara, David and Naomi and loving poppy to Joshua, Rachel and Rebekah. He was a combat veteran and served in the US Army during the Korean War; receiving the Korean Service Medal and the Combat Infantry Badge. Murray and his wife Lenore were the retired owners of Fortunoff's, a houseware and giftware concern in the Bronx.

FEUERSTEIN--Madelyn Berman, died on Saturday, June 7, surrounded by her family. She went out in typical Maddy style, with grace, toughness, and passion to the end. She leaves behind her beloved partner, Solomon Demel, and children Randy, Brandt, and Philip Feuerstein. Adored Bubbe to her grandchildren, Alex and Natasha, and second mom to daughters-in-law Stella Chow and Laura Goldstein. She was a devoted stepmother and mother-in-law to Todd and Irene, Eric and Felicia, and Harris Demel, and loving grandmother to Taylor and Jared Demel. From the Bronx to Boynton Beach, legions of friends mourn her passing. Funeral services at noon on Tuesday, June 10, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, NY. Full details at riversidegordondelraybeach.com.

LEDERER--Richard, 96, June 7th; Actors' Equity Association mourns the passing of Richard Lederer. A member since 1949, he served on National Council for 40 years and was a strong advocate on behalf of the membership. He will be missed.

LOWENFELD--Andreas. NYU School of Law mourns the loss of Andreas Lowenfeld, a faculty member since 1967. A prolific scholar, beloved teacher, and generous mentor, his work inspired generations of lawyers and had a profound influence on our institution, the courts, and the fields of public and private international law. He will be deeply missed. Trevor Morrison, Dean

SPIEGEL--Gail. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed member of more than 35 years, Gail Spiegel. SMITH--Donald C. The Partners of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, together with its employees, honor the life and legacy of former Partner Donald C. Smith and extend their deepest sympathy to his family. Admired for his expertise as both an architect and as a mentor, Smith's long and distinguished career at SOM began in 1961 and continued until his retirement in 1992. Throughout his more than three decades at the firm, Smith contributed to some of SOM's most complex and challenging projects in New York City, including the American Bible Society headquarters on Broadway, NYU's Merrill Hall, and the Vista Hotel. Smith completed numerous projects across North America as well, including Republic Plaza, Denver's tallest building, and BCE Place in Toronto. Though his work ranged in scale from master plans to single buildings, Smith remained unfailingly committed to fulfilling architecture's chief goal of inspiring and delighting its inhabitants. His talents and kindness continue to inspire our firm and will do so for many generations to come. Donations may be made in Donald Smith's honor to the Wounded Warrior Project.

AMIRAIAN--Kenneth, Ph.D, 87, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on June 9, surrounded by his beloved family. Born in New York City, he was the son of Kaspar and Mary Khanlian Amiraian. He entered Brooklyn College at the age of 15 where he excelled academically and on the track team. He received his Ph.D from Columbia University in 1959 in the field of Immunochemistry as a student of Dr. Michael Heidelgerger, the pre-eminent leader in that field. While at Columbia he received several honors including induction in to Sigma XI. Ken had a long and successful career as a Senior Research Scientist with the New York State Department of Health in Albany, NY. His research focused on the application of Immunochemistry to the public good and was referenced in Nobel Prize winning work. He was involved in many community and charitable organizations but was quick to say that of all his accomplishments the one he was most proud of was his wonderful family. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Adrienne, his son Richard and his partner Robert Pontarelli, and predeceased by his son Ronald. He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Ken lived his life with a deep and abiding sense of fairness and equality for all and will be missed by all that had the joy of knowing him. Memorial gifts in Ken's honor may be given to the Ronald Amiraian Memorial Scholarship Fund at Union College, 807 Union Street, Schenectady, NY, 12308.

WERMAN--David Sanford. Born January 1, 1922, New York, NY, died June 3, 2014, New York, NY after a courageous three-year fight with cancer. He is survived by his two children Marco Werman and his wife Schuyler Engel; Claudia Werman Connor and her husband Sam Connor; five grandchildren, Corinne, Caleb, Stella, Luca, and Gabriel; and one great-grandchild, Mathis; and his former wife and friend Marjolijn deJager. David graduated from Bayside High School in Queens, NY, and later earned a BA from Queens College in 1943, and an MD from l'Ecole de medicine at the l'Universite de Lausanne in Switzerland. He trained as an obstetrician and gynecologist, practicing in Manhattan at Beth Israel Hospital until 1964 when he began training in psychiatry. He moved to North Carolina in 1967, taking up a position in the department of psychiatry at University of North Carolina, while completing training at the Psychoanalytic Institute in Chapel Hill. He transferred to the Duke University medical school in 1975, where he taught and practiced psychoanalysis until his retirement in 1992. He was respected and admired by colleagues and students. "He was in huge demand as a psychotherapy supervisor throughout his career, because he was such a kind, thoughtful and often hilarious observer of the human condition," said one colleague. He was inducted as Fellow into the American College of Psychoanalysts. In retirement he moved back to his native New York where he made the most the city had to offer. David slowed down, but continued writing about painter James Ensor, and reading voraciously, from Proust to Alan Furst. He knew firsthand Furst's war, having served from 1943-45 in the 376th Flight Squadron's European Air Offensive. David was fluent in French, maintained close ties to his friends from medical school in Switzerland and France who adored him and loved calling him "Dave." He continued to learn late into life, teaching himself German and Italian. David loved music, from chamber ensembles to Billie Holiday. He played clarinet and flute, and was taking piano lessons up until his death. David asked that any gifts of remembrance be given to the American Civil Liberties Union, of which he was a member for many decades. https://www.aclu.org/secure/ make-gift-aclu-someones-memory?s--src=UNH000001 MEM&ms=web--left--nav A private service will be held at a later date.

GOLIEB--Abner J.,died June 10, 2014 at age 88. Predeceased by Nancy, his beloved wife of 62 years. Survived by daughter Margaret (Jay) Axelrod, son John (Marianne), grandchildren Danielle Axelrod (Jamie Magid), Katie Golieb, Caroline Axelrod and Steven (Crystal) Golieb and great-grandchildren, James Alexander Magid and Leitha Nanette Golieb. An extraordinary son, husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend. Services June 12, 10:30am, Riverside, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be sent to the Golieb Fellows at NYU Law School, the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation or the charity of your choice.

FILLIN-YEH--Susan, beloved wife, mother, sweet sister, friend, art historian, curator, author, educator, mentor, radical feminist fashionista and New Yorker, died June 9th surrounded by friends and family. Susan received her PhD from CUNY, taught art history at Brown, Yale and Hunter and was the Director of the D.F. Cooley Memorial Art Gallery at Reed College. The recipient of Andrew Mellon, Smithsonian and Fulbright fellowships, Susan was the author of Dandies: Fashion and Finesse in Art and Culture (NYU Press) as well as numerous art catalogues and articles in publications such as Art in America. Her latest book explores the work of American artist, John Sloan. In her twenty year battle against breast cancer, Susan's grace and determination were an inspiration. Susan could turn a bowl of pasta into a feast; a piece of driftwood into sculpture; pair an H+M blouse with a vintage skirt and you'd swear she was wearing Dior. She was a fierce defender of women's rights and women artists and had a contagious sense of delight. She is survived by her family and countless friends who travel on more buoyant and confident for knowing her. We love you Susan, you are missed.

CONNERY--Walter Patrick, Palm Bay. Born on St. Patrick's Day, 1933 to Walter and Mae (nee Manning) Connery in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, Walter Patrick Connery passed away on June 8, 2014 in Melbourne, FL. A graduate of Fordham University with a BS in Education, he embarked on his 38 year career in law enforcement with the NYPD, later obtaining his Law degree from St. John's University and graduating from the FBI National Academy. He progressed to detective and retired as Deputy Inspector. His educational background bore fruit when as second in command of the Police Academy, he built a new curriculum and designed the Police Student Law Guide. A Bronx Precinct Command preceded his role as Department Prosecutor, where he directed all internal administrative trials for the entire NYPD. Retiring as the Director of Health Services Division in 1980, he joined the United States Department of Justice INS as Director of the Office of Professional Responsibility where he was in charge of all internal criminal and administrative investigations for the INS. In a five year period he additionally conducted over 100 hallmark criminal civil rights and corruption prosecutions. Honors include the US Attorney for Washington DC Award for Excellence in Law Enforcement and the INS Commissioner's Award. Walter was appointed Assistant Director for Investigation and placed in charge of the largest INS field office in New York City. After retiring from the Justice Department, he continued to work as a consultant regarding immigration law and police procedures. He is survived by his beloved wife and traveling companion Carol, children Lisa and Cliff (Maryanne) and his grandsons Michael, Ryan and Colin. Walter was renowned for his integrity, kindness and humor. He will be sorely missed by many including his relatives-in-law Gail, Steve, Donald and Joan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 1425 Miller Street NE, Palm Bay, FL on Thursday, June 12, 2014 at 10:00am. Services by Ammen Family Cremation and Funeral Care, Palm Bay, FL 321-724-2224. Please share memories and sign guestbook at www.afcfcare.com.

LOWENFELD--Andreas. The family of Professor Andreas Lowenfeld announces with sadness that he died June 9, 2014 in New York, less than two months after the death of his beloved wife of 51 years, Elena. He was a dedicated, devoted and loving father and grandfather. Professor Lowenfeld was a towering figure in the fields of public international law, trade and economic law, private international law, and international arbitration. He served on the NYU Law faculty for 47 years, influencing generations of lawyers, and continued to teach International Litigation and Arbitration and International Monetary System among other courses until as recently as Spring 2013. Professor Lowenfeld wrote more than 18 books and authoritative legal treatises and over 115 law review articles and argued before the United States Supreme Court, the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal, and the International Court of Justice in the Hague. He made landmark contributions to legal scholarship and practice on issues as varied as extraterritorial jurisdiction, international arbitration, international monetary transactions, trans-border child abduction, international monetary law, investor-state dispute settlement, economic sanctions, enforcement of foreign judgments, aviation law, sovereign immunity, international trade, and civil procedure. His most recent work was a comprehensive treatise on International Economic Law. An avid supporter of the interaction between academics and practitioners, he was frequently an arbitrator in international disputes, public and private. He served as a Reporter on two major projects of the American Law Institute and was a lecturer twice at the Hague Academy, first in 1979 and later in 1994. In the 1994 lectures, he proposed criteria for a global community free of strict legal rules and based instead upon what he termed "reasonableness, not certainty." One of the hallmarks of his work was his commitment to eliminating what he viewed as an unnecessary divide between public and private international law. In 2007, he was awarded the Manley O. Hudson Medal of the American Society of International Law for his lifelong achievements in the field of international law. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1930 to a family of German-Jewish doctors, he came to the U.S. as a refugee from Nazism at the age of 8. After graduation with distinction from Horace Mann School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School in 1955, he served in the U.S. Army and then went on to practice law with Hyde and de Vries in New York. He then served for five-and-a-half years in the Legal Adviser's Office of the U.S. Department of State under presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. He provided strategic counsel to those presidents during the Cuban Missile Crisis; the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty; the so-called "Chicken War," in which the U.S. and the European Common Market sparred over poultry tariffs; and the U.S. invasion of the Dominican Republic. He then served as a fellow for a year at the John F. Kennedy Institute of Politics at Harvard University before joining the NYU Law faculty in 1967. At NYU Law School, he was a beloved teacher and mentor, for which he was honored when the NYU Journal of International Law and Politics paid tribute to his extensive scholarship and profound influence on legal education, the U.S. courts, international and comparative law, and the world of private commercial transactions, at the 14th Annual Herbert and Rose Rubin International Law Symposium in April 2009. In addition to all his professional triumphs, Andy Lowenfeld was a great "Renaissance man;" he spoke multiple languages, traveled extensively, and had life-long interest in history, theater, and music. He is survived by his son Julian, his daughter Marianna and his grandchildren Mark, Diana, and Anna. Funeral services will be held on Friday, June 13th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYU School of Law for a scholarship in his name.

TREBOT--Monique. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of Monique Trebot. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family.

WHITE--Catherine (DeCarlo), of New York City, died June 8. Born in 1925 in Union City, NJ, she had a major advertising career at Compton, Benton and Bowles, and SSC&B, where she was Vice President of Talent. In 1981 she joined UNIFEM, a United Nations organization that supported women's rights on a global scale. She continued at UN in multiple leadership roles, including the International Assoc. of Women in Radio and TV, which she co-founded. She received the UN Distinguished Service Award for her work with UNA. Her husband, Larry died in 2007, and she is survived by her loving family; sister Rita Sardos, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, sons-in-law Stephen Barber and Alex Gansa, grandsons Michael and Steven Bishop and William Gansa, and her niece Rita Bookhop. Memorial services held at a later date. Donations in her name to NGO/ DPI Executive committee.

BRAMAN--Richard Gabriel,December 8, 1953, died June 9, 2014. He was the beloved husband of Margo Braman and brother to Sandra and Stuart Braman. Services 2pm Saturday June 14 at Greer's Mortuary in Sedona, AZ. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to a homeless shelter of your choice.

BRITT--Glenn Alan, 65, died peacefully at home in New York City on June 11, 2014 after a valiant fight with melanoma. A magna cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College class of 1971 and recipient of an MBA degree from its Amos Tuck School of Business in 1972, he had a distinguished career in the cable television industry and had retired as Chairman and CEO of Time Warner Cable on December 31, 2013. In addition to serving on the Board of Directors of Time Warner Cable he was a director of both Cardinal Health and Xerox Corporation. He was also on the board of the Manhattan Theatre Club and was a member of the Tuck Board of Overseers. He was a member of The Blindbrook Club, Eastwood Ho Golf Club of Chatham, MA and the Woodbury Country Club of Darien, CT as well as the University Club of New York. He loved gardening at his home in Westport, CT where he has been a trustee of Earthplace. At his home on the Big Island of Hawaii he enjoyed golf, walks by the beach and entertaining good friends. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 38 years, Barbara, and his stepfather, Robert Crupi of Chatham, MA. He was predeceased by his mother, Helen (Bell) Crupi and his father Walter E. Britt. He will be sorely missed by his many friends and colleagues. Family will receive friends Friday, 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Saturday 10am. Burial in Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT private. A memorial celebration of his life will take place in the coming weeks. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Dartmouth College Fund for Financial Aid, c/o Gift Recording, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, NH 03755.

FABIAN--George S, age 84, died peacefully and surrounded by family at home on Saturday, June 7, 2014. George was born in Budapest, Hungary and came to the United States in 1947. He obtained his BA from Columbia University and his MBA from the University of Chicago. He had a prolific career in market research and advertising and was very active and respected in industry groups. He was elected to the Market Research Hall of Fame in 2009. A beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend, it was his love of life and family that fueled George through his heroic 14 year battle with cancer. He was a music lover, passionate reader, tennis player, skier and traveler. Survived by his wife of 49 years Norma, son Andrew, daughter Jennifer, son-in-law Vincent, granddaughters Alexandra and Kathleen and dog Eloise. A memorial service and reception will be held on Friday, June 27th at 11am at the Beaumont Mansion, 601 N. Ithan Ave, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, Attn: The George and Norma Fabian Fund, 383 Main Avenue, 5th Floor, Norwalk, CT 06851, tel: 203-652-0224. www.themmrf.org/fabianfund. Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Cemetery. www.forever-care.com

FRUEHBECK de BURGOS--Rafael. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the loss of our friend Rafael Fruehbeck de Burgos, a genteel and gentle conductor beloved by the Orchestra. His passion, warmth, and originality led to exhilarating and colorful performances. The Philharmonic extends deepest condolences to his family.

GOLIEB--Abner J.,died June 10, 2014 at age 88. Predeceased by Nancy, his beloved wife of 62 years. Survived by daughter Margaret (Jay) Axelrod, son John (Marianne), grandchildren Danielle Axelrod (Jamie Magid), Katie Golieb, Caroline Axelrod and Steven (Crystal) Golieb and great-grandchildren, James Alexander Magid and Leitha Nanette Golieb. An extraordinary son, husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend. Services June 12, 10:30am, Riverside, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be sent to the Golieb Fellows at NYU Law School, the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation or the charity of your choice.

NOVAK--Adam, died on June 11, at age 89, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Nadia and of the late Bronka, cherished father of Linda and Karin, and father-in-law of Robert and Daniel, and adored "Papa" of Julia, Katie, Eric, Alex and Brian. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he survived the Holocaust and surmounted all obstacles to create a loving family and a highly successful international business career. He was beloved and esteemed by all who knew him for his extraordinary intellect, absolute integrity, immense strength of character and deep humanity. A true gentleman and Renaissance man, he spoke multiple languages and traveled extensively, and his gallantry, erudition and quick wit made him wonderful company. Most of all, he was the guiding light and guardian of his family, and will live on in our hearts always. Funeral Services will be held Friday, 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

LOWENFELD--Andreas. The family of Professor Andreas Lowenfeld announces with sadness that he died June 9, 2014 in New York, less than two months after the death of his beloved wife of 51 years, Elena. He was a dedicated, devoted and loving father and grandfather. Professor Lowenfeld was a towering figure in the fields of public international law, trade and economic law, private international law, and international arbitration. He served on the NYU Law faculty for 47 years, influencing generations of lawyers, and continued to teach International Litigation and Arbitration and International Monetary System among other courses until as recently as Spring 2013. Professor Lowenfeld wrote more than 18 books and authoritative legal treatises and over 115 law review articles and argued before the United States Supreme Court, the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal, and the International Court of Justice in the Hague. He made landmark contributions to legal scholarship and practice on issues as varied as extraterritorial jurisdiction, international arbitration, international monetary transactions, trans-border child abduction, international monetary law, investor-state dispute settlement, economic sanctions, enforcement of foreign judgments, aviation law, sovereign immunity, international trade, and civil procedure. His most recent work was a comprehensive treatise on International Economic Law. An avid supporter of the interaction between academics and practitioners, he was frequently an arbitrator in international disputes, public and private. He served as a Reporter on two major projects of the American Law Institute and was a lecturer twice at the Hague Academy, first in 1979 and later in 1994. In the 1994 lectures, he proposed criteria for a global community free of strict legal rules and based instead upon what he termed "reasonableness, not certainty." One of the hallmarks of his work was his commitment to eliminating what he viewed as an unnecessary divide between public and private international law. In 2007, he was awarded the Manley O. Hudson Medal of the American Society of International Law for his lifelong achievements in the field of international law. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1930 to a family of German-Jewish doctors, he came to the U.S. as a refugee from Nazism at the age of 8. After graduation with distinction from Horace Mann School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School in 1955, he served in the U.S. Army and then went on to practice law with Hyde and de Vries in New York. He then served for five-and-a-half years in the Legal Adviser's Office of the U.S. Department of State under presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. He provided strategic counsel to those presidents during the Cuban Missile Crisis; the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty; the so-called "Chicken War," in which the U.S. and the European Common Market sparred over poultry tariffs; and the U.S. invasion of the Dominican Republic. He then served as a fellow for a year at the John F. Kennedy Institute of Politics at Harvard University before joining the NYU Law faculty in 1967. At NYU Law School, he was a beloved teacher and mentor, for which he was honored when the NYU Journal of International Law and Politics paid tribute to his extensive scholarship and profound influence on legal education, the U.S. courts, international and comparative law, and the world of private commercial transactions, at the 14th Annual Herbert and Rose Rubin International Law Symposium in April 2009. In addition to all his professional triumphs, Andy Lowenfeld was a great "Renaissance man;" he spoke multiple languages, traveled extensively, and had life-long interest in history, theater, and music. He is survived by his son Julian, his daughter Marianna and his grandchildren Mark, Diana, and Anna. Funeral services will be held on Friday, June 13th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYU School of Law for a scholarship in his name.
