SIMS--Carol, loving sister of Benjamin, daughter of the late Dr. Charles and Zelda, niece of Eve Weiss, passed away following a three year battle with cancer. She kept her dignity and humor throughout this terrible ordeal. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Barnard College with a masters from Columbia. Funeral will be at 11:30am, Sunday, June 15 at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel in Paramus, NJ.

WATERMAN--Judith. Painter and feminist, died quietly Thursday, June 5, 2014 with her partner Irena Klepfisz at her side in the Brooklyn home they've shared since June 1979. Born on August 19, 1936 in Barrington, IL Judy came to NY in 1961 and studied with Theodoros Stamos at the Art Students League and with Linda Nochlin at Hunter College where she received her MA in art history. She had many interests, was especially drawn to architecture, wrote her MA thesis on South Carolina barns, and painted and photographed rocks, marble and water. A voracious reader, she followed closely Second Wave writers and political journalists covering the Bush presidency and the Iraq war. She was devoted to the writings of Jane Jacobs, Ada Louise Huxtable, Robert Caro and the legal columnist Linda Greenhouse. Passionately committed to her art, she painted during the day and worked paid jobs in the afternoons and evenings. For decades she scavenged dumpsters at night for wood for stretchers for her wall-sized paintings. She received a New York State CAPS grant and taught art, art history and women's studies at Russell Sage, Fairleigh Dickenson, Vermont College and elsewhere. She exhibited in the Selinas and Third Street Galleries, Aldrich Museum, 55 Mercer, among others, and her work is in the collections of Finch College Museum, Albert Johnson Museum (Cornell College), Russell Sage College and Staten Island College. Through NYC's CETA arts program, Judy painted public murals and led art classes for seniors, her favorite work. In the 1990's she became active in her UFT chapter and, through DC37 and the Consortium for Workers Education, taught ESL and GED night classes to restaurant and hospital workers who spoke little or no English and for whom she created original stories and sketches. Of her teaching, one supervisor once said: "Judy can teach anything." Due to illness, she stopped working in 2010. She is mourned by her sister Sue Cooper, brother Tod Waterman, sister-in-law Lise Shellenback, nieces Hayley and Cooper, and life-long friends Janet Yacht, Susan Goldberg, Cheryl Rhuman, Marty Dolin and Julia and Isaiah Zagar, and by her devoted and loving partner Irena Klepfisz.

WHITE--Catherine (DeCarlo), of New York City, died June 8. Born in 1925 in Union City, NJ, she had a major advertising career at Compton, Benton and Bowles, and SSC&B, where she was Vice President of Talent. In 1981 she joined UNIFEM, a United Nations organization that supported women's rights on a global scale. She continued at UN in multiple leadership roles, including the International Assoc. of Women in Radio and TV, which she co-founded. She received the UN Distinguished Service Award for her work with UNA. Her husband, Larry died in 2007, and she is survived by her loving family; sister Rita Sardos, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, sons-in-law Stephen Barber and Alex Gansa, grandsons Michael and Steven Bishop and William Gansa, and her niece Rita Bookhop. Memorial services held at a later date. Donations in her name to NGO/ DPI Executive committee.

WIENER--Geoffrey Richard, of Larchmont, NY, died Friday, June 6, 2014, surrounded by his children at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY from complications of pneumonia. He was 95. Geoffrey is survived by his four children: Margaret (Steven Goldstein), Geoffrey Jr. (Wendy Banner), Robert (Katherine Clark) and Alison (George Bryant); 10 grandchildren: Katherine, Elizabeth, Alexander, and Maura Goldstein, Arrol and Corinn Bryant, and Daniel Wiener, Stephen Gordon, Ellie Wiener, and Olivia Wiener. His wife of more than 58 years, Margaret, died in 2008. Geoffrey was born October 26, 1918 in New York City, the son of Ernest Wiener and Claire S. Wiener. From a young age and throughout his life, he loved sailing. Geoff was a World War II veteran, serving as an Army officer in the South Pacific. His desire to help those less fortunate led to a career as a social worker, with Masters and Doctoral degrees from Columbia University School of Social Work, and made him a fierce civil rights and anti-poverty crusader. He served as executive director of Hamilton Madison House in lower Manhattan where he spent 16 years leading the settlement house and contributed more than 50 years of service, including as a Board member. He also taught at Hunter College School of Social Work and at the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, and served for 10 years as executive director of Abbott House, a child welfare, foster care and adoption organization. In retirement he volunteered with the International Executive Service Corps, with the Larchmont/Mamaroneck Local Summit, and strongly supported the Mamaroneck Hispanic Resource Center. He loved learning, traveling and his family, including the family dogs. Geoffrey was fond of the "Winnie the Pooh" books and had a well-known sweet tooth (especially for ice cream). His bear hugs, even at age 95, were strong - he put all his love into every embrace. In recent years, he loved to walk in Manor Park and weekly visited the Larchmont Senior Center, where he became a prolific painter. His Coolidge Street home has become a veritable art gallery. His family would like to thank his live-in aides Cutie Fraser and Auda Moncion, Karen Schwartz and her staff, and Dr. Steven Meixler and the nurses and staff at White Plains Hospital. He was well-loved and will be missed by all who knew him. Donations in his memory should be made to Hamilton Madison House, 253 South St., New York, NY 10002.
LEEDS--Morton. Our heroes continue to live within us, their lives lighting our way. June 13, 1984.
BRONSTEIN--Murray. Forever bonded, profoundly missed, always in my heart. Love, Anne
NEWMAN--Debra S. Dear Debra, Happy Birthday. I love you and miss you. Hugs, Aunt Sharon
WYMAN WINN--Edith. Always in our hearts and memories with love. June, Susie and Bernice

BRITT--Glenn. The Trustees and Staff of the New York Hall of Science extend their deepest sympathies to the family and colleagues of Glenn Britt, former Chairman and CEO of Time Warner Cable. Glenn was an incredible visionary and will be dearly missed by everyone who knew him.
ALLEN--Fay. A very special lady. Beautiful inside and out; you will remain in our hearts forever. Love, Renee Berger

BRITT--Glenn. Lynne Meadow, Artistic Director; Barry Grove, Executive Producer; David C. Hodgson, Chairman; Bethany Millard, President; and the entire Manhattan Theatre Club Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of our friend, colleague and fellow Board member, Glenn A. Britt. We will miss his generous heart, leadership and love of the theatre. We extend our heart-felt condolences to our friend Barbara, Glenn's wife.

BRITT--Glenn Alan, 65, died peacefully at home in New York City on June 11, 2014 after a valiant fight with melanoma. A magna cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College class of 1971 and recipient of an MBA degree from its Amos Tuck School of Business in 1972, he had a distinguished career in the cable television industry and had retired as Chairman and CEO of Time Warner Cable on December 31, 2013. In addition to serving on the Board of Directors of Time Warner Cable he was a director of both Cardinal Health and Xerox Corporation. He was also on the board of the Manhattan Theatre Club and was a member of the Tuck Board of Overseers. He was a member of The Blindbrook Club, Eastwood Ho Golf Club of Chatham, MA and the Woodbury Country Club of Darien, CT as well as the University Club of New York. He loved gardening at his home in Westport, CT where he has been a trustee of Earthplace. At his home on the Big Island of Hawaii he enjoyed golf, walks by the beach and entertaining good friends. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 38 years, Barbara, and his stepfather, Robert Crupi of Chatham, MA. He was predeceased by his mother, Helen (Bell) Crupi and his father Walter E. Britt. He will be sorely missed by his many friends and colleagues. Family will receive friends Friday, 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Saturday 10am, at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial in Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT private. A memorial celebration of his life will take place in the coming weeks. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Dartmouth College Fund for Financial Aid, c/o Gift Recording, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, NH 03755.

MURPHY--Dr. Robert, 80, passed away at home in NYC. Amazing father to Rachel (Jon), loving grandfather, adoring husband to Joan (deceased). A good person who enjoyed the simple life and was a friend to all. He is loved and will be missed.

HERMANN--Ronald B.,82, died peacefully in his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. He is survived by his wife, France Tessier Hermann; his sister, Carol Goodman (Robert), his daughters, Jennifer Hermann, Sarah Hermann Russell (Glenn), and Alexandria Hermann; his son, Jesse Hermann (Julie), grandchildren, Eric, Matthew, and Bennett Hermann, and Allyson and Alexis Russell; and stepsons, Jonathan and Matthieu McClintock. Ron was born in Brooklyn, NY to Lillian and Jacob Hermann on November 18, 1931. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1953 and attended graduate school at New York University after serving in the Army. He built General Automotive Specialty Company, a company founded by his father and uncles, into a multinational producer of switches and locks supplying car, boat, and industrial original equipment manufacturers and the aftermarkets. He was very active in industry associations and served on the board of, and as Chairman (1984-85) of the Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association. Ron was a strong supporter of the United Jewish Appeal and Jewish Federation. He was the recipient of the Torch of Liberty Award from the Anti-Defamation League in 1980. He served on the Board of Directors for Hackensack University Medical Center in Hackensack, NJ. Ron ran the New York City Marathon in 1981. He had a strong love for the ocean and sailed his boat, Gosling, across the Atlantic in 1989. He was an avid golfer, bridge player, and a life-long Giants fan. Services 11am Friday, June 13th at Temple Judea, 4311 Hood Road, Palm Beach Gardens, Fl. Donations may be made to the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County or the Mandel Jewish Community Center of the Palm Beaches. Services Entrusted to Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapels, Delray Beach, FL. 561-496-7550.

LANDIS--Susan Ellen, (nee Gilbert), July 15, 1933 - June 10, 2014. Daughter of Abbey Edwin Gilbert and Laura Feldstein Gilbert, widow of Mark L. Landis, mother of Laura Jane Landis, Steven A. Landis (Cindy) and Adam G. Landis (Debbie Miller), grandmother of eight, great- grandmother of two. Former school librarian and world traveler, having visited all seven continents and Arctic and Antarctic oceans. Service to be held at 11:00am on Friday, June 13, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York, 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl. SW, Washington, DC 20024.

LARKIN--Adrian Cravath, 94, died on June 8, 2014, following complications from a stroke. He was an arts patron and classical music expert and served as artistic advisor for the Musicians Emergency Fund, co-founded by his grandfather, New York attorney Paul Drennan Cravath, to help classical musicians during the Great Depression. He also oversaw scholarships in the performing arts for the Institute of International Education. He attended Harvard College and served in the Army during World War II. He is survived by nephew Peter Gibbs and his wife Margaret Martinez; niece Susan Gibbs, her husband Ted Piccone, and their children Antonia, Lewis, and Theodora Piccone; his dog Jobie; and many beloved and bereft caregivers and friends. He is preceded in death by his partner Roger Smith; parents Vera Cravath Gibbs and James Satterthwaite Larkin; stepfather William Francis Gibbs; and brothers Francis Cravath Gibbs and Christopher Longstreet Gibbs. In lieu of flowers, tributes may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild or Musicians Emergency Fund. A celebration of his life will take place on June 28.

LANCHNER--Nancy Nelson. East Hampton Tennis Club mourns the passing of Nancy Nelson Lanchner. Nancy had flare, intelligence, wit and a sense of adventure. We will always remember her smile. Condolences to her husband Randy.

SALZ--Theodore, 88, died peacefully at home in Yonkers on June 11, 2014. Predeceased by Rhoda, his beloved wife of 59 years. Devoted father of Richard and Miok Salz and Donald Salz. Adored grandfather of Julian, Margaux and Mathieu. Service Sunday at 12 noon at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

KLORES--Albert M.,88, of Rockville, MD, formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Boynton Beach, FL passed away on Monday, May 19, 2014. Al was a loving and devoted husband to Esther Klores for over 65 years. Along with his wife he is survived by his beloved sons Daniel (Abbe) of New York, NY, and Bruce (Irene) of Chevy Chase, MD. Al was the adored grandfather of Jake, Sam, Luke, Molly and Steven. He was a second father to his loving nephew Michael Schwartz. Al was a World War II combat veteran serving at age 19 in the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa, among others. His only brother Daniel died in the Battle of the Bulge. Al was the consummate old school salesman his entire career. He had a perpetual mischievous smile, a twinkle in his eye and a big heart. He was a lot of fun to be around even when he was sick the last years of his life. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to "The Rens," a 501C3 for inner city kids, RENS, 261 Fifth Avenue, 3rd floor, NYC, NY 10016.

HASLANGER--J. Fred. Leonard Boxer, Chair of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Association Serving the Aging (JASA), wishes to express, on behalf of JASA, its Board of Trustees, and its staff, our deep and sincere condolences to Kathryn Haslanger, CEO, and her family on the loss of her father, J. Fred Haslanger, age 102. Fred was greatly beloved by his wife of 76 years, Isabelle, his children Kathryn and Marty, his late daughters D. Suzanne Driever and Karen Vaneman, six grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. He will be deeply missed. May his memory be a blessing.

FEIGIN--James "Jim", died peacefully in his home in Manhattan on June 12, 2014, surrounded by his family and friends. He was 79 years old. Jim grew up in Brooklyn, New York. He earned his BA from Cornell University ('55) and his MBA from Harvard Business School ('60). He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Army and went on to have a very successful career as a senior executive in the cosmetics industry. Jim is survived by the love of his life, his wife of 52 years, Barbara, and his three sons who were his pride and joy, Michael, Peter, and Daniel. He also leaves his loving daughters- in-law, Stephanie and Natalia, and his six grandchildren who where his heart's delight: Erica, Alexandra, Elle, Thomas, Jackson, and Dylan. Jim possessed an indomitable spirit, a great sense of humor, and the most wonderful laugh in the world. He was adored by all whose lives he touched.

MIRKEN--Alan B. Syracuse University mourns the loss of its dedicated and esteemed friend. An unwavering ally of the University supporting students through scholarships and immersion programs in various fields, Alan made a difference in the lives of many and will be missed. Our heartfelt sympathies to his entire family. Chancellor Kent Syverud, Board of Trustees, staff and faculty at Syracuse University.

MIRKEN--Alan, June 12, 2014. Cherished and loving husband of Joan Weinstein Mirken and the late Barbara Mirken; devoted father of Leslie and Mitchell Rubin and Jane and Richard Zenker; adored grandfather of Matthew Rubin and Andrew and Scott Zenker; brother of the late Marilyn Cohen. A generous, caring, selfless and humble man who brought out the best in all of us. Service Sunday morning 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th St. Contributions can be made to Goddard Riverside Community Center or the Mirken Family Clinical Neuroscience Institute of the Mt. Sinai Health System.

BERK--Samantha. June 11, 2014, the sun became a little less bright and the sky lost a star with the sudden passing of my daughter, Samantha Berk. Samantha was a beautiful woman, inside and out. Her smile would light up any room. Her warm personality, kindness of heart and generosity drew people to her. Following in her father's footsteps, Samantha's intelligence and savvy made her a respected and successful businessperson. At 40 she was a perfect 10! Samantha was my best friend. I loved her to the moon and back. She will always be in my heart and I will miss her forever. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sloane Kettering Memorial Hospital Head and Neck Cancer Research. Services Monday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Burial to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Joan Berk
SCHINE--Jeffrey Meredith, on June 12, 2014. Loving son of Patricia and Richard Schine. Devoted brother of Dwight Gregory Schine. Graveside Services 11am, Sunday, Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY.

HALPER--Murray, died on June 13, at age 85, after a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen of 57 years; son Robert; daughter Suzanne; son-in-law Glenn Pargament; and six grandchildren. A loving and truly gentle man. Services to be held 10am on Sunday, June 15 at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

MIRKEN--Alan. Goddard Riverside Community Center is deeply saddened by the loss of Alan Mirken. Alan was a revered board member, colleague, friend and true champion of our cause. His enduring compassion, deep commitment and boundless generosity will never be forgotten. Alan cared deeply about others but had a particularly strong passion for supporting the aspirations of young people. Alan was a true visionary who was always unwilling to accept anything but the best from himself and from those he mentored. He shepherded the good will of the publishing community to create an unwavering partnership and major source of support for our work with the city's most vulnerable residents. Our thoughts are with the entire Mirken family and with all of those who were touched by Alan. He will be sorely missed. Betsy Newell, President Stephan Russo, Executive Director Goddard Riverside Community Center
DEE--Ruby. Condolences to Ossie and Ruby's posse. With love and respect from your friends at Cherry Lane Theatre.

LANDIS--Susan Ellen, (nee Gilbert), July 15, 1933 - June 10, 2014. Daughter of Abbey Edwin Gilbert and Laura Feldstein Gilbert, widow of Mark L. Landis, mother of Laura Jane Landis, Steven A. Landis (Cindy) and Adam G. Landis (Debbie Miller), grandmother of eight, great- grandmother of two. Former school librarian and world traveler, having visited all seven continents and Arctic and Antarctic oceans. Service to be held at 11:00am on Friday, June 13, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York, 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl. SW, Washington, DC 20024.

MIRKEN--Alan. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Alan B. Mirken, Trustee Emeritus of the Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees. For more than 20 years, Alan served our hospitals with enthusiasm and distinction, first as a member of the Board of the Beth Israel Medical Center and then Continuum Health Partners. A past chair of Beth Israel's Board of Overseers, Alan provided vital support by establishing the Alan and Barbara Mirken Department of Neurology in 1995. In recent months, Alan recognized the need to unite the Mount Sinai Health System neuroscience programs to encourage partnership and collaboration throughout the system. In April, Mount Sinai was proud to formally dedicate The Mirken Family Clinical Neuroscience Institute, bringing together some of the finest leaders in neuroscience. Alan will long be remembered for his vision and wise counsel. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Joan, his daughters Jane Zenker and Leslie Rubin, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., CEO and President; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

SNUGGLE THE BABY Written and illustrated by Sara Gillingham. 12 pp. Abrams Appleseed. $12.95. (Picture book; ages 1 to 4) 
 
“Babies love to play!” begins this silk-screen-style board book, which features simple movable parts. A cardboard-cutout infant can be removed for swaddling and comforting; a real cloth blanket can be tucked in; and a diaper folds over Baby, just for practice. Each little boy and girl pictured is big-eyed and sweet, and Gillingham includes a range of ethnicities. Alongside practical information about infant care, the best lesson of all is that though all babies are individual, each one is adorable.

WHITE--Catherine (DeCarlo), of New York City, died June 8. Born in 1925 in Union City, NJ, she had a major advertising career at Compton, Benton and Bowles, and SSC&B, where she was Vice President of Talent. In 1981 she joined UNIFEM, a United Nations organization that supported women's rights on a global scale. She continued at UN in multiple leadership roles, including the International Assoc. of Women in Radio and TV, which she co-founded. She received the UN Distinguished Service Award for her work with UNA. Her husband, Larry died in 2007, and she is survived by her loving family; sister Rita Sardos, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, sons-in-law Stephen Barber and Alex Gansa, grandsons Michael and Steven Bishop and William Gansa, and her niece Rita Bookhop. Memorial services held at a later date. Donations in her name to NGO/ DPI Executive committee.

RAU--Margaret I.,died Tuesday, June 10, 2014 at her home in Dixon, Illinois. She was born July 24, 1921 in Dixon. She was a registered nurse and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Nursing Corp during World War II. She married John Rau in New York City in 1952. He predeceased her in 1978. She lived in New York City for 36 years, returning to Dixon in 1981. While residing in New York she was an active member of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. Survivors include her children, Susan M. Rau and John C. Rau; her grandson, John W. Rau; her son-in- law, Robert Luckraft; and her daughter-in-law, Joanne Handler Rau. A memorial service will be held at a later date. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

WERMAN--David Sanford. Born January 1, 1922, New York, NY, died June 3, 2014, New York, NY after a courageous three-year fight with cancer. He is survived by his two children Marco Werman and his wife Schuyler Engel; Claudia Werman Connor and her husband Sam Connor; five grandchildren, Corinne, Caleb, Stella, Luca, and Gabriel; and one great-grandchild, Mathis; and his former wife and friend Marjolijn deJager. David graduated from Bayside High School in Queens, NY, and later earned a BA from Queens College in 1943, and an MD from l'Ecole de medicine at the l'Universite de Lausanne in Switzerland. He trained as an obstetrician and gynecologist, practicing in Manhattan at Beth Israel Hospital until 1964 when he began training in psychiatry. He moved to North Carolina in 1967, taking up a position in the department of psychiatry at University of North Carolina, while completing training at the Psychoanalytic Institute in Chapel Hill. He transferred to the Duke University medical school in 1975, where he taught and practiced psychoanalysis until his retirement in 1992. He was respected and admired by colleagues and students. "He was in huge demand as a psychotherapy supervisor throughout his career, because he was such a kind, thoughtful and often hilarious observer of the human condition," said one colleague. He was inducted as Fellow into the American College of Psychoanalysts. In retirement he moved back to his native New York where he made the most the city had to offer. David slowed down, but continued writing about painter James Ensor, and reading voraciously, from Proust to Alan Furst. He knew firsthand Furst's war, having served from 1943-45 in the 376th Flight Squadron's European Air Offensive. David was fluent in French, maintained close ties to his friends from medical school in Switzerland and France who adored him and loved calling him "Dave." He continued to learn late into life, teaching himself German and Italian. David loved music, from chamber ensembles to Billie Holiday. He played clarinet and flute, and was taking piano lessons up until his death. David asked that any gifts of remembrance be given to the American Civil Liberties Union, of which he was a member for many decades. https://www.aclu.org/secure/ make-gift-aclu-someones-memory?s--src=UNH000001 MEM&ms=web--left--nav A private service will be held at a later date.

RASIEL--Amram, of Marblehead, beloved husband of Rosa (Rosenbloom) Rasiel, died, aged 84, on June 13, 2014. Born in Tel Aviv, son of the late Zvi and Nescia (Horwitz) Rasiel, he came to the U.S. in 1954, after completing B.S. and M.S. degrees at The Technion Israel Institute of Technology. He earned a second M.S. and a PhD. at Yale in 1957 and was an assistant professor at Brown for two years. Subsequently, he became active in venture capital, mostly in technology here and in Israel. He had many interests, but above all, he was devoted to his family. Besides his wife, survivors include two sons, David (Deborah) and Ethan (Emma). He was the adoring grandfather of Lee, Annie, Jack, Jessica and Talia, loving brother-in-law of Yaffa Raziel and Naomi Rosenberg. He was the cherished uncle of Lisa Rosenberg, Michael Rosenberg, Asaf (Dahlia) Rasiel, and the late Nimrod (Helen) Raziel, and great-uncle of fourteen here and in Israel. He was the brother of the late Ovadia and Achia Raziel. The family wishes to thank all the kind and attentive staff at The Atrium in Danvers, and his skilled and loving PHC caregivers, especially Heather, Andres, and Scott. Services at the Stanetsky-Hymanson Memorial Chapel, 10 Vinnin St., Salem, on Monday at 1:30pm with burial following at Temple Sinai of Marblehead Cemetery, Danvers. Memorial observance at the family home following interment, and continuing on Tuesday and Wednesday, 4 to 8pm, evening minyan at 7:00pm. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be sent to Hadassah New England, 200 Reservoir Street, Suite 103, Needham MA 02494 for Alzheimer's Research at HMO or cushingcenters.com. Online condolences may be offered at: www.stanetsky hymansonsalem.com "He was a man worth knowing."

WATERMAN--Judith. Painter and feminist, died quietly Thursday, June 5, 2014 with her partner Irena Klepfisz at her side in the Brooklyn home they've shared since June 1979. Born on August 19, 1936 in Barrington, IL Judy came to NY in 1961 and studied with Theodoros Stamos at the Art Students League and with Linda Nochlin at Hunter College where she received her MA in art history. She had many interests, was especially drawn to architecture, wrote her MA thesis on South Carolina barns, and painted and photographed rocks, marble and water. A voracious reader, she followed closely Second Wave writers and political journalists covering the Bush presidency and the Iraq war. She was devoted to the writings of Jane Jacobs, Ada Louise Huxtable, Robert Caro and the legal columnist Linda Greenhouse. Passionately committed to her art, she painted during the day and worked paid jobs in the afternoons and evenings. For decades she scavenged dumpsters at night for wood for stretchers for her wall-sized paintings. She received a New York State CAPS grant and taught art, art history and women's studies at Russell Sage, Fairleigh Dickenson, Vermont College and elsewhere. She exhibited in the Selinas and Third Street Galleries, Aldrich Museum, 55 Mercer, among others, and her work is in the collections of Finch College Museum, Albert Johnson Museum (Cornell College), Russell Sage College and Staten Island College. Through NYC's CETA arts program, Judy painted public murals and led art classes for seniors, her favorite work. In the 1990's she became active in her UFT chapter and, through DC37 and the Consortium for Workers Education, taught ESL and GED night classes to restaurant and hospital workers who spoke little or no English and for whom she created original stories and sketches. Of her teaching, one supervisor once said: "Judy can teach anything." Due to illness, she stopped working in 2010. She is mourned by her sister Sue Cooper, brother Tod Waterman, sister-in-law Lise Shellenback, nieces Hayley and Cooper, and life-long friends Janet Yacht, Susan Goldberg, Cheryl Rhuman, Marty Dolin and Julia and Isaiah Zagar, and by her devoted and loving partner Irena Klepfisz.

PUTMAN--Reding Fenn, of Mendham, NJ passed away peacefully on Sunday, June 8, 2014. Born August 1, 1933 in Brookline, MA he was the only child of Reding and Margaretta Putman. Known to all as Fenn, he graduated from Northwestern University and served as a Captain in the US Marine Corp in the 1950's. Fenn was a leader Muncipal Bond industry, industry, with a career spanning 40 years and holding positions as Chairman of the Public Securities Association, Vice Chairman of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board and President of the Municipal Bond Club of New York. He was also deeply committed to his community as President of the Mendham Township Board of Education, a member of the Vestry, Pastoral Care and Outreach teams for the Church of St. John on the Mountain and as a Trustee of the Schiff Natural Lands Trust. His pride and joy was his over 40 years of dedication to the Frost Valley YMCA in upstate New York. He is the longest serving member of the Board as a Trustee, President of the Board of Trustees, and most recently as Chairman of the Board. Golf was a great passion. He was a long time member of Somerset Hills Country Club, a member of the US Seniors, New Jersey Seniors and Father & Son Golf Associations, as well as a volunteer for the Metropolitan Golf Association. He accepted the award for Family of the Year by the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association in 2009. Fenn's greatest passion however was his friends and his family. He is preceded in death by his wife "Sis". He is survived by his son James, his wife Susan and their daughters Grace and Claire of Bernardsville, NJ, daughter Missy and her children Caroline and Andrew Fink of Pelham, NY and son Jeffrey and his wife Jennifer and their children Audrey, Emily and Harrison of Westport, CT. A memorial service will be held at St. John on the Mountain, 379 Mt. Harmony Road, Bernardsville, NJ on June 19, 2014 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send any remembrances by donation to Frost Valley YMCA, 2000 Frost Valley Road, Claryville, NY 12725 or www.frostvalley.org

MIRKEN--Alan. Goddard Riverside Community Center is deeply saddened by the loss of Alan Mirken. Alan was a revered board member, colleague, friend and true champion of our cause. His enduring compassion, deep commitment and boundless generosity will never be forgotten. Alan cared deeply about others but had a particularly strong passion for supporting the aspirations of young people. Alan was a true visionary who was always unwilling to accept anything but the best from himself and from those he mentored. He shepherded the good will of the publishing community to create an unwavering partnership and major source of support for our work with the city's most vulnerable residents. Our thoughts are with the entire Mirken family and with all of those who were touched by Alan. He will be sorely missed. Betsy Newell, President Stephan Russo, Executive Director Goddard Riverside Community Center

ROCKEFELLER--Richard Gilder, M.D. The Rockefeller University community is profoundly saddened by the tragic death of our lifelong friend Richard Rockefeller. Our sense of loss is immense, both for the enormous void left in his adored family and for the world-changing work in which he was engaged that will be left incomplete by his passing. Richard was a member of our University community for more than 30 years and served on our Board of Trustees for two decades. A caring and compassionate family physician in his home state of Maine, he was a superb Trustee who believed passionately in the importance of basic and patient-based research, and in the ability of scientific advances to save human lives. Richard gave generously of his enormous talents to our Board's Hospital and Scientific Affairs Committees, and our Trustees, faculty members, students, and administrators benefited greatly from their interactions with him. A devoted humanitarian, Richard worked to alleviate human suffering and improve human welfare through his longtime service as chair of the U.S. advisory board of Doctors Without Borders and of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, where he carried on the work begun by his father and uncles. Richard was a pioneer in recognizing that the Internet could help doctors and patients share crucial data, with the ultimate goal of improving medical diagnoses and health care delivery--ideas that are routine today, but were prescient when he created the Health Commons Institute in 1994. Although he left our Board in 2006, Richard maintained an active interest in the work of the University. We will miss him very much. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nancy; his children, Clayton and Rebecca; his stepsons, Maxwell and Griffin; his three grandchildren; his siblings, David, Abby, Neva, Peggy, and Eileen; and his father, our cherished Honorary Chair and Life Trustee David Rockefeller, who has been a visionary leader and inspiration to all of us at The Rockefeller University for more than 70 years. Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse, President Emeritus Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief and David Rockefeller Professor

MURPHY--Dr. Robert, 80, passed away at home in NYC. Amazing father to Rachel (Jon), loving grandfather, adoring husband to Joan (deceased). A good person who enjoyed the simple life and was a friend to all. He is loved and will be missed.

SELTZER--Miriam (Elyn), 90, passed away in New York on June 3, 2014. She is survived by her loving family, her son Reuben and daughter-in-law Rama; her daughter Rebecca; her son David and daughter-in-law Debbie; eight grandchildren; and eleven great-grandchildren. Her late husband, Bernard Seltzer, passed away seven years ago. She was a true Eishet Chayil (Woman of Valor). Miriam Seltzer was born December 30, 1923, in Seattle, WA, daughter to the late Isadore and Goldie (Steinberg) Elyn. She was raised in Seattle, attended Seattle Talmud Torah, Garfield High School and the University of Washington in Seattle. She moved to New York, worked for the Mizrachi Organization and met her husband, the late Bernard Seltzer. They were married for more than fifty years and raised three children, making their home in Far Rockaway, NY. Miriam had strong ties and was a driving force in her community. She served for many years as President of the PTA of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island. She was President of the Sisterhood of the Congregation Kneseth Israel (the White Shul), where she was honored as Woman of Valor, and held integral roles in other Jewish organizations. Miriam Seltzer was understated and modest in matters of philanthropy and was a woman of great intelligence and vast memory until the end of her life. She was a prolific reader and was interested, well informed and conversant in a wide range of subjects. She was Zionistic and also knew the importance of being an American. She was well respected by all who knew her and will be sorely missed.

MIRKEN--Alan. The Harmonie Club notes with sorrow the passing of our honored member Mr. Alan Mirken. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family in this difficult time. Philip R. Cowen, President The Harmonie Club

SELTZERMiriam. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Miriam Seltzer, beloved wife of the late Bernard Seltzer. Her exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of her cherished family. We extend our condolences to Miriam's children, David (Debra) and Reuben (Rama); to her grandchildren; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

LEVY--Jack. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jack. He fought a courageous battle for so many years with dignity and had the admiration and love of all who knew him. Every aspect of our lives has been intertwined with Marcia and Jack for over 40 years and we feel a great loss. Our deepest sympathies to Marcia and their wonderful family. Rest in peace. You will be in our hearts forever. Joan and Marty
STRUMPF--Burton D.,died June 12, 2014. Beloved husband of Irma (Cohen). Adored father of Brian (Mindy) and Suzanne (Lance) Schreier. Dear brother of Sandra Milgrim. Cherished Papa of five.

LEVY--Jack. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our long-time member Jack Levy. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marcia and Family. Paul Kotcher, President

SCHWABER--Jerrold, PhD, an immunologist and cell biologist who independently conceived the concept and technique for monoclonal antibodies (hybridomas) died in his home in Haddonfield, New Jersey at the age of 67 on June 6, 2014. As a graduate student at the University of Chicago, he fused human lymphocytes to mouse myeloma tumor cells and proved that the resulting hybrid cells made both human and mouse immunoglobulins. This work, published in Nature in 1973, laid the groundwork for the development of monoclonal antibodies. In 1975, Kohler and Milstein followed up on his work which led to their receipt of the 1984 Nobel Prize in Medicine. Dr Schwaber continued his research into genetic causes of immunodeficiency. In 1992 he was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Jeffrey Modell Foundation. Cell lines from patients with primary immunodeficiency that he developed were donated to the Coriell Institute for Medical Research in Camden, New Jersey. He worked at Harvard Medical School, Hahnemann and Jefferson University. Born in Evanston, Illinois, he was the third of four sons. He is survived by his wife, Susan Hoch MD, his sons, Jason and Jeff, and four grandchildren. He loved to cook, work with wood, rebuild houses, scuba dive, bike, listen to classical music, opera and jazz and read. Contributions in his name should be made to the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB) or the American Society for Human Genetics (ASHG).

TODOROVICH--Miroslav M. died June 6, 2014 in Seattle, WA. Miro was born on April 7, 1925 in Belgrade, Yugoslavia. He graduated from the University of Belgrade in 1951 and received his Master's Degree in Theoretical Physics from Columbia University in 1959. Miro retired as Emeritus Professor in Physics from CUNY in 1990, but continued teaching part time until 2004. Miro joined Sydney Hook in founding the University Centers for Rational Alternatives (UCRA) in 1968. UCRA was formed in response to the rise in student radicalism in the 1960s and worked to help academia retain its intellectual integrity. Miro was its Executive Secretary from its founding until 1996. In 1976, Miro became the Executive Director of the newly formed Scientists and Engineers for Secure Energy (SE2). The organization, which included Edward Teller, Hans Bethe and other prominent scientists, acted indefatigably in support of peaceful uses of nuclear power. The work continues, today, under the Marshall Institute in Washington, DC. In 1951, Miro married Branka Opacic, who passed away in 2007. He is survived by his son, Mark (Amy) of San Diego and his daughter, Mira (Kirk Kanzelberger), and six grandchildren: Leo, Sophia, Petar, George, Thomas and Luke Kanzelberger, of Seattle. Share memories at www.becksfuneralhome.com.

McDONALD--James Douglas, died at home from pneumonia on Tuesday, June 10, 2014 in Venice, Florida at the age of 81. Jim was born in Chicago on August 2, 1932 to Mac and Glad McDonald graduated St. Ignatius High School. He graduated from Cornell University with a B.A. in Economics in 1954. At Cornell he was a member of the Crew, Quill & Dagger and Phi Psi fraternity. He served in the U.S. Army. He received his J.D. degree from Cornell Law School in 1958. Jim's first job was at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in Manhattan. He received a Master of Laws in International Antitrust from NYU. In 1967 Jim joined American Cyanamid Company where he was manager of Legal Department from 1978-1994. Jim was a volunteer lawyer for the USAID/VOCA in the Czech Republic and Uganda. He was appointed by President Bill Clinton to serve as a Director of the Board of The Woodrow Wilson Center at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington where from 1994 to 2003 he was Chairman of the Legal Committee. Jim and his wife, Kathleen, moved to Venice, Florida in 1997. He became a member of The Florida Bar and worked for eleven years as a full-time volunteer lawyer at Gulfcoast Legal Services in Sarasota. In 2010 he received the Steven M. Goldstein Award for Excellence in Legal Aid Impact granted by the Florida Bar Foundation. In 2011 he was a recipient of the 50 Year Continuous Legal Practice Award granted by The Florida Bar and the Florida Supreme Court. In 2013 he received the Florida Bar Association's Pro Bono Award for giving over 12,000 hours of legal service to Sarasota and Manatee Counties' poor and elderly. In July of 2013 he formed the law firm of McDonald & Boyle with his friend and colleague, Elizabeth M. Boyle and continued to work for their poor and elder clients until his death. Jim was admitted to practice before the United States Supreme Court, United States District Court for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York, Court of Claims of the United States, United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida and United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. Jim was brilliant, funny, generous, kind, compassionate, courteous and a real gentleman. And he loved to waltz! He was a member of the American Bar Association, The Florida Bar, the Sarasota County Bar Association, the American Civil Liberties Union, the Southern Poverty Law Center, the Selden Society, the N.A.A.C.P., Lawyer's Committee for Civil Rights Under Law and the Cornell Club of Sarasota. He is listed in Who's Who in American Law. Survivors include his wife of 27 years, Kathleen Glah McDonald, children Mark, Julia, Maria, Alexandra, Amara, Greg, Timothy, John, Annie, Brenda and Marco (deceased), his brother David and sister Jean Rousseau, eight grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A lifelong Roman Catholic and a man of strong faith, Jim was a member of Epiphany Cathedral Parish in Venice, Florida. A Mass of celebration will be held at Epiphany Cathedral, 350 Tampa Ave. W, Venice on Thursday, June 19 at 11am.
SCHINE--Jeffrey Meredith, on June 12, 2014. Loving son of Patricia and Richard Schine. Devoted brother of Dwight Gregory Schine. Graveside Services 11am, Sunday, Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY.

MAY--James Brendan, 84, died peacefully at home in Vero Beach, FL on June 10, 2014. Jim was a well-respected securities litigation Partner with Brown & Wood for 31 years until his retirement in 1989. He is survived by his children, Patricia, Peter, Timothy, and Susan, eight grandchildren, and his wife of 20 years, Nancy Marquardt Coble. His first wife, Ann Powers, predeceased him. A Korean War Veteran, Jim will be interred in a VA National Cemetery.

SCHREIBER--Jordan C.,of Palm Beach Florida, New York City and The World, was born September 1, 1929 in New York City. He was an exceptionally bright student who attended The Bronx High School of Science. From there Jordan attended Oklahoma University and graduated in 1950 with a BS in Accounting and Statistics, and would continue to be a life-long Sooner football fan. He was a Naval Officer on Far East-based ships from 1950-1954, and this experience ignited a passion for the sea where he spent his last years living aboard a ship with his beloved wife Anne called The World. After his Navy years, Jordan received his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1957, and then earned a PhD from New York University in 1968. In 1975 Jordan earned his CFA. Jordan had an incredible work ethic. His career was divided into two periods; the first was in Advertising where he worked as a product manager with healthcare and pharmaceutical companies, and that lead to his first position on Wall Street as an analyst covering the health care sector. From 1977-1983 Jordan was Vice President and Senior Healthcare Analyst at Citibank responsible for Asset Management and healthcare holdings. He also supervised consumer product analysis. In 1983 he joined Merrill Lynch Asset Management where he was the founder of the first Healthcare Mutual fund, which he ran until 2008 upon his retirement as Managing Director and Senior Portfolio Manager of the BlackRock/Merrill Lynch Healthcare Fund. Jordan was passionate about history, politics, the stock market, and science. The last four years of his life were amongst the happiest, living aboard The World and sharing his knowledge and passions with co-residents. He leaves his adoring wife Anne, a son (Eric), a daughter (Nancy), a sister (Marilyn) and three grandsons. A private memorial service will be held at the Harvard Club.

WIENER--Geoffrey Richard, of Larchmont, NY, died Friday, June 6, 2014, surrounded by his children at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY from complications of pneumonia. He was 95. Geoffrey is survived by his four children: Margaret (Steven Goldstein), Geoffrey Jr. (Wendy Banner), Robert (Katherine Clark) and Alison (George Bryant); 10 grandchildren: Katherine, Elizabeth, Alexander, and Maura Goldstein, Arrol and Corinn Bryant, and Daniel Wiener, Stephen Gordon, Ellie Wiener, and Olivia Wiener. His wife of more than 58 years, Margaret, died in 2008. Geoffrey was born October 26, 1918 in New York City, the son of Ernest Wiener and Claire S. Wiener. From a young age and throughout his life, he loved sailing. Geoff was a World War II veteran, serving as an Army officer in the South Pacific. His desire to help those less fortunate led to a career as a social worker, with Masters and Doctoral degrees from Columbia University School of Social Work, and made him a fierce civil rights and anti-poverty crusader. He served as executive director of Hamilton Madison House in lower Manhattan where he spent 16 years leading the settlement house and contributed more than 50 years of service, including as a Board member. He also taught at Hunter College School of Social Work and at the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, and served for 10 years as executive director of Abbott House, a child welfare, foster care and adoption organization. In retirement he volunteered with the International Executive Service Corps, with the Larchmont/Mamaroneck Local Summit, and strongly supported the Mamaroneck Hispanic Resource Center. He loved learning, traveling and his family, including the family dogs. Geoffrey was fond of the "Winnie the Pooh" books and had a well-known sweet tooth (especially for ice cream). His bear hugs, even at age 95, were strong - he put all his love into every embrace. In recent years, he loved to walk in Manor Park and weekly visited the Larchmont Senior Center, where he became a prolific painter. His Coolidge Street home has become a veritable art gallery. His family would like to thank his live-in aides Cutie Fraser and Auda Moncion, Karen Schwartz and her staff, and Dr. Steven Meixler and the nurses and staff at White Plains Hospital. He was well-loved and will be missed by all who knew him. Donations in his memory should be made to Hamilton Madison House, 253 South St., New York, NY 10002.

MIRKEN--Alan. The Board of Governors and staff of the Colby College Museum of Art mourn the passing of our dear friend and former Board Chairman, Alan B. Mirken. Alan deeply understood the transformative power of art and education, and he will be greatly missed. We send our condolences to Joan, Leslie, Jane and their families and wish for them to know that they will always be welcome at the place where Alan was so beloved.
LEVY--Jack. To my greatest Gin Rummy partner, may he rest in peace. Felix Mendelsohn

LEVY--Jack. Our dear friend. We will miss all the wonderful times we spent together. You brought joy to all of our lives and we have such fond memories of the close friendship you had with your buddy Herb. We will miss you dearly. Love always, The Gutenplan, Handel and Vogel Families.
HALLEY--Dr. Harry J. Died May 23, 2014, Williamsburg, VA. Obituary at www.buck troutfuneralhome.net.

LEVY--Jack. Dearest brother-in-law and friend for 66 years. The most courageous man I have ever known. Now that your struggle has finally ended there is room for a flood of precious memories. For good times as teenagers when we double dated with my Arthur and your beautiful Marcia, the memories of all those Levy family dinners and our happy occasions, weddings, births, all the sharing of young lives. The day you were diagnosed, Arthur and I were there to hear the words that would change your life forever. Watching your strength, courage and determination has been an inspiration to all of us. You were a special man and I love you. My love and condolences to Marcia, Larry, Gary, Janet, Donna, Bobby and all the kids. Barbara

GREEN--Helene, was born in Bayonne, NJ. She is the lone survivor of her mother Syma, father, Motek and sister Caroline. Family and friends mourn the loss of our beloved friend who left our world too early. All were fortunate enough to know her positive energy and contagious smile. Helene had a successful 23 year career as the Vice President of Operations at Simon & Schuster. A long time New Yorker, Helene lived life to the fullest, was a world traveler and lover of food, wine, fashion and life. She enjoyed athletics, the outdoors, and was very active in supporting Jewish charities. Helene was an avid animal advocate and a wonderful mother to OONA and Ruthie. All who knew Helene, whose hearts she indelibly touched, will miss her. Helene will live in our hearts and minds forever. In lieu of flowers, it was Helene's wish that donations be given to: Sloane Memorial, Ovarian Cancer: http://mskcc.convio.net/

GRIFFIN--Dominic B. "Bud" Jr. Madison, CT, died on June 12, 2014 at his home in Madison, CT at the age of 100. He was born in Brooklyn, NY to Dominic B. Griffin Sr. and Elizabeth Kelly Griffin and grew up in Brooklyn and Garden City, NY, where he lived for many years. As a boy on May 20, 1927 he was at Roosevelt Field to see Charles Lindbergh take off in the Spirit of St. Louis on his successful trans-Atlantic flight to Paris. After graduating from Dartmouth College in 1937 he worked for Cunard White Star Line traveling from New York to Europe and the Caribbean. He later commenced a long-term association with the Gulf Oil Corporation - interrupted by work at Grumman Aircraft during World War II - retiring as President of the Gulf subsidiary TA.D. Jones Company, New Haven in 1979. In 1940 he married Margaret L. Robinson of Boston, MA who predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife of 14 years, the former Jane Hutchinson Muckenbeck, a son Dominic B. Griffin III (Mary) of New York, NY and Honolulu, HI; a daughter Ann G. Selinger (John R.) of Washington, DC and Dunstable, MA; four grandchildren, Dominic B. Griffin IV (Tara Mrowka) of Brooklyn, NY; Tara A. Montague (M. Gavan) of Washington, DC; Amy R. Selinger (Mark B. Elefante) of Lexington, MA; John R. Selinger Jr. (Annika) of Dunstable, MA; and six greatgrandchildren. Long and active supporter of community service organizations, he was a member of the Kiwanis Club of Garden City. In 1983 he was among the organizers of the Deacon John Grave Foundation, incorporated to preserve the Deacon John Grave House in Madison CT. He was a member of the Garden City Golf Club, the Madison Country Club, the Madison Winter Club, the Madison Lawn Bowling Club and the Madison Beach Club. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Margaret Church in Madison, CT on June 18 at 10:00 AM. Interment will follow at Cemetery of the Holy Rood in Westbury, NY at 12 Noon on June 19. In lieu of flowers tributes may be made to Deacon John Grave Foundation 581 Boston Post Road, Madison, CT 06443 or Scranton Memorial Library 801 Boston Post Road, Madison, CT. Please visit www.swanfuneralhome madison.com for online condolences and tributes.

BERK--Samantha. June 11, 2014, the sun became a little less bright and the sky lost a star with the sudden passing of my daughter, Samantha Berk. Samantha was a beautiful woman, inside and out. Her smile would light up any room. Her warm personality, kindness of heart and generosity drew people to her. Following in her father's footsteps, Samantha's intelligence and savvy made her a respected and successful businessperson. At 40 she was a perfect 10! Samantha was my best friend. I loved her to the moon and back. She will always be in my heart and I will miss her forever. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital Head and Neck Cancer Research. Services Monday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Burial to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Joan Berk

GOLDSTEIN--Stanley, of Harrison, NY died at the age of 94 on June 13, 2014. He was the much beloved husband of the late Barbara Goldstein, the loving father of Jeff and Jill, grandfather of Jennifer, Lisa, Lauren and Justin, and great-grandfather of Micah and Nora. A self-made man, he was friend to many, legal scholar, entrepreneur and, to those who knew him best, their "wise old owl." A private graveside service will be held Wednesday, June 18. The family will receive friends that afternoon between 1 and 6pm at 20 James Road, Harrison, NY. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

APPLETON--William W.,son of William Henry Appleton and Emily Noel Johnston, died of cardiac arrest on June 7th, 2014 in Manhattan. Born on December 31, 1915 paternally related to a distinguished publishing family and maternally the great-grandson of the founder of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he was educated at St. Bernard's, St. Mark's and Harvard '38. In 1940 he received an MA, in English Literature from Columbia. Drafted as a private in World War II, he was assigned to the first Radar school in the Pacific and remained in Hawaii until his discharge as a Master Sergeant in 1945. Immediately engaged as an Instructor in the Columbia English Department, he remained there for thirty years teaching various courses in the drama. In 1975, he retired as a Professor Emeritus. During this period he wrote and edited a number of books dealing with the theatre. He was an extensive traveler and spent much of his time in England. He also served as a volunteer in the Berg Collection in the New York Public Library and the Theatre Research Library at Lincoln Center as a collaborating curator in a number of their exhibitions. He is survived by his sister, Tina A. Bishop and four nephews, Peter A. Hendricks, Erik Hendricks, Mark S. Newcombe, Lawrence A. Newcombe, two grandnephews and two grandnieces. Interment private in Greenwich, Connecticut.

DEE--Ruby. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of Ruby Dee, actress, civil rights advocate and fervent supporter of public education. Dee was a proud graduate of both Hunter College High School ('39) and Hunter College ('44). "Had there been no Hunter College," she once said, "I perhaps might have not attended college." As an alumna, Dee was a generous supporter of the school and a regular attendee at College events. In 1996, Hunter awarded her an honorary doctorate of fine arts. Dee leaves behind a life of artistic accomplishment and civic courage. To honor that legacy, Hunter will establish a fund in her name. For more information, contact: Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

GLUSMAN--Louise, A Clinical Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and private practitioner whose professional name was Louise J. Coleman, MD, died in Morristown, NJ on June 4th. She was 94. A stunning beauty and superb athlete, she supported herself in medical school by modeling Cole and Catalina swimsuits in the 1940s and working as a synchronized swimmer at MGM in several Esther Williams movies, including "This Time for Keeps." She graduated from the University of Southern California Medical School (one of two women in her class) and did her post-doctoral psychoanalytic training at the Menninger School of Psychiatry in Topeka, Kansas, where she met Dr. Murray Glusman, soon a Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at P&S. They married in 1949, and remained married and devoted to each other until his death in 2005. In a profession dominated by men, she was an inspiration to her colleagues and patients alike, the epitome of grace and endurance. She was beloved by her husband, Murray; her three children, Dr. Steven Glusman of El Paso, TX, Dr. Joan Glusman of Jamestown, RI, and John Glusman of Glen Ridge, NJ; and her six grandchildren, Karl, Elizabeth, Jeffrey, Jenny, Isabel, and Graham. Those who knew her from summers in Woods Hole, MA, will never forget the image of her swimming effortlessly, sometimes far off-shore, a white swimming cap on the horizon, who could part the waters at her will.

LANCHNER--Nancy Nelson, died at home on June 11, after a 2 1/2 year battle with cancer. She was a warm, generous and vibrant person loved by all. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, June 16, 3:30pm.
ALLEN--Fay. A very special lady. Beautiful inside and out; you will remain in our hearts forever. Love, Renee Berger

BOBRYK--Michal Lawrence, 67, of Granby, CT, died June 8, 2014. Born in Chester, England, lived in New York City prior to Connecticut. Received JD from Brooklyn Law School and his LLM from New York University School of Law. He served many years with Phoenix Home Life prior to his role as President of Mass Mutual Trust Company. Survived by wife Karen Doherty, his children, Sarah Leigon, Victoria Bobryk and husband Michael Fisher, and Thomas Bobryk and wife Katie Silbereis, his granddaughter Beatrix Bobryk Fish- er, and his iPod. www.vincentfuneralhome.com

FREIBERG--Robert, 85 years old, of Kismet, Fire Island, passed away after a four-year struggle with Parkinson's Disease. He graduated from Columbia Grammar School in Manhattan and in 1951 earned a B.A. in English from Hamilton College. He also attended the New York Institute of Finance, the University of Wisconsin and Columbia University School of Law. He had a varied and lively career, clerking for Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals; working as a stockbroker for Harris Upham & Co.; as editorial director for Standard Research Consultants and Supervisory Analyst for Drexel, Burnham, Lambert. He edited hundreds of articles and books for banking, law, real estate and corporate affairs publications. He also spent time as a cab driver and a photographer, two careers he thoroughly relished. He retired in 1990 and spent his remaining years at the beach where he was known by his license plate, Mr. Write. He is survived by his wife, Arlene Hirst, cousins, Joan Ostroff and Sylvia Hart, and his beloved cat, Chloe. A memorial service will be held on his birthday, August first, at 50 West Lighthouse in Kismet at 5pm.

HALPER--Murray, died on June 13, at age 85, after a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen of 57 years; son Robert; daughter Suzanne; son-in-law Glenn Pargament; and six grandchildren. A loving and truly gentle man. Services to be held 10am on Sunday, June 15 at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.
CUDILO--Jean (Piwowarski), of Harrison, NY, beloved wife of deceased Roman Cudilo, survived by children Michele, John, Jim, Joan, granddaughter Natalie Tudor and extended family.

BERNSTEIN--Dr. Karl E. Surrounded by his wife and daughters, Dr. Karl E. Bernstein died on Saturday, June 7th after a brave and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer, six weeks short of his 80th birthday. Adored husband of Gail (Eiseman), beloved father of Amy Feldman (Steven), Jan Rosenblum (Michael) and cherished brother of Karen Goldstein and the late Maj. Ivan H. Bernstein. Loving and fun Pampa to Rachel and Brooke Rosenblum and Harris Feldman and a nephew, uncle, cousin and friend to many. Puccini lover, train enthusiast and educator extraordinaire, he worked his entire 32 year career at Meyer Levin Junior High School as both a legendary science teacher and revered assistant principal. As an Eagle Scout and Silver Beaver award recipient, Karl was devoted for more than 68 years to Brooklyn Boy scouting, Ten Mile River Scout Camps and his brothers of the Order of the Arrow. Loved by all who knew him, always ready with a smile, handshake and a joke. Contributions may be sent to The Ten Mile River Scout Camp Museum, c/o Greater NY Councils, Boy Scouts of America 350 5th Ave, NY, NY 10118.

BERNSTEIN--Jeanne, the wife of Arnold Bernstein and daughter of Gilbert and Bernice Postley, passed away on June 10th, 2014 in Washington D.C. She was 94 years old. Prior to D.C. she lived on Manasota Key, Florida and in Scarsdale, NY. Surviving daughters and their husbands are Janael McQueen in Carmel, California, Linda Miller and Bruce Wolff in Washington D.C., and Carol and Michael Clark of Manasota Key, Florida. Jeanne is also survived by eight grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren. She attended Wellesley College and was married for 64 years to Arnold Bernstein, an attorney in NYC, who predeceased her in 2003. She was also predeceased by her sister Margaret Mendell. She volunteered at Blythedale Hospital for many years and was very involved in the Hoff Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale, NY. She had a lifelong love of literature and music, and was an avid golfer and sailor. She and Arnold spent many summers sailing up the northeast coast to Canada. They especially loved the coastal harbors and islands of Maine. She will be sorely missed by all her family who loved her very much.
DEE--Ruby. Condolences to Ossie and Ruby's posse. With love and respect from your friends at Cherry Lane Theatre.

KLORES--Albert M.,88, of Rockville, MD, formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Boynton Beach, FL passed away on Monday, May 19, 2014. Al was a loving and devoted husband to Esther Klores for over 65 years. Along with his wife he is survived by his beloved sons Daniel (Abbe) of New York, NY, and Bruce (Irene) of Chevy Chase, MD. Al was the adored grandfather of Jake, Sam, Luke, Molly and Steven. He was a second father to his loving nephew Michael Schwartz. Al was a World War II combat veteran serving at age 19 in the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa, among others. His only brother Daniel died in the Battle of the Bulge. Al was the consummate old school salesman his entire career. He had a perpetual mischievous smile, a twinkle in his eye and a big heart. He was a lot of fun to be around even when he was sick the last years of his life. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to "The Rens," a 501C3 for inner city kids, RENS, 261 Fifth Avenue, 3rd floor, NYC, NY 10016.

DONOHO--Patricia Laughlin, died Friday, June 6, in New York City. She is preceded in death by her parents, her husband, William Thompson Donoho, and her brother Thomas Richard Laughlin. She is survived by twin sons, Timothy and Gideon, his wife Jill, granddaughters Nora, Sylie, and Claire, her brother, William Joseph Laughlin and wife Fanelle, sister Ann Laughlin Connell and a host of nieces, nephews, family and friends, Pat was passionate about many things-food, art, politics-but most of all people. Her warmth, kindness and unfailing loyalty were a rock to many of us, from her beloved cats to family and many friends. She will be remembered at 4pm July 8 at St. Michael's Church on 99th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LANDIS--Susan Ellen, (nee Gilbert), July 15, 1933 - June 10, 2014. Daughter of Abbey Edwin Gilbert and Laura Feldstein Gilbert, widow of Mark L. Landis, mother of Laura Jane Landis, Steven A. Landis (Cindy) and Adam G. Landis (Debbie Miller), grandmother of eight, great- grandmother of two. Former school librarian and world traveler, having visited all seven continents and Arctic and Antarctic oceans. Service to be held at 11:00am on Friday, June 13, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York, 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl. SW, Washington, DC 20024.

DILLENBECK--Heather Wright, 72, of Old Lyme, CT, died suddenly on June 11, 2014. Heather was born on February 5, 1942 in Toronto, Canada. She was predeceased by her parents, Adeline Gibson Hess and Arnauld Leonard Wright, who received the OBE for service in the Canadian Army in World War II. Heather graduated with a BA in Economics from Stanford, and received a Masters degree in Economics from Yale. She worked for 25 years as an Economist for US Trust Company in New York, retiring as Senior Vice President. After retiring from US Trust, she served as a volunteer in many different capacities, most notably for many years as the Treasurer of St. Ann's Church in Old Lyme. She recently became a grandmother, which brought great joy to her life. Heather leaves her husband of 32 years, Richard Dillenbeck, of Old Lyme; daughter Carolyn Wright Dillenbeck, son-in-law Blake Liggio, grandchildren Quinn and Dante Liggio of Boston, MA; sister Rosemary Wright of Chatham, NJ; and stepchildren Mark R. Dillenbeck of Charlotte, VT, Anne Gilbert Dillenbeck of Rexford, NY, and Christina D. Wood, of Wellesley, MA.

LEVY--Jack Jay. The Levy family lost a giant on Saturday, June 14, 2014. Jack Jay Levy died just as he lived, surrounded by the people he loved most. Jack was a man who focused on life's simple pleasures and remained true throughout. A sunny day on the golf course, a good hand at the card table with friends, and always most important to him, was the time spent with his wife and partner in life, Marcia, and their children and grandchildren. Loving and loyal as a husband to Marcia, father to Larry, Gary, Donna, Janet, Bobby and Darcy. "Pappa" to Samantha, Ryan, Max, Katie, Nick, Taylor, Jake and Remi. Jack was born on June 27, 1932 to Betty and Lou Levy, and raised in Brooklyn with his three siblings Arthur, Sandy, and Michael. He and his brother Arthur became business partners and grew the coat manufacturing company of Lou Levy and Sons into an enterprise that is now in it's fourth generation run by the partnership of Jack's two sons and nephews, Donald and Richard Levy. He was an example to all in courage and determination; he taught us to never quit, to fight for life, and that staying true to the course was the answer to adversity. He led by example and needed few words to convey the goodness within. Always philanthropic, Jack partnered with his doctor and dear friend, Mark Urken, to create Thanc, which has become one of the nation's leading foundations for thyroid, head and neck cancer research and patient care. The family has requested that any donations in Jack's memory be made to: Thancfoundation.org. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 16, 1:30pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. Rabbi Robert Levine of Congregation Rodeph Sholom will officiate.

FRAENKEL--Eva Stolz Gilleran Cantwell, died on June 8 in Riverdale, New York City. Born in Prague in 1932, her family escaped Czechoslovakia in 1938 before the Nazi invasion. They fled to Paris and later to the United States, settling in New York City in 1941. She attended eleven schools by the time she graduated from Chapin in 1950 because of various relocations during World War II. She attended Vassar College and graduated from Hunter College in 1982 with a BA and MA in Economics. Eva worked at Columbia University, AIG, various Wall Street firms and retired as a foundation executive. In 1978 she married Robert Cantwell, a proletarian novelist, who died the same year. In 1990 she married George K. Fraenkel, Dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Science at Columbia University. George died in 2009. She is survived by six children from her first husband, Louis J. Gilleran: Patrica, William, Louis, Eva, Maryanne and Charles, and one grandchild, Maeve. A memorial service is planned for 3pm Friday, September 19th at St Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 1160 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY 10027. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Professor George K Fraenkel Fund, Columbia University, 622 West 113th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.
LANDIS--Susan. How we will miss our Susan, smart, funny, vivacious, strong and loving. All the Baums, Feders and Luskinds

FABIAN--George S, age 84, died peacefully and surrounded by family at home on Saturday, June 7, 2014. George was born in Budapest, Hungary and came to the United States in 1947. He obtained his BA from Columbia University and his MBA from the University of Chicago. He had a prolific career in market research and advertising and was very active and respected in industry groups. He was elected to the Market Research Hall of Fame in 2009. A beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend, it was his love of life and family that fueled George through his heroic 14 year battle with cancer. He was a music lover, passionate reader, tennis player, skier and traveler. Survived by his wife of 49 years Norma, son Andrew, daughter Jennifer, son-in-law Vincent, granddaughters Alexandra and Kathleen and dog Eloise. A memorial service and reception will be held on Friday, June 27th at 11am at the Beaumont Mansion, 601 N. Ithan Ave, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, Attn: The George and Norma Fabian Fund, 383 Main Avenue, 5th Floor, Norwalk, CT 06851, tel: 203-652-0224. www.themmrf.org/fabianfund. Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Cemetery. www.forever-care.com

HOFFMAN--Deena, 93, died peacefully April 15 2014, West Palm Beach. Survived by Judy, Stephen (Nancy), Doran (Lacey), Elizabeth, Mac and Maeve; she was preceded in death by husband Harold Hoffman. jh35813@gmail.com

ALLEN--Fay, (nee Fay Winters). May 8, 1933 - June 8, 2014. 81 years young. Beloved wife of the late Allen Allen. Survived by her sons Mark and Jeffrey. Devoted and loving grandmother of Gregory, Greer, and Perry and Bailey Allen, and of the late Jared Allen. Adoring aunt and friend. Famous for Fay and Allen's Catch of the Sea of the Upper Eastside. Proprietor of The Allen House on 71st Street. Elegance, beauty; the quintessential lady of New York. Will never be forgotten; Fay lives in the hearts of all whom she touched. All donations should be sent to Friends of Karen or the Park East Synagogue Day School.

ALFANDRE--Robert Nelson, born June 9, 1927 in New York, NY, died at his home in Washington, DC on June 12th. He is survived by his wife, Priscilla Alfandre. His parents, Joseph and Annette Henry Alfandre, moved to DC when Robert was eight. Encouraged by his teachers at Anacostia High School to apply, Robert became the first of his family to attend college, choosing Swarthmore when Princeton and Yale offered later matriculation dates. At the end of his freshman year, he enlisted in the US Navy, returning to school in the fall of 1946. Upon graduation from college in 1949, he attended the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Study on a fellowship and received a Master of Arts degree in 1951. After graduate school, his first position was with the Central Intelligence Agency, where he was employed in operations concerning Western Europe. After five years with the CIA, he resigned his position to pursue a career in real estate development with his father and brother Jack. He prospered in the real estate and construction industry in the Washington area, developing his own companies. He married Priscilla Buck, a college classmate, in 1951. They have two daughters, Dominique (Thomas Palmer) and Nicole, and four grandchildren, Carl and Claudia Halbreiner and Luned and Rosamund Palmer (Miles Portek). Alfandre became a force in the DC cultural community, serving on the board of the Woodrow Wilson House and opening his Kalorama Road home to myriad non-profits for fundraising events. He also served for many years on the Board of the Whitman Walker Clinic in DC and was a leader in fighting AIDS, raising millions of dollars for AIDS research and establishing residences and support systems for victims of AIDS in DC and Key West, FL. He founded the Carroll Sledz House at the Clinic in honor of his partner Carroll. He organized and hosted the first Human Rights Campaign Fund dinner. Alfandre maintained residences in DC, Key West, Fire Island and Paris, where he pursued his deep love of French culture. He was an active member of the French Heritage Society, as well as the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He was named a Knight of the Order of St. John. Robert is also survived by his brother Jack Alfandre and devoted grandchildren, nieces and nephews; also by his friend Sidney Martin. Memorials to the breadth of this life lived well will be held in Fire Island (August 17) and in Key West. Visiting hours will be at Joseph Gawler's Sons 6-8pm Friday, June 20th. The funeral will be held on Saturday, June 21 at 11am at All Souls Church in DC with burial at Oak Hill Cemetery. The family extends their heartfelt gratitude to the staffs of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, NY Presbyterian Hospital and the home carers, all of whom cared for him through his long final illness. Donations to the Fire Island Pines Free Clinic would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers.
