MCKINLEY--John Key, passed peacefully in the comfort of his home surrounded by his loving family in Dallas, on the morning of June 12, 2014. He was born in Tuscaloosa, Alabama on March 24, 1920 to a family of educators. His father, Vergil Parks, McKinley was a college professor, and his mother, Mary Emma Key McKinley, was an elementary education school teacher. John was educated in Tuscaloosa, graduating from Tuscaloosa High School in 1937. Living on campus, he was able to walk out the door to The University of Alabama where he earned a B.S. degree in Chemical Engineering, and a M.S. degree in Organic Chemistry in four years. While in college, he was a cadet in the ROTC, rising to the rank of Cadet Colonel, and Brigade Commander. He was inducted into Tau Beta Pi, and the Scabbard and Blade Society, and was a member of The University of Alabama (Capstone) Engineering Society. Immediately after receiving his M.S., he joined Texaco on May 29, 1941, as a chemical engineer engaged in grease research at the Port Arthur refinery in Texas. As a result of the escalating conflict in Europe, on August 15, 1941 he was called to active service as a reserve officer with the rank of Second Lieutenant in the Army. For four and a half years during World War II he wore the Army uniform. The Army ordered the Alabama boy to Newfoundland and put him on skis. After Pearl Harbor he reported to Fort Bragg for additional training, and ultimately shipped out to England on the Queen Mary. After D-Day, in August of 1944, he landed on Utah Beach and fought across France, Belgium and Germany. He saw action in numerous battles, including the Battle of the Bulge as the Allied troops advanced through Western Europe and onto Berlin. As a result of his valor in a pivotal battle for the Roer River, he received the Bronze Star and eventually rose to the rank of Major. Upon returning to Port Arthur and Texaco, he met the love of his life, Helen Grace Heare. After only one date, John proposed and soon after they married on July 19, 1946. They were blessed with two sons John Key McKinley, Jr., and Mark Charles McKinley. Over the next 45 years, he held numerous positions worldwide with Texaco. In the research and development area he held over a dozen patents for petroleum additives and grease components. He continued his education, and graduated from the Advanced Management Program at Harvard University in 1962. In 1971 he was elected President of Texaco, and in 1980, the Board of Directors elected him as Chairman, President and CEO of Texaco. He served in that capacity until he retired from Texaco in 1986 after 45 years of service, and he always cherished his Texaco family. John later served as a consultant to ChevronTexaco Corporation. John and Helen spent their ensuing years enjoying their friends and family. They enjoyed their homes in Darien, Connecticut and Tuscaloosa, Alabama, but their most cherished memories were always at the Steerhead Ranch in Buffalo, Wyoming. More than anything, he loved having people up to the ranch to enjoy a taste of the "McKinley Culture" and a "Ride for the Brand" on the Eastern Slope of The Bighorn Mountains. Above all else John, Dad, Pops, aka JK will be remembered as a turtle with a hard shell and a soft heart. Born into a family of educators, he was always trying to teach those around him. He was a proud American patriot, a teacher, a mentor, a gentle giant, and he always noticed the efforts of others. John was a marksman, and if he aimed at a target, he usually hit it. John served on the Board of Directors of many companies including Texaco Inc., Federated Department Stores, Burlington Industries, Martin Marietta Corporation, Merck & Co., Inc., Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, and Apollo Computer, Inc. He also served on the Board of Directors of organizations including the Metropolitan Opera, The Peregrine Fund, The Americas Society, Business Council for Effective Literacy and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. John received Honorary Doctorate of Law degrees from both the University of Alabama in 1972 and Troy University in 1974. He was also active in various civic and professional organizations, including the Brookings Council, the Business Council Washington DC, and Presidents Commission on Executive Exchange. He was awarded the George Washington Honor Medal by the Freedoms Foundation and the Gold Medal by the National Institute of Social Sciences. In 1982 he was inducted into the Alabama Business Hall of Fame, and in 1983 was installed in the Alabama Academy of Honor. In 1984 he was given The American Eagle Award by the Invest-In-America National Council, and the Wallace Award by the American-Scottish Foundation. Also, in 1984 the Belgian Government presented John with the Commandeur de L'Ordre de la Courrone, the highest decoration awarded to a corporate leader in recognition of significant contributions to Belgium's economic sector. In 1987, John and Helen McKinley established the Merrymac McKinley Foundation, Inc., a charitable organization designed to benefit charities, educational institutions, and to provide scholarships and awards to individual students, educators and non-faculty members. Annual endowments and donations (creating over 30 scholarships and recognition awards) have been made to The University of Alabama, Troy University, Shelton State University, Southern Methodist University, Texas A&M Foundation, Trinity University, as well as a host of other worthy causes. Both John and Helen proudly served as Directors, along with other members of the McKinley family. Despite all of John's great accomplishments, the partnership of 55 years with Helen was his greatest. They were a great team. He is predeceased in death by his parents, Vergil Parks and Mary Emma, his brother, Richard, and his wife Helen Grace. He is survived by his two sons John and Mark, his daughter-in-law Karla, and his three grandchildren Key, Madison, and Charlie. A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday, June 18, 2014 at 2:00pm at the Steerhead Ranch in Buffalo, Wyoming. The family would love for all friends to send their photos and memories to Rememberingjohnkeymckinley@mkresources.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Merrymac-McKinley Foundation Gift Fund at The University of Alabama; the McKinley Award Fund at Troy University, or the Tip of The Spear Foundation. For additional information, please check websites, or call Vickie Smith at 214-922-9033.

ROCKEFELLER--Richard Gilder, M.D. The Rockefeller University community is profoundly saddened by the tragic death of our lifelong friend Richard Rockefeller. Our sense of loss is immense, both for the enormous void left in his adored family and for the world-changing work in which he was engaged that will be left incomplete by his passing. Richard was a member of our University community for more than 30 years and served on our Board of Trustees for two decades. A caring and compassionate family physician in his home state of Maine, he was a superb Trustee who believed passionately in the importance of basic and patient-based research, and in the ability of scientific advances to save human lives. Richard gave generously of his enormous talents to our Board's Hospital and Scientific Affairs Committees, and our Trustees, faculty members, students, and administrators benefited greatly from their interactions with him. A devoted humanitarian, Richard worked to alleviate human suffering and improve human welfare through his longtime service as chair of the U.S. advisory board of Doctors Without Borders and of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, where he carried on the work begun by his father and uncles. Richard was a pioneer in recognizing that the Internet could help doctors and patients share crucial data, with the ultimate goal of improving medical diagnoses and health care delivery--ideas that are routine today, but were prescient when he created the Health Commons Institute in 1994. Although he left our Board in 2006, Richard maintained an active interest in the work of the University. We will miss him very much. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nancy; his children, Clayton and Rebecca; his stepsons, Maxwell and Griffin; his three grandchildren; his siblings, David, Abby, Neva, Peggy, and Eileen; and his father, our cherished Honorary Chair and Life Trustee David Rockefeller, who has been a visionary leader and inspiration to all of us at The Rockefeller University for more than 70 years. Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse, President Emeritus Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief and David Rockefeller Professor

KATZIN--Jerome S. and Miriam Eve, died within days of each other, after 75 years of marriage, she on June 2 and he on June 14. They were known for their public service and philanthropy. In the 1960's Jerome served on the Executive Committee and Board of the Jewish Theological Seminary and as President of Great Neck, NY the Board of Education. They moved to La Jolla California in 1973, where they were recognized by both the San Diego Foundation and the University of California San Diego as leading philanthropists. They both grew up in Chicago and graduated from the University of Chicago in 1939 where Jerry also received his law degree in 1941. Jerry was a partner/ Managing director of Kuhn Loeb in New York and then Lehman Brothers where he was one of the nation's leading experts in financing public works and as long time financial Advisor to the National Rural Utilities cooperative he was instrumental in bringing electricity to rural America. He served on over 20 corporate boards of directors, including Qualcomm from 1987 to 2005 and the Price Company from its early days through its merger into Costco. Miriam earned a Master's in education from Chicago Teachers College and advanced training at Bank Street College in New York. She worked for ten years in Great Neck as a remedial reading teacher and upon moving to La Jolla instituted and administered a similar program at Torrey Pines Elementary School. Together they created the Judaic studies program at University of Cailifornia, San Diego, were leaders in the creation of the Cancer Center the Katzin Research Laboratories at the University Hospital, the Rady School of management, a chair in Jewish Civilization and other faculty chairs and funds, including in 2012 the Katzin Prize Endowment Fund, which awards scholarships to graduate students. They were each awarded the Chancellor's medal for service to the University in 2010. Jerome served on the Board of the San Diego Foundation which named them philanthropists of the year in 2007. There will be a memorial at Congregation Beth El, 8660 Gilman Drive, LaJolla California on Tuesday June 17 at 11:00am. They are survived by their children, David, Dan and Diane, and by two grandchildren, Erica Katzin and Katrina Kurnit. Contributions in their name may be made to Dorot in New York and The Seacrest Foundation in San Diego.

LEVY--Jack Jay. The Levy family lost a giant on Saturday, June 14, 2014. Jack Jay Levy died just as he lived, surrounded by the people he loved most. Jack was a man who focused on life's simple pleasures and remained true throughout. A sunny day on the golf course, a good hand at the card table with friends, and always most important to him, was the time spent with his wife and partner in life, Marcia, and their children and grandchildren. Loving and loyal as a husband to Marcia, father to Larry, Gary, Donna, Janet, Bobby and Darcy. "Pappa" to Samantha, Ryan, Max, Katie, Nick, Taylor, Jake and Remi. Jack was born on June 27, 1932 to Betty and Lou Levy, and raised in Brooklyn with his three siblings Arthur, Sandy, and Michael. He and his brother Arthur became business partners and grew the coat manufacturing company of Lou Levy and Sons into an enterprise that is now in it's fourth generation run by the partnership of Jack's two sons and nephews, Donald and Richard Levy. He was an example to all in courage and determination; he taught us to never quit, to fight for life, and that staying true to the course was the answer to adversity. He led by example and needed few words to convey the goodness within. Always philanthropic, Jack partnered with his doctor and dear friend, Mark Urken, to create Thanc, which has become one of the nation's leading foundations for thyroid, head and neck cancer research and patient care. The family has requested that any donations in Jack's memory be made to: Thancfoundation.org. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 16, 1:30pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. Rabbi Robert Levine of Congregation Rodeph Sholom will officiate.

LEVY--Jack. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jack. He fought a courageous battle for so many years with dignity and had the admiration and love of all who knew him. Every aspect of our lives has been intertwined with Marcia and Jack for over 40 years and we feel a great loss. Our deepest sympathies to Marcia and their wonderful family. Rest in peace. You will be in our hearts forever. Joan and Marty

LEVY--Jack. Dearest brother-in-law and friend for 66 years. The most courageous man I have ever known. Now that your struggle has finally ended there is room for a flood of precious memories. For good times as teenagers when we double dated with my Arthur and your beautiful Marcia, the memories of all those Levy family dinners and our happy occasions, weddings, births, all the sharing of young lives. The day you were diagnosed, Arthur and I were there to hear the words that would change your life forever. Watching your strength, courage and determination has been an inspiration to all of us. You were a special man and I love you. My love and condolences to Marcia, Larry, Gary, Janet, Donna, Bobby and all the kids. Barbara

ALFANDRE--Robert Nelson, born June 9, 1927 in New York, NY, died at his home in Washington, DC on June 12th. He is survived by his wife, Priscilla Alfandre. His parents, Joseph and Annette Henry Alfandre, moved to DC when Robert was eight. Encouraged by his teachers at Anacostia High School to apply, Robert became the first of his family to attend college, choosing Swarthmore when Princeton and Yale offered later matriculation dates. At the end of his freshman year, he enlisted in the US Navy, returning to school in the fall of 1946. Upon graduation from college in 1949, he attended the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Study on a fellowship and received a Master of Arts degree in 1951. After graduate school, his first position was with the Central Intelligence Agency, where he was employed in operations concerning Western Europe. After five years with the CIA, he resigned his position to pursue a career in real estate development with his father and brother Jack. He prospered in the real estate and construction industry in the Washington area, developing his own companies. He married Priscilla Buck, a college classmate, in 1951. They have two daughters, Dominique (Thomas Palmer) and Nicole, and four grandchildren, Carl and Claudia Halbreiner and Luned and Rosamund Palmer (Miles Portek). Alfandre became a force in the DC cultural community, serving on the board of the Woodrow Wilson House and opening his Kalorama Road home to myriad non-profits for fundraising events. He also served for many years on the Board of the Whitman Walker Clinic in DC and was a leader in fighting AIDS, raising millions of dollars for AIDS research and establishing residences and support systems for victims of AIDS in DC and Key West, FL. He founded the Carroll Sledz House at the Clinic in honor of his partner Carroll. He organized and hosted the first Human Rights Campaign Fund dinner. Alfandre maintained residences in DC, Key West, Fire Island and Paris, where he pursued his deep love of French culture. He was an active member of the French Heritage Society, as well as the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He was named a Knight of the Order of St. John. Robert is also survived by his brother Jack Alfandre and devoted grandchildren, nieces and nephews; also by his friend Sidney Martin. Memorials to the breadth of this life lived well will be held in Fire Island (August 17) and in Key West. Visiting hours will be at Joseph Gawler's Sons 6-8pm Friday, June 20th. The funeral will be held on Saturday, June 21 at 11am at All Souls Church in DC with burial at Oak Hill Cemetery. The family extends their heartfelt gratitude to the staffs of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, NY Presbyterian Hospital and the home carers, all of whom cared for him through his long final illness. Donations to the Fire Island Pines Free Clinic would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers.

SISKIND--Bernard Richard, April 10, 1934 June 16, 2014. Loving husband of Patricia and father of Lawrence (Shoshannah) and Peter (Judi). Proud grandfather. Dartmouth 1955, Tuck 1956. We will always remember his love of travel, art, opera, the beach, East Hampton, Hanover, and anything French, but most of all his sense of humor. Memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, on Friday, June 20, at 12 noon.

McKINLEY--John. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of John McKinley, a Managing Director and later Honorary Director on the company's board for more than 30 years. McKinley spent his professional life at Texaco, the major corporate sponsor of the Met's international radio broadcast series for 63 years, eventually serving as the company's CEO from 1980 until his retirement in 1986. In addition to his service on the Met board, McKinley was the National Chairman of the company's Centennial Fund, a campaign he helped launch with a $5 million pledge from Texaco. The campaign culminated in the Met's 1983 Centennial Celebration and raised $100 million for the Met's endowment. We offer our sincerest condolences to his sons, John and Mark, and his three grandchildren. Ann Ziff, Chairman Kevin Kennedy, President Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association

Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

LEDERER--Claire, of Great Neck, New York passed away on June 15, 2014. She was born on July 20, 1929 in Basra, Iraq and emigrated to the US in 1948 with her parents Sabiha and Heskel Saleh and sisters. Survived by her children Karen Lederer (Michael Scher), Steven Lederer (Carolyn), former husband Arthur Lederer, grandchildren Roxanne Lerner (Todd), Travis Scher, Matthew Lederer and Austin Lederer, sisters Joyce Slotkin (Arnold), Tina Barland (Dr. Peter) and Yvonne Lurie (David). She had a long career working in accounting at several companies on Long Island, became a Bat Mitzvah as an adult, enjoyed bridge, tennis and our dogs, and was one amazing cook. A loving and energetic woman, she will be terribly missed. Service at 12 noon on Tuesday, June 17th at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.
PHAW--Philip. Retired CFO of The New York Jets died at home in Wurtsboro, NY on Sunday June 15th. Survived by his wife Anne, his son Jeff and daughter-in-law Trish. Burial was on Monday June 16th.

KATZ--Joan Schwartz, 85, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on June 16, 2014 in the comfort of her devoted husband, Herbert J. Katz, with whom she shared 65 glorious years. Loving daughter of Lee and A.L. Schwartz, proud mother of Steven J. Katz, MD, Bruce Katz and the late Jeffrey Katz, adored mother-in-law of Helene Katz and the late Patti Katz, cherished grandmother to Haley, Zoe, Max, Andrew and Justin Katz, great-grandmother of Sofia and Kaya, and close friend to many, Joan will be sadly missed by all. To all of us who knew and loved Joan, she was the complete package: stunningly beautiful, charismatic, quick-witted, big-hearted, steadfastly upbeat, sharp as a tack and always elegant. Alongside her fierce loyalty to her family, Joan was a celebrity judge coordinator for the Miss Universe pageant for over twenty years, the founder of the North Shore chapter of Fight for Sight, committed fundraiser for several other charities, including Boystown of Italy and even "Queen for a Day" winner in 1945. Graveside services will be held on June 17, 2014 at 11am at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

SAFRA--Moise Yacoub. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly grieved by the passing of Moise Yacoub Safra, of blessed memory, in Brazil, who together with his beloved wife, Chella Cohen Safra, is a Benefactor of Yeshiva University and received of an honorary degree Doctor of Humane Letters in 2012. A brilliant business leader in the field of banking and a world renowned real estate investor and industrialist through M. Safra and Co. in Sao Paulo and New York, companies that specialize in a wide array of investments around the world. He was a kind, gentle, humble giant in philanthropy on behalf of Jewish and secular education, medical research and undergraduate education at Yeshiva University. Moise and Chella Safra were honored in 1992 at the inaugural dinner of YU's Sephardic Council of Overseers and in 2006 they established the Chella and Moise Safra Chair in Obstetrics and Gynecology and Women's Health at YU's Albert Einstein College of Medicine to expand critical scientific investigations in the area of women's health. He regarded Yeshiva University as the perfect balance of Torah and secular education and stated he was continuously impressed with all that YU does for humanity. May the memory of this great humanitarian serve as an inspiration and a source of enduring blessings for all who knew him. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Mrs. Chella Cohen Safra and their children: Jacob, Azuri, Edmundo, Esther and Olga and their spouses and grandchildren. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

SISKIND--Bernard R. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Bernard Siskind, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

ROCKEFELLER--Dr. Richard G. The trustees, staff, and grantees of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) mourn the death of Dr. Richard G. Rockefeller, a former trustee, board chair, and very dear friend. Richard served on the RBF board of trustees for 23 years, starting in 1989. He was chair of the board from 2006 2013 and was an advisory trustee at the time of his tragic death. Richard was an exceptional human being -- a person of great intellect and curiosity, profound common sense, wit, and compassion. He gave generously and completely to all of those with whom he worked and all he met. He was a gifted, caring, and joyful leader. During his decades of service to the RBF he engaged deeply in our philanthropic efforts to help improve democratic practice, advance solutions to climate change, and build durable peace in regions afflicted by conflict. His appetite for knowledge was insatiable and he most enjoyed learning from the leaders and staff of grantee organizations, whether here in the United States or abroad. He immediately touched all those he met, who felt his genuine respect and curiosity about them and their work. Richard was a leader in his generation of the Rockefeller family, continuing the principled philanthropy of his father, David, and uncles who established the RBF in 1940, while responding to the needs of a profoundly transformed world. As chair, Richard thoughtfully guided members of the next generation of family leaders to assume leadership and to shape the future of the RBF to suit the challenges of their time. Richard's work at the RBF complemented his many other philanthropic activities -- a deep concern for environmental stewardship that motivated his leadership of the Maine Coast Heritage Trust and the Sargasso Sea Alliance; a devotion to science which guided his 30-year association with The Rockefeller University; and a love of humanity which inspired his own practice of family medicine, his founding of the Health Commons Institute, and his long service with Doctors Without Borders. In recent years, Richard was a leader in the exploration of new treatments for those afflicted with severe trauma. Our hearts go out to all the members of his family, especially his wife Nancy, children Clayton and Rebecca, and their children; stepchildren Maxwell and Griffin; his father David, all his siblings, and the extended Rockefeller family. All of us who knew Richard loved him. And his love was felt by countless others around the world who never met him. Valerie Rockefeller Wayne, Chair Stephen Heintz, President

ABRAMS--Rick, died June 15, 2014 at the age of 57 after a long battle with thyroid cancer. Rick is mourned by all of his former colleagues at Scholastic and at Tom Snyder Productions, the Watertown, Mass., company where he worked for 30 years. Rick's contributions to the educational publishing community were historic. He was a pioneer in the educational technology industry, and his commitment to using technology to raise student engagement, critical thinking skills and achievement set an agenda which still applies today. Rick co-founded Tom Snyder Productions in 1982 and ran the business side of the groundbreaking educational technology company. At TSP, which was acquired by Scholastic in 2001, he harnessed visionary technical, artistic and editorial talent, managed finances, inspired employees, and helped bring to market some of the first and most impactful educational technology products the industry has seen. Ever self-effacing, Rick always credited those around him for the company's many successes. He leaves an enduring legacy of friendship, professionalism and compassion at TSP and Scholastic and will be greatly missed. A trustee of Wheelock College and on the boards of the Concord Consortium and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Rick never stopped contributing, learning and giving. Rick is survived by his wife Susan Kenyon, his father Justin Abrams, his three children Archie, Stanley, and Sydney, and two siblings, Rita Draper and Mark Abrams. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 18, at Temple Isaiah, 55 Lincoln Street, Lexington, Mass., at 11:30 a.m. Contributions in his memory can be made to the International Thyroid Oncology Group (ITOG), ACROSS Lexington, and/or the Pan Mass Challenge (under the names of participants Archie and/or Stan Abrams). MARGERY MAYER, President, Scholastic Education

GERSTENBLATT--Wilfred, 80, of East 74th St.,died Thursday, June 12, 2014 at Cornell Medical Center, NY. He was the husband of Judith (Furedi) Gerstenblatt for 31 years. For complete obituary and condolences, go to ShalomMemorialChapel.com.

GOTTLICH--Myra B.,April 20, 1925 - June 13, 2014. Born in New York City, Phi Beta Kappa Hunter. Masters Columbia. Taught English 20 years in New Rochelle. Survived by Abbe and Eric Harkavy, three nieces, two stepdaughters and four grandchildren. Loved by All. Donations to Alzheimer's Foundation.

KAHAN--Rabbi Norman, 92, z"l of Great Neck, NY. Devoted husband of 64 years of Shirley, loving father of Dr. Sylvia Kahan, Cantor Judi Rowland, and Eric Kahan, affectionate father-in-law of Michael Rowland and grandfather of Rachel, Benjamin, Noah, and Carly. A towering leader in the Reform Jewish movement, he was senior rabbi at Temple Sinai of Roslyn and Temple Beth Jacob, Newburgh, founder of the Department of Small Congregations of the Union of Reform Judaism, and president of the New York Board of Rabbis. His kindness, generosity of spirit and endless devotion to the Jewish people helped make this world a better place. Funeral to be held Wednesday, June 18 at 10am at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, LI. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery.

HONOROFF--Richard A.,on June 13, 2014 after a long illness. Born in Chicago, May 24, 1951. A composer, arranger, musician and musical director, he worked in television, musical theater, jazz and classical venues. He wrote music for television sports including theme music for the National Football League, Atlanta Hawks basketball and for the 1988 and 1992 Olympic Games coverage. He performed as pianist on Broadway for the show, Eubie, and performed with many jazz greats. Off-Broadway he was musical director for five shows, including The Cotton Club Revisited. He wrote three orchestral works. Symphony No. 1 "Shoah" and a companion piece "Testament" were composed for and performed at The Shoah Concert in Berlin on February 4, 1994. Symphony No. 2, "From Ashes Reborn" was in part inspired by the protest of a Viet Nam War veteran. All three works were recorded in 1994 and 1995 by the Moscow Radio and Television Orchestra, led by Alexander Mikhailov. He is survived by his son, Zachary, and daughter, Julia, as well as his brother and sister-in-law, Brad and Jane Honoroff. A private memorial service will be held in July.

KATZIN--Jerome S. and Miriam Eve, died within days of each other, after 75 years of marriage, she on June 2 and he on June 14. They were known for their public service and philanthropy. In the 1960's Jerome served on the Executive Committee and Board of the Jewish Theological Seminary and as President of Great Neck, NY the Board of Education. They moved to La Jolla California in 1973, where they were recognized by both the San Diego Foundation and the University of California San Diego as leading philanthropists. They both grew up in Chicago and graduated from the University of Chicago in 1939 where Jerry also received his law degree in 1941. Jerry was a partner/ Managing director of Kuhn Loeb in New York and then Lehman Brothers where he was one of the nation's leading experts in financing public works and as long time financial Advisor to the National Rural Utilities cooperative he was instrumental in bringing electricity to rural America. He served on over 20 corporate boards of directors, including Qualcomm from 1987 to 2005 and the Price Company from its early days through its merger into Costco. Miriam earned a Master's in education from Chicago Teachers College and advanced training at Bank Street College in New York. She worked for ten years in Great Neck as a remedial reading teacher and upon moving to La Jolla instituted and administered a similar program at Torrey Pines Elementary School. Together they created the Judaic studies program at University of Cailifornia, San Diego, were leaders in the creation of the Cancer Center the Katzin Research Laboratories at the University Hospital, the Rady School of management, a chair in Jewish Civilization and other faculty chairs and funds, including in 2012 the Katzin Prize Endowment Fund, which awards scholarships to graduate students. They were each awarded the Chancellor's medal for service to the University in 2010. Jerome served on the Board of the San Diego Foundation which named them philanthropists of the year in 2007. There will be a memorial at Congregation Beth El, 8660 Gilman Drive, LaJolla California on Tuesday June 17 at 11:00am. They are survived by their children, David, Dan and Diane, and by two grandchildren, Erica Katzin and Katrina Kurnit. Contributions in their name may be made to Dorot in New York and The Seacrest Foundation in San Diego.

FIORENZA--Joan, on June 15, 2014. Beloved wife of Fred. Loving mother of Larry, Maryellen, Lisa and John. Cherished grandmother of Sara, Emily, Marie, Julia, Ben and Grace. Friends may call Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, NY. Religious Service on Thursday at 10am at Trinity Lutheran Church, 5 Durham Road, New Hyde Park, NY. Interment at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

FASSLER--Leon, age 81, devoted husband of Estelle, loving father of Dr. Ronald and Wendy Weissman, grandfather of Matthew and Seth Weissman and Natalie Karafiol, brother of Joseph, Gustave, and the late Michael. Funeral Wednesday June 18 at Westchester Hills Cemetary, 400 Saw Mill River Rd, Hastings on Hudson, NY. Call cemetrary for time of service 914-478-1767. Shiva Wednesay and Thursday 5-8pm at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Weissman, 5 Renaissance Square, Whiteplains, NY. Died peacefully at home on June 15. He was a Renaisance Man, a brillant conversationalist and devoted enthusiast of the arts, particularly the opera.

COOK--Richard Charles, Playwrights Horizons extends their condolences to Helen R. Cook and her family on the passing of husband, father, and playwright Richard C. Cook. Memorial contributions may be made to playwrightshorizons.org/ richardcook/

BERNSTEIN--Jeanne. The Board of Trustees and staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of Jeanne Bernstein. Jeanne was a volunteer for many years, and, along with her husband, Arnold (former Blythedale trustee and Board Chair) were devoted supporters of our hospital. We send our deep and sincere condolences to her entire family. Owen Gutfreund, Chairman of the Board Larry Levine, President and CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, New York

FRISINA--R. Warren, died June 15, 2014. His beloved wife of 53 years, Gloria Dell'Omo predeceased him in 2006. A veteran (U.S.M.C./Korea) and former president of the New York Assessors' Association, he is survived by siblings, Armida Giglio, Gloria Saccoliti, and Donald, a son Warren and daughter-in-law Patsy Cooper, daughters Diane Ventre and Lisa Ann and her fiance Michael Markos, and three grandchildren, Kyle, Jessica, and Joseph. He is also survived by a dear friend and companion Judy Cotter of Highland Beach, FL. Services: Ascension Catholic Church, Boca Raton, FL, Wednesday, June 18 at 11am and the St. Bernadette Parish, Brooklyn, NY on June 21 at 9:45am.

SISKIND--Bernard, we have lost a beloved friend whose memory shall always be with us. Bernie was a world class enthusiast, creative, adventurous, embedded with a wicked sense of humor and devoted to a wide circle of friends. SISKIND--Bernard Richard, April 10, 1934 June 16, 2014. Loving husband of Patricia and father of Lawrence (Shoshannah) and Peter (Judi). Proud grandfather. Dartmouth 1955, Tuck 1956. We will always remember his love of travel, art, opera, the beach, East Hampton, Hanover, and anything French, but most of all his sense of humor. Memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, on Friday, June 20, at 12 noon.

STERN--Louis I.,June 7, 1929 June 12, 2014. Son, brother, husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, and friend, died in his 85th year. He was predeceased by his wife of 49 years, Marilyn "Mindy" Stern. Lou leaves behind his sons: Mike (Laura and son Tom), Dave (Debbie) and Jon (Patricia and children Dominic and Lydia) as well as his sister Joann Kobin. Born and raised in New York City, Lou was an Eagle Scout and graduated from Brooklyn Tech, MIT and Harvard. His civil engineering career took him across the globe to Singapore, Vietnam and Tehran. He was a lifelong devotee to the Boy Scouts, becoming a scout master in New Jersey and all three of his sons became Eagle Scouts. For his 70th birthday; he, his sons, and first grandson took a rafting trip in Idaho. He passed on his love of the outdoors, a healthy appetite and snoring capabilities to his sons. He was the rock of the family as he cared for his beloved wife during her battle with cancer and later slipped into the grips of Alzheimer's. His life was defined by integrity, compassion for others, commitment and passion for his family and career, and his own brand of humor. He set the bar high and will be missed.

SQUIRE--John Lawton, of East 66th Street, New York City, passed away on June 12, 2014 after a long illness. He was seventy-six. Mr. Squire worked in the financial business, first as an analyst and more recently as a self employed entrepreneur engaged in the oil business as well as raising large amounts of capital for a cancer research firm. John was passionate about skiing and music. He could often be found at Bromley Mountain in Vermont. He also was on the board of directors of the Clarion Music Society and sang with the choir at St. Bartholomew Episcopal Church on Park Avenue, New York City. John will be missed by all the lives he touched: his loving partner of many years, his daughter, her husband and beloved granddaughter, his son and daughter-in-law and his sister and her husband, not to mention his many friends. A memorial service will be held in the near future at Bartholomew Church at the convenience of the family.

SHORE--Adam. The partners and staff of Goldfarb & Fleece mourn the passing of Adam Shore, son of our partner and friend, Steve Shore. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Susan, Steve, Jared, Melissa and the entire family.

FASSLER--Leon, Three generations of Granoff's mourn the passing of our dear friend Leon Fassler. He was the kindest, sweetest and wittiest gentleman we have had the pleasure of sharing our lives with. The Granoff Clan

SAFRA--Moise Yacoub. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of our cherished honorary alumnus, Moise Yacoub Safra, and express our sorrow on behalf of the Administration, the Sephardic Council of Overseers, the faculty and students of our schools who have benefitted from his philanthropy as a Benefactor, together with his beloved wife Chella. Our sympathy is extended to Chella Cohen Safra and all their children. We also wish to express sincere condolences to his siblings: Mr. Joseph (and Vicky) Safra, our longtime friends and supporters who participated in Yeshiva University's special occasions where the family's leadership was cited and to the sisters of Moise Yacoub Safra: Mrs. Huguette Michaan and Gaby Safra, both of Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Stella Kattan of Geneva, Switzerland and all the members of their families. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus David Eshaghian, Chair, Sephardic Council of Overseers

MIRKEN--Alan B. Dr. Susan Bressman and the staff of the Mirken Department of Neurology at Mount Sinai Beth Israel sadly mourn the passing of our beloved benefactor, Alan B. Mirken. For over two decades Alan gave unflaggingly to build and support the Department and was especially focused on clinical, teaching and research programs for Parkinson's disease. His extraordinary generosity, wisdom and vision had no limits. Ever selfless and humble, his joy was helping others to succeed. Alan was our steadfast pillar and will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Joan, his children, Leslie and Mitchell (Rubin) and Jane and Richard (Zenker), his adored grandchildren and the extended Mirken family. Susan B. Bressman, MD Alan and Joan Mirken Chair Departments of Neurology, Mount Sinai Beth Israel, Mount Sinai St. Luke's & Mount Sinai Roosevelt Hospitals Professor of Neurology, Icahn School of Medicine

QUICK--Jonathan Richard, February 9, 1942-May 13, 2014. Rutgers '63, Yale PhD '68, Prof. Quick taught James Joyce, Modern Novel at UMass until retirement in 2002. Predeceased by parents the Rev. Joseph Quick and Katherine Brock Quick; and brother David, he leaves behind beloved wife of 33 years Elaine, son Benjamin Joseph Quick, grandson Zachary Austin Quick and family. Memorial service at Wildwood Cemetery, Amherst, MA, Sept. 20, 2014.

ABRAMS--Rick, died June 15, 2014 at the age of 57 after a long battle with thyroid cancer. Rick is mourned by all of his former colleagues at Scholastic and at Tom Snyder Productions, the Watertown, Mass., company where he worked for 30 years. Rick's contributions to the educational publishing community were historic. He was a pioneer in the educational technology industry, and his commitment to using technology to raise student engagement, critical thinking skills and achievement set an agenda which still applies today. Rick co-founded Tom Snyder Productions in 1982 and ran the business side of the groundbreaking educational technology company. At TSP, which was acquired by Scholastic in 2001, he harnessed visionary technical, artistic and editorial talent, managed finances, inspired employees, and helped bring to market some of the first and most impactful educational technology products the industry has seen. Ever self-effacing, Rick always credited those around him for the company's many successes. He leaves an enduring legacy of friendship, professionalism and compassion at TSP and Scholastic and will be greatly missed. A trustee of Wheelock College and on the boards of the Concord Consortium and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Rick never stopped contributing, learning and giving. Rick is survived by his wife Susan Kenyon, his father Justin Abrams, his three children Archie, Stanley, and Sydney, and two siblings, Rita Draper and Mark Abrams. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 18, at Temple Isaiah, 55 Lincoln Street, Lexington, Mass., at 11:30 a.m. Contributions in his memory can be made to the International Thyroid Oncology Group (ITOG), ACROSS Lexington, and/or the Pan Mass Challenge (under the names of participants Archie and/or Stan Abrams). MARGERY MAYER, President, Scholastic Education

KOENIG--Julian. April 22, 1921 - June 12, 2014. The One Club mourns the loss of Julian Koenig, esteemed member of the Creative Hall of Fame. Julian was inducted in 1966 to the Copywriters Hall of Fame, as it was known then. Born in New York, April 22, 1921, he graduated from Dartmouth and then studied at Columbia Law School. Julian was an eccentric intellectual who created a new style of copywriting that went on to define advertising's creative revolution. It was smart, simple and accessible to the public--writing that neither exaggerated nor overpromised. Contemporary writers compared him to Holden Caulfield, for being aloof and reserved in a business that favored popular culture. Julian is best known for his iconic work for Volkswagen while at Doyle Dane Bernbach. Working with art director Helmut Krone, he created the groundbreaking ads "Think Small" and "Lemon," which came to define the new style of advertising. Julian and Fred Papert launched a new agency with George Lois called Papert Koenig Lois where they created award-winning work for Wolfschmidt Vodka, Xerox, Peugeot and Allarest, proving as he once said that good taste is good for business. Many well-known advertising talents started their careers at PKL, including Carl Ally and Sam Scali, who went on to start their own agencies. Fred Papert and Julian remained good friends throughout their lives and made annual trips to Saratoga for the races. During his lifetime, Julian amassed a large coterie of colorful characters, including sportswriter Jimmy Breslin, Senator Jacob Javits, and his own alter ego, Groucho Marx. Among his many contributions was the naming of "Earth Day" in 1969, for a committee organized to bring environmental awareness to the public. The One Club offers heartfelt sympathy to Julian's children and grandchildren. (Photo credit, Carl Fischer)

BROWN--Mary "Sue", Lover of New York City, passed away on June 16, 2014. Retiree of Cornell-Weill Medical College. Devoted mother, grandmother and great- grandmother. For further information please visit: www.efcarterfuneralhome.com

SAFRA--Moise. Tel Aviv University and its American Friends deeply mourn the passing of honorary doctor Moise Yacoub Safra, brilliant financial leader and extraordinary humanitarian. His visionary philanthropy is manifest in The Chella and Moise Safra Building, cornerstone of the university's ambitious Student City complex, a home for residents from needy backgrounds and outlying communities. And every day, thousands will continue to enter the campus through a major new portal, The Chella and Moise Safra Gate. We will miss the warmth of a treasured friend and a devoted benefactor of the State of Israel. We extend our deepest sympathies to Chella Cohen Safra; their children Jacob, Azuri, Edmundo, Esther, and Olga; and the entire family. Prof. Joseph Klafter, President, TAU Jon Gurkoff, Chairman, AFTAU Gail Reiss, President & CEO, AFTAU

KATZ--Joan. It is with deep regret and sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our member, Joan. ROCKEFELLER--Dr. Richard G. The trustees, staff, and grantees of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) mourn the death of Dr. Richard G. Rockefeller, a former trustee, board chair, and very dear friend. Richard served on the RBF board of trustees for 23 years, starting in 1989. He was chair of the board from 2006 2013 and was an advisory trustee at the time of his tragic death. Richard was an exceptional human being -- a person of great intellect and curiosity, profound common sense, wit, and compassion. He gave generously and completely to all of those with whom he worked and all he met. He was a gifted, caring, and joyful leader. During his decades of service to the RBF he engaged deeply in our philanthropic efforts to help improve democratic practice, advance solutions to climate change, and build durable peace in regions afflicted by conflict. His appetite for knowledge was insatiable and he most enjoyed learning from the leaders and staff of grantee organizations, whether here in the United States or abroad. He immediately touched all those he met, who felt his genuine respect and curiosity about them and their work. Richard was a leader in his generation of the Rockefeller family, continuing the principled philanthropy of his father, David, and uncles who established the RBF in 1940, while responding to the needs of a profoundly transformed world. As chair, Richard thoughtfully guided members of the next generation of family leaders to assume leadership and to shape the future of the RBF to suit the challenges of their time. Richard's work at the RBF complemented his many other philanthropic activities -- a deep concern for environmental stewardship that motivated his leadership of the Maine Coast Heritage Trust and the Sargasso Sea Alliance; a devotion to science which guided his 30-year association with The Rockefeller University; and a love of humanity which inspired his own practice of family medicine, his founding of the Health Commons Institute, and his long service with Doctors Without Borders. In recent years, Richard was a leader in the exploration of new treatments for those afflicted with severe trauma. Our hearts go out to all the members of his family, especially his wife Nancy, children Clayton and Rebecca, and their children; stepchildren Maxwell and Griffin; his father David, all his siblings, and the extended Rockefeller family. All of us who knew Richard loved him. And his love was felt by countless others around the world who never met him. Valerie Rockefeller Wayne, Chair Stephen Heintz, President

HECKELMAN--Anita (nee Wederholt). died on June 16 at age 70, after bravely living with cancer for five years. Services to be held at 11:45am on June 19 at Riverside Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Kids Cancer Alliance.

A veteran (U.S.M.C./Korea) and former president of the New York Assessors' Association, he is survived by siblings, Armida Giglio, Gloria Saccoliti, and Donald, a son Warren and daughter-in-law Patsy Cooper, daughters Diane Ventre and Lisa Ann and her fiance Michael Markos, and three grandchildren, Kyle, Jessica, and Joseph. FISCHER--Nancy Sarah Kaplan, (1928 2014) passed away peacefully at her home in New York City on June 16, 2014, after a brief illness. She earned her degrees in art and education from the University of Chicago and Columbia. Mrs. Fischer served as an educational advisor to the Department of Education at City College and was the Director of the Long Ridge School in Stamford, Connecticut. Nancy was predeceased by her beloved husband, Roy; and her brother, Stephen Kaplan. She is survived by her three children, David Schaffer and his wife, Amy, Peter Schaffer and his wife, Wendy Lecker, and Joanna Schaffer and her husband, Joseph Pastore; also, her stepson, Richard Fischer and his wife, Donna DeLaurentis; and her stepdaughter, Patrice Fischer; also by nine grandchildren, Philip, Caleb, Nicole, Megan, Laura, Julia, Hannah, Heather and Noah; and four great-grandchildren. She is also survived by a sister-in-law, Caryl Kaplan; her niece, Judy Kaplan Walker, her husband, Robert Walker and their sons, Aaron and Isaac Walker; and by her nephew, Allan Kaplan. She is fondly remembered by her loving cousins and her truly dear friends whose devotion she cherished and returned. A memorial service will be held in August. In lieu of flowers, we welcome you to make a donation to a charity of your choice in her memory.

FLAGG--Thomas Richardson, died on June 9, 2014 surrounded by family at his home in Redding, CT where he lived for 40 years. Born in 1936 to the late Irene Richardson and John H. Flagg, Tom grew up in Oradell and Englewood, NJ. He graduated from Deerfield Academy, Princeton University, and received his Master's in Architecture from Columbia University. Tom served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy on the USS Hanson in the Pacific Fleet. He designed single family residences in the tri-state area and served in numerous volunteer roles in the communities he loved; Redding, CT and Point O'Woods, NY on Fire Island. He is survived by Terry Stratton, his loving wife of 50 years; his twin brother Dr. Stephen V. Flagg; his son Christopher S. Flagg of New York, NY; daughter Deborah Flagg Smith of Petaluma, CA; daughter Julia Flagg Leaver of Healdsburg, CA; and grandchildren, Emmeline, Conrad, Elliot, Calvin, and Ginger. A memorial service will be held on Saturday June 21st at 3pm at the First Church of Christ Congregational, Redding, CT. Please send contributions to: The Mark Twain Library or The Point O'Woods Community Fund.

FASSLER--Leon, age 81, devoted husband of Estelle, loving father of Dr. Ronald and Wendy Weissman, grandfather of Matthew and Seth Weissman and Natalie Karafiol, brother of Joseph, Gustave, and the late Michael. SAFRA--Moise. The Faculty of the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health join me in mourning the death of our revered friend and benefactor Moise Safra. Merkatz, MD The Chella & Moise Safra Professor, University Chair Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University Montefiore Medical Center

SAFRA--Moise. The Edmond J. Safra Synagogue of Turnberry Florida mourns the passing of Moise Safra Z"L, our wonderful friend and esteemed congregant. Moise was a man of dignity with a warm and friendly smile to all. Our congregants were always honored by his presence. He will be missed, may his memory be a blessing to us all. Our deepest condolences to his wife Chella, his partner in life, his children, Jacob, Ezra, Edmond, Esther, Olga, their spouses, grandchildren and siblings. Edmond J. Safra Synagogue Aventura, Florida Rabbi Yosef Galimidi Jack Beyda, President Ivor Braka, President Emeritus

SANG--Nancy S. M. (Hou), age 87, of Brookline, Massachusetts, passed away after a brief illness on June 6, 2014. Devoted wife of the late Heng-Kang Sang; mother of Delia N. Sang and her husband, Mark S. Hughes, of Brookline; Daniel N. Sang and his partner, Eleanor H. Powers, of New York; and Christine N. Sang and her husband B. Kemp Dolliver, of Cambridge, Massachusetts. She is survived by her beloved sisters, Diana H. Yeh and Evelyn H. Huang, and her dear brothers, David H. Hou and Roger H. Hou. Beloved grandmother of Michael S. Hughes and Alexandra S. Dolliver. Prior to moving to Brookline, she was a resident of Jamaica Estates, New York. She traveled extensively to Asia, Africa, and the Middle East with her husband, who was an economist with the United Nations and Nankai University, China, and lived for extended periods of time abroad. Mrs. Sang enjoyed Chinese history and arts, animated political discussions, classical poetry, and Western and Chinese orchestral and chamber music, and was an avid patron of local Chinese Opera in the greater Boston area and, prior to that, the Peking Opera Society in New York. She enjoyed many years as Principal of the International Chinese School in New York, and taught Chinese language classes at the United Nations. She served on the Friends' of the Queens' Library Committee in Flushing, and was a longtime advocate of lecture and concert programs at the library, as well as being active in campaigning for their fund-raising and legislative efforts for its funding. Family and friends will honor and remember Mrs. Sang's life on Saturday, June 21st from 9 to 11:30am, at Lehman, Reen & McNamara, 63 Chestnut Hill Avenue, Brighton, Massachusetts. Interment will follow at the Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mrs. Sang's memory may be made to The Nancy Sang Memorial Education Fund, Hebrew Senior Life-Development Office, 1200 Centre Street, Boston, MA 02131.

MORGAN--Thomas B. The Board of Trustees and Staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of Thomas B. Morgan. Tom was the President of the WNYC Communications Group from April 1990 to April 1994. He also served on the WNYC Board of Directors and was an Honorary Trustee of the New York Public Radio Board. His commitment to excellence in journalism and public radio was his gift to the city of New York. Tom was the former Press Secretary to Mayor John Lindsay and an accomplished writer and journalist. He was the editor of The Village Voice in 1974-75 and his work appeared in magazines including Esquire, Life and New York. He was the author of two novels. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and his many friends. Cynthia King Vance, Chair; Laura Walker, President and CEO

GOLBY--Richard A. His family mourns his passing this past Monday. Richard, an educator for 38 years with the New York City Board of Education, dedicated his career to the teaching and training of special needs children. Retiring in 2003, he was a recipient of the Award of Gratitude from the Queens School for Career Development. He was Dean at John Bowne High School and sat on the board of YAI. He counseled, advised and advocated for his students' education and career training, enriching many lives. Richard, a food connoisseur, owned his own catering firm and was a dietician at summer camps and nursing homes. Richard is survived by his wife, Arline Optekman Golby, whom he met at the World's Fair, his daughters Stacy and Barbara, and his grandchildren Craig, Sarah, Benjamin, Abigail and Andrew. Service on Thursday at 10am at Beth Shalom Chapels in Smithtown, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Chabad of Stony Brook would be greatly appreciated.

EDDY--Ellen Stover, of Short Hills, New Jersey and Bayville, Maine died on Monday, June 16, 2014. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 19th at 2pm at Christ Church in Short Hills. Ellen was born to the late Charles and Jane Stover on February 2, 1940. A graduate of Smith College, Class of 1961, Chapin House, she was a lifelong active alumnus. She was a member and former president of the Short Hills Garden Club and a co-founder and owner of Patchpoint, Ltd. She is survived by her husband of 51 years, John S. Eddy, her daughter Hilary Eddy Lafferty and her husband Wayne Lafferty and their three children Kristin, Ashlyn and Megan Lafferty, brothers Charles and David Stover and many nieces, nephews and cousins. She was predeceased by her son, John "Jeff" Eddy. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions to www.smith.edu or www.greenwoodgardens.org.

MILLER--James Robert. February 15, 1942 - June 16, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Julius and Belle Miller, Jim grew up on East 27th Street with brother Daniel. He attended Syracuse University and St. Johns University law school. Jim's profession was in business affairs for the motion picture industry, including more than 20 years at Warner Bros. But to Jim, his most important accomplishment was as a devoted and loving father. Survived by his wife Lisa, sons Julius and Michael, brother Daniel and nieces and nephew. Funeral services will be Friday, June 20 at 2pm at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, Queens, NY. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, June 25th at 10am at Sinai Temple, 10400 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be made to Wilshire Boulevard Temple, 3663 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles 90010 or a charity of your choice.

ROWAN--Barbara J.,of Hollywood, Florida passed away peacefully in her sleep on June 15, 2014 after struggling with small cell lung cancer. She was the daughter of Florence and Emanuel Stein of Long Beach, NY. She is survived by her daughter Andrea and her son Marc. She is also survived by six adoring grandchildren Joshua, Zachary, Andrew, Charlotte, Jade and Deva. All will miss her dearly. Her community of friends in Florida will also miss her greatly. Barbara was the heart and soul of her family. She was smart, kind, funny and a great connector of generations and extended family and friends. All benefited from her love of Jewish heritage and culture. Barbara was a trained concert pianist. Barbara graduated with a BA from NYU and worked for a time as a teacher. Later in life Barbara ran an auto leasing company. Barbara devoted her life to family, friends and community. Her loss leaves a forever hole in the lives of all who knew her. Contributions in her memory may be made to FasterCures (The Milken Institute), 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401.

FEY--Albert E.,81. The lawyers and staff of the law firm of Fish & Neave, now part of Ropes & Gray, mourn the passing of Albert E. Fey. He was an extraordinary friend and mentor to generations of lawyers at the firm. After receiving his degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Michigan in 1955 and his law degree from George Washington University in 1958, he served as an associate and partner in the firm until he retired in 2002. Al was one of the nation's most respected intellectual property trial lawyers, having served as lead trial counsel in many cases for such prominent companies as AT&T, Bell Labs, Lucent, Ford, General Electric, Becton Dickinson, Varian, Georgia-Pacific, and Arrow International, among others. Consistent with his high standing at the bar, he was a great colleague and teacher to all of us who sought to follow in his footsteps. We are inspired by his example and will remember him fondly.

OXMAN--Leon, died on June 13, 2014. His primary passions were music, art and investing. He was a percussionist and traveled the world as a member of the 7th Army Symphony. He also performed on Broadway, including in productions of Indians, Celebration and Oliver! He was an avid investor in real estate and owned and managed several commercial properties. A man of tremendous intellect, strong opinions and wide-ranging interests, he will be sorely missed by his beloved wife Elaine Cameron-Oxman, and many friends. A memorial gathering will be held on June 27, 2014 in Manhattan. Contact m.voelz@hohlaw.com

RAJARATNAM--J.M.,Loving husband of Rajes, father of five, and grandfather of ten. J.M. Rajaratnam passed away at the age of 86. He was born in Alvai, Sri Lanka and attended Hartley College before graduating with honors in Chemistry from the University of Ceylon. He proceeded to England on scholarship and was 5th in the world as a Chartered Accountant. He later became Chief Financial Controller of Browns Group and then General Chairman of Singer (Sri Lanka) before being promoted to head Singer's Asia operation. Mr. Rajaratnam then led in philanthropy in Sri Lanka, enhancing education, healthcare, and women's rights. He was recognized by Stanford's Who's Who list and by Illankai Tamil Sangam for the Lifetime Achievement Award. We will memorialize his legacy at Barrett Funeral Home in Tenafly, NJ at 11 a.m. on Saturday, June 21.

KATSKE--Joyce Ruddy, in her hundredth year, passed away peacefully after a brief illness June 17th. She was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Floyd Katske, Sr. and mother of Dr. Floyd (and Faye) and Dr. Gordon (and Leslie) Katske and a loving grandparent to David, Julie, Aaron, Jennifer, Erika and Mark. She worked at the New York Design Center for over 30 years, and served as Corporate Comptroller. Services private. OXMAN--Leon, We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Elaine and friends. Leon was a good friend and client. He will be greatly missed. Michael L. Landsman, Partner, Holm & O'Hara LLP

WALDMAN--Carolyn Evelyn (Greiner), passed away comfortably in St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY on May 13th following a brief but serious illness at the age of 64. She was the loving daughter of Paul and Lillian Greiner who preceded her in death. She was also the beloved sister of Paul-john Greiner and the much adored aunt of Amanda Greiner, David Greiner and Paul Kuhn-Greiner. She leaves behind a multitude of friends and colleagues who miss her greatly. Carolyn was raised in Elmhurst, Queens. She attended City College where she took part in several demonstrations against the Vietnam War, graduating with a Bachelor's Degree in English. She began her professional career as an editor for Vanguard and later Elektra/ Asylum Records. She worked as a Contract Manager at Stein & Day Publications and spent her later years as an Executive Assistant to several CEO's, most notably Joshua Muss of the Muss Development Corporation. Voracious reader, avid world traveler, talented quilter, excellent cook and creator of extraordinary cakes, Carolyn's amazing holiday meals were greatly anticipated by family and friends. She truly enjoyed completing The New York Times crossword every Sunday and always had a warm heart for dogs and cats. If love was a cure, Carolyn would be with us today. A Memorial Inurnment Ceremony will be held in her honor at the Fresh Pond Crematory, 61-40 Mt. Olivet Crescent, Middle Village, NY, on June 24th at 11am. http://www.leofkearns.com/

SAROT--Daniel, Ph.D. We mourn the loss of Daniel Sarot, Ph.D. Passed away June 18, 2014, age 74. Devoted husband and father, caring friend and teacher. Survived by loving wife, three children, and sister. He will be missed forever.

BELSHAW--Elizabeth "Betsy" (Wheeler), of Princeton, New Jersey and Prout's Neck, Maine died on Tuesday, June 17, 2014 at home. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 24 at 11 a.m. at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton. Betsy was born to the late Richard E. and Wilhelmina West Wheeler in 1931 in Providence, Rhode Island. She graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1948 and from Smith College in 1952. An accomplished pianist and avid bridge player, Betsy devoted much of her life to the Episcopal Church, supporting parish activities in Honolulu, Hawaii, Dover, Delaware, Rumson, New Jersey and Princeton. Betsy is survived by her husband of 60 years, G.P. Mellick Belshaw, the 9th Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, her son Richard and his wife Julia, her daughter Elizabeth (Lisa) Ham and her husband Peter, her son George and his wife Dorothy, and by seven grandchildren: Emily, Elizabeth, Daniel, Martha, Alexandra, Alice and George. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ 08540. www.trinityprinceton.com

ALFANDRE--Robert Nelson, born June 9, 1927 in New York, NY, died at his home in Washington, DC on June 12th. He is survived by his wife, Priscilla Alfandre. His parents, Joseph and Annette Henry Alfandre, moved to DC when Robert was eight. Encouraged by his teachers at Anacostia High School to apply, Robert became the first of his family to attend college, choosing Swarthmore when Princeton and Yale offered later matriculation dates. At the end of his freshman year, he enlisted in the US Navy, returning to school in the fall of 1946. Upon graduation from college in 1949, he attended the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Study on a fellowship and received a Master of Arts degree in 1951. After graduate school, his first position was with the Central Intelligence Agency, where he was employed in operations concerning Western Europe. After five years with the CIA, he resigned his position to pursue a career in real estate development with his father and brother Jack. He prospered in the real estate and construction industry in the Washington area, developing his own companies. He married Priscilla Buck, a college classmate, in 1951. They have two daughters, Dominique (Thomas Palmer) and Nicole, and four grandchildren, Carl and Claudia Halbreiner and Luned and Rosamund Palmer (Miles Portek). Alfandre became a force in the DC cultural community, serving on the board of the Woodrow Wilson House and opening his Kalorama Road home to myriad non-profits for fundraising events. He also served for many years on the Board of the Whitman Walker Clinic in DC and was a leader in fighting AIDS, raising millions of dollars for AIDS research and establishing residences and support systems for victims of AIDS in DC and Key West, FL. He founded the Carroll Sledz House at the Clinic in honor of his partner Carroll. He organized and hosted the first Human Rights Campaign Fund dinner. Alfandre maintained residences in DC, Key West, Fire Island and Paris, where he pursued his deep love of French culture. He was an active member of the French Heritage Society, as well as the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He was named a Knight of the Order of St. John. Robert is also survived by his brother Jack Alfandre and devoted grandchildren, nieces and nephews; also by his friend Sidney Martin. Memorials to the breadth of this life lived well will be held in Fire Island (August 17) and in Key West. Visiting hours will be at Joseph Gawler's Sons 6-8pm Friday, June 20th. The funeral will be held on Saturday, June 21 at 11am at All Souls Church in DC with burial at Oak Hill Cemetery. The family extends their heartfelt gratitude to the staffs of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, NY Presbyterian Hospital and the home carers, all of whom cared for him through his long final illness. Donations to the Fire Island Pines Free Clinic would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers.

ANANIA--Gregory, of New York, NY passed away on Wednesday, June 18, 2014, after a long battle against cancer. Gregory was born on March 23, 1985, and grew up in Edgemont, NY. He is survived by his parents Sheryl and Michael, his twin brother, Matt, and his sister, Justine. Gregory graduated Edgemont High School in 2003, where he was a member of the varsity football and golf teams. Upon graduating high school, Gregory went on to Babson College in Wellesley, MA, where he graduated in 2007 with a degree in Business Administration. Just prior to graduation, Gregory was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer Atypical Thymic Carcinoid. He had already accepted a job with the firm of Perelson Weiner in New York City as a staff accountant and the firm graciously deferred his start date until he completed his treatments. During this time, Gregory underwent chemo- therapy, two surgeries and radiation but somehow found the energy and will to study for the CPA exam, and when he started his job at Perelson Weiner a year later, he had already passed all four parts of the CPA. Despite never ridding his body of cancer and having to undergo countless treatments, over the next six years Gregory never stopped living life to its fullest. He worked diligently, traveled, played golf passionately, worked out endlessly, looked forward to spending time with his family and friends, and always had time to brighten the lives of others with his infectious grin and kindness. Gregory inspired everyone whose lives he touched, and while he is missed, he is not gone. Contributions in Greg's memory can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (www.mskcc.org or the Caring for Carcinoid Foundation (www.caringforcarcinoid.org) Service today (Friday), 11am at Central Synagogue.

SMITH--Donald C. Today the Partners of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, together with its employees, honor the life and legacy of former Partner Donald C. Smith on the occasion of his memorial service, which is being held today at 1pm at the United Nations Chapel in Manhattan. Admired for his expertise as both an architect and as a mentor, Smith's long and distinguished career at SOM began in 1961 and continued until his retirement in 1992. Throughout his more than three decades at the firm, Smith contributed to some of SOM's most complex and challenging projects in New York City, including the American Bible Society headquarters on Broadway, NYU's Merrill Hall, and the Vista Hotel. Smith completed numerous projects across North America as well, including Republic Plaza, Denver's tallest building, and BCE Place in Toronto. Though his work ranged in scale from master plans to single buildings, Smith remained unfailingly committed to fulfilling architecture's chief goal of inspiring and delighting its inhabitants. His talents and kindness continue to inspire our firm and will do so for many generations to come. Donations may be made in Donald Smith's honor to the Wounded Warrior Project.

SIMON--Kathy Gale (Shapiro), born March 5, 1957 in Manhattan, died June 19, 2014 at her home in Cold Spring Harbor, NY. She is the daughter of the late Theodore Shapiro and she is survived by her beloved mother, Judith Shapiro, her beloved husband Scott and daughters, Matti and Alix, sister Hilary, brother John and his wife Geri, sister-in-law Randi, brother-in-law Ricky and mother-in-law Nancy in addition to several nieces, nephews and cousins. Kathy graduated from Boston University with a degree in Art and was a senior executive at Ciao Ltd in addition to being a wonderful mother and devoted wife. She traveled the world extensively, had a passion for life and truly loved her family and dear friends, for which she had many. She will be eternally missed by everyone who had the great fortune to know her. In lieu of flowers, please make all donations to the Elizabeth R. Woods Foundation. Service Sunday at 2pm at Star of David Memorial Chapels in West Babylon. For info go to www.jewish-funeral-home.com

TRAVERS--Robert J. Bob was born in Jersey City, NJ and lived the past 20 years in Manhattan. He worked for Bloomingdale's for over 26 years, as Director of Construction for Store Planning. Beloved husband of Joe Nacci; beloved son of Dorothy Travers, Venice, FL; brother of Claire Doherty, Winthrop, MA, Dr. William Travers, Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., Dr. John Travers, Asheville, NC and Paul Travers, Millstone Twp, NJ. He is survived by nine nieces and nephews and a grand niece. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the American Cancer Society. Visitation will be at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (21st St), NYC, on Saturday from 2 - 4 p.m. and 7 - 9 p.m.

LEWIN--Kurt, The residents of 3 East 71st Street are saddened by the passing of a long time fellow resident Kurt Lewin. He was an extraordinary man and our heartfelt condolences go to his wife Donatella and his sons Andrew, Clement and Luigi.

MARCUS--Junis Roberts. Peacefully on June 18, 2014. Teacher, art collector and jazz club owner. Survived by husband Burt, son Michael (Diane), daughter, Stacy (Aaron), her "fabulous" grandchildren Hannah, Philip, Jonathan and Avery and sister Samoan. Pug lover and passionate friend to many.

MOSIER--Frank Moffett, May 15, 1929 - June 13, 2014. Actors' Studio Playwrights' group; New Dramatists; The Actor's Place at St. Luke's; Off-Off-Broadway Alliance; Quintano's School for Young Professionals. Obituary at frankmoffettmosier.com.

BATES--Chandler, Jr.,a resident of Greenwich, CT, died June 18, at 94 years of age. He was born in New York City, the son of Chandler and Amy Reick Bates, of New York City and Gloucester, VA. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Patricia Dickinson Bates. He leaves behind four children: Candice Gammill (Ken) of Woodstock, VT; Chandler Bates III (Jeanne) of Orem, UT; Christopher Bates (Marie) of Palm City, FL; and Cheryl Pace (John) of Barrington, RI; 11 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. Chan served with the OSS in World War II. After a career in advertising in New York City, he retired in 1973 to travel. He served with many Greenwich civic and community organizations. Chan was the first Director of the Cemetery at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich in the 1970's. His funeral service will be at St. Barnabas at 2:30pm, Monday, June 23, 2014.

CUTRONA--Marianne J. (nee DiCostanzo), on June 18th, 2014, wife of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. Cutrona. Born August 18th, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of the late Philip F. and Aurelia (Mirabito) DiCostanzo. Marianne is survived by her daughter, Marianne Cutrona Ritz, son-in-law, Charles Ritz, daughter, Carol Anne Cutrona, son, Michael Cutrona, and daughter-in-law, Antonietta Chieco Cutrona. She will be dearly missed by her five grandsons, Charles Ritz, Anthony Cutrona, Nicholas Ritz, Anthony Ritz, Tommaso Cutrona, by her sister Jacqueline LaBella, brother Vincent DiCostanzo, sister-in-law, Kathleen DiCostanzo and all whose lives she touched. Family and friends may call at John J. McManus & Sons Funeral Home, 4601 Avenue N, Brooklyn, NY on Saturday, June 21 and Sunday, June 22 from 2-4:30pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday June 23, 9:30am at Our Lady Help of Christians RC Church, 1315 E 28th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Entombment will follow at Greenwood Cemetery. In honor of Marianne, donations may be sent to her favorite charity, Salesian Missions, 2 Lefevre Lane, New Rochelle, NY 10801.

SAROT--Daniel, Ph.D. We mourn the loss of Daniel Sarot, Ph.D. Passed away June 18, 2014, age 74. Devoted husband and father, caring friend and teacher. Survived by loving wife, three children, and sister. He will be missed forever.

PERMUT--Michael, 84, longtime resident of Kings Point, New York died at home on June 19th, 2014 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. His family was by his side. Son of the late Miriam and Morris Permut, Michael was born on August 22, 1929, and was pre-deceased by his sister, Minette Kushner. Michael was a proud graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and The New York University School of Law. He and his devoted wife, Connie, celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary this past April. A member of the New York Bar Association for almost 60 years, Michael was a well respected New York attorney who specialized in Real Estate Law and was considered to be a foremost expert in the area of Title Insurance. Best known for his warmth and gregarious personality, "Mike" loved all people, had a smile for everybody, and was the consummate gentleman. He was a die hard sports fan who loved his hometown Rangers and Giants, and could give you the complete history of all of the New York team's origins. Mike and Connie shared a love of bridge where they were both "Life Masters," collected antiques, and devoted much of their time together to raising and showing their champion bred Boxers. Michael is survived by his wife, Connie, daughter Kerry (Ronny) Baron, son Dr. Todd Permut, and son Kyle (Barbra) Permut and loving grandchildren Chelsey, Jory, Jacy and Jamy (Baron) and Oliver and Hayley (Permut). He was most proud of and involved with all of them. He attended countless sporting events and graduations for all of his children and grandchildren. Funeral services will be private and any donations in Michael's memory should be directed to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation: www.pdf.org

MASLIN--Herb, passed away peacefully, at 91 on June 18, 2014. He is survived by his loving partner and best friend of 30 years, Arlene Lichterman. Devoted father of Joan and Mitchell (Joy) and grandfather of Jessica and Derek. He had two separate careers: Chairman/CEO of a publicly traded aeronautical firm and in 1978 he opened the Cajun Restaurant in New York City, where he introduced Dixieland Jazz. Affectionately known as the "Cajun Maven," Herb was always ahead of his time - a self made, creative entrepreneur - a unique man. "Young at heart," with a zest for life, he and his sense of humor/jokes will be missed.

AHERN--John "Jack" Thomas. The Board and staff of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center are deeply saddened by the passing of their friend and board member Jack. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Brian O'Dwyer, Chairman

FINKELSTEIN--Paul. The Boards of Directors, leadership and staff of MJHS mourn the loss of esteemed board member Dr. Paul Finkelstein. For more than 30 years, Paul advanced the mission of MJHS, regularly sharing his medical expertise. His involvement with MJHS dates back to the original Brooklyn Ladies Hebrew Home for the Aged. He served on a number of our boards, including MJHS, MJHS Home Care and HomeFirst. At the time of his passing, Paul was an active board member of Menorah and Shorefront Centers for Rehabilitation and Nursing Care. A tireless advocate for access to quality, compassionate and innovative health services to New Yorkers, Paul will be greatly missed. Our sympathies go out to his wife Doris as well as his family. May his legacy serve as a source of inspiration and his memory be for a blessing. Ronald Milch, Chairman Eli S. Feldman, CEO
